HEADLINE: U.S. Shift on Beijing: Will Embrace Win Change?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has subtly shifted its China policy in recent months, gambling that intensified economic and political contacts with Beijing will prove more effective than the threat of trade sanctions has been in changing China's human rights policies.
The Administration has by no means removed the threat of withdrawing China's preferential trade status this June, if Beijing does not meet very specific criteria on respecting human rights and abandoning illegal trade practices. That threat still exists. It seems real. American officials have even stated publicly in recent weeks that if the decision were made today, China would lose its benefits, which allow it to export products to the United States at the lowest possible tariffs. 
 But in an effort to persuade the Chinese to meet the President's conditions by June, and to broaden the relationship in such a way that the United States would not have to rely anymore on the threat of trade sanctions if China complies, the Administration has, without fanfare, been pursuing a new policy of intensive engagement.
 
A Parade of Visitors
 President Clinton met with President Jiang Zemin in Seattle in November. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen paid a four-day visit to China this week, following on the heels of Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy. Mr. Bentsen restored the Joint Economic Committee, a bilateral discussion group, with his Chinese counterpart and announced that the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, would also be visiting.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher has scheduled two days of talks in Paris next week with China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen. Technical advisory missions from the Securities and Exchange Commission and United States Customs are expected in China soon.
One reason for the shift in strategy is that the old standoffish approach did not seem to be working. But, more important, is an acknowledgement that the old approach of using the threat of withdrawing China's "most favored nation" trade status is becoming an anachronism. A tactic adopted in the 1970's to give Congress and the President a lever in pressing the Soviet Union to allow more Jews to emigrate, the trade threat makes less and less sense in the American relationship with China today.
Trade between the United States and China, the world's biggest emerging economy, is now so economically important to the United States, and so politically important to the reform process in China, that threatening to cut it off has become the diplomatic equivalent of the United States holding a gun to its own head and threatening to pull the trigger.
 
Other Interests at Stake
 China is expected to spend about $560 billion on infrastructure projects between now and the end of the century. Just 1 percent of those projects would mean several hundred thousand American jobs.
But there are more than commercial interests at stake now with China. As Chinese reformers themselves point out, trade with the rest of the world has become the engine of so many economic, social and even political changes here that to diminish it in any way now would hurt their cause much more than the Government.
Trade has brought China the satellite dish, the portable fax, the cellular phone, increased freedom to travel abroad, international newspapers, Western investment banks and financial services. It has forced the state to relinquish some control over individual businesses and permit more of the individual initiative required for successful capitalism and entrepreneurship.
"The areas where contacts with the West are the greatest, the areas where they have moved ahead most on human rights and accepting influences from the West, are those where trade is most intense," said Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and a former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, who is to arrive in China on Sunday.
Today Treasury Secretary Bentsen visited the Shanghai Diesel Engine Company Ltd., a newly privatized factory that has been heavily influenced by systems imported from International Harvester. The company's president told Mr. Bentsen that just in the last year the Government had allowed the executives here autonomy in investment, recruiting, and decisions on manufacturing and management.
 
Toward a 'Virtuous Circle'
 Even allowing for China's continued practice of organizing labor in work units that are carefully controlled by the state, the arrival of Western businesses is forcing liberalization, factory by factory. Business demands for contract laws, bankruptcy laws, repossession laws -- all critical elements of a market economy -- are also forcing greater reliance on rule by law rather than arbitrary edict.
The hope of American officials and Chinese reformers is that over time the demands of the global market will force the Government into what economists call a "virtuous circle" in which more economic reform leads to more growth, more growth leads to more economic reform, and eventually economic reform begins to spill over into political reform.
China is still a long way from democratic change, but the dynamics of such a circle are apparent. It is precisely such an evolutionary process that hard-line Communist conservatives here denounce as an American "plot."
In some ways the Administration's logic is in line with that of former President George Bush, who was roundly condemned by Democrats -- and by candidate Clinton -- for insisting on continued engagement with Beijing after the brutal 1989 crackdown in Tiananmen Square and other acts of political repression.
 
A Broader Agenda
 But in linking renewal of trade benefits to explicit demands on human rights, Mr. Clinton appears to have gone further than President Bush did in putting pressure on Beijing.
It is a recognition of the new political and commercial reality of China that has prompted the Clinton Administration since September to broaden the range of contacts between Beijing and Washington, in the hope that the mass of those contacts will be a far greater source of pressure on Beijing to change its human rights practices than the annual threat of trade sanctions, officials said.
It would also make human rights part of a broader agenda rather than the focus of the whole relationship. Some human rights campaigners argue that will only make abuses easier to ignore; Administration officials, basically accepting the Asian argument, say that human rights will be easier to address if the issue is out of the spotlight.
There is only one problem with this new approach. It cannot really go fully into effect until June, if China passes what American officials hope will be their last most-favored-nation exam. If Beijing meets the criteria set by the Clinton Administration, the reasoning goes, the United States will shift to conventional diplomatic means of pressing China to respect human rights rather than adopting a new set of goal posts for renewal in 1995.
 
The Chinese Respond
 Last June, when he renewed China's most-favored-nation benefits, President Clinton issued an executive order naming the conditions that China would have to meet to get the preferential trade status renewed this June. In recent weeks, the Chinese have obviously started to respond.
They agreed to a demand to allow more visits by American customs inspectors to Chinese prison factories to make sure they are not producing goods for export to the United States. They released some Tibetan political prisoners in Lhasa. They have begun serious discussions with the Red Cross about allowing the organization to visit political prisoners and about providing a list of all those prisoners -- two crucial demands made by Mr. Clinton that are still unmet.
"Progress has been made," Mr. Bentsen said. "We're hoping for more. I hope sufficient progress can be made so we can put this issue behind us and there will not be an annual review" of China's most favored nation status any longer.
Senior Clinton Administration officials say that as much as they know it would be self-defeating both for them and for Chinese reform to cut off China's most-favored-nation status, politically the President will have no choice but to do so if the Chinese do not live up to the terms of his executive order. Not to revoke it would open the President to charges of ignoring his own executive order, violating his campaign promises on China and cynically giving into commercial interests. Those familiar with his thinking assert that he is determined not to let that happen.
"Anyone who tells you that the President is just looking for a fig leaf and he will renew M.F.N. again is dead wrong," a senior Administration official said.
Still, Mr. Hormats said, so much is now at stake in maintaining the trade relationship between Washington and Beijing, "I have to believe that they will find a way to work this out."

HEADLINE: Japan's Crisis on Political Reform Overshadows Bentsen Trade Trip

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 22

 BODY:
With Japan's coalition Government reeling from a surprise internal rebellion that could drive it from power, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen arrived here today prepared to tell the country's leadership that Tokyo's political chaos would no longer be an excuse to resist major concessions on trade.
But Mr. Bentsen, who is scheduled to meet Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa on Sunday, has little leverage. Japanese leaders spent the day preoccupied with strategies to salvage their Government after the defeat on Friday of legislation to clean up the country's political system. Even with deadlines looming on trade issues, a conflict with the Clinton Administration seemed the least of their problems. 
 Today Mr. Hosokawa's Government still seemed shocked by the magnitude of its miscalculation. Though the bills had passed the more powerful lower house of Parliament in November, they were defeated in the upper house after the defection of some Socialists who feared the legislation would eventually wipe out their party's seats and influence.
 
Compromise Bill Planned
 Mr. Hosokawa has vowed to try to work out a new, compromise bill before the Parliament goes out of session in a week. But the opposition Liberal Democratic Party, eager to embarrass Mr. Hosokawa after he helped oust them from power last summer, would not even agree on a meeting to discuss the issue. Many doubt a compromise is possible, out of a suspicion that the Liberal Democrats and many Socialists will seek to kill any reform bills that would disturb the status quo, if they can do so without taking the blame.
"Hosokawa's coalition has completely lost its confidence," said Minoru Morita, a leading political commentator. "Right now, there really isn't a Government." If Mr. Hosokawa chooses to call a snap election in the hope of regaining a mandate to push through political reform legislation, the turmoil could go on for weeks.
But the brunt of public criticism over the defeat of the legislation seemed to be aimed at Mr. Hosokawa's opponents. Several major newspapers warned the Prime Minister to hold fast and resist any temptation to give in to to the Liberal Democrats, especially on the regulation of political donations.
Mr. Bentsen made a last-minute decision to add Tokyo to the end of his Asian tour even though the Japanese have made it clear he is an unwelcome guest. Treasury officials said President Clinton asked Mr. Bentsen to go to Tokyo to insure that Japan's political leaders, rather than its bureaucrats, begin taking control of the crucial decisions needed before Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa meet on Feb. 11 in Washington.
 
New Approach on Trade
 That date was chosen last July, when the two countries agreed on a new approach to solving trade issues. But in the interim, no progress has been made, and the two sides are still arguing over fundamental issues that were supposed to be solved last summer.
After giving a grace period of several months to Mr. Hosokawa, who took office in August on a pledge to fight corruption in government, the Clinton Administration has declared that it is out of patience.
When Mr. Bentsen decided earlier this week to come to Tokyo, the assumption was that he would be delivering the tough message to a Prime Minister empowered by an expected victory in securing passage of legislation to change the way campaigns are financed and members of Parliament are elected.
Instead, Mr. Bentsen landed as Mr. Hosokawa was scrambling to hold on to his job. Even if he survives, he may be so weakened that there would be little he could do to override the Japanese bureaucrats who are running the negotiations with the United States and are resisting many of Washington's demands.
 
No 'Cosmetic Agreements'
 "We are not going to accept cosmetic agreements," said a senior Treasury Department official traveling with Mr. Bentsen. "We can't reach a satisfactory agreement without political determination on both sides."
"There is no question that the Japanese Government has the capacity to take the steps necessary," the official added. "We've shown quite a lot of understanding for a long time on the political issues in Japan."
Despite the stern words, there is very little the Clinton Administration can do to force concessions. Just as it has staked its bets for reform in Russia on President Boris N. Yeltsin, it has counted on Mr. Hosokawa and the movement that brought him to power to open up Japan's economy, deregulate many of its industries and press for greater access for imports. If Mr. Hosokawa's coalition collapsed, it would probably bring back the Liberal Democratic Party, which has expressed little commitment to such changes.
Mr. Bentsen's aides suggested today that Mr. Hosokawa could move quickly to cut taxes to revive economic growth, but they made it sound far simpler than it seems to the Japanese.
"Tax cuts are hardly a strain for any government," one American official asserted. "They would not exactly weaken this Government."
In fact they might well do that. Japan's Finance Ministry has said that an income tax cut would mean a sharp and unpopular increase in Japan's 3 percent "consumption tax," to avoid deficit spending by the Government.
The battle over adding to the burden on consumers seems bound to raise more objections within the Socialist Party, and Mr. Hosokawa cannot afford to lose more of their votes.

HEADLINE: New York Car Theft Draws Police Priority

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

 BODY:
For Jason Wolder, a 34-year-old Queens sales representative, the theft of his 1980 Delta 88 in August was troubling enough. But then there are the near-nightly screams of car alarms that stir his otherwise graceful Douglaston neighborhood and frequently wake his infant son.
They are not only a constant reminder of the loss of his old car, but just as important, they make him feel that maybe his family isn't safe. "An anxiety pops up," he said. "God knows what could happen if you have to face one of those guys by mistake in the street." 
 As the most pervasive property crime afflicting the nation's big cities, motor vehicle theft is a constant irritant to New York City's 1.8 million auto owners, costing them an average of $360 a year in added insurance fees alone. Mr. Wolder's Oldsmobile was one of an estimated 112,000 motor vehicles stolen in New York City last year, and his case, like more than 90 percent in the city, went unsolved and unprosecuted.
 
Recent Trend Is Down
 Stark figures show the magnitude of car theft in New York. About 1,700 vehicles were stolen in the city in 1992 per 100,000 residents, compared with a national average of about 650. In the region, only Newark, with 5,000 thefts per 100,000 residents, has a more overwhelming problem.
In New York, there are some hopeful signs: reported car thefts in the city have drifted significantly downward since peaking at 146,300 in 1990, according to police statistics. That trend roughly matches the experience of the metropolitan suburbs and the nation's cities at large.
The downward trend in auto theft numbers, both in New York and nationally, suggests to law-enforcement authorities that stiffer Federal and state laws and improved security measures by auto companies and owners are having an effect, as well as increased political pressure on police forces and local district attorneys to apply more resources.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani promised during the fall campaign to step up the police effort against car theft, which was already rising during the Dinkins administration with more investigations of dealers in stolen cars and parts and with nightly checkpoints on major thoroughfares.
"Car theft will have a higher priority than it does now," the new Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, promised in a recent interview. "This is one of those things that drives people crazy, that constantly creates fear and reminds them that the street isn't safe." He promised to come up with new strategies to fight the problem in the next few weeks.
 
Tougher Law Enforcement
 Of 31,000 police officers in the New York City department, 375 now work full time on auto theft. The Police Department plans to strengthen its borough car-theft units with a significant number of police academy graduates in February. The Queens Auto Larceny Unit, for instance, has been told 5 graduates will be added to its 10 full-time members.
Police patrol cars have been given more sophisticated computer software in recent months to check licenses and vehicle identification numbers quickly for stolen cars during patrols and at checkpoints. And local officers are urging residents to visit precincts to have identification numbers etched on their car windows.
Since car ownership became commonplace in the 1920's, there have been several waves of car theft followed by years when thefts tapered off. The trends matched economic cycles to some degree, but in recent years appear to have soared as organized crime has become more involved, operating junkyards willing to buy stolen parts for resale and repair shops that rebuild vehicles for export.
The crime of auto theft has, in fact, changed radically in recent years, creating new challenges for the police but also providing new opportunities to manage the problem. Auto theft was once the province of young thugs, who stole cars to get money for drugs or take joy rides.
 
Entry-Level Crime
 Today, it is an entry level for organized-crime apprentices, who typically make $200 to $400 a car, the police say.
In New York City, according to the police, organized crime commonly hires people to steal cars and deliver them to so-called chop shops, where they are dismantled for parts or resold, frequently for export.
"Back in the old days, they hung horse thieves," said Inspector Charles DeRienzo, the head of the auto crime division. "But now the answer is simpler: regulate the businessmen who are using and exporting these parts."
Early this month, in an effort to do just that, 30 of Mr. DeRienzo's men raided the sprawling junkyard attached to Dom's Truck Sales in East New York, Brooklyn, which the police say is one of the city's major chop shops. In the raid, which followed more than six months of surveillance, the police found a pile of semiautomatic weapons and vehicle parts that they said were stolen. They also accused the owner and employees of removing and altering vehicle identification numbers to mislead the police and customs authorities.
 
Suspects Back at Work
 But less than a week later, the junkyard hummed and clanked with the usual cacophony, as mechanics sanded fenders and ran their clattering lifts. At least one mechanic was back at work less than a week after his arrest, released without bail along with 10 other employees. The owner, Dominick Vitucci, was held for two days and released on $5,000 bail.
Mr. Vitucci's wife, Carol, a bookkeeper in his office, expressed confidence that Dom's Truck Sales would quickly return to full operations. "Our customers are repeat customers," she said. "They'll come back."
Police officers are still visiting the junkyard, to monitor its workings and scare away the car thieves who they say deliver their wares there.
To many victims, the way to solve car theft is to arrest more street criminals. But law-enforcement officials and criminologists agree that the most efficient way is to attack those who make the big profits from the trade in stolen parts.
 
Identification Deterrent
 Mr. DeRienzo, the chief of the auto crimes division, suggested that a major reason for the decrease in auto theft was the growing prevalence of vehicle identification numbers on cars and parts. The identification plates, which are the principal way the police can spot stolen parts and cars, have deterred a growing number of legitimate businessmen from using stolen parts out of fear they will be caught, said Mr. DeRienzo.
"If we can regulate the auto repair and auto salvage industry, we can cut auto theft in half," he said. "Everybody is looking for the police to solve the problem, but it is up to the auto industry and the Government to regulate the industry to label every component part that is manufactured."
Congress took a step in that direction when it passed the Anti-Auto Theft Act of 1992, which requires car makers to mark 13 parts with vehicle identification numbers and makes the removal of the numbers a Federal offense.
Still, some lawmakers, law-enforcement officers and criminologists have accused the auto makers of dragging their feet in providing better anti-theft security. Representative Charles E. Schumer, who was the main House sponsor of the car-theft measure, complained that the auto industry lobbied hard to limit the number of parts covered by the identification-number regulation.
 
Do Auto Makers Care?
 "There's a suspicion that it doesn't bother them that lots of cars are stolen, because when somebody's car is stolen they buy a new one," the Brooklyn Democrat said. Two of his cars have been stolen from his Park Slope neighborhood in the last five years, and he says he now prays for rain, which discourages thieves, after parking his car each night.
Andrew Karmen, an auto-theft specialist at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, also contended that car makers put profits before security. "Vehicle security is given a low priority by the auto companies," he said. "Consumers should be outraged that it is so easy to start a car without a key."
Representatives of car companies insisted that they were concerned about security, but said they opposed the Congressional mandate on identification numbers because they were expensive and ineffective. "Our basic position on parts marking is that they are a cost burden to consumers with no benefit in terms of anti-theft prevention," said Patrick Morrissey, a General Motors spokesman in Washington. He estimated that the cost of parts marking was $225 million for customers "with no proven benefits."
 
Checking Every 3d Car
 But the New York City police see it differently. At a moving checkpoint on Hillside Avenue and Queens Boulevard last week, bordering Jamaica and Kew Gardens, officers in a car-theft unit wearing bulletproof vests checked the identification numbers of every third car, along with license plates and the drivers' documents.
As the officers in one car punched the numbers into the computer, looking for evidence that the vehicle was stolen, the officers in a second car waited behind, ready for possible pursuit. Most nights the officers make an arrest or two, in an operation they began in Queens only three years ago.
Arashb Shoughi, an Iranian-born Briarwood resident, was startled by the piercing red flashes of the rotary lights of four patrol cars following him, but quickly expressed support when the officers assured him he had broken no laws. "I've had four cars stolen in the last two years," he said with a sigh. "If this helps, why not?"

HEADLINE: U.S. ASKS INCREASE ON BIRTH CONTROL

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is seeking a substantial increase in spending next year on population control programs with the goal of providing birth control to every woman in the developing world who wants it by the end of the decade.
The emerging policy, a sharp departure from the approach taken by the Reagan and Bush Administrations, emphasizes not only family planning but also education for women, which by boosting their living standards and independence ultimately increases their power to decide how many children they will bear. 
 In revamping American foreign policy to take account of the passing of the cold war, the Clinton Administration has concluded that slowing population growth is crucial because it promotes so many goals at once: reducing political instability, hunger, migration and strains on the environment.
"When we think about what factors are going to affect the future of the world, population is absolutely at the top of the list," said Timothy E. Wirth, the State Department Counselor and the Administration's main spokesman on population policy.
"Everything that we would think of doing to further our goals of increasing political stability and living standards around the world can be compromised and destroyed by unchecked population growth."
 
Request $585 Million
 To back up the new policy, President Clinton plans to request $585 million in spending on population programs in his budget for fiscal 1995, up from $502 million this year and almost double the amount spent in fiscal 1992, the year before he took office.
Mr. Wirth talks of raising annual spending to $1.2 billion by the year 2000 to meet his goal of providing family planning services to the more than 600 million women of childbearing age in developing countries.
Population experts predict that if present trends continue unchecked, the world's current population of 5.5 billion will double in 40 years and reach between 13 to 15 billion by the year 2050.
With the efforts proposed by Washington, other governments and the World Bank, Mr. Wirth said, world population could stabilize near 10 billion around 2050.
 
Influence of Gore
 Administration officials said the population strategy was perhaps the most concrete sign of Vice President Al Gore's influence on foreign policy. Mr. Gore argues that unbridled population growth will severely tax the environment by, for example, speeding up deforestation of the planet.
Patrick J. Leahy, who as chairman of the Senate appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations spent years asking the Bush Administration for more spending on population control, praised President Clinton's approach. In the long run, the Vermont Democrat predicted, the effort will save governments money.
"If you don't do something on population, you really can't do anything effective for the rights of women, for economic development, for children's health, and for hunger programs, all to which we have contributed tens of billions dollars to over the years," he said.
The Reagan and Bush Administrations fought spending increases for population control largely because many conservative supporters opposed the idea of the Government paying for abortions and contraceptives.
 
More Money for Health Services
 As part of its strategy, the Administration wants the Agency for International Development to channel money into health services for women in developing countries. If women in poor African, Asian or Latin American regions come to rely on such clinics for their care, the reasoning goes, they will more readily take advantage of assistance on birth control.
The Administration is also emphasizing the link between higher rates of child survival and lower fertility rates. If women know that more of their children will survive, demographic statistics suggest, they tend to have fewer children.
Population experts say the introduction of programs emphasizing survival, a strategy that involves child immunizations and improved nutrition, initially accelerate the rate of population growth but ultimately reduce it because fertility rates fall as a result.
For population experts, one of the most intriguing aspects of the Administration's broader approach is the effort to improve women's education. In Colombia, for example, women with no education bear an average of 5.4 children, while those with some primary schooling average 4.0 children and women who have completed secondary school average 3.2.
"The purpose of these population policies is to improve people's well-being, not simply to control some nebulous idea such as population growth," said Joan Dunlop, president of the International Women's Health Coalition.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ACCORD IS REACHED ON USE OF FORESTS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 22

 BODY:
With the world's forests vanishing at an accelerating rate, rich and poor countries have agreed on a draft accord that would put forest preservation on a par with the commercial demands of the global timber industry. But the agreement, reached late Friday in Geneva, falls far short of what many developing countries and environmental groups sought.
The final round of talks was convened two weeks ago under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. The goal was to complete a new version of the International Tropical Timber Agreement, a 1983 commodity pact that is supposed to promote environmentally benign free trade in wood harvested in the tropics, including logs, plywood and veneer sheets. The original agreement expires on March 31. 
 United Nations figures show tropical timber as worth $7.5 billion a year in an $85-billion-a-year global industry.
 
Split Among the Signers
 The agreement's signers -- 23 producer countries like Malaysia and Brazil and 27 so-called consumers, including European countries, the United States, and Japan, the world's biggest timber importer -- entered the talks bitterly split over calls by tropical producers that the pact be broadened to encourage conservation-oriented logging in the temperate forests of the northern industrial nations. Similar demands doomed diplomatic efforts to produce a world forestry pact in time for the 1992 Earth Summit in Brazil.
Under a compromise that awaits formal ratification, developing countries would drop their insistence that the pact be expanded to cover all timber. For their part, the northern countries would pledge to adopt "appropriate guidelines and criteria for sustainable management" of their forests, and affirm the need to provide developing countries with "appropriate resources" for conservation programs.
The draft agreement also calls on countries to submit regular reports on progress toward practices that would let them use their forests while preserving them for future generations.
But environmentalists at the talks expressed dismay, characterizing the overall compromise as a public-relations facade by both sides to cover up a lack of political will to come to grips with the problems of deforestation. Studies cited by United Nations agencies say human activity has led to the destruction of as much forested land in the last 20 years as has been previously cleared in all of history.
 
Pledges of Assistance
 Developing countries pledged early in the talks to adopt specific policies by the year 2000 that would help sustain their forests. But they assert that the consumers -- especially European nations led by Germany, France and Britain -- refused to offer more than vague nonbinding promises to do the same.
Many people close to the talks sympathize with the developing nations, noting that the tropical timber pact is the only commodity agreement that covers a trade item originating in one part of the world but not another.
"They see I.T.T.A.'s current tropical focus as a perpetuation of the very kind of onerous double standards so widely condemned at the Earth Summit -- those which require developing countries to abide by standards the industrialized countries are unwilling to accept themselves," former President Jimmy Carter told Secretary of State Warren Christopher last year.
The United States is both a major producer and a consumer, but it speaks for the timber-consuming countries. In June, Washington pledged at a separate ministerial meeting that it would adopt sustainable forestry management policies by the end of the century. But officials have released few details on the plan, provoking doubts among many developing countries.
 
East European Timber
 Environmentalists assert that the Europeans, eager to maintain their furniture industries, do not want environmentally safe cutting rules because they are hopeful that a major new source of cheap timber will soon open in untapped areas of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
William E. Mankin, coordinator of the Global Forest Policy Project, a Washington-based advocacy group supported by the Sierra Club, the National Wildlife Federation and Friends of the Earth-U.S., said, "It boils down to northern countries determined to protect their economic interests and unwilling to abide by common standards -- and developing countries who say, 'If you want us to save our forests you've got to give us money.' "

HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
Traveling Far and Lying Low to Get Nancy Kerrigan

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 22

 BODY:
On a freezing night two weeks ago, Shane Stant checked into a budget motel on the edge of Detroit's main airport, rented a couple of X-rated movies and settled in for the final phase of a calculated mission to injure one of America's top figure skaters.
The account of the attack was made public by investigators this week, who said Stant, a 22-year-old weight lifter and unemployed bar bouncer, was promised tens of thousands of dollars to track down the skater, Nancy Kerrigan. And like a heavy from an old gangster movie, he agreed to club her in the knees to prevent her from competing in the United States Figure Skating Championships, being held in Detroit. 
 It was a plan, the authorities say, to guarantee a place at the Winter Olympics and a shot at great profits for Tonya Harding, Kerrigan's chief rival and her opposite image in the pristine world of glistening ice and precision movement.
Rather than taking on the assignment for a fixed amount, Federal law enforcement officials now say, Stant and his 29-year-old uncle, Derrick Smith, told the investigators they were promised that their prize for keeping Kerrigan out of the competition would be permanent jobs as bodyguards for Harding at $1,000 a week each.
Although that kind of money may sound absurd, the investigators said it was no more bizarre than the rest of the plan, which, according to law enforcement officials, court documents and many who had contact with the principals, was as clumsy and ill-conceived as it was nasty.
It was a scheme that failed in nearly every way. Kerrigan was knocked out of the championship in Detroit with a powerful blow to her right knee from a telescopic metal baton, and Harding went on to win the event. But the United States Figure Skating Association decided the night competition ended that both skaters should go to the Winter Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway. Kerrigan is recovering from the injury, and she and Harding have both resumed training for next month's Games.
Stant, Smith and two others, Shawn Eckardt, Harding's bodyguard, and Jeffrey Gillooly, her former husband with whom she had been living until last week, have now been charged with conspiracy. Moreover, officials of the figure skating association have considered removing Harding from the Olympic team.
The authorities say Stant, Smith and Eckardt have acknowledged roles in the plot. Gillooly and Harding insist they are innocent.
The attack riveted the nation with its juxtaposition of the figure skater's porcelain world against a tawdry panorama of raw ambition, petty scheming and ham-handed thuggery. As much as anything, it was a tale of stunning banality.
 
Starting the Trek
 By the time Stant checked into the Super 8 Motel on the eastern flank of the Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Jan. 4, he had been stalking Kerrigan for more than a week in Boston and Cape Cod, near where she lives.
According to court documents in Oregon, where Harding lives and where the authorities say the plot was hatched, Stant flew to Boston from Portland, three days after Christmas.
Stant and Smith, who both live near Phoenix, drove to Portland in Smith's black 1983 Porsche a day or so after the holiday, law enforcement officials say, for a meeting at the home of Eckardt. There, the three worked out the details of the attack.
After the meeting, Oregon authorities say, Gillooly gave Eckardt $2,000 in $100 bills, which in turn went to Smith to pay for Stant's travel expenses.
 
No Holiday Success
 Arriving on the East Coast, Stant checked into the Logan Airport Hilton, across the harbor from Boston. He stayed for two nights before deciding to go to the Tony Kent Arena on Cape Cod, where Kerrigan regularly practiced.
On that Friday, New Year's Eve, Stant headed out for the practice rink, which was 75 miles south in the Cape community of South Dennis. But by then, Kerrigan had already left the Cape to bring in the New Year with her parents at their home in Stoneham, 10 miles north of Boston.
Out on the Cape, unaware that his quarry was gone, Stant took a room at the Gull Wing Suites, a resort motel on Route 28 and a short ride to the big green shed of the Tony Kent Arena.
Gull Wing Suites, which boasts a heated indoor pool, was offering a New Year's package of two nights with dinner and dancing at a nearby restaurant for $260. But Stant took just the standard suite -- with a sitting room, refrigerator, king-sized bed and color television for $90 a night -- said William B. Chase, the hotel's general manager.
Through the long holiday weekend, Stant could do nothing but kill time. Finally, on Monday, Jan. 3, Kerrigan returned to the rink.
"But she was only here for a short time," said Dottie Larkin, the manager of the rink. "The weather was getting bad, we had some light snow and the parking lot had ice in it, and she had a costume fitting in New York and then had to fly on to Detroit."
 
Rink in the Focus
 The Oregon authorities say that on Dec. 28, three calls went to the Tony Kent Arena from the home shared by Gillooly and Harding in Oregon City, south of Portland. Another call to the rink came from Stant's room at the Gull Wing Suites on Jan. 1, the authorities say. On Jan. 3, another call came from the Harding-Gillooly home.
But Larkin said neither she nor any of her staff recalled seeing anyone fitting Stant's description -- 6 feet tall and more than 200 pounds of muscle -- at the arena.
"We watch who comes in and we didn't see him," she said. "He would kind of stand out in a crowd."
Later that same day, as Kerrigan was flying to New York, Stant went back to Boston and bought a $125 ticket for a grinding 20-hour trip on a Greyhound Bus bound to Detroit.
When he checked into the Super 8 Motel, a Tudor-inspired three-story building flanked by acres of parking lots, Stant asked for a room with a waterbed, which went for $33.92 including tax. It was 11 P.M. Tuesday.
 
Movies and Phone Calls
 Using his own name, as he had at the other hotels, and occasionally glancing into the eye of a constantly running security camera, Stant filled out the motel registry and paid $101.76 in cash for three nights, a clerk said.
He also rented a videotape player and two "mature titles," "Hollywood Fantasies" and "The Girls of Beverly Hills," for $10.39, the clerk said, and handed over another $10 as a deposit against telephone charges.
Shortly after midnight, the authorities in Oregon say, a telephone call was placed from Stant's room to Harding's home.
Altogether, motel employees said, Stant made about a dozen phone calls to Arizona, Oregon and the Detroit area. The conversations were brief and the charges came to $20 to $25.
The next day, Jan. 5, investigators believe, Stant made his way downtown for a reconaissance of the riverfront Cobo Arena, where the competitors in the United States Figure Skating Championships were practicing.
 
Money Is Wired
 At some point, the investigators say, he picked up a brown General Motors car from an Alamo Rent A Car agency just down Middle Belt Road from his motel.
As Stant was checking out the Cobo Arena, Eckardt went to a grocery store on the West Coast and wired $750 to Smith in Phoenix. Smith then boarded a plane, and later that day, Stant met him at the Detroit airport.
"I believe they went back to the hotel where Stant was staying," one Federal investigator said. "I don't know if they went there directly or not. But I know they got a pizza and took it back to the hotel."
On Jan. 6, the day of the attack, the investigators say, Stant and Smith went together to the skating arena on the banks of the Detroit River and adjacent to another athletic auditorium and a convention center, where automotive journalists and industry workers were attending a preview of the annual Detroit Auto Show.
"They looked the place over, and 45 minutes before the attack Smith went to get the car," one investigator said. "He put it out on the street, where he could see the doors."
 
Corrider of Attack
 Sometime shortly before 2:40 P.M., the investigators and witnesses say, Stant made his way into a tunnel-like corridor leading off the ice to the dressing rooms.
Moments later, Kerrigan, in a short white skirt and lacy top, finished her drill, slipped plastic guards over her skate blades and stepped through a blue curtain draped over the entrance to the corridor.
Dana Scarton, a sports writer for The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, had eased into the cooridor earlier in hopes of asking Kerrigan a few questions.
"I took maybe a step forward to introduce myself," Scarton said, "but she never responded verbally."
Suddenly, out of nowhere, Scarton said, a dark, bulky form shot past her. Instinctively, Kerrigan fell back and drew close to the wall, the writer said. The attacker crouched and swung the baton into her legs as if it were a baseball bat.
"It almost seemed to flex or give a little when it made contact," Scarton said.
 
'Blood-Curdling Scream'
 Back in the arena, Cynthia Patrasso, an executive producer for Intersport, a television sports production company based in Chicago, said she heard "a blood-curdling scream" as Kerrigan staggered backward and crumpled to the corridor floor and her assailant fled.
Patrasso, a cameraman and others bolted into the corridor. "At first glance you think, she just might have slipped, even though the scream didn't fit," Patrasso said. "Then someone says someone hit her and that's when the panic started to take off."
Kevin Cusick, a freelance producer working with Patrasso, sprinted toward the rear of the arena.
Outside, a steady snow was falling. Guiding Ford Motor Company employees from the auto show into a bus heading back to their headquarters, Meredith Meyer, a 22-year-old public relations assistant, heard frantic pounding from a bank of narrow, plexiglass doors.
It was Stant, the authorities say. The doors were chained and padlocked, and he now found himself trapped. But with a wild lunge, the investigators say, Stant lowered his head like a charging ram and butted the plexiglass panel out of its frame.
 
Fruitless Chase
 "I saw this man crawling through the door frame," said Meyer, "and a woman was shouting, 'Somebody stop him. Somebody stop him.' "
Seconds later, Cusick wriggled through the broken door frame. He and Meyer gave chase. But by then the attacker was gone.
Inexplicably, Stant and Smith did not immediately leave Detroit, the investigators say, but slowly made their way through the snow along 17 miles of accident-clogged expressway to the Super 8 Motel.
Shortly after the attack, the investigators say, Smith telephoned Eckardt. After they spoke, Eckardt wired $1,300 more to Detroit.
Early the next morning, on Jan. 7, Stant and Smith flew to Phoenix, the investigators say, and, for the first time in their haphazard odessey, traveled under false names.
 
Two Arrests, Then Another
 People to whom Eckardt had confided details of the caper soon began contacting the police, and one by one, the suspected plotters were arrested. Smith and Eckardt were arrested on Jan. 13, and the next day, Stant turned himself in.
Since the attack, Stant and Smith have sometimes been referred to as hit men. To some investigators, though, that is hyperbole.
"These guys are just opportunists," said one investigator. "The term 'hitman' suggests a certain professionalism and expertise that didn't exist here. These are thugs. Nothing more."

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE;
Health Concerns Mounting As Tents Rise After Quake

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Hundreds of green canvas tents went up today in parks around the city as thousands of earthquake refugees began a new routine, cooking breakfast on campfires, combing their hair in their car mirrors and heading off in search of housing.
With rain forecast for Sunday, Henry G. Cisneros, the Housing Secretary, announced on Friday that six tent cities would be opened in North Hollywood and the San Fernando Valley, where the earthquake was centered, despite a debate over whether they would become a long-term problem for the city. 
 Early today, he moved among the tents and through disaster-relief centers, looking over the shoulders of Federal employees and sometimes personally escorting applicants through the process, offering directions to shelters and once even giving a woman $5 for gas.
 
Fighting Frustration
 With people camped under cardboard and plastic, and long lines of angry applicants stranded outside disaster-relief centers, Federal, state and local officials were eager to ease public frustration after the earthquake on Monday.
The Clinton Administration moved to streamline the application process for housing grants, to open more disaster-assistance centers and to double the number of telephone operators handling requests for aid over a special line.
The White House also announced today that it would release $283 million in new Federal aid: $140 million for loans through the Small Business Administration and $143 million to the Federal Emergency Management Agency for its earthquake operations, like debris removal and housing assistance, The Associated Press reported. With this new money, the White House said, the Government has so far provided $639 million for small-business loans, $41 million for emergency highway repairs and $143 million for F.E.M.A. operations.
 
Sanctions for Price Gouging
 Meanwhile, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said it would aggressively enforce an emergency prohibition on price gouging, and the Southland Corporation threatened to revoke the franchise licenses of three of its 7-Eleven stores suspected of boosting prices on scarce items.
Mr. Cisneros said he understood the concerns of some local officials that the tent complexes might become something other than an emergency shelter remedy, but he said measures were being taken to insure against this.

 "The strategy of tents is to be temporary," Mr. Cisneros said. "The danger is that it will be impossible to take them down, and city officials legitimately were concerned that we were putting up some facilities that would be there for a very long time."
To prevent this, he said, large tents were being used to minimize any feeling of home, and people were being told they had about three weeks to find housing.
 
Fear of the Indoors
 Many of the refugees said that even though their homes had been found to be structurally sound they were afraid to sleep indoors. Some people camped out within sight of their apartments, returning to them in the morning to make breakfast and take showers.
Martin Leyva, a 25-year-old shipping clerk who is one of the Hispanic immigrants who make up the overwhelming majority of the people living outside, said he was avoiding any building with a roof. "I don't feel safe in any place," he said. "I'm really scared. I don't want to put my family in any shelter or any building."
Mr. Cisneros said tents erected by the National Guard could accommodate up to 6,000 people in total and that other tents would be obtained by contract from other sources, if needed. The Red Cross said 4,000 people were living in its shelters and another 6,000 were camped outside them. The National Guard estimated that 14,000 people were sleeping in parks, mostly in the San Fernando Valley.
 
Health Concerns
 With fears rising over sanitation and illness in the camps, and with the sound of coughing coming increasingly from the tents, the county health department sent teams of doctors and nurses to tour the tent cities. Hospital emergency rooms, which have handled thousands of earthquake injuries since Monday, reported an increasing number of exposure-related illnesses.
As soldiers swung circus-sized wooden mallets to put up the heavy canvas tents -- most of them capable of housing 30 people -- the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and several private organizations, as well as some neighboring residents, served food and hot coffee. Generators provided lighting inside the tents, but no heat, as nighttime temperatures dipped.
Some city parks took on the look of refugee camps as people sat aimlessly outside their shelters while children played ball, religious organizations handed out food and clothing, clowns performed skits, and armed and helmeted soldiers stood guard to maintain order. The air was filled with the smell of wood smoke, and sea gulls picked through the garbage.
 
'Emphasize Temporary'
 "These are not tent cities," said Maj. Dan Nation, a spokesman for the National Guard, in a refrain heard at refugee camps around the world. "These are temporary -- emphasize temporary -- shelters."
Mr. Cisneros, who flew here on the day of the earthquake, said he hoped that an accelerated disaster-assistance program would help people move quickly into new housing.
By late today, he said he hoped the first 1,000 of what he said could be 10,000 certificates would have been issued to cover the cost of temporary housing, bypassing the normal wait for verification of damage by housing inspectors.
"The first part of our effort is to get people from parks into shelters," he said. "The second is fielding 'reassurance teams' -- housing counselors, crisis counselors, clergy -- to work with people to advance the housing situation."
 
'Truly, Truly Afraid'
 The next priority, he said, would be to begin work on home repairs for the many thousands of people whose homes remained structurally sound but had damage serious enough to make them uninhabitable.
"In some communities I have driven through, every third house has damage in the $20,000 to $25,000 range -- damaged roofs or porches, broken and crushed masonry," he said.
Some of the people with serious damage to their houses, which were still inhabitable, were too afraid to return to them. Speaking of them, Mr. Cisneros said, "Many people are truly, truly afraid."
One such person is Olga Moreno, a 19-year-old student who spent last night in a National Guard tent with her husband, two children and about 25 other people, even though she and her parents had been told that their apartment was safe.
"We still see cracks in the walls," she said. "I don't know, it's just scary."
 
Little Trust in Buildings
 Larry Mellon, the recreation director for Lanark Park in the neighborhood of Canoga Park, where Miss Moreno spent the night, said most people here had come from nearby buildings that were found to be safe.
"They're scared," he said. "They're from third-world countries where a 5-magnitude quake will knock down a home. Officials tell them it's safe, and they don't believe it."
Stephen Barnaby, a Spanish-speaking specialist with the National Guard, said: "Owners of buildings are telling people that their apartments and houses are safe. Then an aftershock hits and they come back here. They can't trust anything."
Lieut. Jeff Soundas of the National Guard said: "Some people go back into their house for showers. When we have another aftershock, you'll see everybody running out."
 
Cabinet Chief's Helping Hand
 At a disaster-assistance center in Van Nuys late Friday, Mr. Cisneros seemed to be the busiest man in a room full of clerks who sat at long tables offering Federal, state and local help in 13 steps: loans, grants and housing assistance, tax advice, Social Security assistance, veterans assistance, insurance information, crisis counseling and disaster unemployment aid.
As weary families waited in lines with their even wearier children, Mr. Cisneros hustled from table to table, inquiring into individual cases and taking some of the people in hand, hustling them through the system.
"Look, here's one around here," he said to Antonette Robinson, an unemployed 23-year-old woman with three children who had received her 18-month rental-assistance certificate and was now looking through a binder showing available low-income housing.
"What about Western Avenue and Santa Monica?" Mr. Cisneros asked, as Mrs. Robinson scribbled notes on the back of an envelope. "Here's one, 6828 Troost. That's around here. The next one, 68 Coldwater Apartments. The next one, just next door."
Bending to the force of Mr. Cisneros's energy, Mrs. Robinson's hardships seemed to be easing. The slow-moving line for disaster assistance stretched far outside into the chilly night.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 14; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 821 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. CHALLENGES CLINTON'S AGENDA

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Setting an acrimonious tone as the election year opens, Republican leaders put President Clinton on notice today that they were ready to fight him on virtually every major issue on his agenda, from crime to health care to welfare.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, went a step further at the winter meeting of the Republican National Committee here, suggesting that Mr. Clinton's involvement in the Whitewater real estate deal when he was Governor of Arkansas might be used to the Republicans' benefit during the fall Congressional campaigns. 
 "If the Democrats don't want to have a hearing, they're going to suffer the consequences," Mr. Dole said of the Democrats' unwillingness to hold Congressional hearings on Whitewater. He said he was not fully reassured by Attorney General Janet Reno's appointment this week of an independent counsel, Robert B. Fiske Jr., to investigate the matter.
 
Kemp Urges Caution
 But most of the speakers at the committee's three-day winter meeting, which ended today, emphasized policy differences with the Administration. Jack F. Kemp, who like Mr. Dole is mentioned as a possible Presidential contender in 1996, was most critical of the President's health care plan.
Asserting that the country's health care system was a "problem" and not a "crisis," Mr. Kemp echoed Mr. Dole's comments that Mr. Clinton was moving too fast on trying to overhaul the system. "President Clinton is trying to scare the American people into thinking that we have to radically nationalize," Mr. Kemp declared in a luncheon speech today.
But on the issue of violence, Mr. Kemp departed from many other speakers here who sought to outdo one another in trying to appear toughest on the need to lock away criminals. He cautioned the party against becoming too fixated on building prisons in its zeal to score political points.
"There's got to be something in between gun control on the left and just building more prison space on the right," said Mr. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Bush Administration.
The recent polls showing that Mr. Clinton's popularity has rebounded only seemed to encourage Republicans to attack the President harder. "I know that President Clinton is going to try to steal the crime issue," Mr. Dole said, "and try to steal the welfare issue and try to steal the immigration issue. He'll probably get credit for health care."
The only thing the Republicans were giving Mr. Clinton credit for was the party's victories in every major election last year. It was a mantra heard in almost every speech here.
"The powerful principles that we forgot to talk about enough over the last few years but which unite us as Republicans have catapulted us back to victory in 1993," said Haley Barbour, the party chairman.
Despite the upbeat talk, the Republicans are still adjusting to the notion of a Democrat in the White House, and they were hard-pressed to explain Mr. Clinton's improved standing in recent polls.
At a news conference on Thursday at the opening of the party's conference, Mr. Barbour said Mr. Clinton's popularity reflected in part positive economic news. But the chairman said former President George Bush, not Mr. Clinton, deserved the credit.
 
Look at News Media
 Mr. Barbour then offered a second explanation for Mr. Clinton's popularity: with Congress not in session, Mr. Clinton had been able to dominate the news media. But he did not point out that the coverage was far from glowing because much was devoted to Mr. Clinton's involvement in the Whitewater deal and to accusations from Arkansas state troopers about Mr. Clinton's private life while he was Governor.
Perhaps because the accusations do not appear to have dented Mr. Clinton's ratings, Mr. Barbour backed off from his comments to reporters last week that the party would attack the President on character issues. Asked about such accusations this week, Mr. Barbour was strikingly less critical, saying, "I think the President should get the benefit of the doubt."
Yet today Mr. Dole was not so willing to let Whitewater drop although he had said last Sunday that he might forgo his call for Congressional hearings depending on who was chosen as independent counsel. "We're not after anybody," he said today, "but we do have some oversight responsibilities."
Mr. Dole stopped well short of predicting that Republicans would win control of the Senate this fall, saying of the Democrats, "As long as 41 Republicans stick together, they can't pass legislation."
But Representative Bill Paxon of New York, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said Republicans had a good shot at taking control of the House in the next two election cycles. And Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, chairman of the Republican Governors' Association, predicted that Republicans would dominate governorships in this year's elections.

HEADLINE: The G.O.P.: Wising Up About Race?

 BODY:
In a nation that's growing blacker and browner by the day, the Republican Party remains astonishingly white. Blacks were so scarce at the last national convention in Houston that TV news-show hosts held hostage the few they could find, whisking them from one appearance to the next, trying to show some diversity.
At election time, George Bush got only 11 percent of the black vote. David Bositis, of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies in Washington, says the G.O.P. could have reaped almost 20 percent, simply by campaigning in black areas and touting black appointments to the Administration. 
 But pride in diversity was not the game plan. As in years past, when the race-mongering Lee Atwater was at the helm, Republican strategists wrote off the black vote, and exploited racial tension in an attempt to lure conservative whites. With Ross Perot splitting the vote a third way, that strategy was dead on arrival. Bill Clinton swept the black vote without breaking a sweat. The irony here is that the black middle class -- prosperous, often conservative and larger than at any time in history -- is natural Republican timber.
A more diverse Republican Party would be less tempted to race-mongering and therefore less corrosive of the racial atmosphere. Such a party would be better equipped to win and keep a substantial representation in Congress. It would also bring balance to American politics. But to break the Democratic lock on blacks, the G.O.P. needs to shed the racial attitudes that have dominated the party since Barry Goldwater's ascension in 1964 and return to the more moderate positions that were still in force four years earlier, when Eisenhower was the standard-bearer. Simply put, the G.O.P. needs a diversity push.
The Republican National Committee seems to be waking up. Call the R.N.C. these days, and you're apt to hear spokesmen bragging about how many black votes their candidates received while winning governorships in New Jersey and Virginia. In New Jersey Christine Todd Whitman got 25 percent of the black vote -- and defeated Jim Florio by less than two percentage points. In Virginia, George Allen received 20 percent of the black vote, defeating the Democratic candidate, Mary Sue Terry. Smart money says Republican candidates will need similar numbers to win back the White House.
Prompted by moderate black Republicans from Massachusetts, the R.N.C. is planning grass-roots African-American policy conferences in Chicago, Atlanta, and that bastion of the black middle class, Washington. The strategy emerged from the Massachusetts Black Republican Council, which held its first annual convention last fall. The council's most important recommendation: Repeal the delegate selection rules that shortchange the most populous states, where blacks are more numerous. Last year only 3 of the R.N.C.'s 165 voting members were black -- all three from the Virgin Islands.
The council sees an urgent need for Republicans to "regain credibility and recover lost ground and votes among African-Americans." The R.N.C. needs to take that message to heart. The party would be healthier. So would American politics.

HEADLINE: Tip O'Neill Gave Leadership as House Speaker

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Shrinking Speaker," your Jan. 8 editorial on Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.'s tenure as Speaker of the House of Representatives, approvingly recalls the autocratic rule of Thomas B. Reed as Speaker in the 1890's and criticizes O'Neill. 
 Your ode to partisan leadership asserts that Reed "clearly spoke for" Republican majorities, conveniently ignoring that he lacked the guts to take the floor and speak against declaring war against Spain and, two months later, was a no-show on the vote to annex Hawaii, preferring instead to send an announcement that he would have joined his three Republican colleagues who voted against the resolution.
When it came to the most important votes the Constitution gives Congress, declaring war and expanding United States territory, Reed was not only silent but, in the case of Hawaii, also could not be found.
Reed may have been adept at counting quorums and recording majorities, but he seldom engaged in the art of political persuasion. O'Neill, in contrast, preferred the friendly embrace over the iron hand, the gentle nudge over the twisted arm in seeking votes. But his voice was never muted in debate, and his presence was not absent from the chair during important votes.
When Tip O'Neill's ideals were at stake, the prospect of defeat in the roll call did not deter him from taking the well of the chamber to persuade his colleagues to vote with him.
As Mickey Edwards, a former member of the Republican House leadership, wrote recently, the O'Neill axiom that all politics is local "meant knowing -- really knowing -- the people in the streets in the precinct, in the shops," not just to please them with your vote, but to explain to them like family and friends when you voted against their wishes. O'Neill did this when he opposed the war in Vietnam before most of his constituents did and when he opposed President Reagan's economic legislation in 1981, when his constituents strongly supported it.
O'Neill served in the leadership of the House nearly two decades. It was a time of enormous change when the "go along to get along" Congressional ethos was replaced by the antileadership ethos of independent legislators. Yet it was also the occasion for the emergence of the Party Caucus, a body that Speaker Sam Rayburn spurned and Reed feared. O'Neill welcomed the rise of the caucus and worked with it, most notably in forging support for landmark legislation on Social Security in 1983 and tax reform in 1986.
The Democratic Caucus was not only a vehicle for procedural reform, but in the hands of Tom Foley, Gillis Long and Dick Gephardt, it became a vehicle for the development of new ideas like tax reform. Indeed, under Gillis Long, it laid the foundation for the Democratic Leadership Council and the New Democrat Agenda embraced by President Clinton.
You assert that O'Neill's legacy is a weakened speakership. On July 5, 1981, you suggested that after the 1982 Congressional elections, "Democrats in the House of Representatives may not be electing anything higher than a minority leader." You underestimated O'Neill's political leadership in 1981 and have done so again in 1994.
 
KIRK O'DONNELL
Washington, Jan. 14, 1994
 
The writer served as counsel to the Speaker of the House, 1978 to 1986.

HEADLINE: Conversations/Frank Sweeney;
Prison Graduate Sells 'New Fish' Words to Live (or Do Time) By

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

 BODY:
THE classified advertisement in USA Today and The National Law Journal was a model of brevity and wit:
"Going to Federal prison for the first time? We will tell you what to expect and how to survive. Our consultants are graduates of the Federal prison system. Frank A. Sweeney & Associates. Box 15 Demarest, N.J. 07627." 
 At last, in a country that offers Dr. Ruth for your sex life, Bob Vila for your old-home life and enough syndicated investment columnists to liquidate the gross national product, comes Frank Abbott Sweeney, convicted swindler and consummate prison insider, with an intuitive grasp of a potentially bottomless new advice market.
Until inspiration struck Mr. Sweeney last fall, felons as famous as Sol Wachtler and Charles Keating and as anonymous as Mr. Sweeney himself were being spirited off to the great maw of Federal prison like 10-year-olds to their first sleep-away camp.
But 10-year-olds can network to get the lowdown on camping's tribal pathways. For first-time prisoners ("new fish," in prison parlance), once bail is revoked the darkness descends quickly and the woods are not marked.
This anxiety and what to do about it is at the heart of Mr. Sweeney's idea, which evolved after he read that Officer Laurence Powell of the Los Angeles Police Department was "terrified" at the prospect of a prison sentence in the Rodney L. King beating case.
Recalling his epiphany, Mr. Sweeney said: "I thought to myself, 'My God, there's probably a lot of people going to prison who've never been in jail before, primarily white-collar criminals, and they're probably terrified, too. They're just as frightened as he is.'
"So I thought maybe I can use my misfortune to help people and maybe make a profit doing it."
Since November, he said, 27 clients paying up to $200 each (the standard fee) have answered his ad. In their search for help, they have put themselves in the hands of Mr. Sweeney and two equally experienced associates -- a pilot/drug smuggler (seven years served) and a bank robber (14 years served). In almost any other walk of life, offering such resumes would be awkward at best. For Sweeney & Associates, it is bread and butter.
Trim, articulate and elfin-like, with a curly mop of red hair, Mr. Sweeney, 50 years old, is the son of a successful architect from Tenafly, N.J. Bright but bored, he left school after the 11th grade and, as a result of his time in prison, never established a career. He lives primarily on income from an inheritance.
A brief curriculum vitae:
1967: First arrest, on state charges, after he wounded a police officer with a Thompson submachine gun. Mr. Sweeney had legally purchased the nonfunctioning weapon by mail and undertook to restore it to working order. A mistake. During a field test in the woods near his home, he was confronted by -- and fired at -- a police officer who had drawn his own weapon. Seven years in state prison.
1976: Arrested for mail fraud. "I claimed to be selling firearms that I didn't have." Three years.
1982: Pistol-possession charge. (It is illegal for a convicted felon to possess a weapon.) Four years.
1988: Rearrested for mail fraud (same m.o.). Three years 8 months.
Having shared his record, he gently rebuffed attempts at self-analysis, saying: "I remember it was Nietzsche who wrote, 'The crime is not in the act but in the stupidity of being caught.' I was caught, and stupid."
But not dumb.
Mr. Sweeney is to prisons what the mythical Master Sgt. Ernest G. Bilko was to the barracks in the the post-World War II Army: a charming and persuasive goldbrick, adept at finding advantage in a bureaucracy designed to thwart him. In Mr. Sweeney's view, a system as rigid as the Bureau of Prisons is bound to crack under even minimal pressure and expose a loophole or two, a fact borne out by his own experience.
"We advise our clients how to manipulate the Bureau of Prisons to their advantage," he says in a letter sent to prospective clients. Then, by eliciting a rundown on the client's criminal and personal history, Mr. Sweeney essentially tries to duplicate the Government's assigning process, to give the client an idea of where he might go and what he might expect when he gets there.
A minimum-security prison camp like Allenwood, in Pennsylvania, a typical resting place for nonviolent white-collar criminals, is less onerous, say, than the penitentiary at Terre Haute, Ind., a high-security prison for drug offenders and bank robbers serving 10 years or more. Mr. Sweeney will tailor his advice accordingly.
He will also advise on how to arrange transfer from prison to prison (perhaps to be closer to home) and intercede with regional administrators by phone or letter on issues ranging from safety, to work assignment to diet.
"I say I'm a consultant," he said. "You know how readily people will give you information over the phone if you sound convincing enough."
With few exceptions, he said, clients are in their mid- to late 40's and typically face sentences for income-tax evasion, embezzlement, computer fraud, wire fraud and low-level drug offenses. Few will enter the most dangerous prisons and do really hard time. But almost all of them have the same concerns.
"The two questions my clients ask: 'Will I be the recipient of homosexual or racial violence?' " Mr. Sweeney said. "The answer to the first is almost always no. There is homosexuality, but men generally enter into these arrangements consensually and there is no violence."
Racial violence, or violence of any sort, he said, often occurs because prisoners become involved in gangs or in avoidable disputes -- failure to repay a loan, for example -- with other prisoners.
"We advise people to try to do their own sentences, and not bother with other people," he said.
Having been an inmate in 17 of the Government's 70 prison camps and penitentiaries, Mr. Sweeney relied on his own advice. "Everything I've done is legal," he said, "though some is kind of underhanded."
For example, here's how he approached some basic issues:
*Cuisine. Revolted by ordinary prison food, he persuaded the rabbi in Springfield, Mo., to put him on a kosher diet. "He was skeptical because of my appearance and my name. But my mother had a German name. That seemed to do it. The food was delicious." (Mr. Sweeney's mother is Lutheran.)
*Lodging. "When I was at Jessup, Ga., a fairly nice institution, I feigned mental illness, so the psychologist gave me a cell by myself."
*Career. "I tried to get out of work as much as I could. In fact, I never really had work. I claimed I had terrible arthritis. I have a mild case, but I exaggerated it to the point where I borrowed a cane from a prisoner who was crippled and I went to see the doctor. I said, 'Oh, my God, I can barely bend over.' "
Mr. Sweeney said he was thinking of producing a guidebook, a kind of Penal Michelin, to annotate the Government's own "Facilities" manual. As to the difficulty of being on the outside and staying current with conditions inside, he says that's not a problem.
"I'll tell you the truth," Mr. Sweeney said, "It hasn't changed from the time I went in in 1976 to the time I was released 14 months ago."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Sweeney outside his office in Demarest, N.J. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Windows Pop: A Mystery Story

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Hundreds of windows have been popping and shattering inside apartments at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, and the problem is getting worse, tenant leaders say.
Complaints were first heard two years ago, when 138,000 new windows were installed as part of a major capital improvement program at the two developments. But they escalated late last year, and a recent survey has turned up 20 broken windows in one apartment building on First Avenue. 
 No casualties have been reported but 30 to 40 complaints are coming in daily to the office of the tenants association for the two communities, said Jo-Ann Polise, vice president of the organization. The group has received complaints from more than 500 people since November, she said, with some reporting several broken panes.
The windows have two panes for insulation, and most of the shattered ones are on the inside, so the glass has generally been falling inside apartments.
It is possible the bitter weather has aggravated the problem, but no one knows for sure. Building workers have boarded up the broken windows to keep out the cold.
Metropolitan Life Insurance, which owns and manages the two rent-stabilized complexes for 10,000 residents, has received complaints on "less than half of 1 percent of the windows," said a company spokeswoman, Nancy Peskin. But that means more than 600 broken windows, and the company has asked its technical consultants and the manufacturers to investigate.
The manufacturer, Efco, based in Monett, Mo., says it has never experienced such a problem. Chris Fuldner, president of Efco, said the two panes of the aluminum-frame windows are separated by a space filled with argon gas to enhance insulation.
Preliminary investigations show that the units are "imploding, not exploding," Mr. Fuldner said. This indicates a loss of gas between the panes, putting stress on the inner pane and causing it to shatter, he said, adding that he hoped to find a cause within two weeks.
Concern has spread among the residents. Last Tuesday, Charmian Neary, a Stuyvesant Town resident, said, she heard what sounded like a muffled explosion. "I looked up and saw the whole inner pane, which is five feet high and one foot wide, had totally shattered inside the screen," she said. "Some of the shards were 18 inches long and there was glass dust all over the place."
It was her second experience with imploding glass. The first one was last summer.
Metropolitan Life is seeking a $9-a-room rent increase for its capital improvement program. The tenants association has asked Donald Halperin, commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, to turn down the proposal until the window problem is solved.
 M.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BUSHWICK;
New Stores To Serve Retail Desert

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
Since the 1970's, when arson fires raged through the streets of Bushwick, destroying as many as 500 wood-frame buildings a year, hundreds of new and rehabilitated homes have been completed along with thousands of units of public housing. But retail development has lagged, forcing residents to go to other communities to find coin-operated laundries and dry cleaners and to buy simple necessities like aspirin and disposable diapers.
Next month, weather permitting, construction will begin on five storefronts on vacant city-owned lots along Broadway between Gates Avenue and Cornelia Street. The tenants will include a currency exchange, a pizzeria, a coin laundry and Saverama, a variety store. The developer, Broadway Bushwick Builders, is also negotiating with other possible tenants, including Rainbow Shops, a national clothing chain, and Blimpie's, the fast-food chain. 
 "The hardest thing in attracting tenants," said Jeffrey Stern, a partner in Broadway Bushwick, "is that no one believes anything will happen there." The project is being financed with $5.5 million from a retail redevelopment program that was set up by the City Economic Development Corporation.
"Bushwick is a long neglected part of the city," said Daniel Gerard, another partner. "Since the fires in the 70's, nothing in terms of large-scale retail development has happened. But with the new homes that have been built there in the last decade, it's fast becoming a vibrant and growing neighborhood. We're just a small part of the revival."
A major factor in the Bushwick revival was the construction 15 years ago of Hope Gardens, a housing development. With its neat, three-story buildings spread over a half-mile of once-vacant lots, Hope Gardens is the largest public housing project built in America since 1981. Its 3,586 residents raised Bushwick's population nearly 12 percent in a decade, according to 1990 census figures.
Mildred Stevens, a Westchester County resident, shops for her elderly mother in Hope Gardens once a week. She said the new storefronts would be a blessing.
"I think my mother would be more inspired to go out walking around if there were more stores," said Mrs. Stevens, whose mother has lived in Hope Gardens' 14-story apartment building for the elderly for five years. "Right now, she won't go out because it's so barren around here."
In July 1977, in the days after the power blackout, Bushwick was the scene of more looting and arson than any other neighborhood in New York City.
"We're trying to get beyond the past and move toward the future," said Anna Gonzalez, who is the chairwoman of Community Board 4, which covers Bushwick. "We really have hope that we can wipe out this image of Bushwick as being a troubled place with vacant lots and abandoned buildings."
 LYNETTE HOLLOWAY
