HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Corporate Headquarters;
Marketing Opulent Waifs Abandoned by Austerity

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT the metropolitan New York region, one can see opulent corporate headquarters buildings that now stand as reminders of the halcyon days when a booming economy led companies like Nestle, the American Can Company and Exxon Chemical to build monuments to themselves and their achievements.
 Many of these buildings are now only partially occupied or, in some cases, vacant, victims of corporate relocations, downsizing and a generally more austere corporate climate. 
They now find themselves competing for tenants alongside an abundance of other, often more modern, office buildings in Westchester County, Connecticut and New Jersey. And their opulent appointments, winding driveways, campus settings and huge parking lots are not always an easy sell, according to several local real estate brokers.
 "In the 70's and 80's, a C.E.O. would find an architect that would convince him that he was a Medici prince," said John L. Dowling, an executive vice president at Cushman & Wakefield in Manhattan. "And then the architect would build him a palace. The building would win a magazine award, but it was an instant image of that business on that day. And buildings survive C.E.O.'s, and many of these buildings are now dysfunctional."
 One building that might have seemed that way is the 279,180-square-foot former Nestle Food Corporation headquarters in Purchase in Westchester County. Built in 1986, it has a two-story atrium lobby, a dining area that doubles as a 325-seat theater and an executive wing with private bathrooms and a mahogany-paneled board room with an octagonal skylight. The four-story building is faced with blue-gray granite and blue reflective glass.
 It languished on the market for more than a year until TransAmerica Leasing took 125,000 square feet of office space there in 1993, Westchester's largest lease for the year.
 TransAmerica Leasing, which leases large container boxes for transportation of goods in ships and tractor trailers, moved from a comparable office building at 711 Westchester Avenue, where it was the sole tenant.
 "We thought the time was right to upgrade our work environment," said Edward T. Mann, chief financial officer for TransAmerica Leasing. "The building we were in had gotten tired,"
 Mr. Mann said that his company had looked at several other "premium" buildings, both in Westchester and Connecticut, several of them corporate headquarters. In some cases, the buildings were just too opulent for the company's taste.
 For instance, Mr. Mann said, he looked at the former American Can Company headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., where Witco Corporation, a chemical company, recently leased 250,000 square feet.
 "It's an absolutely spectacular headquarters," said Mr. Mann. "We're a $2 billion company, and we thought it was more appropriate for our parent company, TransAmerica, which is a $30 billion company."
 BUILT in 1971, the 500,000-square-foot American Can building has huge floor sizes and high ceilings. And on its 155-acre campus are a 50,000-square-foot annex building and a guest house that sleeps 12.
 Because of the high ceilings, it was not thought capable of being easily broken up into smaller spaces. Witco, which took over half the building and will consolidate its management and support staff there, said it would relocate about 800 employees from several states to the new offices.
 Witco will receive $8 million in direct financial assistance from the State of Connecticut in an incentive package negotiated by its Department of Economic Development. As part of the package, the company has agreed to remain in Connecticut at least 10 years with an average minimum employment of 800 people.
 To keep TransAmerica in Westchester, it was also given some financial incentives in the form of tax abatements by the Town of Harrison and energy rebates by Consolidated Edison.
 "Since we have no state program to help us, we have to do the best we can to try to keep our companies," said Alfred B. DelBello, former Lieutenant Governor and Westchester County Executive, who is now a private lawyer and an unpaid consultant for the county. "We work with the towns, industrial development agencies and the utilities to work out the best package we can."
 As for TransAmerica Leasing's reduced tax rate, Mr. DelBello said that the town "saw a greater benefit in having a building occupied than getting the most taxes they possibly could."
 According to Mr. Mann, with incentives and a very competitive rental, his company was able to move from a grade B building to a grade A and achieve a greater than 25 percent savings.
 "It was really a matter of being in the right place at the right time," he said. "It's like we outsmarted the market."
 Such grade A space that in the mid-80's leased for $33 a square foot now goes for $21 to $25, according to Michael H. Siegel, executive director of the Westchester/Fairfield office of the Edward S. Gordon Company, the commercial brokerage firm. But that could change when supplies diminish.
 "What we're finding is that large blocks of space, in excess of 100,000 square feet or more, are diminishing," Mr. Siegel said. "There's still a lot in Westchester, but if a large block goes on the market in Connecticut, it's good news."
 One of the largest blocks now on the market in Westchester is perhaps I.B.M.'s premier property at 2000 Purchase Street in Purchase. While it is not the headquarters of International Business Machines, which is in Armonk and is still occupied by the company, 2000 Purchase is considered a "headquarters-quality" building, according to John Rostenberg, a principal at Rostenberg-Doern, a commercial brokerage with offices in Stamford, Conn., and Purchase.
 "I think it's the architectural jewel of Westchester," said Mr. Rostenberg of the 476,823-square-foot building, designed by I.M. Pei.
 Built in 1983, it had been occupied in its entirety by I.B.M. for seven years starting in 1985. As a cost-cutting measure, the company started moving 550 employees out of the building in May 1992 and relocating them to Armonk and company owned buildings in White Plains and Mount Pleasant. The company found it could cut its costs at the Purchase building by 50 percent simply by shutting it down.
 Edward S. Gordon is the exclusive sales agent for the property, which is being marketed for a single tenant.
 "I.B.M. desires to find a single user," said Mr. Siegel. "Every company who's even thinking about leaving New York City wants to see this building. We've had a lot of showings in the last few months for whatever reason."
 THE preference on the part of I.B.M. is to sell the property. The asking price has been quoted at $75 million, "which is as official as any other number at this point," Mr. Siegel said.
 Taking a slightly different tack is Newmark & Company Real Estate, which is now marketing the former world headquarters of Exxon Chemical Corporation in Darien, Conn. The 214,200-square-foot building has been on the market for two years. Like many headquarters buildings, it features wood interiors, a private dining room and an executive board room.
 "We'd like to get the first big bulk tenant in there first," said John D. Goodkind, senior vice president and director of Newmark's Westchester/Connecticut office. He said he was now in negotiation with a tenant who was interested in half of the building.
 "Then we can break up the space as needed," Mr. Goodkind said, "preferably into 20,000- to 30,000-square-foot blocks. That's the market now. And that's good. One reason Connecticut is now doing better than Westchester is that it never relied on one major company like Westchester did with I.B.M. If you have a variance of companies, the risk is so much less."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 27, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 23 about the marketing of corporate headquarters buildings misstated the size of the former Exxon Chemical Corporation building in Darien, Conn. A reader's letter, received last week, points out that the building totals 71,400 square feet, not 214,200.

HEADLINE: THE GOVERNORSHIP;
Changing of the Guard: The Whitman Team

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman will have 20 Cabinet members, one more than Gov. Jim Florio. She is restoring the chairman of the Board of Regulatory Commissioners. Mrs. Whitman has not announced her appointments for Corrections Commissioner, Adjutant General, Health Commissioner, Insurance Commissioner, Labor Commissioner and Public Advocate. Cabinet members are paid $100,225 a year.
 
ELIZABETH RANDALL, Banking Commissioner
AGE: 40.
HOMETOWN: Westwood. N.J.
BACKGROUND: State assemblywoman, 1985-1991. Partner, Randall, Randall & Stevens of Westwood, March 1984-February 1991. Has served in a variety of legal jobs in state and local government including assistant counsel to former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, Assistant Essex County prosecutor, municipal prosecutor in Park Ridge, and borough attorney in Hillsdale. She has been Bergen County counsel since 1991.
FAMILY: Single.
 
 ROBERT C. SHINN JR., Commissioner of Environmental Protection and Energy.
AGE: 56.
HOMETOWN: Hainesport, N.J.
BACKGROUND: Founder of Material Handling Systems, a heavy-equipment sales firm. Elected to the Burlington County Board of Chosen Freeholders in 1977. Since 1985, he was served in the New Jersey Assembly, where he has been chairman of Assembly committees on solid waste and land use planning.
FAMILY: Divorced, two daughters.
 
GUALBERTO MEDINA, Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development
AGE: 45.
HOMETOWN: Cherry Hill, N.J.
BACKGROUND: A Temple University law graduate, served in 1979-80 as an attorney for the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development in Philadelphia. Private law practice since then and has worked for accounting firms. Most recently, director of management advisory services for John Milligan & Associates, a regional accounting firm in Philadelphia.
FAMILY: Married, two sons and a daughter.
INTERESTS: Classical literature, classical music, running.
 
JUDITH SHAW, Chief of Staff
AGE: 50.
HOMETOWN: Princeton, N.J.
BACKGROUND: Deputy director for marketing of the Lottery Commission for three years, then joined the Department of Transportation and became its chief of staff in 1987. Left in 1990 and joined Public Policy Advisers, a lobbying firm in Trenton. Became a partner and vice president in 1991.
FAMILY: Divorced, two stepdaughters.
INTERESTS: Golf, photography.

BACKGROUND: Director of the Federal Transit Administration during the Bush Administration. Most recently president and chief executive of Railway Systems Design Inc., a transportation engineering concern in Harrisburg, Pa.
FAMILY: Married, a son and daughter.
INTERESTS: Fishing, golf.

HEADLINE: Finding Profits in Architectural Specialties

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
POOLS and schools. In a profession that continues to suffer from the slowdown in construction, architects who have developed special areas of expertise seem to be faring better than most.
Lap pools are a specialty of Leonard Weinberg, an architect who started his own practice 21 years ago today in White Plains. And schools are a specialty of Barbara and Allan Anderson of the firm Anderson La Rocca Anderson Architects and Planners in Rye. 
 To take Mr. Weinberg's experience first, he recalled that in 1973, "one of my first commissions was to design an indoor lap pool for a client who lived on the Sound in Mamaroneck." Mr. Weinberg continued: "It was an unusual site, a point surrounded by water on two sides. The pool was housed in its own house, which was connected to a studio and a guest room we also designed. It was really beautiful, and what happened is that on the strength of that project, I began to get referrals mostly from people of that town who wanted pools for health reasons -- bad backs and that kind of thing. Then when fitness became the watchword, there was increased interest in installing lap pools."
Before Mr. Weinberg started his practice, he worked for several large architectural firms in Manhattan. Two of his projects were for the Metropolitan Museum of Art: the Blumenthal Patio and expansion at the Cloisters. Yet, he said, he had always been drawn to residential design.
 
Year-Round Use
 "When we bought our house in White Plains, I started doing freelance residential work and by 1973 I felt the time had come to go out on my own," he said. "Currently my practice consists of custom residential work: new homes, additions and alterations. However, many of the alterations are more than that; they are complete changes to existing homes. And about 20 of the additions I have done have been involved with pools, designing both lap and recreational swimming pools and their houses."
Indoor pools, he explained, are in reality year-round pools. "It makes sense to be able to use a pool 12 months a year, and the trend has been for year-round use," he said. "The pool houses I design can be opened up on two or three sides."
Demand is about evenly split for lap pools -- 12 feet by 50 or 60 feet -- and recreational pools -- 20 by 30 feet.
"Of course a lot depends on the site and the zoning restrictions," Mr. Weinberg said. "A pool house is essentially an addition, but an addition that can be very tricky to build since it has very specific requirements such as air changes, which have to be taken into consideration. Designing a system to take out the humidity created by the pool and substituting warm dry air is critical. If the flow of air can't be controlled properly, what happens is that you end up with jungle conditions that lead to rot and growth of mold."
Mr. Weinberg added, "I experimented with various systems before I found the best way to go."
Despite the recession and the cost, -- a complete indoor pool project ranges from $200,000 to $600,000 -- there is still a steady demand for indoor pools in the county.
"It's a limited market, by no means an everyday type of project," Mr. Weinberg said. "Some are very elaborate with heated spas, saunas, kitchens and bars, but in general there has been increased interest in year-round pools. Of course, they are particularly great when it's snowing outside."
The price of indoor pools, Mr. Weinberg said, reflects construction costs and the materials used. "The pool itself costs $35,000 to $45,000," he said. "And there is the construction of the addition, which is a building with movable walls, a mechanical system, heating equipment, and even the laminated wood beams that have to be used for the decking are expensive items."
Mr. Weinberg said he may soon have a partner in his practice. "My daughter, Denise Dorfman," he said. "She recently graduated with a degree in architecture from Pratt, which is just 30 years after I graduated from Pratt."
As for the Andersons -- a husband-and-wife design team -- they have received a number of architectural awards for school projects, including their design for the new Rye Middle School, which won a historic preservation award from the city of Rye last May.
"What especially pleased us about the award is that the historic preservationists would honor a new building," Mr. Anderson said. "Our aim as architects, was to design an addition to be compatible with the original 1931 Gothic structure in size, scale and material. We were lucky to be able to get random hand-cut ashlar stone from the same quarry that was used for the original building, and we repeated the old slate roofs. In the interiors we used the deep rich tones favored in medieval times."
 
A Staff of 16
 The project, he said, was finished under budget at a total cost of almost $3 million.
"School design means dealing with budgets, schedules, night meetings and knowing how to work with constraints, if you are going to be successful at it," said Mr. Anderson, who obviously is, because school projects account for 90 percent of the firm's work.
"The work is steady but very competitive," he continued, adding that it was in 1974, shortly after the couple established their practice, that they landed their first project, the Milton Elementary School in Rye.
"I had attended Milton myself as a kid, which made the assignment a lot of fun for me," he said. "We won an award for our design, and on the strength of that project we got a commission to do the Woodlands Junior High School in White Plains. Eventually we got so busy with schools that we gave up doing residential work entirely."
The Andersons have 16 people in their firm, 8 of them architects, and they expect the rise in the national birth rate to keep them all busy.
"School work has been very steady," Mr. Anderson said. "Some projects are even coming around for the second time. For instance, 21 years later, we are back working on Woodlands Junior High School in White Plains. Right now we are doing a $16 million middle school in New Fairfield, Conn., two other school projects in Connecticut, and we recently got a job, competing against a field of 19, for a school in Dorset, Vt., in addition to several other school projects. The technology in school design today, Mr. Anderson said, focuses on security. "Casual supervision is built in. And the trend is to make schools more home-like in appearance. We do the classroom development as well as the classroom design as well as the architecture and before we start any project we meet with building committees, school staff parents and children to get their input."
Eugenio Maria de Hostos Microsociety School, or School 19, a magnet school in Yonkers, designed for the Yonkers Board of Education and completed in October 1992, is a case in point, Mr. Anderson said.
"In addition to the normal space of a contemporary elementary school, we included areas that reflect the students' own environment," he said. "There are microsociety spaces that include a marketplace, banks, government offices and manufacturing, media and publishing spaces." The project won two awards, one from the American Institute of Architects and another from the American Association of School Administrators.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leonard Weinberg, an architect who specializes in designing lap pools for homes. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Profile;
The 'Iron Lady' Keeping Lotus on Track

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
JUNE L. ROKOFF dislikes nicknames, but at the Lotus Development Corporation, where she is senior vice president for software development and a cult hero, Ms. Rokoff is known as St. June, or sometimes the Iron Lady.
As Lotus rides the crest of a remarkable upturn in its fortunes, Ms. Rokoff plays a central role: the glue that holds Lotus's development organization together. 
 In the tempestuous, ego-driven industry that creates software for personal computers, she is a manager who combines technical savvy and an understanding of a programmer's mindset with intuitive people skills and a willingness to fight on others' behalf. Many people around her say she has saved more than one crucial product.
"June Rokoff is the most widely respected executive at Lotus," said Mitchell Kertzman, chairman and chief executive of Powersoft, a neighboring software maker.
Ms. Rokoff is credited, for example, with saving the crucial follow-on release to the company's 1-2-3 spreadsheet package in 1989 by leading a disastrous development project to success.
And more recently, her strong support and leadership brought 1-2-3 for Windows to a highly successful debut and kept key team members from leaving. She has run almost every piece of Lotus at one time or another, including its hugely successful communications group, which included its hot Notes software, during a delicate formative stage.
She has also forged close relationships with many Lotus customers. "She sees to it that Lotus meets its commitments, even if it's not the best economic deal for them," said Craig D. Goldman, chief information officer at Chase Manhattan, who often uses Lotus software.
Lotus -- after several years of product delays, harsh press notices and management defections -- has been boosted by strong sales of Notes software and emerged in the past six months as one of the hottest software companies. It is now an industry darling and its stock is trading near an all-time high.
A soft-spoken 44-year-old, Ms. Rokoff is so respected within Lotus, which she joined in 1986, that word of her deeds has spread, making her a prized target for recruiters looking for chief executives. Having spent time as chief operations officer of Isys, a high-tech start-up, in the early 1980's, she fits a rare profile: an executive who understands both technology and management.
The reason for such high praise is Ms. Rokoff's ability to build trust and commitment within groups of software programmers, notorious for being temperamental and cynical. "Technologists don't generally like to take direction, but they like to take direction from June," said Don McLagan, a former boss of hers. Ms. Rokoff sums up her skill simply: "When things are crazy, I tend to be a calming influence."
When Lotus was being hammered 18 months ago because its Windows version of 1-2-3 was late, morale hit rock bottom and some talented software developers considered leaving. Lotus had gone through a steady stream of technology chiefs since the founder, Mitchell Kapor, left in 1986, and the latest was Frank King, a respected former I.B.M. executive, who resigned in 1991.
Jim Manzi, Lotus's chairman and chief executive, then hired John Landry, an industry veteran, a move not embraced by everyone at Lotus. Outspoken and aggressive, Mr. Landry acknowledges he lacks the operational skills needed to handle the 1,300-person organization. But when, five months later, Mr. Manzi elevated Ms. Rokoff to her current position as Mr. Landry's equal partner, the disgruntled designers decided to stay.
The two-headed leadership has succeeded despite early misgivings around the company and rumors that it signaled more management turmoil. Both Ms. Rokoff and Mr. Landry say their skills and personalities are well matched, which they agree is crucial.
Mr. Landry, as chief technology officer, spends his time on strategy and evangelizing Lotus's products to the outside world while Ms. Rokoff runs day-to-day operations. They handle personnel matters jointly.
"A lot of key people are still at Lotus today because of June Rokoff," said Jeffrey R. Beir, vice president of the spreadsheet division. "She's got an insight about how to motivate and lead people that is unmatched."
It was Ms. Rokoff, for example, who backed the spreadsheet development team when it wanted to spend more time building added features for a new version of Lotus 1-2-3 for Windows when internal pressure from sales and marketing people to ship the product was at a fever pitch.
She and Mr. Landry participated in triage and "bug detection" meetings, sometimes three times a day and on weekends, to help determine which problems needed fixing first. That showed the programmers that senior management was not only supportive, but willing to work side by side with them.
Three years earlier, Ms. Rokoff had volunteered to take over the development team that was building the follow-on to Lotus's original 1-2-3 spreadsheet for DOS. That product, known as Release 3, had become a company nightmare and threatened to scuttle Lotus completely.
The product was late, the development team disorganized. Six managers had come and gone as the project dragged along. Ms. Rokoff, who at the time had been with the company only two years, had never handled a project of that magnitude, but she persuaded Mr. King, then a senior vice president, that she could break the logjam.
"I thought, 'I'm here. I've got to get the company moving,' " she said. "The truth is, I had no idea what I was getting into." From October 1988 until the product was shipped the following June, Ms. Rokoff, with three young children at home, worked seven days a week alongside the software developers. Her husband, David Rokoff, a lawyer, took over many of the family obligations. "We underestimated the whole experience," he said. "It was horrible." But they agreed that it was a career-making opportunity.
MS. ROKOFF walked into a maelstrom when she took over the Release 3 team. The developers thought Lotus managers could not be trusted. Ms. Rokoff recognized quickly that these people weren't getting the leadership they needed. At the same time, the technical mess needed to be cleaned up, and morale had to be lifted.
She immediately set and clarified objectives and made sure they were communicated clearly and often. She set interim milestones to test the progress of the new software and had daily "bug" meetings in which quality-assurance engineers and programmers discussed problems, taking immediate action if needed. Knowing that programmers hate meetings, she instituted a rule limiting them to an hour. The company has institutionalized these changes.
In most such projects, there is one quality-assurance engineer to each programmer, but given this product's importance, Ms. Rokoff assigned two to each programmer.
She also tackled personnel issues. The programmers' area was cleaned up, and the quality of people's lives was addressed. After months of cold pizza, deli sandwiches and beer, Ms. Rokoff instituted a "guest chef" night. On Tuesdays, when testing forced everyone to work well into the night, Lotus executives, including Mr. Manzi, would cook up a gourmet meal for 70 or 80 people.
People started getting recognition for their work -- for example, tailor-made posters for individual achievements.
She insisted that Mr. Manzi and other top executives stop in regularly to congratulate team members who had made some important breakthrough. And she had a rock video made of the team members, which was shown to the entire company. When the product was shipped, she took out a full-page ad in the local newspaper to thank the team, and champagne bottles were broken over the first delivery trucks at a company picnic.
"We called her the Iron Lady during the process because she was so strong about being decisive and making sure team needs were met," Mr. King recalled. "She made listening the culture of her team. Without her, Release 3 wouldn't have happened."
At a company known for its philanthropy and commitment to diversity, Ms. Rokoff is also the leading voice for bringing in more women and minorities. She insists that the people who report to her execute plans to increase hiring and promotion of women and minorities and assesses the managers' efforts in performance reviews. "She stays in everyone's face on this," Mr. Landry said.
THE oldest child in a middle-class family from Queens, June Lapides was doted on by her parents, who encouraged her in science and math. Her father, an accountant who grew bored with his work and became a successful stock trader on his own, instilled a willingness to confront a challenge.
She said her parents are proud but not especially surprised at her accomplishments. But she is still not satisfied. "We women don't believe we are as good as we are," she said. "I see all the warts, all the things I still want to accomplish. I still have so much I think I need to do, and I'm very hard on myself. I don't ever feel I'm done."
A former programmer, Ms. Rokoff spent 13 years at Data Resources Inc., rising to the rank of vice president. She credits her boss there, Don McLagan, for being her key mentor, pushing her into projects that tested both her technical and managerial skills.
And it was at Data Resources that she learned about the commitment necessary to make disgruntled developers into teams.
"I put myself in other people's shoes," she said. "It's a combination of really listening and remembering the days when I was a programmer. Once you get into their shoes, you can solve the problem from their side."
It was also about commitment, a willingness to move in with the group, live their schedules, see the world through their eyes. "Whatever it takes," she said. "If I'm going to do something, I jump in whole hog."
Ms. Rokoff says she is not motivated by money. Her husband cringes at the 1989 Oldsmobile she insists on driving and her refusal to indulge herself. "She's happier knowing the money's in the bank," he said.
And there is money in the bank. On top of a $325,000 salary, she recently cashed in more than $1 million in stock options and still owns options worth nearly $7 million.
She says she has no interest in a chief executive position, saying she needs at least two more years to get Lotus's development organization where she wants it. "I can't imagine a place where I could make the impact I can here," she said.
 
June L. Rokoff
 
 
 Born: June 22, 1949; Queens, N.Y.
 
 Education: B.S., math and computer science, State University of New York at Albany.
 
 Family. Husband, David, a lawyer. Three children, aged 10, 13 and 15.
 
 Recent reading: "Fire With Fire," by Naomi Wolf.
 
 Ideal vacation: Houseboating on Lake Powell in Utah with her family.
 
 Drives: 1989 Oldsmobile.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 26; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1032 words

HEADLINE: The Other Side of the Wall

BYLINE: By Joan Countryman; Joan Countryman, a daughter of the first African-American high school teacher in the Philadelphia public schools, is head of the Lincoln School in Providence, R.I.

 BODY:

ON THE EDGE
A History of Poor Black Children and Their American Dreams.
By Carl Husemoller Nightingale.
254 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $24.
 
HARDBALL
A Season in the Projects.
By Daniel Coyle.
317 pp. New York:
G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95. 
IF the walls that many affluent communities would like to construct as barriers between suburb and city were mirrors, suburban residents looking to explain the alarming rise in violence across the United States would see not poor children in inner cities, but reflections of themselves and their American values. Both Carl Husemoller Nightingale, an assistant professor of history at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and Daniel Coyle, a senior editor for Outside magazine in Chicago, would find those pictures more accurate.
In "On the Edge," Mr. Nightingale argues that the drastic increase in urban crime is not evidence of a widening gulf between city and suburb. Rather, he says, the enthusiasm of poor black children both for conspicuous consumption and for violence suggests that inner-city residents aspire to embrace all the trappings of mainstream America, even the link many white people in this country make between race and violence.
Gun sales in the United States increased more than 20 percent from 1990 to 1992 alone, a startling measure of fear in a country that prefers not to acknowledge its own acceptance of violence. Poor African-American children see that attitude and celebrate it. "I know y'all don't like violence," said a teen-age girl in the Philadelphia neighborhood where Mr. Nightingale lived from 1987 to the early 90's, working on a study of African-American children growing up there in the 1950's and 1960's. "But I like my movies violent," she told him. "Movies that don't got violence is corny to me."
Mr. Nightingale's research has produced a fine book about American children in the second half of the 20th century; it is a story of history, of horror and of hope. Explaining that he found himself learning more about the lives of African-American children in Philadelphia 40 years ago by paying attention to the voices of the contemporary children he was befriending in his urban neighborhood, Mr. Nightingale offers a vivid portrait of a poor community. "On the Edge" weaves together social service agency case reports on children who grew up in Philadelphia immediately after World War II, recent urban history and the story of the Kids' Club, a volunteer neighborhood organization formed in the late 1980's to find alternatives to violence by helping a group of children with schoolwork, recreation and employment. The book tells a depressing story of failed leadership potential: Chauntey Patterson, one of the most intelligent and attractive children Mr. Nightingale first met in 1987, became a drug dealer and later went to jail, "largely because of the grinding memories and the delusions of psychic relief that his American upbringing has offered to him and his generation."
The children in "On the Edge" love television, action-adventure movies, popcorn, basketball, boxing, football, Mickey Mouse T-shirts, Coca-Cola, McDonald's, fancy cars, the Army and the Marines. "During the cold war they hated Russians; and during the gulf war many of them wore a red, white and blue T-shirt with 'Support Operation Desert Storm' on it," Mr. Nightingale reports. At the same time, he says, they continue to grow up with "the nagging feeling that blackness is something to be ashamed of." To compensate for the hurt of growing up poor, jobless and outcast, they have sought these essentially American dreams and made them their own. "On the Edge" describes in painful detail the ways that poor black children both suffer and embrace the effects of racism, deprivation and violence.
In "Hardball," Mr. Coyle's daily chronicle of the 1992 Little League season in Cabrini-Green, the Chicago housing project where the death of a 7-year-old boy by sniper fire caught national attention during the Presidential campaign of that year, children and adults struggle with the same visions. Can you pull dozens of African-American children from one of the country's worst housing projects, put them on a baseball field with a bunch of white suburban businessmen as coaches, have them play a difficult and demanding sport, and expect it to come off? As Mr. Coyle's affecting narrative shows, fielding a grounder in Carson Field, the sports complex at Division and Sedgwick where the First Chicago Near North Kikuyus practice and play the great American game, may be tough, but no tougher than dodging bullets, avoiding gangs and coping with the devastating effects of poverty.
The efforts of countless social workers and community leaders notwithstanding, there is no evidence that recreation programs will help the boys of the Near North Kikuyus learn the ways that the middle class claim as values: be responsible, play fair, show up on time. Indeed, showing up at all was an accomplishment for some of the Kikuyus. The team roster listed 16 players, but some days the tardy appearance of the ninth boy was a welcome relief; the coaches had feared they might have to forfeit a game. Most Little Leaguers have some measure of comfort, a space that allows them time to play. "Hardball" shows that baseball is a poor substitute for what is missing in Cabrini-Green: safety, education, jobs and money.
In Mr. Nightingale's view, the ultimate test of America's political and economic arrangements may be our willingness to raise the children of inner cities in "more healthy, more cherishing, more optimistic ways." He finds hope in two goals: the creation of employment for inner-city residents and the construction of "a national culture of commitment and community that is emotionally expressive, ethnically diverse and compelling to children." Many of the coaches in Daniel Coyle's book make an effort to do the latter, with mixed results. At best, as one child reports, "It ain't really so bad, living here. In summertime, we play baseball."
Both books demand that we pay attention to these children and their very American dreams. Both books make compelling reading.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
'Home,' Uplifting Tale Of Young Black Farmer

BYLINE: By LEAH D. FRANK

 BODY:
THEATER Three in Port Jefferson is one of the few theaters on Long Island to make an effort to produce drama by black playwrights on a regular basis.
In honor of Black History Month, the Second Stage is presenting through Feb. 9 Samm-Art Williams's uplifting drama "Home." It is the story of a young black farmer who finds himself torn from his land and thrust into the turmoil of the Vietnam War and American urban decay. 
 The play, which on first description might sound anything but uplifting, is in fact a valentine to the indomitable soul of so many black men and women who have fought and triumphed over personal tragedies, racial barriers, political movements, economic upheaval and social and cultural discrimination.
The hero of "Home" is Cephus Miles, a black man growing up in rural South Carolina. His mentors are his grandfather and uncle, who instill in him a deep respect for the land, for nature and for God.
Cephus might on occasion use his Sunday school money for a bit of gambling, but he has a love of God and nature that is humbling in its purity. Yet like all good men in literature, Cephus, like Job for instance, must be put to a test to see if his faith and goodness are true and unyielding.
When his uncle is killed in an accident that also claims their horse, Cephus begins to believe God is vacationing in Miami. Then his grandfather dies working in the field and his beloved girlfriend, Pattie Mae, goes away to a teachers' college and winds up marrying a lawyer.
What finally does Cephus in, however, and convinces him that God has indeed taken time off from caring for his flock is the war in Vietnam. When he is drafted, Cephus simply states his conviction that "Thou Shalt Not Kill" is a commandment from God that must be taken seriously. He quickly discovers that that particular commandment is suspended in wartime.
The rest of the story is about Cephus's fall and redemption, and its ending is so stirring that it can evoke copious tears of the sort that one shares at weddings and other joyful occasions.
This three-member cast has been artfully directed by Bill Van Horn, who wisely allows the material to unfold without adding the kind of melodramatic fireworks that might be expected from a less talented director. Mr. Van Horn has also cast "Home" with care.
The struggling Cephus is played by Kenshaka Ali, a large man with a Charles Barkley haircut, who manages to create a character with pride and dignity without the added burden of militant fervor.
Although it would have been nice to have a greater sense of Cephus's emotional change and development, Mr. Ali presents us with such a kind, gentle farmer that it is difficult to wish for anything more.
Tessa Martin is riveting in a variety of roles, ranging from the flirtatious Pattie Mae to a number of other women and children in Cephus's life. Ms. Martin gives a fresh, original performance and is remarkable for the smooth and effective manner in which she brings each character to life.
The third member of the cast is Andrea Fletcher, who plays a number of minor characters. The play has several song segments, and Ms. Fletcher and Ms. Martin have clear, strong musical voices whether singing or speaking.
Proving that ingenuity and talent can overcome the challenge of a tiny space and a limited budget, Ned Fox, the set designer, and Marvin Lune, who designed the lighting, have created a world that ranges from Cross Roads, N.C., to an unnamed megalopolis, with a couple of stops in between.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 689 words

HEADLINE: Viewpoints: 10 Years After Bell's Breakup;
The Split-Up Worked. No, It Didn't.

BYLINE: By ELI M. NOAM; Eli M. Noam is a professor of finance and economics at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business and the director of its Institute for Tele-Information.

 BODY:
WHEN the old Bell System came to an end a decade ago, there was instant nostalgia for a lost golden age and great anxiety about the future. Many dire predictions were made about the breakup's effect on affordable rates, service quality and technological progress.
The reality has been much more benign. The percentage of households with telephones has increased, from 91.4 percent in 1983 to 94.2 percent in 1993, according to the Federal Communications Commission. For the poorest fifth of the population, this rose from 80.1 percent to 83.7 percent. Average telephone rates did not double or triple, but grew at only half the rate of inflation. Industry research and development increased, too, as did productivity, although at the expense of some employment. The market for telecommunications equipment became competitive, with prices that are now among the lowest worldwide. Nor were the very poor damaged by divestiture; a cheap "lifeline" service was introduced. 
 True, technological advances were in part responsible for these many successes. But the Bell breakup deserves credit, too. Without question, today's communications sector is more dynamic and innovative than it was under the stately, tightly regulated A.T.& T. monopoly.
And it was precisely that promise of greater dynamism and innovation that was the driving force behind the divestiture. Why? Because as technology advanced and the service economy grew, large corporations and other organizations realized that the electronic transmission of information was of ever-increasing importance -- and expense. But the American Telephone & Telegraph Company was too slow, too dominant and too tightly regulated to meet these growing needs.
As a result, MCI Communications and other new carriers emerged. The Government gradually let these companies compete with A.T.& T. but, understandably, the monopoly resisted at each step. Soon, it became clear that the tiny new carriers could not compete with an 800-pound gorilla whose cooperation -- and phone lines -- they needed to do business. The result was the A.T.& T. divestiture.
It was the correct move. The monopolistic A.T.& T. was like I.B.M. at the dawn of the minicomputer age -- too dominant and too powerful to respond to the explosion of new electronic technology and applications. With one big difference: as a regulated monopoly that controlled the telephone lines, A.T.& T. could keep competitors out of telecommunications much more effectively than I.B.M. could keep them out of computers.
Also, despite A.T.& T.'s large size and impressive past, it is clear that no single company can tend the information infrastructure of a large high-tech economy, and do it well, across all hardware, software and services. Some economies of scale may have been lost by the divestiture, but this loss was more than offset by gains in innovation and customer responsiveness.
Today, policy makers face a different challenge: fitting the multiplying pieces of the telecommunications puzzle together. Their many tasks include establishing technical and legal inter-connectivity, assuring local phone competition, designing pricing policies that equitably distribute among carriers the cost of affordable rates, protecting privacy and encouraging the spread of new applications of telecommunications technology to aid economic growth.
For its part, industry is responding to these issues by reshaping itself at a dizzying pace through mergers and other reorganizations.
And how is the Clinton Administration responding? Earlier this month, after a year of high-sounding generalities from Washington, Vice President Al Gore added some specifics. In a forward-looking speech in Los Angeles that endorsed some pending Congressional efforts, he committed the Administration to local telephone and cable competition nationwide. The traditional companies, in return for new freedoms, must cooperate with the new competitors, offering them inter-connection and open access.
But if the established companies suppress competition, the future will bring calls for strict regulation and, yes, Divestiture II.

HEADLINE: Viewpoints: 10 Years After Bell's Breakup;
The Split-Up Worked. No, It Didn't.

The result was the A.T.& T. divestiture.
It was the correct move. The monopolistic A.T.& T. was like I.B.M. at the dawn of the minicomputer age -- too dominant and too powerful to respond to the explosion of new electronic technology and applications. With one big difference: as a regulated monopoly that controlled the telephone lines, A.T.& T. could keep competitors out of telecommunications much more effectively than I.B.M. could keep them out of computers.
Also, despite A.T.& T.'s large size and impressive past, it is clear that no single company can tend the information infrastructure of a large high-tech economy, and do it well, across all hardware, software and services. Some economies of scale may have been lost by the divestiture, but this loss was more than offset by gains in innovation and customer responsiveness.
Today, policy makers face a different challenge: fitting the multiplying pieces of the telecommunications puzzle together. Their many tasks include establishing technical and legal inter-connectivity, assuring local phone competition, designing pricing policies that equitably distribute among carriers the cost of affordable rates, protecting privacy and encouraging the spread of new applications of telecommunications technology to aid economic growth.
For its part, industry is responding to these issues by reshaping itself at a dizzying pace through mergers and other reorganizations.
And how is the Clinton Administration responding? Earlier this month, after a year of high-sounding generalities from Washington, Vice President Al Gore added some specifics. In a forward-looking speech in Los Angeles that endorsed some pending Congressional efforts, he committed the Administration to local telephone and cable competition nationwide. The traditional companies, in return for new freedoms, must cooperate with the new competitors, offering them inter-connection and open access.
But if the established companies suppress competition, the future will bring calls for strict regulation and, yes, Divestiture II.

HEADLINE: Magnificent Obsession

BYLINE: By Nick Salvatore; Nick Salvatore is the author of "Eugene V. Debs: Citizen and Socialist" and the forthcoming "Amos Webber's World: The Making of a Nineteenth-Century African American."

 BODY:

RED HUNTING
IN THE PROMISED LAND
Anticommunism and the Making of America.
By Joel Kovel.
331 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $25. 
COLLECTIVE biography is a complex genre. An author must sketch portraits of individuals that remain credible against a broader biographical canvas, yet make them pointed enough to connect each with the common motif of the larger work. Joel Kovel, the Alger Hiss Professor of Social Studies at Bard College, has chosen this approach for his study of anti-Communism in American life, "Red Hunting in the Promised Land." His subjects range from Charles Coughlin, the "radio priest" of the 1930's, to the diplomat George F. Kennan, and include J. Edgar Hoover, John Foster Dulles, James Jesus Angleton and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. One chapter, entitled "Liberal and Born-Again Anticommunism," offers slivered perspectives of Hubert H. Humphrey, Walter Reuther and Arthur Koestler.
For Mr. Kovel, the theme that ties these men together is their common obsession with an anti-Communism that "has lodged itself so deeply in the American psyche that it need not depend on the existence of Communism." In his view, each also contributed to the development of a political climate that stifled dissent, repressed labor's militancy and created "the phenomenon of the national security state," which transformed anti-Communism "into the freestanding demonology of a state religion." But, the author insists, anti-Communism is not at root about Communism at all. "It is, rather, a way of being American that proceeds from a deep historical wound." In short, "Red Hunting in the Promised Land" contains two tousled themes: a collective biography of anti-Communism interwoven with a meditation on the American character from Puritan New England to the 1990's. Neither is satisfactorily developed.

AS a biographical portrait, the book is a montage of stick figures that stand in for more complex people, and it lacks credibility. "The men are chosen," the author writes, "insofar as it is through them that the black hole of anti-Communism speaks, and their portraits are foreshortened accordingly to achieve the desired goal." Not surprisingly, then, Mr. Kovel's research is highly selective, reflecting largely secondary sources that support his views.
By design, no discussion of actual Soviet-American tensions in the post-1945 period is allowed. The result is a historical study in which a faddish, heated rhetoric stands for serious commentary. "It is speculative but not too farfetched to suggest," Mr. Kovel writes in his discussion of the effect of J. Edgar's Hoover's psychosexual politics, "that the orgasm of erotic release and the mushroom cloud of atomic explosion were subjectively associated."
Driving the country's pervasive anti-Communism, Mr. Kovel believes, was the need of the national security state to overcome traditional American resistance to centralized government -- a government dedicated to protecting the "naked economic interest beneath [America's] Puritan ideals." This need demanded, he argues, an "American inquisition," one that was not "too dissimilar" to Stalin's show trials and the gulag itself. To overemphasize "distinctions in culture, technology, timing or context," the author maintains, is to "miss the essential points of comparison." The moral and intellectual relativism evident here makes other arguments in the book appear learned in comparison.
Special pleading also influences the author's meditation on American life. Briefly put, Mr. Kovel states that "susceptibility to the black hole became fixed in the national experience and formed the matrix for anti-Communism" as early as the Puritans' rejection of the state of nature he maintains they found among indigenous people. Since anti-Communism in this interpretation has no concrete historical or political context, its only meaning is as a mirror on the American psyche, which is itself driven by a perverse attraction "to the notion of communism or to specific Communist movements." In this tortured logic, the Puritans' refusal to adopt Native American culture (or, more accurately, the author's hopelessly Edenic image of it) in favor of pursuing their "naked economic interest" resulted in the original "red scare," which was aimed at the Indian, "the primal communist of American history."

MR. KOVEL'S obsession with Puritanism, with "the remorseless Calvinist conscience which haunts the national soul," is tendentious. Nowhere in the volume is there recognition of how the moral vision embedded in that conscience propelled civic good. One need only recall 19th-century abolitionism or agitation for women's rights, to say nothing of the more recent civil rights movement, to question Mr. Kovel's assertions. Nor is his obsession original. D. H. Lawrence's "Studies in Classic American Literature" projected similar themes in 1923; two generations later, Charles Reich's "Greening of America," with all of its exuberant irrelevance, covered the ground again. If, as Karl Marx suggested, history is first tragedy and then repeats itself as farce, this third cycle is simply banality.
Anti-Communism, the actual historical event, wreaked havoc with the lives of many Americans caught in its vicious currents. But social criticism that would condemn the very essence of the American experience in a twisted torrent of pop psychology and vitriolic anger leaves little foundation for the "revitalization of an emancipatory vision" Mr. Kovel argues we need. To work toward that goal requires a criticism grounded in this country's complex history, one that also possesses the subtlety to recognize that the critical impulse itself emanates from America's moral and political traditions.

LENGTH: 1528 words

HEADLINE: New York Hospitals Fear Harm In Plan to Reduce Specialization

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
For months, deans and doctors from New York's medical schools and hospitals have been making office visits to Ira C. Magaziner, President Clinton's top health care adviser, to take his temperature on the hottest topic in their lives. On a recent flight to New York, a member of the city's Congressional delegation plied Hillary Rodham Clinton with news clippings on the same subject.
The issue causing such concern is medical education, and the Clinton Administration's proposals for changing it. New York's huge research and teaching hospitals are particularly worried that the Administration's proposals would cut the number of residency positions for medical school graduates nationwide and limit the number of specialists.
 
Cutting 3,800 Residencies?
 The New York hospitals say they share the Administration's goal: to lower overall costs and train more of the nation's doctors in basic care. But because about 15 percent of the country's medical residents are now trained in New York State, the hospitals say any changes could affect New York disproportionately. They also say their expertise in specialized medicine is a major drawing card in attracting doctors and making research breakthroughs. 
 What is more, the residents at these hospitals provide a relatively cheap pool of skilled, round-the-clock labor, heavily subsidized by the Government. That is important in a city in which poor people go to emergency rooms in search of basic care, and in which public and private hospitals alike depend on their affiliation contracts with the teaching hospitals.
By 2007, the Clinton plan could reduce the number of residencies in the state by 3,800, nearly all of them in New York City, from 14,000 now, according to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's task force on the issue. That could cost the state's teaching hospitals $750 million a year from the more than $2.5 billion they now receive for medical education, the task force estimates.
Many of the city's premier hospitals worry that a reduction in the number of residents, or specialists, could fundamentally alter the quality of their programs. Moreover, city and state officials worry that reducing the city's role as a medical research center could harm economic development in one of the few fields in which employment has grown markedly in recent years.
"It's almost not comparable to any other city," said James R. Tallon Jr., former majority leader of the State Assembly and now president of the United Hospital Fund, a research and charitable group. "Maybe the only other place where you'd get a similar concentration of such institutions is Boston. We in New York would argue that the way in which you build a future system, quite apart from health care reform, has an economic development impact on the city, and this is a New York chit that needs to receive attention in the debate."
Last week, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan went to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to hear medical deans from around the country and said he had left "shaken," while Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato called the potential effects "a horror."
The fears about residency programs are just one of many complex concerns about the effects of the President's health care proposals on New York. The concerns range from reductions in the Medicare and Medicaid subsidies -- payments that support basic care, training and research -- to proposed health insurance alliances along state lines.
New York institutions are concerned that the alliances could make it more difficult for suburban patients to seek treatment at one of the city's seven academic health centers or major private hospitals, like Sloan-Kettering, which draws more patients from northern New Jersey than from Manhattan.
 
'A Real Problem'
 Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said, "New York becomes a real problem for the administration in many respects, because it doesn't quite fit the national profile."
Senator Moynihan, chairman of the Finance Committee, through which the health care legislation must pass, has made no secret of his qualms about many aspects of the Clinton proposals, and insists that he intends to protect New York's interests.
"Something there is in this plan that doesn't like a university health center," Mr. Moynihan said in an interview. "It's thought somehow to be elitist. Sloan-Kettering isn't Acapulco. We're all bodies to them, and they're trying to find out what cancers are."
Asked how the White House had responded to such concerns, Mr. Moynihan said: "The uniform answer of Mr. Magaziner is, 'We can fix that.' Well, if you can fix it, why did you do it in the first place?"
 
An Early Alarm
 As with most such debates, sorting out the hospitals' worst fears from what is likely to happen is difficult, and the hospitals are raising an alarm now to try to protect their turf. The administration argues that it would build flexibility into the plan, providing compensating payments for hospitals that lose residency positions and insuring that patients who needed access to specialized care could get it, and that providing insurance for poor patients who do not now have it would compensate for cuts in other programs like Medicare.
Dr. Philip R. Lee, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services, who did some of his medical training at Bellevue Hospital, said protecting the nation's premier medical centers was an important goal of the Clinton plan. He said the plan would assign resident slots based not only on the quality of programs, but also on historic patterns, both of which would help shield New York from losses. He also said the program would be phased in gradually enough so that the average hospital would probably lose only a handful of residents a year.
"The issue is certainly going to be debated, and people like Senator Moynihan are going to ask tough questions," Dr. Lee said. "There are some valid concerns."
A sticking point is the hospitals' assumption that the number of resident slots would be curtailed. A proposal by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia calls explicitly for eventually capping the number of entering resident positions nationwide at 10 percent above the number of the country's medical graduates, though Dr. Lee said the Clinton plan had no concrete limit. Now the annual number of first-year residents is about 30 percent above the number of domestic medical school graduates, with the difference accounted for by foreign students, many of whom are trained in New York.
That shift alone would markedly cut the number of residents in New York, the teaching hospitals say, but they also fear that the Government would seek to redistribute residencies around the country more evenly. That might be a desirable national goal but would diminish a major New York industry.
"One of the ironies of the system is that the residents represent cheap labor, and if we have to replace them with clinician-nurses, you're talking about doubling the cost of each position," said Dr. Paul A. Marks, president of Sloan-Kettering. "It's a fact of the health care industry in this city that it's a large, well-trained labor force that's relatively low paid, in exchange for the privilege of being educated in these world-class institutions."
Jim O'Donnell, the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation's representative in Washington, said it strongly supported the Clinton plan's goal of universal health insurance coverage and better access to care.
"We very much support the concept of moving to more primary care and fewer specialties," he said. "However, we are very dependent on those specialists to staff our facilities through affiliation agreements with the teaching hospitals. If the teaching hospitals lost residents, they would hold on to the specialists, and we'd be left with a severe shortage."
 
A Threat to Research
 Dr. Herbert Pardes, the dean of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, which through its affiliation agreements with Presbyterian, St. Luke's-Roosevelt and Harlem Hospitals, helps care for thousands of indigent patients, said the medical centers worry that the new pools of money established to finance graduate medical education would not be adequate to provide care through the residents or to allow the universities to subsidize clinical research.
"If you ratchet the system down very tightly in an effort to cut costs, we have a problem," he said.
Dr. Robert Michels, dean of the Cornell University Medical College, which is linked to a group of hospitals on the East Side of Manhattan, said the debate reflects the jerry-built nature of the present health care and medical education system, and the complex financial and service links between them.
"We currently have an irrational system, which functions and which does support some great institutions," he said. "No one is against fixing it. But we're terrified that fixing it without making sure that we maintain those institutions and their valuable projects would be very destructive. Just simply doing away with the irrationality is not enough."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Tokyo Stocks Plunge After Reform Loss

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Fears that the political turmoil that struck on Friday could delay Japanese Government efforts to revive the recession-bound economy sent stock prices into a tailspin here today.
Trading was largely one-way -- in sell orders -- but calm, analysts said. The Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks plunged 954.19 points, or 4.94 percent, to close at 18,353.24. That is still up sharply from a month ago, when the Nikkei was trading at close to 17,000. 
 "The feeling is that the market is going to go much lower," said Robert Sasaki, a trader at Jardine Fleming Securities here. "The political worries are very strong."
 
Imbalances Prevent Trading
 The selling was so strong that for the first 30 minutes of trading only a tiny handful of the 225 issues that make up the Nikkei could even open.
The Nikkei futures contract for March maturity, the most actively traded of the contracts, also could not start trading because of the imbalance of sell orders.
The plunge in prices was largely expected, after Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa lost a crucial vote on electoral reform bills in the upper house of Parliament on Friday. The vote occurred after the Tokyo market had closed. Later that day in London and New York, the prices of Japanese securities fell sharply in reaction to the defeat for the coalition Government.
But the market plunge accentuated sharp differences in opinion between Japanese and foreign investors over the prospects for the Tokyo market, which for four years has struggled against a tide of negative economic news.
For weeks now, the market has been rising, largely on heavy buying from overseas. Foreign analysts have predicted that sooner or later, the Japanese Government would introduce a strong program of public works spending and tax cuts to jump-start the economy. The economy shrunk slightly last year and is expected to show little growth this year, economists say.
In addition, some of the foreign mutual fund money that had flowed to Southeast Asian stock markets -- notably Hong Kong, Thailand and Malaysia -- is now flowing into Tokyo as the emerging Asian markets experienced corrections.
 
Skeptics on Government Help
 By contrast, Japanese have been and remain pessimistic. Japanese investors, particularly large institutions, have been far less hopeful that the Government will assemble a credible stimulus package or that even if it does, it will work, given that Governments have already tried three times in the last two years with no success.
"There might be some naivete on the part of the foreigners," said Kathy Matsui, a market strategist here with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities. "But at this point I would say politically things could go very well, if we're lucky, or they could go very wrong. I would sit tight for awhile longer."
Tim Hayashida, an analyst here with Merrill Lynch Japan, said he remained cautiously optimistic, adding that foreigners were prepared to start buying if the market fell much further.
"Any delay in putting together a stimulus package is negative, but we don't think the process will stop completely," Mr. Hayashida said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
For companies from cruise lines to hotels, computer technology holds the promise of increasing their profits by allowing them to price their products much more efficiently than they ever could with just paper and pencil. The idea is to raise prices when demand is highest, and set prices low enough to draw customers when demand is slack. However, marketing experts warn that consumers may be irked by the change. [Page A1.] 
 The National Security Agency is trying to establish a standard for electronically scrambling computer communications, a move that would go far beyond the agency's usual military and intelligence domain to include civilian activities like electronic tax returns and computerized medical payments. The plan by the N.S.A., which may be announced as early as today, worries business executives and privacy advocates. Some Clinton Administration officials think the agency is overstepping its statutory bounds. [D1.]
A growing number of Federal regulators, as well as Congress and the White House, are concerned over the sales of depositor-owned mutual savings and loans in which top executives profit handsomely. New limits on such deals seem likely. [D1.]
Competition in the hotel business has roughed up even the high-styled hotels of Four Seasons. While on the surface the company's financial statements seem to portray an enterprise that's solidly in the black, a closer look suggests that accounting loopholes are being stretched to the breaking point. And the market is beginning to wonder; Four Seasons Hotel shares have dropped 35 percent. [D1.]
A former Macy executive may be named to replace Chaim Y. Edelstein, as head of Federated Department Stores' A.& S.-Jordan Marsh division. Mr. Edelstein resigned last week. [D2.]
Pacific Bell has agreed to buy four powerful computers from Hewlett-Packard to be used to deliver digital movies to thousands of homes in California. [D9.]
Wal-Mart has been welcomed with open arms across the Northeast by the unemployed and others who have jobs but see the chain as a springboard to an improved life. [B1.]
 
International
Japanese stocks plunged this morning as investors feared that political turmoil would delay efforts to revive the economy. The Nikkei 225-stock index lost nearly 5 percent on the first day of trading after the Government's defeat on campaign reform. [D1.]
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen warned Japan's leaders that if they did not begin making some concessions in trade talks, the United States would consider other measures for dealing with the huge trade imbalance between the two countries. [A3.]
The United States, in a pact with Japan, has agreed to change its patent law to prevent patent holders from seeking royalties long after they first made their inventions. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
In its first public discussion of plans for Macmillan, Paramount Publishing said it would reorganize divisions, reduce the number of imprints and published titles and lay off up to 10 percent of the two companies' combined work force of 10,000. [D8.]
Will the quake cause networks to think twice about new investments in Los Angeles? Bill Carter: Television. [D8.]
Time Inc. is looking into the possibility of starting a publication aimed at gay and lesbian readers. [D8.]
Wine Enthusiast is mounting a challenge to Wine Spectator, the nation's biggest periodical for wine consumers. [D8.]
Airlines are competing to woo passengers with some pretty offbeat promotions. Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Islamic Guerrillas in Algeria Gain Against Military Rulers

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALGIERS, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The armed Islamic insurgency that has been fighting for two years is swiftly gaining ground against a military-backed Government whose authority seems to be deteriorating daily.
Many of the army generals who rule the country, along with their supporters, have retreated to tightly guarded seaside compounds outside Algiers, frequently using helicopters to travel to and from offices and meetings. 
 Thousands of foreign workers and diplomats, 26 of whom have been shot dead in the last four months, have fled Algeria. Police officers and troops withdraw at dusk from many villages and slums where the militants enjoy wide support, and the nightly curfew is punctuated with the sound of gunfire.
Hundreds, perhaps as many as 8,000 young men, have deserted from the army this year, diplomats say. And many have taken their weapons with them to the mountainous interior where Islamic militants are forming a formidable guerrilla army. Responding to the killing of Algerian officials and members of the security forces, paramilitary death squads have in recent months killed dozens of suspected militants, say Western diplomats and human rights officials. [Page A6.]
Foreign embassies, including the American Embassy, have reduced their staffs, warned their citizens to leave and relocated remaining diplomats to secure compounds. One Western embassy requires bulletproof vests for its diplomats, who like all foreigners in Algeria have been threatened with death by the militants if a deadline of Nov. 30 for leaving was not met.
"The biggest risk now is a convergence of the social and political problems," a European diplomat said. "If there is unrest on the streets because of the growing food shortages the troops may not want to shoot. At that point things would unravel. I could then see an alliance between junior officers and Islamic leaders that would lead to an Islamic state."
Algeria, a former French colony that had been governed by National Liberation Front since independence in 1962, felt the political power of Muslim militancy in 1991 when the Islamic Salvation Front soundly defeated the governing party in the first round of Parliamentary elections. Rather than allow the Islamic party to form a government, the military removed President Chadli Benjedid in January 1992 and canceled elections that would have given the Islamic Front control of Parliament.
The generals later named a five-man committee to rule the country. Although a national conference to choose a new president is scheduled this month, it is widely seen as window-dressing for continued military rule.
 
Fear of Exodus to France
 The creation of an Islamic state in Algeria could force 500,000 Algerians to flee to France, European diplomats said. With Islamic fundamentalists in control in the Sudan and with Egypt facing a violent campaign by militants, a Muslim takeover could further destabilize neighboring North African nations like Tunisia and Morocco.
Islamic groups, after being outlawed in 1992, began an armed insurrection, ambushing police and Government officials. In the last two years, the campaign has killed 2,000 people, including many intellectuals and writers who opposed the Islamic movement. But Islamic leaders say they have lost control of the insurrection as new groups, like the Islamic Armed Movement and the Armed Islamic Group, have emerged to supplant the traditional leadership of the Islamic Front.
"The best organization is no organization," the senior leader said. "You now get five or six kids with a few guns who want to help the revolution. Even we don't often know who they are."
 
Dialogue With Rebels
 The only tactic that might salvage some form of the widely unpopular military-run Government is a dialogue between the generals and the outlawed Islamic Salvation Front, say many critics of the Government. But with the generals and the militants showing little willingness to compromise, the two sides appear locked in a deadly contest that is plunging the country of 26 million into anarchy.
Islamic militants, who often own the streets after dusk, have already carved out small enclaves. In the militant stronghold of Blida, 30 miles south of Algiers, the militants run whole neighborhoods and battle the police.
After burning down establishments that sell alcohol and assassinating at least one bar owner, militants have dried up Blida, a city of 400,000 people. Beauty parlors, anathema to the fundamentalists, have been ransacked. Most of the women on the street are veiled. Several have closed and the two that remain now operate behind locked doors. Stores that sell music cassettes no longer carry recordings by Western groups or female singers. Satellite dishes, which bring in foreign broadcasts, have been dismantled. And kiosks and shops stopped selling newspapers a week ago.
Fear drives most Algerians home before dark, where they sit trapped in tiny, overcrowded apartments watching the censored Government-run television network or French channels.
"We voted for the Islamists and we abide by what they demand,"Mohammed Abdel Majid, a 35-year-old unemployed librarian said, alluding the elections that were canceled. "The Government closed down the Islamic newspapers two years ago. If we can't get the Islamic papers, why should we get the Government papers?"
In the muddy streets of the Kouba slum in Algiers, where the police and Islamic militants open fire on one another almost daily, the reach of the militants is widening. A dozen police officers, armed with automatic weapons and wearing bulletproof vests, nervously man a roadblock on the outskirts of Kouba. They scan embankments and check identification cards. But by nightfall this roadblock, and another down the street, is abandoned.
A few blocks away, in a small house, a senior leader of the Islamic Salvation Front and several lieutenants sat over cups of tea and a plate of chocolate cookies. All are in hiding and sleep at a different place each night.
 
'The Chiefs' Must Go
 "We have many supporters in the lower ranks of both the army and the police, but the chiefs, the ones who govern, must go." the senior leader said
In a country where oil and gas account for more than 90 percent of exports, the violence has also fueled an economic decline already driven by a mismanaged Government-controlled economy and falling oil prices. Foreign investors, with the exception of a few oil companies, are pulling out despite substantial losses.
"We have several hundred thousand dollars committed to a new pharmaceutical plant we were scheduled to build," a European businessman said, "but we just don't want to be here any more. We will have to write the Algerian operation off. It's time to leave."
The bleakness is mirrored in the gray, overcast skies that linger over this hilly, Mediterranean port city. Burdened by prices that have tripled in the last year, many people are forced to stand in lines outside shops for much of the day to buy what little there is of bread, flour, cooking oil and meat.
 
'There Will Be Chaos'
 "If the food shortages and bread lines continue to grow, people will take to the streets," said Ali Rachedi, the director of the newspaper El Haq.
The Government, negotiating a refinancing of payments on a $26 billion debt with the International Monetary Fund, is set to impose new austerity measures. But diplomats say the Government lacks the legitimacy to demand further sacrifices.
In the Government effort against the militants, there are signs that violence is spinning out of control on both sides as the daily death toll includes about a dozen members of the police and security forces and at least as many civilians, Western diplomats say.
On the afternoon of Jan. 14, troops and armored personnel carriers sealed off the town of Larba, the scene of frequent firefights with the guerrillas 30 miles southeast of Algiers.
On the morning of Jan. 15, the soldiers dragged five men from their homes and killed them in front of the town hall, witnesses said. At 3:30 that afternoon, while many townspeople were forming bread lines, the soldiers opened fire on the crowd.
"Four people were killed," said a 47-year-old airline employee, who was wounded along with a 60-year-old woman, Najat Naouhook and her 2-year-old granddaughter, Hayat.
Doctors at the hospital confirmed the account, and one surgeon added: "When bodies come in, they are often not only riddled with bullets but they have been run over by tanks or armored personnel carriers. They don't even resemble human beings."
