HEADLINE: Computers as Price Setters Complicate Travelers' Lives

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
For savvy consumers who pride themselves on knowing where the best buys are and how much to pay for them, life is becoming a great deal more complicated.
The same thinking that created airline fares that seem to change dizzily from one day to the next is spreading. Now other businesses from cruise lines to hotels are taking a page from the airlines' playbook and using powerful computer technology to set prices continually based on the up-to-the-minute demand for their products. 
 This digital upgrade of the law of supply and demand means that the cost of renting a truck from Ryder System Inc. could rise and fall by more than $200, or the price of a cruise on Royal Caribbean could change by $1,000 on the same ship for the same type of cabin. People who stay at Sheraton hotels can save from 5 to 30 percent on the cost of a room by booking 14 days in advance.
 
 
Promise of Profits
 For these companies and others, computer software holds the promise of increasing their profits by allowing them to price their products much more efficiently than they ever could with paper and pencil. The idea is to raise prices when demand is highest and set prices low enough to draw customers when demand is slack.
 But what companies may gain on the one hand they may lose on the other. "I don't like it at all," said Carol Christian of Katonah, N.Y., who flies frequently on her job as a training consultant. "It causes consumers a lot of unnecessary stress because you always have the sense that you didn't get the best deal, and it puts an awfully big burden on you to get the right information."
Al Ries, a marketing expert in Greenwich, Conn., said that whenever companies offered more than one price, customers typically assumed that everything above the lowest price was intended to gouge them. "You undermine your good will," Mr. Ries said.
That sense of unease is why Ms. Christian's mother often calls airlines back after receiving a fare quote. She has learned that the second call sometimes gets her a lower fare for the same flight. It is also one reason Ms. Christian bought a car three years ago from Saturn, a company whose dealers do not haggle. "I knew that everyone else was going to pay the same price," she said.
Airline executives reluctantly concede that many customers resent their pricing system, where a round-trip ticket from New York to Los Angeles can cost anywhere from $400 to $1,400, and acknowledge that legions of travelers scour the airlines' reservation systems for loopholes with a fervor they typically reserve for tax time.
Some companies that are buying the airlines' pricing technology have tried to avoid the carriers' mistakes by, among other things, limiting the size of price swings. "Fortunately, I think the airlines bore the brunt of having to re-educate consumers," said Andy Anderson, director of operations and support services for Ryder's consumer truck rental division.
Even so, putting the technology into practice still appears to present something of a public relations minefield.
When France's railroad system started using computers last year to set prices by demand rather than by distance, the complexity of the new fare structure and the additional time required to issue tickets prompted complaints from travelers and travel agents.
Elsewhere, however, AMR, the parent of American Airlines, which helped the French railroad, seems to be having better luck introducing the technology. The airline company helped pioneer the technology with its computer network, which it says is the world's largest privately owned system operating on a real-time basis, meaning that it is continually transmitting and processing data like flight bookings.
Its subsidiary, American Airlines Decision Technologies, has about 110 clients, with roughly 35 signed up since 1988 for help in managing capacity and prices. They include travel and tourism companies like Hilton Hotels, Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines, Avis and Amtrak. AMR has even had some discussions with theater and concert ticket sellers about the technology.
American competes with a number of other companies in this emerging field, which is estimated to generate $50 million a year over all in revenues. They include Behavheuristics Inc. of College Park, Md.; Arthur D. Little of Cambridge, Mass.; Andersen Consulting, based in New York, and Decision Focus Inc. in Mountain View, Calif.
Businesses that are potential customers for the technology typically have "perishable capacity," said Thomas M. Cook, president of American Airlines Decision Technologies.
When an airline seat or a hotel room or truck goes unrented, it represents a wasted opportunity to earn at least some revenue. And in businesses like airlines and hotels, the cost of serving every extra passenger or guest is minimal. So once costs are met, most of the money from additional customers flows directly to the bottom line.
Companies that use this technology typically accumulate historical sales data to predict demand and the likely number of no-shows and cancellations, all the while tinkering to set the most profitable combination of fares based on demand and, of course, competitors' prices.
 
Bargains, With Restrictions
 At the airlines, this results in low prices with plenty of restrictions, like a requirement that passengers stay over on Saturday night, to attract discretionary travelers and fill seats that would otherwise go empty. Business travelers, who often cannot take advantage of the lower fares because of the restrictions, pay more when they book at the last minute before a midweek flight.
At the Ryder truck rental company, which replaced five full-time pricers with the computer technology in 1992, the differences in prices are not so striking.
For example, the spread from its lowest to its highest rate is no more than 20 percent. The company limited the spread partly because it wanted to avoid the pitfalls of a wider range encountered by the airlines. But it also kept it narrow because, in the truck rental business, a price difference of just a few percentage points is often enough to swing demand.
So customers moving from New York to Los Angeles and leaving on a recent Friday or Saturday would be charged $1,564 for a 15-foot truck, the highest rate for that route. Customers who leave on any other day, and reserve the truck 30 days in advance, would pay the lowest rate of $1,336.
But those prices are subject to change, and change they do in comparison with the previous system. Before the switch, Ryder typically changed rates once a month and then mailed out a new rate sheet to dealers.
 
'A Huge Chess Game'
 "It was a huge chess game, and you learn whether you bet right or bet wrong four weeks later," said Gerry Riordan, president of Ryder's consumer truck rental division.
Now Ryder rejiggers its prices almost daily and keeps hundreds of millions of rates in its system based on trip originations and destinations and truck sizes as well as shifting demand during the year. Price changes are updated through the computers at every Ryder dealer.
Ryder typically charges its lowest rates for customers renting a truck on a weekday in the middle of the month, when demand is lowest and many trucks sit idle. Like the airlines, they also offer discounts for booking in advance. The highest rate is set for the weekend at the end of the month, when most people move. The company says the system has helped increase its revenue for each truck in 1993 by 7 percent from 1992. Similarly, American Airlines said the pricing technology added 7 percent a year to its revenues.
Ryder said that no customer had complained about the widened gap from the highest to the lowest prices. And Herb Comrov, a Chicago businessman who has rented a few Ryder trucks in recent years, said the company would hear no complaints from him about the technology. He said he applauded the change if the higher prices helped make more trucks available during peak times, when he has had trouble finding one.
"Supply and demand is classic economics," he said. "If demand is up during certain weekends, they have a right to do that as long as they are not socking it to customers."
If any Ryder customers balk at the higher prices that results from the technology, Ryder dealers are given leeway to shave rates.
"If the customer is so insistent that it puts our brand equity on edge, our dealers can discount the price," Mr. Anderson said.
Whether they like it or not, consumers are likely to encounter the new pricing technology more often, including in the home, where many people are already familiar with cheaper long-distance phone calls after certain hours and on the weekend.
This thinking may soon extend to setting the thermostat and using electricity if an experiment under way in Chenal Valley, Ark., is successful. There, dozens of families have agreed to hook up their electric service to a computer and telecommunications network that helps them cut costs by shifting energy consumption from peak times to off-peak.
Home computers give customers estimated monthly bills at any time, as well as show the cost of running each appliance. The change resulted in rates fluctuating to levels both higher and lower than before.
Whether such changes will sit well with consumers is unclear. But executives at American Airlines and its competitors have bet a big part of their companies on it, and there is a clear hint of salesmanship in the voice of Mr. Cook, president of American Airlines Decision Technologies, when he discusses the technology.
"When people think about it," he said, "it makes a lot of sense."

HEADLINE: Bentsen Warns Japan on Stalemate in Trade Talks

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen warned Tokyo today that if it did not make concessions in trade talks with Washington, the United States would consider other measures for dealing with the huge trade imbalance with Japan.
In a hastily arranged stopover in Tokyo at the close of his Asian tour, Mr. Bentsen met separately with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and Finance Minister Hirohisa Fujii to deliver a personal message from President Clinton -- that progress in the so-called Framework trade talks of the last six months has been insufficient. 
 Mr. Bentsen did not specify what alternatives the United States would consider, but he seemed to hint at some form of punitive trade measures.
"What we are looking for in the Framework is progress in Japan getting into step with the world economy," Mr. Bentsen said at a news conference after the meetings. "Japan is out of step right now. It has a continuing trade surplus. It has the lowest penetration of manufactured imports, and it has the lowest foreign investment levels among the major nations."
He added: "If we do not have credible agreements by the time of the summit, we would have to re-examine the basis of the framework."
 
Two Leaders to Meet
 President Clinton and Prime Minister Hosokawa are scheduled to meet on Feb. 11 in Washington to review the talks.
Mr. Bentsen came to Tokyo to try to get Japanese political leaders more involved in efforts to break the deadlock so that the meeting in Washington highlights progress rather than exposes a stalemate.
But with the unexpected defeat last week of Mr. Hosokawa's political reform bill, it is not clear that he has the will, the focus or the clout to make the concessions Washington wants.
Some American diplomats and analysts in Tokyo believe that Mr. Hosokawa, assuming he holds onto power, will try to give the Americans just enough concessions to enable the two leaders to legitimately claim on Feb. 11 that progress is being made. Senior negotiators for both sides return to the bargaining table on Monday in Washington, and Mr. Hosokawa assured Mr. Bentsen he would attend the summit meeting on schedule.
 
Minister Says 'Trust Us'
 Mr. Bentsen quoted Mr. Hosokawa as assuring him: "I am telling my people that we want to bring this to a successful conclusion."
Mr. Fujii, the Finance Minister, later told reporters that he and Mr. Hosokawa would make something happen. He said that Japan's response to Mr. Bentsen was: "Trust us."
The Administration's attitude toward Japan these days could best be described as: trust but quantify. It is ready to give the Japanese one last chance to show progress, officials say, but the concessions have to be concrete and measurable.
Some analysts believe the United States does not have a great deal of leverage to pressure Japan, otherwise, Washington would probably have already done so. Also, the Administration cannot push Mr. Hosokawa so hard that his enemies, such as the Liberal Democratic Party, would be able to say that the Prime Minister is selling out Japanese interests.
The Administration insists there is much Mr. Hosokawa can do without exacerbating his political problems.
The Framework talks were slapped together in two nights of marathon negotiations during Mr. Clinton's visit to Tokyo last July for a meeting of the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies. The idea was to produce a negotiating structure that Mr. Clinton could hold up before he left town and that Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa could point to before he left office.
 
Many Unanswered Questions
 That was the problem. In their haste, the two leaders left vague or unanswered some of the key questions defining their accord, most notably what indicators they would use to determine whether Japan was opening its markets in five key areas: insurance sales, automobiles and auto parts, telecommunications, medical technology sales and intellectual property rights.
As a result, the two sides have spent the last six months simply trying to agree on how to measure results, rather than how Japan would open these markets.
The original agreement also called on Japan to cut taxes and stimulate domestic spending so consumers would buy more foreign goods.
While the talks have languished, every economic indicator they were supposed to improve has gotten worse, American officials say. In July, the Americans projected Japan's growth rate for 1993 at 1.5 to 2 percent and for 1994 at 2 to 3 percent. But Japan's economy ended 1993 with about zero growth and is projected to expand at less than 1 percent in 1994.
Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world was $120 billion in 1993, up from the previous record of $106 billion in 1992. Its trade surplus with the United States topped $50 billion by the end of 1993, up from $43 billion in 1992.
Under the Framework agreement, Mr. Bentsen said, "the United States agreed to cut its deficit. We have done that. Japan agreed to do what was necessary to achieve strong domestic demand, and if you look at the figures, that has not happened yet."

HEADLINE: Retail Giant Becomes a Job-Seeker's Oasis

SERIES: When Wall-Mart Comes to Town - Second article of a series

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENPORT, N.Y., Jan. 19

 BODY:
Robert Eggleston was ready to move out of his home state last November after losing his job on the pit crew of an auto-racing team and finding no other work here in the Hudson Valley, despite 20 years' experience as an Army mechanic.
Then something changed his mind: the prospect of a full-time job at the new Wal-Mart that is to open in the spring in this town across the river from the Catskills. 
 "I'll do anything to get a job right now," said Mr. Eggleston, 41, who has been told by the store's managers that he has a good chance of securing a $6-an-hour position as a maintenance worker. "At least it's going to mean I can pay my own rent without falling behind and without having to collect unemployment to do it."
Since Wal-Mart opened a makeshift hiring office on Jan. 5 in the Moose Lodge here, Mr. Eggleston and more than 1,600 other people have applied for the 245 jobs the store plans to begin filling next week. The ratio of applicants to available slots is comparable to that of some Ivy League colleges. The most coveted are the estimated 172 positions -- including stock clerks, sales clerks and department heads -- that will be full-time and include health and dental insurance.
 
Welcomed by the Jobless
 Often vilified by merchants for its tendency to flatten mom-and-pop businesses on Main Streets across the country, Wal-Mart has been welcomed with open arms here and across the Northeast by the unemployed, who represent 5 percent of the population here in Columbia County, and by untold others who already have jobs but who see the Arkansas-based chain as a springboard to an improved life.
Almost overnight, the nation's largest retailer has become one of Columbia County's 10 largest private employers. But not even Wal-Mart can solve all of this area's economic woes, which mainly stem from the loss of hundreds of manufacturing jobs over the last 20 years as more than a dozen factories closed.
Before being accepted onto the Wal-Mart payroll, applicants must be interviewed three times by several of the six store managers that the company has moved here from around the country. Finalists must pass a drug test and answer an array of sensitive questions, which frequently touch on the "family values" theme that permeates Wal-Mart's corporate philosophy.
Among those who hope to work in the cavernous new store is John Malek, 50, a struggling construction worker who has survived for the last year on the Social Security checks and the savings of his 82-year-old mother, with whom he lives.
"I'm trying to help Mom and meanwhile she's helping me right now," Mr. Malek explained over coffee at her kitchen table. "The wheel goes round. Sonny Boy came home."
One of 600 people who braved a chill wind to apply for work on the first day of interviews, Mr. Malek is being considered for a full-time job as a night-receiving clerk, a position that he said would restore his independence and give him health insurance.
 
Hoping for Jobs
 Rhoda Zukowski, a 34-year-old mother of two who has applied to sell jewelry or children's clothes, said a position at Wal-Mart would allow her to leave the factory job that she said has exposed her to "a lot of chemicals" over the last 16 years.
And David Slemp, 20, who works part-time cutting firewood, said he was counting on a full-time sales job in the store's sporting-goods department to help start a new life with his fiancee, Tanya Robinson, a 20-year-old waitress whom he plans to marry in July.
During a follow-up interview at the Moose Lodge this week, Patrick D. McCormick, a Wal-Mart assistant manager reassigned here from the store in North Adams, Mass., asked Mr. Slemp to respond to a series of hypothetical scenarios.
"Tom is an excellent employee," Mr. McCormick began, sitting at a long wooden table set under an illuminated bingo board. "One day at lunch he and a friend go out and smoke a marijuana cigarette. He comes back only a little high. Should we fire him?"
"Yes," said Mr. Slemp immediately, prompting Mr. McCormick to tell him enthusiastically, "That's right. At Wal-Mart, we don't put up with that."
If there is a downside to the new jobs Wal-Mart is offering, it is the salaries, which begin in many cases at $5.50 an hour, only $1.25 above minimum wage. The estimated $240 that Mr. Eggleston, the retired Army mechanic, would be paid from Wal-Mart before taxes each week is only $9 more than the weekly unemployment check he recently began drawing from the Government.
 
No Complaints
 But Mr. Eggleston is not complaining, saying that a Wal-Mart job would make a world of difference for his self-esteem and give him frequent opportunities to increase his salary. "I can see myself managing one of them one day," he said.
Ed Van Wagner, the manager of the State Department of Labor office in nearby Hudson, said that Wal-Mart was bringing "good jobs" to an area that has, in recent years, lost factories that once made products like matches, artificial Christmas trees, thermostats, computer cables and various textiles.
"Any time you have a company open up with that number of jobs, it just gives everyone so much encouragement," said Mr. Van Wagner, adding that nearly 2,300 people in Columbia County and neighboring Green County collected unemployment checks last week.
"You have to be careful you don't get hung up on salaries," Mr. Van Wagner said. "That's only a portion of the economic stability they're bringing with them."
Before its doors have even opened, Wal-Mart has become a presence here. It has provided 75 construction jobs lasting anywhere from one week to six months. It has tantalized residents with promises of rock-bottom prices. And it has prompted the merchants on Warren Street in Hudson, the closest shopping district to the new store, to rejuvenate their businesses in order to compete.
 
Waiting for the Call
 Similar dynamics have been observed across the New York region over the last two years as Wal-Mart has rapidly established a Northeastern foothold. By early next year, the chain estimates it will have at least 49 stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, all built since 1991.
Carol Moore, who is eager to rejoin the work force after five years spent raising her daughter, Heather, is among many here who have been heartened by Wal-Mart's arrival. Like hundreds of others who have completed the round of interviews, she is now awaiting word on whether the store has decided to hire her, in this case for a job selling women's clothes.
"I'm just waiting for the telephone call," Mrs. Moore, 37, said one morning this week, as her daughter stepped off the van that brings her home from preschool. "I hope I get it."
 
 
 
THE SERIES SO FAR
 The first article of this series on Wal-Mart's arrival in the Hudson, N.Y., area appeared on Nov. 28. It looked at the effect of Wal-Mart's presence on businesses along the city's main thoroughfare, Warren Street, including a 161-year-old hardware store.

HEADLINE: Syrian Capital Is Still a Center Of Exiles, Rebels and Secrets

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria

 BODY:
For all the talk of peace with Israel and a new and more open relationship with the West, this ancient capital remains a city of shadows and secrets, not only for Palestinian guerrilla organizations but also for both exiled Arab leaders and rebellious Kurds.
They work from offices in dusty apartment buildings on the sidestreets of Damascus, where silent men keep constant watch. The Syrian capital is home to 10 hard-line Palestinian groups, most of them driven from Beirut about a decade ago, as well as to Kurdish nationalists and Baghdad intellectuals who are bitterly opposed to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, and Shiite Muslims who are foes of the Government in Saudi Arabia. 
 For the last seven years, the capital has also provided refuge for Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani, the former President of Southern Yemen, who fled here after he was deposed in a violent coup by hard-line Marxists in 1986, and who now often holds court at a restaurant in the city's fashionable Shaalan neighborhood.
To some in the West, tolerance by Damascus for guerrilla groups and political plotters with whom it is sympathetic is prima facie evidence that Syria is still supporting organizations that export violence. It is this relationship that persuades Washington to keep Syria on its list of nations considered participants in state-supported terrorism and to enforce economic sanctions against the country.
But while those ties loom as a major obstacle to improved relations with Washington, diplomats here say President Hafez al-Assad is only doing what any shrewd Middle Eastern politician would do, given the constantly shifting sands of Arab politics: offering refuge, and succor to the enemies of his enemies, if only because it allows him to keep a closer eye on them.
Syria's internal security forces closely monitor the activities of the array of resistance groups and guerrillas based here, from the Popular Union of Kurdistan to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.
In September, for instance, when Palestinian groups staged protests and rallies in Damascus to oppose the agreement between Israel and the Palestinian Liberation Organization, hundreds of uniformed Syrian police officers lined the sidewalks, and armed plainclothes security men watched from windows overlooking the route.
 
Military Activity Barred
 "In recent months, the Syrians have effectively restrained these groups," a European diplomat here said, adding that Syria was restricting their activities to distributing information, including radio broadcasts, and organizing political discussions. They are not allowed to undertake any military activity on Syrian soil.
"But just by having them here, it also gives President Assad a strong card," the diplomat continued. "It gives him the ability to undermine anything he doesn't like."
But Syria's future relationships with some of these groups may be on the line as Washington presses Damascus to cut its ties with the hard-liners, especially groups like the Islamic Party of God or the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command. Both of them are continuing to carry out military operations against Israel in southern Lebanon and the occupied territories.
At the offices of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a basement warren of small rooms alongside a hairdressers' salon, Daoud Talhamy, the group's urbane spokesman, said it was wrong for the West to blame Syria because there are Palestinian groups at war with Israel.
"The Palestinian opposition in Damascus, and other places, is part of the political map of the Palestinian people," Mr. Talhamy said. "To force Syria to close us down will have no effect on the struggle, because the real opposition comes from inside the territories themselves, not from an office in Damascus."
Rather than foment intrigues and plot the overthrow of their home governments, some of the Arab political exiles taking refuge here have recently engaged in what Syrian officials describe as constructive activities. Sheik Hassan al-Saghar, the exiled leader of a group of Saudi Arabian Shiite Muslims opposed to the Riyadh Government, has used his base here to try to reach an accommodation with the Government of Prince Fahd.
In November, Mr. Hassani, the former leader of Southern Yemen, became involved, at the request of officials back home, in efforts to mediate growing political tension and violence in his former country, which unified with Yemen, its northern neighbor, in 1990.

HEADLINE: Governors' '94 Message: Crime, Crime and Crime

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The issue of crime is sweeping the nation's statehouses, with governors sounding like tough-talking sheriffs as they declare that fighting violence is at the top of their legislative agendas.
A review of dozens of State of the State addresses delivered this month by Democrats and Republicans, in large states and small, finds similar if not identical themes. The emphasis was more on locking up prisoners than on rehabilitation. Again and again, the governors talked about cracking down on juvenile criminals. 
 And in what may foreshadow President Clinton's State of the Union Message on Tuesday, many governors -- from Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, to Mario M. Cuomo of New York, a Democrat -- called for mandatory life sentences for offenders convicted three times of violent crimes. Mr. Clinton is considering endorsing a Federal "three-time loser" law in his address, White House officials said.
 
Guns to Make a Point
 To drive home the law-and-order point in his address, Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana, a Democrat, stunned the audience when he brandished three handguns at the lectern. Saying they had been confiscated from juveniles, he declared, "We must get guns out of the hands of children."
The new focus on crime is driven at least in part by recent polls showing that although violence is not on the rise, the issue now rivals the economy as the leading domestic concern among Americans.
The notion that governors see the issue as important politically is particularly obvious because the oratory from those seeking re-election this year is particularly strong.
Few governors, however, spoke of new resources to match their new emphasis. With little money available to build new prisons or put many new police officers on the street, many of the efforts are intended to redirect resources.
 
The Message Is Sent
 Though several speeches touched on education, health care, welfare reform and the economy, the governors were so united in seizing on crime that some tossed off the same applause lines.
Gov. Bruce King of New Mexico, a Democrat: "I want to send a message to the violent criminal, that if you commit the crime you do the time."
Gov. Ben Nelson of Nebraska, a Democrat: "We're sending a message -- if you commit a crime, you will do time."
Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri, a Democrat: "If you've done the crime in this state, you will do the time."
Many of the speeches were filled with frightening talk of criminals and warnings that their behavior would not be tolerated. "I was not hired to be Arizona's chief social theorist," said Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona, a Republican. "I was not sent here to sit meditating on Freud or on the latest 'root causes' of criminal behavior. The criminal law deals not with theories but with thugs."
 
'Hand Me a Shovel'
 Another Republican, Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi, called for $12 million for new prison space in the state. Ridiculing the idea that he could open up prison space by shortening sentences, he said: "It will be over my dead body before that ever happens. I will fight with every breath in my body to see that the criminals we take off the streets serve their time. And if that means we have to build a bigger jail house, then hand me a shovel, stand back and we'll get it built."
In most of the speeches, it was impossible to distinguish the Republican phrasing from the Democratic. Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chairman, accused Mr. Cuomo of mimicking a former Republican Attorney General in his State of the State address, saying he "sounded like Ed Meese."
One Democrat who talked especially tough was Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia. Saying he would not stand still while "thugs take charge of the streets," Mr. Miller proposed mandatory 10-year sentences for violent crimes and life without parole for second-time violent offenders. He also endorsed a requirement that young people between the age of 13 and 17 who commit violent crimes be tried and prosecuted as adults.
"These are not the Cleaver kids soaping up some windows," said Mr. Miller, who is seeking re-election this year. "These are middle school kids conspiring to hurt their teacher, teen-agers shooting people and committing rapes, young thugs running gangs and terrorizing neighborhoods and showing no remorse when they get caught."
Some governors illustrated their points by citing crimes in their own states, or others. Mr. Wilson, who is seeking re-election this year, called the man accused of kidnapping and murdering 12-year-old Polly Klaas an "animal." He added: "Our streets are being stained with the blood of our children, and it's going to stop. Damn it, it has got to stop."
Mr. Symington also cited the Klaas case, saying he had just read an article that concluded that money spent on prisons is wasted. "The author's cause suffered in my case from bad timing," he said. "I had just finished reading an article about Polly Klaas."
 
Seeing Larger Picture
 Gov. Barbara Roberts of Oregon, a Democrat, recalled how she and the local police had stopped by a house in Portland on a recent Saturday night that was filled with gang members and some young teen-age girls. "The gang members come and go," she said, "trashing the place, crashing on mattresses in the filthy upstairs bedrooms, dealing drugs, slamming the girls around. The girls treated our arrival, between constant phone calls, with apathy, as if it were nothing unusual."
Alex Castellanos, a Republican political strategist, said the governors' attention to crime was not simply playing politics. States, he said, had responsibility for shaping the bulk of the penal code as well as prosecuting and jailing most prisoners.
"I don't think it's a quick-fix thing," Mr. Castellanos said. "I don't think it's responding to poll numbers. There is an increasing randomness to violence that threatens people, there is vulnerability that wasn't there before. These governors are the front-line guys."
Even so, there seemed to be a rush to mention crime, even in states like New Hampshire, which Gov. Stephen Merrill said was "comparatively free from violence." After citing the state's mandatory minimum-sentencing law as a model, Mr. Merrill, a Republican, said, "We will spend more time in 1994 talking about crime, and we should."

HEADLINE: President's Address Will Emphasize Crime and Health

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
In his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, President Clinton will try to defuse criticism of his health care plan and make a new bid for middle-class support by emphasizing themes like the need for more individual responsibility and issues like Federal action against crime, aides said today.
Mr. Clinton spent the weekend at Camp David going over the details of a speech that is not expected to include major new initiatives. But aides consider this address pivotal and said that the President would move beyond the economic security issues he concentrated on last year in his first major speech to Congress. 
 This year's address, which will be Mr. Clinton's first official State of the Union Message, will instead focus on the fight for universal health coverage, crime control, worker retraining and, to a lesser degree, restructuring of the welfare system.
And in an effort to demonstrate that he can be as tough on crime as any Republican, Mr. Clinton is expected to endorse a provision of the Senate's crime bill that would require those who are convicted of three violent felonies to be sentenced to prison for life.
That measure, sponsored by Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, applies only to convicts who commit the final crime on Federal property, meaning its application would be narrow. Its significance is primarily symbolic, as governors in several states are proposing similar provisions.
 
Public's Crime Fears
 In endorsing that idea, Mr. Clinton will join many Senate Democrats who approved it in November, but at the same time he will place himself in opposition to Democrats in the House who oppose it. The President has praised some provisions in the Senate bill, like a proposed ban on assault weapons, but has not taken a position on the entire package.
Crime initiatives are not the most significant elements of Mr. Clinton's domestic agenda or of the speech the President will deliver. Health care remains the Administration's priority, but aides said the references to crime have expanded in the text in response to the polls showing it outpacing even health care as a matter of public concern.
The pattern that is emerging for Mr. Clinton's televised, prime-time speech draws heavily on one of his favorite themes: that the United States can prosper only if its citizens rely less on Government and more on themselves.
Mr. Clinton's advisers hope that such an approach will deflect Republican criticism that his health care plan would give Government too big a role in personal choices. They also hope it will calm Congressional liberals who worry how a Government run by a self-described progressive Democrat can be more active when it has less money to spend.
"This is a moment when he will have an audience," said Stanley B. Greenberg, the President's pollster. "The public is very focused on him. He is very much at the center of their contradictory feelings about where the country is going. As a result, they watch him very closely."
At least five drafts of the speech have been assembled since Christmas, and Mr. Clinton is working on yet another this weekend. Aides who have read versions said the core of the address is drawn from four previous speeches delivered in Washington, New Haven, Memphis and Raleigh, N.C. In those appearances, the President spoke to audiences of academics and members of the clergy about crime, violence and moral responsibility.
 
Rhetorical Safety Net
 For several months, Mr. Clinton has sought to weave a rhetorical safety net by combining his major domestic priorities. This way, gun control and health care cost control can be linked. Welfare change, Administration officials reason, becomes a component of health care revision, even though health care is clearly taking precedence.
The whole package, unwieldy as it may seem, is aimed at middle-class voters, the constituency Mr. Clinton has long considered the spine of his support. And those voters, Mr. Clinton's advisers assert, are perfectly content with the President's crammed agenda.
"They're not assessing whether it's fast or slow or messy or neat," said Mark D. Gearan, the White House communications director. "They're making evaluations based on results."
With his relatively high poll ratings and the benefits of a revived economy, Mr. Clinton is now prepared for the demands of a pitched battle on health care that even his most optimistic aides predict will be messy, partisan and filled with compromises.
"The program for this year is making more changes that people have been waiting to have Washington make for 10 or 20 or 30 or 60 years," said one White House official. "We have health care reform within our hands, but it's going to be hard. It's going to be eight months of a ground war."
The White House's own report card on Mr. Clinton's first year puts the various setbacks to one side and instead emphasizes what aides say the President has achieved. "If anything, in the past year, we've suffered from very bad timing," Mr. Gearan said.
While the public's attention was being diverted by incidents like repeated stumbles over high-level appointments, Mr. Clinton has overturned anti-abortion regulations, signed a family leave law, overseen the enactment of an earned-income tax credit for the poor, won Congressional approval for the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, signed a handgun control measure known as the Brady Bill into law and created a national service program for young volunteers.
Moreover, Mr. Clinton won passage of an economic plan that reordered some Government priorities and suggested that he was serious about reducing the Federal budget deficit. This helps him claim credit for the improved economy.
 
Seeing a Lull Ahead
 If Mr. Clinton and his advisers have learned anything in their first year in office, it has been to take advantage of blue sky whenever it presents itself. And as a newly appointed special prosecutor moves the investigation of Mr. Clinton's involvement in an Arkansas real estate deal to Little Rock, Ark., and away from Washington, Mr. Clinton fully intends to capitalize on the lull.
The President, his advisers say, is now in the best political position he has been in since his term began.
"He's not Teflon," said one senior official, "but he was much more vulnerable to the ups and downs and battering of the early months before he got anything done on Nafta, the budget and the Brady bill. They made a difference in how people see him.
"Now, " the official said, "things bounce off a little better than they did before."

HEADLINE: A Test Case for Nuclear Disposal

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEEDLES, Calif.

 BODY:
There is probably no more useless tract of land in the United States than an arid 1,000-acre parcel of Federal land in the Mojave Desert 22 miles west of here.
About the only person who has ever made anything from it is Milton Blair, who leases this expanse of sand and creosote bushes from the Bureau of Land Management to run a few head of cattle. Those who know him also say Mr. Blair picks up litter along nearby Interstate 40 to make ends meet. 
 Yet this Godforsaken tract in Ward Valley in California has emerged as the leading national proving ground for whether the United States can find a suitable place to dispose of radioactive waste, and for President Clinton's stated environmental philosophy of finding economically feasible solutions to environmental problems.
The State of California has licensed a company to build a disposal site here for what is defined as low-level nuclear waste, but the Clinton Administration has yet to decide whether it will transfer the land to the state for that purpose.
 
A Serious Setback
 If the dump is built, it would be first such site opened in this country since 1971. But if it is not built, it would be a serious setback for years of effort by Congress to force the states to cooperate in finding places to dump the less-potent wastes from their nuclear power plants, hospitals and pharmaceutical makers. These wastes, which can variously retain substantial levels of radioactivity for just a few months up to millions of years, include things like like tools and gloves used near nuclear reactors, isotopes used in making drugs, and radioactive film and chemicals used in hospital diagnostic machines and procedures.
In 1985 Congress set a date for states to find a way to dispose of their own low-level nuclear waste by joining in compacts with other states, but more than a year has passed since that deadline, and in almost every state the process has stalled in a tangle of protests, lawsuits and fiscal problems.
Only one existing low-level disposal site, in Barnwell, S.C., is still accepting waste from California and other states outside Barnwell's Southeastern Compact, whose member are Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia. And that practice will end on June 30, if no progress is made toward opening the Needles site.
Apart from Barnwell, only one other low-level disposal site is operating in the United States, the Hanford Reservation in Richland, Wash. But Hanford accepts low-level waste only from the 11 members of the Northwest and Rocky Mountain regional compacts.
 
Waste Is Piling Up
 This situation was not what Congress envisioned in 1980 when it passed the Low-Level Radioactive Waste Policy Act and amended it in 1985. Since then, 42 states have joined in nine regional compacts; but eight other states, including New York, have neither formed nor joined any compacts, and their low-level wastes are either being stored where they are generated or are being shipped by rail and truck under contract to Barnwell while they search for long-term sites and disposal methods.
In California, by contrast, the process seemed to be on track. The state formed the Southwestern Compact with Arizona, North Dakota and South Dakota and moved steadily toward developing the Ward Valley site. But now that, too, is in limbo, caught up in scientific debate, considerable political opposition within California and uncertainty over whether the Federal Government will turn over the land.
On a recent visit here, Stephen A. Romano gazed out over the bleak valley between the Sacramento and Paiute Mountains and pronounced it ideal for radioactive refuse -- remote, geologically stable and hydrologically isolated. Mr. Romano, who is the manager of California operations for U.S. Ecology, the company that California licensed to build and operate the dump, was reflecting his company's conclusions that the site was suitably distant from rivers and lakes and more than 600 feet above the water table.
"From a national perspective, if we cannot put a disposal site here, you cannot put one anywhere," said Mr. Romano, whose company is a subsidiary of a Houston concern, American Ecology, that has invested $47 million in the project since 1986.
 
Buried 24 Feet Down
 Under the company's plan, the low-level waste would be buried in sealed and shielded containers in five unlined trenches at least 24 feet deep. (High-level wastes, like spent fuel from nuclear power plants, are scheduled to go to another repository planned by the Federal Government under Yucca Mountain in Nevada.)
For a time, it seemed like Ward Valley was on a fast track to approval, with strong backing from Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican. In an 11th-hour act before the Bush Administration expired early last year, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan agreed to transfer the federally owned land in Ward Valley to California.
At first, it seemed the Clinton Administration would go along. Both President Clinton and his Interior Secretary, Bruce Babbitt, had been involved as governors in original compact legislation, and they seemed content to let the states proceed without hindrance. Mr. Babbitt, as Interior Secretary, accepted the environmental-impact report compiled by U.S. Ecology. Governor Wilson issued the company's license on Sept. 16, before holding a hearing to discuss the environmental issues.
But over the last several months, political pressures have steadily built against the project in an effort led by two Los Angeles groups, the Committee to Bridge the Gap and Americans for a Safe Future.
 
A Senator's Opposition
 Probably the largest political factor was the opposition of Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California. On Oct. 11, she issued a report from the United States Geological Survey that said there was a significant danger that the site could contaminate the Colorado River, 25 miles away, a major source of drinking water for Southern California. Scientists hired by the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California raised similar fears. U.S. Ecology disputed the findings.
Opposition also came from the powerful President pro tem of the state Senate, David A. Roberti, a Democrat.
A White House official said these pressures, reinforced by editorials in California newspapers critical of the project, registered in Washington.
On Nov. 24, Secretary Babbitt brought the whole process to a halt by postponing further action until two lawsuits in state court against the project were resolved.
 
Past Leaks and Violations
 "They don't like having this on their plate," said Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club in San Francisco, discussing Mr. Babbitt's decision. "They had hoped initially they could leave it to the state. But the state made such a hash of it that they could not."
Complicating matters is the record of U.S. Ecology, which had numerous leaks and procedural violations at three other nuclear disposal sites it operated, at Maxey Flats, Ky.; Sheffield, Ill., and Beatty, Nev. All are now closed to nuclear waste.
Mr. Romano acknowledged that there had been problems in the past, but he said the contamination had been cleaned up and that the site here was quite different, particularly because rainfall here is minimal, only five inches a year.
The issue is further confused by a welter of competing claims by each side. Opponents of the dump insist that, as more nuclear power plants are taken out of service in the next 20 years, as much as 97 percent of the nuclear waste disposed of here will come from nuclear power plants. Although this material will have to meet the criteria for low-level waste, opponents contend that it nonetheless will be very long-lived and potentially dangerous. U.S. Ecology disputes this assertion, saying that only 12 percent of the waste dumped here will come from electric utilities.
The issue of the dump seems inexorably headed for California's next campaign for governor.
If the site is opened, observant motorists along Interstate 40 will notice low-level bunkers just south of the freeway. If not, Milton Blair's cows will probably continue to roam this forbidding range for as long as the old rancher lives.

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE;
2 Angelenos Who Took a Second Hit

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Piero Selvaggio had barely finished clearing the charred rubble of his Big Rock Canyon home, which burned to the ground in November's brush fires, when last week's earthquake tore through one of the restaurants he owns here, sending a red river of wine worth a million dollars coursing down Pico Boulevard toward the sea.
On the other side of town, Hung Lee was also a two-time loser. His furniture store, stripped bare by looters in the 1992 riots, took a hard hit in Monday's predawn tremor. Chunks of plaster fell from the ceiling, deep cracks laced the walls, and Mr. Lee, already so deeply in debt that he had just leased his building to a tenant, wondered where he would find the money for repairs. 
 Mr. Selvaggio, a Sicilian immigrant who made his fortune on these golden shores, and Mr. Lee, who fled Vietnam in a rickety boat for the land of freedom, are two of the untallied Angelenos who took a second or even a third blow last week when a deadly earthquake battered this already battered city.
 
Windows Into the Soul
 In apocalyptic succession, Los Angeles has been ravaged, first by riots in the inner city, then by fires in the enclaves of the privileged and now by an earthquake that has spread suffering among rich and poor alike.
It will be months before people like Mr. Selvaggio and Mr. Lee tally the latest round of damage to their businesses and homes and take the measure of their accumulated loss, material and emotional. But their stories, while incomplete, are windows into the soul of this region, which has borne a world of misery in the last few years.
"We go through bad things here," said Mr. Lee, clutching a bulging folder marked "insurance" as he talked in his Koreatown store, where plaster litters the carpets and lamp shades sit askew. "It happens again and again. But what can we do?"
Mr. Selvaggio made jokes about living through "first the bake and then the shake." But he has also had moments of wondering, "Why me? Why me again?"
But he, too, sees his own troubles in the context of a stricken place. "This city has gone through so much that rebounding is becoming a way of life," Mr. Selvaggio said, offering cappuccino and apologizing for the stench of wine in his Santa Monica restaurant.
His wife, Stacy Dalgleish, a part-time psychologist and mother of three, spoke of the double dose of trauma in the language of her profession. "I was just getting through the shock so I could get to the depression," she said. "Now I'm back to the shock."
 
Success in America
 Mr. Selvaggio's restaurants are among the most renowned in the area, and are the pride of a 47-year-old immigrant who came to the United States as a teen-ager with a few dollars in his pocket and no knowledge of English. Mr. Selvaggio worked in a cafeteria in Brooklyn and later made his way to Los Angeles, where he joined an uncle who was waiting tables at Chasen's in Beverly Hills.
Mr. Selvaggio opened his first restaurant, Valentino, more than 20 years ago at the eastern fringe of Santa Monica, serving chicken cacciatore in dowdy surroundings. But today Valentino is a stylish palace of haute cuisine, one of the first restaurants in the country to import fine olive oil and white truffles and the home of a prized wine collection, which numbered 90,000 bottles before last week's quake.
Mr. Selvaggio also owns two other restaurants, and they were largely undamaged. They are Primi, in the West Los Angeles section, a virtual commissary to 20th Century Fox Studios, and Posto, in the city's Sherman Oaks section, just miles from the earthquake's epicenter. Posto was the only building on its block of Ventura Boulevard to go unharmed.
Not so Valentino, where 13,000 bottles of wine flew from their racks in a second-floor storage area, sending a cascade of wine down a narrow staircase, toward the dining rooms and kitchen and out onto the street. Dozens of employees rushed to the restaurant before dawn and helped clean up the mess. Two days later, decked with fresh flowers and sweet with the smell of warm bread, Valentino reopened.
 
Loss Put at $1 Million
 Mr. Selvaggio estimates the retail cost of the lost wine to be $1 million, although most of it is irreplaceable and none of it was insured.
As he grieved for the wine, his wife had earlier grieved for their home on the cliffs of Malibu, destroyed in the fires that swept through the canyons last fall. It was a relatively modest ranch-style home, but lushly appointed with Art Nouveau antiques, Persian rugs and a library of first editions.
All that is left on the lot overlooking the Pacific Ocean is a stone barbecue pit, a children's playhouse, a garden where the couple grew rosemary, tomatoes, lemons and figs for the restaurants and a cat that refuses to relocate.
After the fire, Mr. Selvaggio and Ms. Dalgleish rented a house in the hills of Santa Monica. That house, a stilted aerie of redwood and glass, is no longer habitable because the quake shattered its huge windows, just yards from where 6-year-old Girogio was sleeping.
 
School and Church Destroyed
 The family is now staying with an elderly friend, godmother to 4-year-old Gianpiero, and looking for yet another place to rent. And their dislocation does not end with housing: the Malibu school that the children attended was destroyed in the fire, and the family's church in Santa Monica tumbled in the quake.
By contrast, Mr. Lee and his family were spared damage at their home in Arcadia, a suburb east of Los Angeles, both during the earthquake and the earlier fires and riots. But their business, the Elegant Lifestyle furniture store at the edge of downtown Los Angeles, was ravaged in the riots that erupted in late April and early May 1992 after a jury acquitted four white police officers on all but one count in the beating of Rodney G. King, a black man.
While many other Koreatown merchants stood armed on the roofs of their stores to ward off looters on the second day of the riots, Mr. Lee 42, huddled at home in the San Gabriel Valley, far from the violence.
In his absence, rioters smashed the windows of his corner store, burned rugs and sofas and stole the rest of the furniture, hundreds of huge pieces in all. Mr. Lee said the property damage amounted to about $20,000 and the furniture was worth $120,000.
 
A Refugee With Dreams
 It was a terrible blow to Mr. Lee, a self-made merchant who fled Vietnam in 1977, making the treacherous passage across the South China Sea to Hong Kong in a 36-foot boat with his wife, infant son and 60 other people. One of his brothers, also with a wife and child, tried the same escape in another boat and were lost at sea.
In the United States, Mr. Lee and his wife, Tina, found jobs within months, he at the loading dock in a warehouse and she behind a sewing machine in a garment factory. At night they went to a community college to learn English.
A few years ago, he bought the furniture store and a manicure parlor for his wife. Then the riots shattered Mr. Lee's dreams.
For weeks afterward, he was too traumatized to work. Then he began repairing the damage, replacing the merchandise and applying for Federal assistance.
The Federal Emergency Management Agency gave Mr. Lee $1,000 to pay one month's rent at his suburban town house, but only after a long siege of haggling because the building was in probate and proving ownership and tenancy was difficult.
"If I need more money, I have to submit more papers," Mr. Lee said, "so I forget it."
 
'How Do I Fight Them?'
 He also applied to the Small Business Administration for a loan. But his request was denied because he had accumulated $40,000 in debts to replace his merchandise and pay his family's day-to-day bills, and the agency doubted his ability to repay a loan.
"They are the Government," Mr. Lee said. "How do I fight them?"
In those days, he said, the Good Samaritan in his life was the Bank of America, which waived his $10,000-a-month mortgage payments for the six months it took him to reopen the store.
Amid a stubborn recession here, and with business down more than a third since the riots, Mr. Lee was buried in debt. Earlier this month, seeing no other recourse, he rented his 8,000-square-foot store to his longtime manager, Jesse Kim, who asked Mr. Lee to stay on as an employee.
Then came the earthquake. "I thought when Mr. Kim took over my responsibilities would end," Mr. Lee said. "But I own the property. Now I don't know where to find the money to repair."
 
Father's Death Recalled
 His voice broke for the first time in a long conversation. Softly, he recounted his father's death from a heart attack in 1975, shortly after the Communists seized his plastics factory near Cam Ranh Bay.
"Now I know how my father felt at that time," Mr. Lee said. "You work for how many years, and you lose everything."
But Mr. Lee and Mr. Selvaggio have mostly resisted self-pity.
"It hurts, sure," Mr. Selvaggio said. "There are moments of tears, of feeling everything's unfair. But life is not supposed to be easy. It's been mostly a smooth ride for us. So now there are bumps, but we'll continue."
Mr. Lee said essentially the same thing. "Even though I lost everything, I will be working hard again," he said. "This country, if you work hard, you really get somewhere. I am still young. There is time to go."

HEADLINE: 'Funky New York,' and Other Exports

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Ordinarily it would have been no big deal that Hironobu Sekiguchi chose to go shopping in New York City on Saturday afternoon. He even made it clear he didn't have unlimited money to spend.
But on his trip, Mr. Sekiguchi, a businessman from Tokyo, was driven about in a chauffeured car, attended by New York State officials and assorted publicly financed consultants and greeted by merchants like a long-lost friend. He was in New York to find things to sell in his new boutique in Harajuku, a popular Tokyo shopping area, especially among teen-agers. It is called See the Scene and specializes in what he calls "funky New York" merchandise. 
 "We're looking for something great that isn't yet in Japan that has the potential to be hot," he said in Japanese translated by Meggie Yamazaki, a business associate.
 
Feeling It Firsthand
 The shopping trip was the result. "He's interested in funky New York," said Kathryn D. Leary, a consultant whose expertise is bringing black-owned and Japanese businesses together. "We're letting him touch it and feel it firsthand."
By the end of the day Mr. Sekiguchi had visited an artist's loft in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn and had been pleased with some chopstick holders shaped like New York taxicabs. In Harlem, he politely turned thumbs down to a mink crown like the one worn by Queen Latifah, the rap artist. It appeared not to matter that the crown was cleverly designed to convert to a collar for a jacket or sweater.
What he most wanted to buy, it turned out, was not even for sale until he mentioned it: the colorful uniforms -- made of Kente cloth and bearing the phrase "Harlem U.S.A." -- worn by the staff of the McDonald's on West 125th Street, a few doors east of the Apollo Theater. "A refreshing surprise," he said, as a hip-hop group hired for his benefit, GQ and the Funky Republic, performed in the restaurant.
Mr. Sekiguchi is the first real business contact corralled by New York State economic development officials to test a plan to increase exports by black-owned businesses to Japan. Tomorrow he will meet with all 10 companies selected for the program's first stage, and possibly make some selections and sign a check or two.
The National Minority Business Council, a private educational and training group in New York, chose the program's participants, looking for companies whose products had promise as exports to Japan and whose owners were willing to adapt them to meet Japanese demands. The council then hired consultants to work with the business owners.
They have been attending weekly classes, learning such useful tidbits as the proper way to give and receive a business card in Japan. Products have already been shipped to Japan for inspection. Among other lessons, the Americans have learned that many Japanese prefer lighter jewelry made from precious metals, not heavier pieces done in metals like brass.
 
Justifying State Help
 Nina Liebman, chief of international programs for the New York State Department of Economic Development, said the state help was justified because exports created jobs. Also, she said, all the companies taking part would have had great difficulty exporting on their own, particularly to a market as difficult as Japan's.
"It seems so abstract," she said. "If you're a small business, the last thing you're going to think about is how to expand into Japan."
But the economic official suggested that if small companies could learn to export to Japan, especially given the economic downturn there, they could probably succeed anywhere.
Chey Backuswalcott, whose W. W. Chey New York Company makes jewelry, umbrellas and T-shirts, among other products, wholeheartedly agreed. She said that just as she learned to modify her products for Japan, she could now do the same for other markets.
"The Japanese market is very fertile today," she said, "but another market may be more fertile later on."
The shopping trip to Brooklyn was intended to give Mr. Sekiguchi some idea of the places where the products -- including tailored capes that convert to miniskirts and sculptured pins of African masks -- come from.
He was not overwhelmed by the sights. "Wherever you go in New York, it looks the same," he said, even as the car crawled down 125th Street past a visual explosion of street peddlers and swarming shoppers.
But he could hardly forget that many Japanese are beginning to discover American black culture. Ms. Leary, the consultant, who regularly travels to Japan, said that rap music was a favorite among young Japanese and that Spike Lee had three shops in Tokyo selling memorabilia from his movies. She said some Japanese had even made a weeklong tour of important sites in the life of Malcolm X.
 
Seeking Positive Images
 Japanese politicians have sometimes been criticized for insensitive comments about blacks in the United States, and Ms. Leary, who is black, said one of her goals was to introduce the Japanese to successful blacks. "Part of what I try to do is show them positive models of African-Americans who made it in business," she said.
At MoNoCo Design, which features colorful ceramics reflecting the Jamaican roots of Noel Copeland, a street artist in Fort Greene, Mr. Sekiguchi seemed pleased with the company's newest product: sushi plates. But he said that a teapot needed little teacups to go with it, rather than the large mugs on display.
Mr. Copeland said that would be no problem, and said he could also whip up a dandy rice bowl if desired. He said he was very conscious of the Japanese reputation for high-quality products. "It's forced me to bring up my standard," he said.
At STIX Place, a furrier in Mart 125 in Harlem, Mr. Sekiguchi looked at all manner of things made from mink: baseball caps, bomber jackets, ponytail holders, a hat modeled after the big-billed sort favored by Janet Jackson, the singer. Halter tops and bikinis made of fur were also available. "Unbelievable," the Japanese businessman said in English.
But he didn't see anything he wanted to buy. "A tough sell in Japan," he later said through an interpreter.

HEADLINE: Giuliani and the Eternal Diva Debate;
Can a True Opera Fan Admire Both Callas and Tebaldi? Absolutely, the Mayor Says

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
On Saturday night, Rudolph W. Giuliani entered a realm that can easily match the New York City streets in animosity and extravagance. It is a realm where most politicians are reluctant to tread, where fistfights have broken out and lifelong friendships broken up, a realm of high passion and low opinions -- the realm of the opera fan.
The Mayor was interviewed on "Opera Fanatic," a radio program on WKCR-FM. He was prepared to take tough positions, answering questions on pressing issues: How good is the Metropolitan Opera? Who was a better tenor, Jussi Bjoerling or Franco Corelli in his prime? Should there be booing in the opera house? And what about young Andrew Giuliani -- does he have a future in opera? 
 This is not the first time Mr. Giuliani has ventured into the world of vocal registers and devoted claques. His host, Stefan Zucker, who bills himself as "the world's highest tenor" (the Guinness Book of World Records gave him that title after he held an A above high C for 3.8 seconds in a Town Hall recital), began the interview by recalling that the Mayor's first appearance on his show in October "almost cost him the election."
At that time, the candidate, whose resume included the leadership of his high-school opera club, asserted that his two favorite sopranos of the century were Maria Callas and Renata Tebaldi. The judgment caused a scandal among "Fanatic" listeners. "Everyone knows," Mr. Zucker declared, "you can't be a fan of both." Mr. Zucker was finally convinced of the candidate's integrity when he expressed dissatisfaction with the Metropolitan Opera.
This time, speaking for a half-hour on the telephone, Mr. Giuliani was ready to defend his positions while tempting listeners with the prospect of a mayor who might take an active interest in the arts.
He called for "preserving New York City's role as cultural capital" of the United States and the world. He argued for the economic importance of the arts to New York. He declined to enforce his tastes on any institution because of his belief in the "free marketplace." He sought to dispel any impression that he might advocate cutting back on city money given to small arts organizations in favor of more established "tourist attractions." And he acknowledged that yes, Andrew "has a flair for drama" and might "take naturally to the operatic stage."
 
Corelli vs. Bjoerling
 But back to the scandal, which Mr. Giuliani handled with the skill of one used to political battle. Despite the rivalry between fans of Callas and Tebaldi, he argued, "It's very easy to like both." Callas, after all, had an extraordinary instrument and was an unparalleled dramatic actress; her voice was not beautiful, but her performances could be superb. Tebaldi did not have as great an instrument, but her voice was "lyrical, lovely, luscious."
When he was pressed to give a verdict in the case of Corelli vs. Bjoerling, Mr. Giuliani was equally judicious. Mr. Corelli was a master of the heroic tenor roles, he said, noting that he had been present at Mr. Corelli's 1961 Metropolitan Opera debut in Verdi's "Trovatore" and called it "one of the most exciting experiences I have ever had."
"Bjoerling had different strengths," the Mayor said, evident in more lyrical roles because he had such an "unusual quality to his voice."
 
What About the Met?
 As for the Met, Mr. Giuliani felt that the orchestra had improved, that there were some "daring productions," but that sometimes there were disappointing casts. The size of the house, he said, requires "both a gigantic voice and a beautiful voice" -- a rare combination.
"Have you ever booed?" Mr. Zucker asked the Mayor.
"No, I never have," he replied, though he thought there were times when it might be appropriate, just to keep up standards.
"Have you ever wept?"
"Sure," Mr. Giuliani said, mentioning Marcello's murmur of "Coraggio!" ("Courage!") to Rodolfo in Puccini's "Boheme."
"Have you ever fallen asleep at the opera?"
"Sure," admitted the Mayor again, "several times during the 'Ring' operas." The Mayor promised to return to Mr. Zucker's show to compare recordings of Verdi's "Otello" and converse with Mr. Corelli. And though he may find that he is too busy, he hoped he would get to the opera "quite a bit" during the spring. One listener was already offering him a pair of seats.

HEADLINE: Proposal to Overhaul Schools Brings Opposition From Parents and Teachers

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 22

 BODY:
Teachers concerned about job security and parents who oppose the philosophy behind outcome-based education spoke out in force this month at hearings on a state commission's recommendations for remaking Connecticut's public schools.
Some members of the panel, the Commission on Educational Excellence for Connecticut, were more concerned afterward by a lack of enthusiasm they sensed for the plan to overhaul Connecticut's schools, which they are to submit to the state legislature on Feb. 1 after 19 months of work.
 
'If It Isn't Broken. . . .'
 Barbara Toman, who represents the Parent-Teacher Association on the commission, said: "People are saying, 'The schools aren't broken in my community. They're not broken, therefore they don't need to get fixed.' " 
 The legislature created the commission in 1992 to develop a plan "to promote an outcome-based, world-class educational system" for Connecticut that would prepare students to compete in a global economy.
Its proposal, following a model endorsed by national groups like the Business Round Table and the National Governors' Association, focuses on the educational outcomes -- like knowledge and skills gained in schools -- rather than the money spent on schools or the time students are in class.
The idea is that once schools decide what their graduates need to know, they can redesign their curriculums to help nearly all students reach that goal. The role of teachers will be to help all students learn the lesson, at their own pace according to their ability, rather to sort them into winners and losers after each test. But the final standard will be high for everyone, supporters of the idea say.
After more than a year of immersion in this educational philosophy, some commission members said they were troubled by what they learned at the hearings, not only by comments that showed that speakers did not understand what they were trying to do, but also by their own inability to explain their proposals clearly and concisely.
 
A Social Experiment?
 Several speakers from a group called the Committee to Save Our Schools, for example, assailed the philosophy of outcome-based education, saying it was, in reality, a social experiment to shape the values of children and to achieve social equality by holding all children to one level.
"The commission is not looking for excellence in education," a founder of the group, Kenneth Von Kohorn of Weston, told the commission at a hearing in Stamford this week. "Through its recommendation of universal standards or results, it is seeking, even demanding, mediocrity. Wherever universal outcomes have been attempted, standards have always been set low."
In reply, commission members accused Mr. Von Kohorn's group of being interested in winning public financing for private schools. The group does advocate school choice as a way of improving schools, and Mr. Von Kohorn acknowledges that he has four children in private schools.
Some panel members said the commission's draft recommendations and summaries did not provide research that refute his charges, or give examples of how outcome-based education, as the panel defines it, would actually change a classroom, so that parents could picture how it might affect their children.
"Because we have not stood up and said what we mean, we have been defined by others, who have no good will and have no interest in what this commission is about," said State Senator Kevin Sullivan, a commission member and Senate chairman of the legislature's Education Committee.
 
Some Teachers in Opposition
 While public hearings are often a forum for critics rather than supporters, the criticism heard by commission members during the last two weeks was disconcerting because it was evidence of sharply focused opposition from two directions, not only some parents, but also teachers, as the panel sought a consensus among its own members.
That conflict threatened to create an impasse last Thursday as the commission considered a recommendation to allow school districts to extend the school year without negotiating higher salaries for teachers.
To the two teacher representatives on the 43-member commission, the proposal, along with a proposed change to the state's tenure law, was more evidence that the panel was blaming teachers for everything wrong with public education. Why should teachers finance reform by donating their time, they asked.
Other members disagreed, saying a longer year was not much to expect in return for the pay raises Connecticut teachers received in the 1980's, as part of another wave of education reform. The public would not support a reform plan now that raised salaries even more, they said.
In the end, the commission sidestepped the issue. But it raised the larger one of how much anyone was willing to spend to improve the state's schools, as the recession lingers and corporations continue to announce layoffs.
The commission's mandate was to think big. Yet the cost, to finance programs like preschooling for all children and extensive retraining for all teachers, is estimated at $600 million a year, nearly half again what the state now spends on education.
Senator Sullivan and other legislators warned that the legislature would not take the commission seriously if it recommended that price tag. Others warned that they were going through "a hollow exercise" if they did not call for enough money, especially to provide enough to give poor children in rundown city schools equal opportunities.
But the commission defeated a motion to state the full estimated cost. Instead, it is recommending a combination of grants, incentives and programs totaling $200 million.
