HEADLINE: Four Dead, and Family's Charred Dream as Well

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY

 BODY:
The fire engines had left, the scent of smoke was fading and Sonia Bishop stood on the sidewalk on Staten Island yesterday, looking up at the charred window frames of the apartment building across the street and trying to remember the sound of her son's voice.
"I miss him -- 'Mommy, Mommy, Mommy" -- said Ms. Bishop, 22, her round, youthful face tight with grief. "That's it: 'Mommy, Mommy, Mommy.' " Quivering with tears, she hugged the man next to her, and the two rocked back and forth on the slushy sidewalk. 
 In addition to killing her 8-year-old son, Jeremiah, a fire that rapidly engulfed a three-story apartment building shortly before midnight Sunday cut a jagged swath through Ms. Bishop's family, killing three others: a brother, Deray Bishop, 6; a sister, LaToya Myrick, 16, and Ms. Myrick's daughter, Keysiana, 3.
Ms. Bishop's mother and another sister escaped by jumping from third-floor windows. Ms. Bishop was not in the apartment when the fire started.
 
Flammable Finding
 Fire officials said yesterday that they found evidence of a flammable liquid on the second floor of the building, at 500 Bay Street in the Stapleton section, where they determined the fire started, and are investigating whether the fire was set. Fire officials are also investigating whether the fire had any connection to what neighbors said was frequent crack-smoking in the second-floor apartment.
Firefighter Steve King, of Ladder Company 77, said his company arrived minutes after the fire was reported at 11:47 P.M., but by then, fire and heavy smoke were shooting out of all six windows of the third-floor apartment. Firefighters who tried to make it up the stairs to rescue the children were repelled by the fire, he said. Six firefighters were injured fighting the blaze, none seriously.
Mr. King said he was fighting the fire on the roof when the firefighters reached the apartment and he heard their conversation on his radio. "I heard them say, 'We have a 1045, that's our code for a victim,' " Mr. King said. "Then they said, 'We have a second one.' It turned out that three of them were huddled on the floor and they were so badly burned that it was hard to tell it was three of them."
Jeremiah Bishop was found alone on the floor in the bathroom.
The extended family of mothers and children lived in the rundown neighborhood near the Navy's Homeport installation, which arrived in the early 1980's spreading hope of economic revitalization, but is now shutting down in a Federal budget-cutting move.
The family lived on the third floor, paying $650 for three bedrooms. The first floor once housed the Narrows Tavern, but is now vacant.
The family was headed by Ms. Bishop's mother, whose name is also Sonia Bishop.
Michael Williams, 17, who said he was a former boyfriend of LaToya Myrick, said Ms. Bishop moved her family from the Stapleton Homes housing project just over a year ago because drug dealers were threatening to use her apartment as a place of business.
"People were trying to take over her house," Mr. Williams said. "They wanted to sell drugs."
Fire officals said that when the fire started, Ms. Bishop, 46, jumped out of the front window of the apartment. She was hospitalized and was reported in stable condition yesterday with multiple cuts. Another daughter, Essence Myrick, jumped from a back window, officials said, and was in stable condition with a broken pelvis.
The younger Ms. Bishop said that her mother had complained about one of the tenants on the second floor leaving food on the stove and falling asleep. Ms. Bishop also said that her mother had had an argument with one of the tenants Sunday night about $5 the man said he wanted from her. She said the man had earlier fixed the family's heating system.
Along with trying to determine the origin of the fire, fire officials are also investigating whether the building was overcrowded. Witnesses said between 30 and 40 people left three buildings along Bay Street when the fire started.
The fire gutted the building at 500 Bay Street, and residents in the buildings on either side of it were left homeless, at least temporarily. Mary Lee Montalvo, the director of the Staten Island chapter of the Red Cross, said her agency was trying to find emergency housing for 31 people who were living in those buildings.
The building at 500 Bay Street had previously been cited for fire code violations but there was no indication of outstanding violations at the time of the fire. In July 1991 the building was ordered vacated because it was being operated as a single-room occupancy building but had no sprinkler system and did not have two exits, according to a copy of the violation notice.
Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President, who visited the fire scene yesterday, said city records indicated the building was vacated at city expense and that the violations notice was rescinded in December 1992 when the building was re-registered as a single-family residence. Such a residence does not require the same level of fire safety as an SRO.
In January 1992, the city filed a lien against the property in an attempt to collect $20,869 in relocation expenses. The lien is outstanding, according to Mr. Molinari's office.
Jacob Perlmutter, who is listed as the owner of the building, was reached yesterday in Malibu, Calif., where officials said he lives, but he refused to comment.
"Listen, I have no comment for you," he said. "Have a good day."

Map of Staten Island showing site of the fire.

HEADLINE: Suburban Towns And Politics of Salt

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 24

 BODY:
In this incorrigible winter, the most precious mineral in the communities ringing New York City has been neither gold nor diamonds but simple salt.
There was so little rock salt last week to thaw the ice-slicked roadways of New York State and New Jersey that cars skated into one another like novices at Rockefeller Center's rink. More than a few drivers were left icebound, including Paul J. Feiner, supervisor of the Westchester County town of Greenburgh, who could not get his car out of its parking space for 40 minutes so he could run the town. 
 Even today, with temperatures reaching the 40's, officials were fuming that they had too little salt to fully exploit the thaw.
"I've called Canada, I called all over and at this point I'm on a first-name basis with all the shipping clerks around the country," said Jesse D'Amore, the Hackensack, N.J., superintendent of public works.
 
Losing Out to Others
 There are a batch of reasons for the shortage, including one that qualifies as a cosmological Catch-22: trucks bringing salt from a major salt mine near Rochester cannot get to their distribution points because of unsalted roadways.
But Mr. Feiner and a number of other town officials said they have learned of another reason by talking to workers at the companies that supply them: New York State has been, well, salting away the substance for itself.
"At the storage depot, they're saying that the state takes precedence over all other local jurisdictions," said Elaine Price, the Mamaroneck supervisor.
State officials reject the charge, saying they, too are having trouble getting enough salt.
But the town officials say the state wants to make sure there is enough salt for major highways like the New York State Thruway and Route 287 in Westchester. Some note that New York City, with 40 percent of the state's population -- and voters -- has also been kept well-stocked. Indeed, Kathy Dawkins, a spokeswoman for the city's Sanitation Department, confirmed that New York City is "able to get all the salt we need" and has 40,000 tons on hand.
In short, the town officials say, suburban towns have been losing out to bigger competitors in the politics of salt.
 
Trying to Buy or Borrow
 "I don't know who's getting it, but somebody's got what there was," said Richard R. Blessing, Pelham Manor's administrator. "I didn't."
David Murray, a spokesman for New York's Department of Transportation, insisted, "We certainly are not hoarding salt."
While major highways have been kept clear, he said, some of the secondary two-lane roads throughout the state are still icy. Besides, he said, during the most bitterly cold days, when temperatures plunged below zero, salt was ineffective anyway.
"It's not political," he said.
Whatever the reasons, municipal officials like Mr. D'Amore of Hackensack and John A. Lombardi of North Castle in Westchester County were scrambling today to buy or borrow salt wherever they could find it and complaining that some suppliers were tagging on large fees for prompt delivery. At the same time, homeowners are finding few hardware stores have stocks of rock salt or any other deicers.
The city of White Plains, which typically uses 750 tons of coarse rock salt for every winter storm, has only 150 tons for the next storm, enough for major roads but not enough to assure clear side streets.
"We've been using sand for traction, but sand just creates a mess and it does nothing much for thawing," said Joseph J. Nicoletti Jr., the city's public works commissioner.
 
Distribution a Problem
 Rock salt, a coarser version of kitchen salt that lowers the freezing temperature of water, comes to New York State from three major suppliers, with most downstate localities relying on Akzo Salt Inc. Akzo, an international company with headquarters in Clarks Summit, Pa., with $10 billion in sales in 1992, also supplies much of New Jersey. State officials in Connecticut, which uses four suppliers including Akzo, said its supplies appear to be adequate for now.
In New York, 598 towns, villages, cities and school districts buy their salt through the state's contract, which allows them to make their purchases at an economical $30 a ton. Akzo's salt is mined in its Restof, N.Y., mine. Officials say the mine, 1,100 feet below ground, is the size of Manhattan and is producing enough salt even for this winter.
But, they say, distribution has been the problem. Akzo uses rail, barge and trucks to deliver the salt to depots, like the one in the Fordham section of the Bronx that most New York City suburbs tap. But the subzero temperatures, said Catherine Bolton, a spokeswoman for the company, has frozen crucial rail equipment and trucks carrying salt cannot get through on icy roads.
Moreover, she said, the demands of recent weeks have been unprecedented. All the company has been able to do, she said, is "to give it a little bit to everybody," rationing it by the amounts the various jurisdictions historically use.
She blames the towns and cities, spoiled by 10 years of mild winters, for storing enough only for two or three storms. But Mr. Lombardi, North Castle's supervisor, said large mountains of salt can create a hazardous runoff into the town's aquifers.
So drastic has the shortage become that Akzo has dispatched an armada from the Caribbean island of Bonaire, where the company harvests "solar salt," sea salt that is dehydrated in the sun.
Meanwhile, Mr. Feiner of Greenburgh has his own political way of dealing with the problem. Last Tuesday, he faxed a letter to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is seeking re-election in November, complaining that because the state was demanding priority, his town was being left with "an inadequate supply of material to guarantee the public safety."
Two days later, his town received a delivery of 100 tons of salt.

HEADLINE: Ex-Opera Manager Named To Cultural Post by Giuliani

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Calling the arts an economic engine vital to New York City's recovery, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday named a former manager of the Metropolitan Opera and dean of Columbia University's School of the Arts to be the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.
The Mayor appointed Schuyler G. Chapin, 71, who most recently served as a vice president of Steinway & Sons, to run the $85.3 million-a-year Cultural Affairs Department, which finances and oversees 31 cultural institutions on city property, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Natural History. The department also administers grants to 400 other private groups, running from large organizations like the Museum of Modern Art to smaller operations like the Boys Choir of Harlem. 
 In announcing his choice, Mr. Giuliani said advances in technology and communications had given many businesses the option of moving out of the city and thus increased the importance of the arts in attracting and holding people and companies.
"It really is the core of a great city to maintain and preserve the arts, certainly as part of the spiritual identity of the city but also because this is an important industry," Mr. Giuliani said. "This is vital to our economic renewal."
 
Subsidies and Donations
 Mr. Giuliani, who is grappling with a $2.3 billion deficit in next year's budget, said he had yet to decide whether to cut city subsidies for the arts. But he said he had asked Mr. Chapin and the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, John S. Dyson, to find ways to increase private donations to cultural institutions.
The Mayor also denied that his administration had plans to cut funds for smaller, less established theaters and museums in favor of the big institutions in Manhattan that traditionally attract tourists. Mr. Dyson drew fire from some in the art world last month when he suggested that the current roster of 431 groups getting part of the $87.3 million in city aid could be pared to offer more support to the premier institutions.
"There is no plan to cut small institutions in favor of large institutions," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, but he added that he would scrutinize all city subsidies to see whether they were used in a way that bolsters the economy and fosters excellence in the arts.
"I have to look at the entire arts budget from the point of view of how accountable is it, how effective is it, how much is it returning in terms of jobs and dollars to this city," he said.
 
Main Strategy
 For his part, Mr. Chapin said he was committed to spurring groups as diverse as the city's population. But while he said he favored city financing for smaller institutions as well as the 31 large institutions, he also warned that the city's fiscal hardships meant there would be little new money available. He said his main strategy would be to help the less established groups tap into private donations.
"Our concern is going to make certain that the quality of the small is as great and as promising and as exciting as the quality of the big, and then it will be my intention to try to help them find private funding," he said.
Several heads of cultural groups greeted Mr. Chapin's appointment with enthusiasm, saying he was regarded as an "eminence grise" in the art world, an effective spokesman for their needs.
"Schuyler Chapin is a pro," said Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society. "He's passionate about the arts and he starts with an enormous reservoir of good will from organizations in the performing and visual arts."
 
'A Real Coup'
 Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center, said Mr. Chapin, a former vice president of the center and still chairman of the center's artistic affairs committee, was internationally known and could be expected to be a strong advocate for arts groups.
"This is a guy who has entree around the world," Mr. Leventhal said. "It's a real coup for Giuliani that he got him to take the job."
Mr. Chapin, whose family has been in New York for 10 generations, was a vice president in charge of programming at Lincoln Center in the 1960's and went on to become general manager of the Metropolitan Opera from 1972 to 1975. He then took over the School of Arts at Columbia, and in his 10 years as a dean he was credited with doubling enrollment, strengthening the fine-arts curriculum and attracting more than $7 million in private donations to the school.
He is a trustee of Carnegie Hall, the Lenox Art Center and the Museum of the City of New York. Mr. Chapin has written two books, "Musical Chairs" and "Leonard Bernstein: Notes From a Friend."

HEADLINE: Health Plan's Foes Tap Well of Public Fear

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton passed through town two months ago campaigning on behalf of health care reform, but "Libby" and "Louise" are on the airwaves now, courtesy of the latest advertising campaign of the Health Insurance Association of America.
Interested in health care reform but worried about the Clinton plan, the two appealing actresses share their fears again and again with the television viewers of Georgia. 
 As the interest groups in the struggle over health care recognize, it is not hard to find -- or to stoke -- hesitation and doubt on the issue these days. Four months after President Clinton outlined his vision of "health care that's always there," and as he prepares to try to rally the nation once again with his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, the debate has moved into the confused and worrisome realm of programs and mandates and vast structural changes.
Atlanta, the capital of a region that so often tilts the balance of power on Capitol Hill, is a microcosm of the difficulties now facing the Clintons.
Like many lawmakers, Representative John Lewis, a liberal Democrat who represents Atlanta, spent much of the Congressional recess meeting with representatives of hospitals, various health provider groups and a wide swath of the public. And, he said, he will return to Washington convinced that "the great majority of people want us to do something." But Mr. Lewis, who is a co-sponsor in the House of both the President's bill and a Canadian-style, single-payer plan, adds that there is another undercurrent: "People are concerned. They don't want to lose what they have."
That fear is at the heart of many of the warnings being directed toward the public and their elected representatives here these days by hospitals and doctors, insurance companies and drug companies and a host of other interests.
The Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group representing 270 companies that provide coverage for 55 million people, is financing a commercial in Georgia and 13 other states in which "Libby" worries about "these mandatory government health alliances" that would serve as middlemen between consumers and health plans. Her friend "Louise" tells her the alliances would restrict the choice of health plans available to people (an assertion that Administration officials reject).
Dr. Roy W. Vandiver, president of the Medical Association of Georgia, which is aggressively presenting its views on a health care overhaul, worries that the Clinton plan would inevitably restrict the patient's choice of doctor (another assertion the Administration rejects). A pamphlet by the state medical association lists as "things that could hurt our patients" both a single-payer system and "any plan that would restrict Georgians' freedom of choice of doctors, place of treatment or type of insurance."
The political counterbalance to all these accusations and all these fears, of course, is the promise of universal health care. Mr. Clinton's strategists are counting on that promise to be so appealing and so desirable that it sweeps away everything in its path.
But Mr. Lewis, who was in the forefront of the 1960's struggle for the right to vote and the right to public accommodations, said he worried that the Clintons and their allies have yet to galvanize a majority of Americans around the notion of health care as a right. "A lot of convincing remains," he says. "They've got to spend a lot of time during the spring educating people, mobilizing the country, getting people to buy into the the idea that in order to have a healthy nation, a productive work force, we've got to have healthy people."
Moreover, universal coverage carries a political catch of its own, particularly in this region. In the Clinton plan, it is achieved by requiring employers to contribute to the cost of their workers' insurance -- the so-called employer mandate. This raises alarms among conservative Southern Democrats like Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia.
 
Rival Proposals
 "I'm dubious about it," Mr. Nunn says, "for the jobs we're trying to create, and particularly because it's going to squeeze out the marginal worker." Administration official sassert that their plan would cushion the economic impact of the employer mandate with a system of subsidies to small companies. But Mr. Nunn is a co-sponsor of a rival plan in the Senate, a version of the more conservative managed-competition plan advanced in the House by Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee. The Cooper plan, like the Clinton version, would blend regulation with market forces but would stop short of promising universal coverage and would not require an employer mandate.
"I think more and more people are saying it's got be done a step at a time," Mr. Nunn argued. "It's too big, too complicated. Cost projections are too uncertain to roll the dice and bet on estimates when you're really betting about one-sixth of the gross national product."
 
Resistance in South
 Merle Black, an expert on Southern politics at Emory University, said Southern Democrats may particularly resist an employer mandate. "One of the reasons that the Southern Democratic party has survived as long as it has is that many small business people continue to do business with the Democratic Party," Mr. Black said. "All that makes Southern democrats particularly susceptible to looking for an alternative" to the Clinton plan.
Robert Blendon, a specialist in public opinion and health at Harvard University, also notes that the South has some of the higher percentages of uninsured.
Mr. Nunn predicts that the Clinton plan "will have to be scaled back" and ultimately blended with rival plans, including Mr. Cooper's.
That leads to another important dynamic of the current health care debate: it is turning into a remarkably complicated discussion of rival proposals that, some analysts suggest, leaves the public behind.
Beverly Tyler, executive director of Georgia Health Decisions, a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization that has spent two years talking to 6,000 Georgians about the health care system, worries that the public here is simply not prepared for a deeply politicized debate on this issue.
"It's a difficult issue for people to get their arms around when you talk to them about specific reform proposals," Ms. Tyler said. "They are so overwhelmed by them and so confused by them that the fear factor sets in."
She added: "We know from talking to people that they are angry about prices, that they want something to be done. But now they're reacting to, 'omigod, someone's going to tell us what we have to have.' "
 
Support Expected to Grow
 Former Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, who is heading the Clinton campaign's outreach effort, predicted in a telephone interview that the grass-roots campaign on behalf of the President's plan would escalate in the weeks to come as it becomes more organized. "It's a big effort," Mr. Celeste said. "It's so much easier to do a brief mischaracterization of the program."
Moreover, a Georgia coalition of health care professionals, business, labor, civic and other groups will announce its formation next week to push for a "comprehensive" overhaul of the health care system. The group, loosely affiliated with the National Health Care Reform Project, a nonpartisan coalition in Washington, is dedicated to a set of broad principles, like universal coverage, said Pat Ford-Roegner, one of its organizers.
"What we were talking about the other day at our meeting is the fact that there is this growing feeling that those who oppose change or want to slow it down want people to say I'm fine, I'm happy, everything's O.K. for me," said Ms. Ford-Roegner, a consultant and a nurse. "And this group, particularly the health care professionals, sees what happens when people are undercovered or one step away from being uncovered."
Mr. Lewis, meanwhile, says he continues to worry. Describing the "Libby" and "Louise" commercial this week, he said with a short laugh, "To me it's a very effective piece, very convincing."

Vandiver, president of the Medical Association of Georgia, which is aggressively presenting its views on a health care overhaul, said he worried that the Clinton plan would inevitably restrict the patient's choice of doctor. The Administration rejects that assertion. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times) (pg. D21)

HEADLINE: Farrakhan Is Warned Over Aide's Invective

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Four months after warily embracing Louis Farrakhan, the minister of the Nation of Islam, a number of prominent blacks are now urging him to distance himself from anti-Semitic comments made by a senior aide.
In recent days, Benjamin Chavis, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and William H. Gray 3d, president of the United Negro College Fund, have condemned comments made two months ago by Khalid Abdul Muhammad, an aide to Mr. Farrakhan, in a speech at Kean College in Union, N.J. 
Last Friday, Representative Kweisi Mfume, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Congressional Black Caucus, wrote Mr. Farrakhan to ask if Mr. Muhammad's remarks reflected the official position of the black Muslim group. "It was extremely agonizing for me to even read what I read," Mr. Mfume said of excerpts of Mr. Muhammad's remarks.
Taken with comments made in an interview on Sunday by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the criticism of the anti-Semitic statements represents a forceful denunciation by established leaders of prominent black groups.
 
Harsh Criticism
 Some prominent blacks have said the sharp tone of the recent denunciations stems in part from the outrageousness of Mr. Muhammad's remarks. But some say they also stem from a need to distance themselves from the Nation of Islam.
The criticism from Mr. Mfume is particularly significant because he has been trying to forge a partnership between the Black Caucus and the Nation of Islam, which advocates economic power and discipline for blacks.
In a Nov. 29 speech full of invective and coarse language, Mr. Muhammad lashed out at Jews, calling them the "blood suckers of the black nation" who "crucified Jesus in a kangaroo court" and who control the financial system, including the Federal Reserve.
Last week, after the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith ran what it said were excerpts from the speech in a full-page advertisement in The New York Times, Mr. Chavis condemned Mr. Muhammad's remarks. In an address at the National Museum of Natural History in Washington, he said anti-Semitism was a "virulent strand of racism that must not go unchallenged."
Referring directly to Mr. Muhammad's comments, Mr. Chavis said he "was appalled that any human being would stoop so low to make such violence-prone anti-Semitic comments."
In a speech in Philadelphia on Jan. 16 to commemorate the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Gray was equally strong in denouncing Mr. Muhammad's comments.
"We must be clear that at no time can we tolerate racism and anti-Semitism, nor can it be justified as a response to repression," the former Pennsylvania Congressman said. "Martin taught us better than that. I am talking specifically about the tragic and anti-Semitic comments that occurred at Kean College a few weeks ago."
In denouncing Mr. Muhammad, several black leaders today said they were hopeful that Mr. Farrakhan would distance himself from the comments of his subordinate. Some commentators have suggested in recent weeks that Mr. Farrakhan, who a decade ago called Judaism a "gutter religion," has moderated his views. In a speech in New York last month, Mr. Farrakhan reiterated his message of black pride but denied being racist or anti-Semitic.
In a telephone interview today, Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat, said that from reading the transcripts of Mr. Muhammad's remark, "clearly, we're dealing with a person who is very dangerous, bitter and, in my opinion, very sick."
In September, Mr. Mfume announced that the caucus would enter into a "covenant" to work with Mr. Farrakhan on legislative concerns and would work with the Nation of Islam just as it would work with other black groups. Saying he wanted to bring about a more formalized working relationship with the Nation of Islam, Mr. Mfume said he was motivated by the idea of unifying the disparate parts of the black political spectrum.
Today, Mr. Mfume said he wrote Mr. Farrakhan because he worried about the effect Mr. Muhammad's comments would have on efforts to begin working with the Nation of Islam.
Mr. Mfume said he had yet to receive a response from Mr. Farrakhan, and he would not speculate on what he would do if the answer was that Mr. Muhammad's views accurately reflected Mr. Farrakhan's.
The affiliation with the Nation of Islam has caused the caucus some embarrassment. Soon after the announcement of a covenant with the organization was announced it was denounced by Jewish groups.
Tensions between Jewish groups and the caucus were eased after Mr. Mfume met with officials from Jewish organizations and told them of the caucus's need to form partnership with groups representing diverse opinions.
Still, a number of senior members of the Black Caucus stressed today that the 40-member group of black lawmakers had never officially ratified the partnership with the Nation of Islam. "I don't think it was ever an official position of the caucus," said Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia. "It was a statement made during a town meeting last September during the black caucus meeting. I don't think a great majority of the caucus ever saw ourselves engaged in any type of partnership or covenant with Minister Farrakhan."

HEADLINE: Anti-Abortion Protests To Continue, Groups Say

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Anti-abortion groups say they will not be stopped by a Supreme Court decision yesterday allowing the Federal racketeering law to be used against protesters who block access to abortion clinics.
"We will continue our activities that save lives," said Wendy Wright, communications director of Operation Rescue National. "For us, this is the same old thing. For years, we've faced massive lawsuits and horrendous jail sentences. But we're accountable to God, not to the Government, and as long as people believe it's right to save unborn children, they'll be willing to pay the price." 
 That price may be much higher now, though. Under the racketeering law, the Racketeering-Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, groups that conspire to break the law can be found liable for triple damages. The Court ruled that RICO could be applied to ideologically motivated crimes as well as economically motivated crimes.
"To be honest, now that RICO can be used against us, anyone who gets a newsletter can be culpable," Ms. Wright said in a telephone interview from Melbourne, Fla. "At one point, a judge in Washington ordered that anyone who donated to Operation Rescue could be liable for fines. But even people who oppose Operation Rescue realized that was going too far."
 
Concern Over Peaceful Protests
 Ms. Wright expressed concern that the High Court's ruling would be used even against peaceful protesters. Of the 200 defendants named in the RICO case, she said, most had done nothing more than pray peacefully on the sidewalk in front of clinics.
"It's blatantly false that this is only against violent activities," she asserted. Referring to a demonstration at an abortion clinic in Melbourne, Ms. Wright said: "There were 150 people arrested for kneeling and praying. I was praying on a grassy public area, with one other person. I weigh 100 pounds and I couldn't block anyone if I wanted to. But I was arrested for that."
Now that the Supreme Court has ruled that the racketeering law can be used in cases involving political demonstrations, the National Organization for Women, which brought the case, will have to go back to the Federal court in Chicago and prove that illegal acts occurred.
Joseph Scheidler, executive director of the Pro-Life Action League who was the first named defendant in the case, said he welcomed that chance to go to court and prove his innocence.
"I think this is a step toward the downfall of RICO," Mr. Scheidler said in a statement issued in Chicago yesterday. "We are not racketeers and we are not going to back down from our pro-life activities. If anything, we'll step it up. Social protest is at the heart of what America stands for, and has been since the Boston Tea Party."
Mr. Scheidler and other anti-abortion leaders said they had not yet begun to think about the possible impact of RICO damages.
"That's the furthest thing from my mind right now," Mr. Scheidler said. "We haven't been found guilty of anything yet. I don't know what damages they could show or what they could take. We don't own the office, I don't own my home, and if they want the fax machine, they're welcome to it."
The National Right to Life Committee stressed in a prepared statement that it does not endorse any illegal acts, but those at the group's headquarters said yesterday that they would not discuss how the Court's decision might affect its members.
Many anti-abortion leaders said yesterday that the Court's decision would probably lead to the use of the anti-racketeering law against other kinds of groups that used civil disobedience to force social change.
 
Warning to Other Protesters
 "Under this decision, Martin Luther King Jr. would have been a racketeer," said Randall Terry, the founder of Operation Rescue, who now has a daily radio show that is broadcast from Binghamton, N.Y., on 31 Christian-oriented stations. "What I'd say to the AIDS activists, the anti-nuclear groups, the animal-rights people, is get your affairs in order and line up, because you're next."
Mr. Terry, who like Mr. Scheidler is a defendant in the RICO case, vowed to continue his anti-abortion work but conceded that yesterday's ruling might scare off those who were less committed to stopping abortions.
"We're going to go on doing what we do," he said. "The leaders aren't going to change. This is an effort to intimidate the rank and file so they won't associate with us. And for some people, that may work. But we're going to see who's brave and who listens to God, not to man."

LENGTH: 1063 words

HEADLINE: Court Rules Abortion Clinics Can Use Rackets Law to Sue

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that abortion clinics can invoke the Federal racketeering law to sue violent anti-abortion protest groups for damages.
The opinion, written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, gives abortion clinics a potentially powerful legal weapon -- including the prospect of triple damages -- to combat and possibly to deter the violence that has made it increasingly risky and expensive for the clinics to stay in business. 
 The issue in the case decided today did not concern abortion itself, but rather was about how broadly to interpret the Federal racketeering law.
Abortion-rights groups hailed the ruling as a significant victory, although it leaves abortion clinics with the task of proving the allegations in an eight-year-old lawsuit that the decision reinstated.
In the suit, the National Organization for Women is accusing Operation Rescue and several other groups and individuals of running a nationwide conspiracy to drive abortion clinics from business through a campaign of intimidation, bombings and other violent acts.
While there is no doubt that bombings, vandalism, harassment of staff members and other acts have occurred, the plaintiffs have to prove in court that the acts were part of a "pattern of racketeering activity" undertaken by the groups and individuals named in the lawsuit.
Anti-abortion groups condemned the Court, branding its ruling "a vulgar betrayal of over 200 years of tolerance toward protest and civil disobedience," as Randall A. Terry, the founder of Operation Rescue and a defendant in the suit, said today.
Two lower Federal courts in Chicago had dismissed the suit on the ground that the Racketeer-Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, the Federal law known as RICO, applied only to activities motivated by a desire for economic gain. In dismissing the suit in 1992, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, said the defendants' actions as described in the suit had been "reprehensible" but had a political and ideological motive rather than an economic goal.
 
No Economic Motive Required
 But Chief Justice Rehnquist said Congress had not included an economic motive requirement when it passed the racketeering law in 1970. Noting that an economic motive requirement was "neither expressed nor, we think, fairly implied" in the law, the Chief Justice said, "We believe the statutory language is unambiguous."
The decision, National Organization for Women v. Scheidler, No. 92-780, was the latest in a long list of Supreme Court rulings to give a broad interpretation to the RICO law, which Congress had passed to combat the infiltration of legitimate businesses by organized crime. The law quickly became popular as a useful tool in business disputes and other contexts far removed from organized crime.
The Court has expressed discomfort with this development but has frequently declared that any limitations in the vaguely written law had to be placed there by Congress, not by Federal judges. It was evident when the Court heard arguments in the case last month that a majority of the Justices was prepared to let this suit proceed.
The racketeering law makes it illegal to conduct the "affairs" of an "enterprise" through a "pattern of racketeering activity." A pattern is established by proof of at least two actions that violate any of a number of state and Federal crimes; an actual criminal conviction is not necessary.
In this case, the Seventh Circuit found that the allegations, if proved, would show that the defendants' pattern of intimidation, threats, trespassing and vandalism had violated the Hobbs Act, the Federal extortion law.
But the appellate court then went on to conclude that the anti-abortion groups did not constitute the required "enterprise" because, as used in the law, that word meant an association with a profit motive. Chief Justice Rehnquist said today that the word "enterprise" meant nothing more than an "association in fact," regardless of motive.
In addition to Operation Rescue and Mr. Terry, the lawsuit also named the Pro-Life Action League Inc. and its leader, Joseph Scheidler; the Pro-Life Direct Action League, Project Life and several other individuals.
 
Class-Action Status Sought
 The National Organization for Women filed the lawsuit on behalf of two abortion clinics, the Delaware Women's Health Organization in Wilmington and the Summit Women's Health Organization in Milwaukee. NOW is seeking to have the case certified as a class-action lawsuit representing clinics across the country. The Federal District Court in Chicago had not ruled on that request when it dismissed the lawsuit in 1991.
In their briefs, the defendants warned the Supreme Court that the effect of permitting RICO suits would be to curb legitimate political protest and the free speech rights of peaceful demonstrators. Briefs filed for the clinics contended that because of the requirement of two criminal acts, lawsuits based on RICO would have no effect on peaceful protests.
"When they picket, when they pray, when they leaflet, when they petition Congress," anti-abortion groups are protected by the First Amendment, Fay Clayton, the lawyer representing the National Organization for Women, told the Court during arguments last month.
Noting this dispute today, Chief Justice Rehnquist said the case at this stage did not raise a First Amendment question for the Court to decide. But Justice David H. Souter, in a concurring opinion also signed by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, addressed the free-speech issue more directly.
The ruling today "does not bar First Amendment challenges to RICO's application in particular cases," Justice Souter wrote. He said he agreed that the case at this stage did not raise such an issue, but added, "I think it prudent to notice that RICO actions could deter protected advocacy and to caution courts applying RICO to bear in mind the First Amendment interests that could be at stake."
Last week the Court agreed to hear another abortion protest case that directly poses the First Amendment question. That case, Madsen v. Women's Health Center, No. 93-880, to be argued in April, is a free-speech challenge by anti-abortion demonstrators to an injunction that a judge issued to create a protest-free buffer zone at an abortion clinic in Melbourne, Fla.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Lower in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mostly lower yesterday as traders and investors said they were leery of trading ahead of President Clinton's State of the Union address tonight and Government note auctions today and Wednesday.
Charles E. Rhoden, a managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross described yesteray's market as "dull, dull and duller." 
 "Presently there is a tremendous difference of views in the market," he said. "Some investors are of the opinion that interest rates are going higher, others say they are going lower with traders waiting on day-to-day events."
 
Concern on Tokyo Stocks
 In the morning, traders were concerned that the overnight plunge in the Tokyo stock market would prompt a Japanese selloff of Treasury securities to raise cash. But the selling never materialized, traders said. The Nikkei index fell 954.19 points, or 4.9 percent, to 18,353.24.
Given the lack of new economic reports, the market focused on the Commodity Research Bureau index. The index, a closely watched but not always reliable barometer of inflationary pressure, rose 0.85 point, to 226.13. The price of the March contract for light crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 23 cents a barrel, to $15.17, and the February gold contract on the Commodity Exchange fell 30 cents, to $381.40 an ounce.
By late in the day the price of the 30-year bond fell 1/3, to 9911/32 for a yield of 6.30 percent, up from 6.27 percent on Friday.
A Federal Reserve governor, Edward W. Kelly Jr., said in a Knight-Ridder interview that he saw only a moderate slowdown in first quarter growth compared with the strong fourth- quarter pace at the end of last year.
 
Change in Calculations
 However, for the year as a whole, growth should be slightly better than 1993, because the "headwinds" are diminishing, he said. He warned that the change in the Labor Department's method of calculating the unemployment rate would keep the Fed from getting a good reading on the jobless conditions over the near term.
Some analysts think this week's market is being partly shaped by the expectation of two economic reports toward the end of the week -- December's durable goods orders and the fourth-quarter gross domestic product -- both expected to register strong gains.
Economists are forecasting that the durable goods orders report on Thursday will show a 1.5 percent gain for December, its fourth consecutive monthly gain, while gross domestic product is expected to be about 5.4 or 5.5 percent. One analyst said that if the number turned out to be the 6 percent that Vice President Al Gore had mentioned, it could provoke some heavy selling.
But all agree that the issue in the market now is not how strong the fourth quarter was, but how much growth will slow in the first quarter.
 
Budget Report Delayed
 The report on the December budget deficit that was scheduled yesterday was postponed a day by the Treasury because the Government was shut down last Thursday in Washington as a result of the cold weather.
There was little trading in two-year notes ahead of today's auction. In when issued-trading, the two-year note showed a yield of 4.10 percent, while the five-year notes to be auctioned on Wednesday had a yield of 5.06 percent.
The Treasury's auction of bills yesterday was well received, traders said. The average rate for a three-month bill was 2.96 percent, down from 2.99 percent last week, while the rate for a six-month bill was 3.14 percent, down from 3.15 percent.

HEADLINE: A Tug-of-War on Bank Regulation

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Companies lobby the Government all the time, but in recent weeks the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department have turned the tables by lobbying the banks they regulate.
The Fed and the Administration are at war over Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen's plans to change the way banks and savings and loans are regulated. Both sides are actively seeking the political support of financial institutions whose regulatory fortunes and futures they control. 
 The dispute has produced the surprising spectacle of officials of the Fed and the Treasury condemning one another's ideas in speeches, news conferences and talks with bankers.
 
'When the Elephants Dance'
 The dispute has alarmed some in the banking community and sent bankers and trade groups scurrying to the sidelines. "I have a very strong aversion to being a daisy when the elephants dance," said Karen D. Shaw, a bank consultant here.
Treasury officials are waging an aggressive campaign. Eugene Ludwig, a Treasury official who is the Clinton Administration's top bank regulator, helped present the Treasury's case this month to a group that included top executives from some banks he oversees.
The Fed has also been active. Thomas M. Hoenig, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, condemned the Treasury's position in a speech to the Kansas Bankers Association earlier this month. He gently reminded his audience of the Fed's help in recent years in keeping some of them financially afloat, while refraining from actually suggesting that bankers owed the Fed a favor or that more help might be forthcoming.
 
Showing Its Strength
 Few modern institutions can match the raw political muscles of the Fed, although its fist is seldom seen. The Fed is now flexing its muscles as they have not been flexed in years, and appears so far to be winning its battle with the Treasury.
The Fed is making its first broad appeal to commercial bankers for political support since 1977, when it successfully fought an effort by the Carter Administration and some Congressional Democrats to reduce the influence of the Fed's regional banks. The next year, the Fed also blocked a proposal by Senate Democrats for a single bank regulatory agency, a proposal strikingly similar to the Clinton Administration's current proposal.
Under the Treasury's proposal, the bank supervisory powers of the Fed and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would be taken over by a single Federal Banking Commission. The commission would also take over the Treasury's two bank monitoring arms, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Office of Thrift Supervision. The Treasury and the Fed would each supply one director to the commission's five-member board, while the President would appoint the three remaining directors.
Treasury officials describe this as a way to eliminate wasteful multiple regulatory reviews of the same banks. But they have offered no estimates of cost savings and the Congressional Budget Office says any savings would be quite small.
Under the Treasury plan, the F.D.I.C. would continue to handle deposit insurance and the Fed would continue to handle monetary policy as well as emergency loans to distressed banks and money transfers between institutions.
Mr. Greenspan and the other six Fed governors have rejected the Treasury's plan as a threat not only to their turf but also to their ability to run monetary policy and prevent financial crises.
The Fed offered its own proposal early this month for a system that would give it the bank supervisory powers of the F.D.I.C., while combining the Treasury's two agencies in a separate office. By keeping at least two regulators in place, the Fed plan would allow banks to continue their practice of choosing their regulators based on which one will give the most lenient treatment.
The fight is also complicated by controversy over President Clinton's involvement in an Arkansas real estate company, Whitewater Development, and his possible ties to an Arkansas savings and loan that failed while he was governor of the state.
 
Alarm on Wall Street
 The quarrel between the Fed and the Treasury has begun to alarm some Wall Street economists who are trying to figure out if it will engulf monetary policy and affect the economy. For example, if the battle continues, the Fed, seeking to maintain cordial relations with Congress, might be tempted to delay any inflation-fighting move to raise interest rates this spring, said David M. Jones, a longtime Fed watcher at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York.
But Fed and Treasury officials say they can contain the damage and keep their differences about bank regulation from interfering with consultations on monetary policy. "We have a lot of different levels on which we work with the Administration," said Susan M. Phillips, a governor on the Fed's seven-member board.
Secretary Bentsen said the fight had not affected his overall relations with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. "I have a great deal of respect for Chairman Greenspan; we are longtime friends -- it has not interfered with our tennis games or our breakfasts," he said.
John P. LaWare, a Fed governor and former commercial banker who is directing the Fed's battle, said the Fed was not asking banks to lobby Congress, which would be illegal. Instead, it is presenting its side of the case to decision makers.
The Fed has already given its views to the chairman and vice chairman of each of the Fed's 12 regional banks and will soon present its case to all other members of each nine-member board, Mr. LaWare said.
 
Influential Backers
 These board members have long been the Fed's most influential backers, including the chairmen of many of the biggest financial and industrial companies. "By law, we cannot ask anyone else to lobby on our behalf," Mr. LaWare said. "We can brief the boards. What they do as individuals is entirely up to them."
Mr. LaWare said that Fed governors would also be ready to present their views to the boards of banks if asked about the fight. "We often sit in on board meetings, and I'm sure that will be a topic of discussion," he said.
Fed officials make no attempt to disguise their effort to appeal to commercial bankers, who have historically wielded considerable influence over the fate of banking legislation. Mr. LaWare, for example, said that he chose to disclose the Fed's plans early this month in an opinion column in The American Banker, a daily industry newspaper, because he thought more bankers would see it there than elsewhere.
 
One Complaint
 When asked about the Fed's appeals to bankers, Mr. Bentsen complained that "they're in a position to have a lot of influence over bankers."
The Fed and the Treasury have been lobbying Congress aggressively for weeks. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat on the House Banking Committee, said Mr. Bentsen called him earlier this month and Mr. Greenspan visited him the next day. "When he's coming here, you know it's important to the Fed," Mr. Schumer said.
The Treasury has also sought to enlist support from financial institutions, including some that it regulates. Mr. Ludwig said he and Frank Newman, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, presented the Treasury's case recently to a group from the Independent Bankers Association of America, a trade group of small banks.
Mr. Ludwig said that it was the trade group's decision to send to the meeting a delegation that included several bankers whom he regulates, and that he had avoided calling bankers individually for support.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ziff to Offer A Computer Data Service

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS

 BODY:
The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, seeking to take advantage of its strength in computer publications, said yesterday that it would create an electronic information service that it hoped would become a model for publishing in the electronic age.
Ziff-Davis will provide the contents of its magazines -- including PC Magazine, PC Computing, PC Week, Mac User, Mac Week, Computer Shopper and Computer Gaming World -- in the new publishing service, the Interchange Online Network. 
 "There's no reason we can't expand outside the computer industry in time," said Rob Lippincott, vice president of Ziff-Davis Interactive, the Cambridge, Mass., company that is developing the system. He said tests of the service would begin within six weeks and would gradually expand to include "tens of thousands" of testers by midsummer.
The company plans to offer nationwide commercial service in the fall. Prices have not been set but probably will be $10 to $15 a month for basic services, plus an hourly fee for extended use, Mr. Lippincott said.
Ziff-Davis is one of several companies trying to establish beachheads in the emerging consumer market for electronic data.
 
'Piling Into the Market'
 "People are absolutely piling into the market right now," said Mary Modahl, who analyzes interactive information services for Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. She noted that both A.T.& T. and Apple Computer Inc. recently announced plans for networks. She suggested that more companies, including the Microsoft Corporation and Ziff-Davis's rival the International Data Group of Framingham, Mass., were also preparing to enter the fray.
The market is now dominated by Compuserve Information Services of Columbus, Ohio, a division of H & R Block of Kansas City, Mo., and Prodigy Services Inc. of White Plains, jointly owned by I.B.M.Sears, Roebuck. Compuserve and Prodigy have more than a million subscribers each.
Ziff-Davis already offers much of the content of its computer magazines and periodicals over an information service called Ziffnet, which is carried by Compuserve, Prodigy and Applelink, an electronic information service operated by Apple Computer.
A spokeswoman for Compuserve said Ziffnet had nearly 200,000 subscribers on Compuserve alone, with most paying a surcharge for access to the Ziff-Davis data base.
Mr. Lippincott said there were no plans to alter Ziff-Davis's agreements to sell Ziffnet to rival services. But he said the technical superiority of the Interchange software, coupled with the full complement of Ziff's data bases, would be very attractive to the computer-savvy audience Interchange was seeking.
"I think it's war," said Joshua M. Harris, president of the Jupiter Communications Company, a market research company in New York. "While Ziff is happy to take money from Prodigy and Compuserve, at every turn they are going to try to get Ziffnet customers and potential customers to switch over."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Political Turmoil in Japan Strengthens Dollar vs. Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended firmer against the Japanese yen yesterday as fears about Japan's political future temporarily eclipsed worries over chilly trade relations between the United States and Japan.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 111.80 yen, from 111.55 yen on Friday. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices slipped. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery fell 30 cents, to $381.40 an ounce.
 
 
Reaction to Parliament Vote
 Traders dumped yen for dollars overnight after Japanese stock prices dropped sharply in response to Friday's parliamentary vote against an electoral-reform bill backed by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa.
Mr. Hosokawa had staked much on passage of the bill, and many analysts now wonder if Japan's fragile governing coalition can survive. With the Japanese Government in disarray, they fear Japanese leaders will be unable to pass a stimulus plan to spur the nation's listless economy.
With the focus on Japan's political problems, there was little immediate reaction to news that Sunday's meeting by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Mr. Hosokawa and the Japanese Finance Minister, Hirohisa Fujii, ended with neither progress on trade nor overt confrontation.
Usually, a stalemate on trade favors the yen on speculation that Washington will push for a stronger Japanese currency to trim Tokyo's trade surplus if other methods fail.
"Everyone is cognizant of trade issues. But Hosokawa's problems and worries over the stimulus package are all fresh factors in the market," John Nelson of Barclays Bank said.
But dealers said that could change if the White House started talking tougher on trade.
The dollar drifted against European currencies in listless trade. Dealers said they were awaiting United States economic data and further clues on Germany's inflation outlook later this week before taking new positions. Inflation data from one major West German region showed price increases moderating in early January.
 
Dollar at 1.7495 Marks
 The dollar fell to 1.7495 marks in late New York trading from 1.7524 marks late Friday. And the British pound closed in New York at $1.4945, up from $1.4917 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4660 Swiss francs, down from 1.4674 francs; 5.9325 French francs, down from 5.9470 francs, $1.3115 (Canadian), up from $1.3113 (Canadian), and 1,706 Italian lire, unchanged.

HEADLINE: Oliver Smith, Set Designer, Dead at 75

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON

 BODY:
Oliver Smith, one of the most prolific and imaginative designers in the history of the American theater and a former co-director of American Ballet Theater, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 75.
The cause was emphysema, said Richard D'Arcy, a friend. 
 Mr. Smith's theatrical activities were dazzlingly protean. He designed such Broadway hits as "Brigadoon," "West Side Story," "My Fair Lady," "Camelot" and "Hello, Dolly!" and major ballets by such choreographers as Jerome Robbins, Agnes de Mille and Eliot Feld. He was equally at home in operas and films. By his own estimation in an interview, he had designed more than 250 productions by 1966.
Mr. Smith also taught scenic design at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University for 22 years, until last Thursday. Mary Schmidt Campbell, dean of the arts school, said yesterday that he was regarded as "a cornerstone of the design department."
Over the last 50 years Mr. Smith was a co-producer of shows ranging from lighthearted musicals to serious intellectual dramas. He became co-director of Ballet Theater with Lucia Chase in 1945 and helped the troupe -- now known as American Ballet Theater -- to attain international eminence. When Miss Chase retired in 1980, he stepped down, too, but served again as co-director with Jane Hermann from 1990 to 1992, when he was named director emeritus.
Mr. Smith knew a great deal about architecture and was an accomplished painter. He studied architecture at Pennsylvania State University, where he received a bachelor's degree in 1939. His paintings have been shown in exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum, the Chicago Art Institute and other institutions.
 
'You Can Get Smith For Anything'
 His versatility as a designer led the producer David Merrick to say of him in 1965: "Most designers are masters of a single color. So if the basic color of your show is red, you get so-and-so; if it's green, you get somebody else. You can get Smith for anything."
Mr. Smith was a master of styles as well as colors. His sets for "West Side Story" (1957) were somber cityscapes that had some of the austerity of paintings by Ben Shahn. In contrast, several scenes of "Flower Drum Song" (1958) looked as exquisite as classic Chinese prints. For "Les Noces," choreographed for Ballet Theater in 1965 by Mr. Robbins to the monumental choral score by Stravinsky, Mr. Smith designed a backdrop dominated by stern ascetic figures resembling sacred icons. For "Camelot," the 1960 musical about King Arthur, which Mr. Smith considered his most elaborate production, he conjured up a fairy-tale vision of the Middle Ages with parks, terraces, jousting fields and castles in colors that ranged from soft pastels to sumptuous gold.
Perhaps Mr. Smith's most visually striking, theatrically resourceful and symbolically meaningful balletic setting is the one he devised in 1948 for "Fall River Legend," Miss de Mille's dance drama about Lizzie Borden. From a few architectural shapes and a staircase, Mr. Smith suggested both a New England house and a family atmosphere of smug and stifling rectitude. When the house swung around in one scene, it was instantly transformed into a church. But in the ballet's grim finale the set split and vanished, leaving only a gallows onstage.
Mr. Smith was born in Waupun, Wis., on Feb. 13, 1918. His family moved to Niagara Falls, N.Y.; when he was 3 and later settled in Wellsboro, Pa. Shortly after his graduation from college, and armed with a portfolio of paintings, drawings and architectural sketches, Mr. Smith moved to New York City.
He shared a house in Brooklyn Heights with other talented young artists, including the composer Benjamin Britten and the writers W. H. Auden, Carson McCullers and Richard Wright. In their division of chores, he served as dishwasher and furnace man.
He later bought and restored a four-story Federal-style house in Brooklyn Heights and used its attic as his studio. Over the years, several of its rooms served as the residence of illustrious house guests, including the theatrical director Sir Tyrone Guthrie and Truman Capote, who wrote "In Cold Blood" there.
Sheer gumption led to Mr. Smith's first theatrical commission. One day in 1941, he read in a newspaper that Leonide Massine, the Russian-born choreographer who was then associated with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, was in need of a scenic designer for a work in progress, "Saratoga." In an outburst of bravado, Mr. Smith, a total unknown, rushed to the Ballet Russe offices with his portfolio and managed to get an interview with Massine. The choreographer liked his work and hired him.
"Saratoga," a comedy about love and horse racing, was a failure. But Mr. Smith's bright sets were admired and Ballet Russe soon hired him again, for what became one of the smash hits of 20th-century ballet, "Rodeo." In 1942, Mr. Smith designed the corral, ranch house and sun-baked prairie for Miss de Mille's western ballet to a memorable score by Aaron Copland. Companies still dance it, always with Mr. Smith's decor.
Mr. Smith began his long association with Ballet Theater in 1944, and once again made history. He designed a waterfront bar for "Fancy Free," a ballet about sailors on shore leave, which catapulted Mr. Robbins, its choreographer, and its composer, Leonard Bernstein, to fame.
 
Other de Mille And Robbins Projects
 In addition to "Fall River Legend" and "Les Noces," Mr. Smith collaborated on other ballets with Miss de Mille and Mr. Robbins, among them Miss de Mille's "Rib of Eve" and "The Four Marys" and Mr. Robbins's "Facsimile," "Interplay" and "Age of Anxiety."
Among the other dance productions he designed were "Harbinger," Eliot Feld's much-praised first ballet, which received its premiere in 1967; Michael Kidd's "On Stage!" and Martha Graham's "Gospel of Eve."
As a co-director of Ballet Theater, Mr. Smith left the day-to-day running of the company to Miss Chase and, later, to Mrs. Hermann. Yet his presence was felt. In "Lizzie Borden: A Dance of Death" (1968), Miss de Mille's account of the creation of "Fall River Legend," she wrote that Mr. Smith's chief function was that of catalyst. "He brings talents together, fusing them, providing the atmosphere in which they can ignite," she wrote. "He is a master of dynamics, which is the reason he has served well as co-director of Ballet Theater."
Although the company was often in financial peril, Mr. Smith always encouraged choreographers. In 1957, he helped supervise the Ballet Theater Workshop, which produced new ballets on shoestring budgets. In 1981 he administered, with Richard Englund, a comparable project called the Emerging Artists Laboratory.
But no matter how deeply involved he was in ballet, Mr. Smith always found time to return to the theater. The long list of major Broadway productions he designed includes "High-Button Shoes," "Miss Liberty," "Paint Your Wagon," "Candide," "Auntie Mame," "Jamaica," "Destry Rides Again," Flower Drum Song," "A Taste of Honey," "Luv," "Cactus Flower" and "Plaza Suite."
Mr. Smith also designed productions of "La Traviata" and "Martha" for the Metropolitan Opera" and "Naughty Marietta," "The Tender Land" and "The Most Important Man," a 1971 work by Gian Carlo Menotti, for the New York City Opera.
Mr. Smith's Hollywood credits include designs for "The Band Wagon" and the screen adaptations of "Oklahoma!," "Guys and Dolls," "Porgy and Bess," "The Sound of Music" and "The Unsinkable Molly Brown." He also served as artistic consultant for "The Turning Point," a film about life in a large ballet company that some viewers thought resembled Ballet Theater.
In addition to designing productions, Mr. Smith was occasionally a co-producer of plays and musicals. His first venture in this field was "On the Town," a successful musical inspired by "Fancy Free," which he and Paul Feigay produced in 1944. He worked with several other producers in the decades that followed. Asked why, Mr. Smith told The New York Times in 1957: "There are only two reasons that make a man seek out the agony of economics, hurly-burly and temperament of producing in the theater. First, to make money. Second, the love of ideas. I've done both. 'Gentlemen Prefer Blondes' was for money. 'Clearing' I liked for idealistic reasons."
The first of the two shows he mentioned was the 1949 musical about the Roaring Twenties that made a star of Carol Channing. The second was "A Clearing in the Woods," Arthur Laurents's moody 1957 drama about an emotionally troubled woman's attempt to make peace with her past. Although it failed at the box office, Mr. Smith remained convinced of its artistic worth.
 
Designed Works By Sartre and Joyce
 Among the other serious works he co-produced were Jean-Paul Sartre's "No Exit" (1946), Jane Bowles's "In the Summer House" (1957) and "Stephen D." (1968), which was based on the writings of James Joyce. Mr. Smith's intellectually challenging productions also included Peter S. Feiblman's "Tiger, Tiger Burning Bright" (1962), a drama about a black family in New Orleans in which the choreographer Alvin Ailey took an acting role as one of the sons, and Arthur Kopit's "Indians" (1969), which sharply criticized the treatment of American Indians by whites.
Mr. Smith was never content with commercial success alone. Typically, in 1971, he was a co-founder with Lyn Austin of the Lenox Arts Center, an organization in the Berkshire Hills dedicated to unusual new productions. Gazing with alarm upon the Broadway scene, he told The Times in 1957: "New York is becoming a kind of vast merchandise mart. People go to the theater for escapist entertainment. They don't want a theater of ideas any more. And I don't want a theater of 'Auntie Mames.' "
A tall, lanky man with closely cropped white hair, Mr. Smith was always impeccably groomed. Even in his impoverished youthful days, he managed to give the impression of a man of the world who lived in a grand style. Well read and artistically knowledgeable, he was a slow, thoughtful speaker who conveyed a sense of languid sophistication.
But this veneer concealed his dynamism and helped make him a welcome and even soothing presence in the often hysterical atmosphere of Broadway and ballet. As the playwright Jean Kerr once said of him, he served as "an island of calm in the sea of temperament."
His many honors include several Tony Awards, Donaldson and Critics' Circle Awards, the Sam S. Shubert Foundation Gold Medal of 1961, the Pennsylvania State University Distinguished Alumni Award of 1962, a Handel Medallion of 1975 and a Great Teacher Award from New York University in 1981. Mr. Smith was a member of the National Arts Council from 1965 to 1970, and was inducted into the Theater Hall of Fame in 1981.
He is survived by two brothers, Larue and Kincaid.
