HEADLINE: Japan Set to Launch Rocket to Match West

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TANEGISHIMA, Japan

 BODY:
IN 1543, a Portuguese ship bound for Macao was blown off course and landed on this island, exposing the isolated Japanese people for the first time to the gun. In a few years, Japanese craftsmen were making muskets superior to the Portuguese ones.
Four and a half centuries later, this island in southern Japan will again be the scene of an effort to match the West. On Feb. 1, Japan plans to launch its first major rocket built without reliance on American technology, marking, in some sense, its arrival in the top tier of space-faring nations. 
 The technologically sophisticated H-II rocket is the first Japanese rocket that will be able to hoist large communication and earth observation satellites into orbit, and it will allow Japan to enter the commercial launching business in competition with American companies, Russia, China and the European consortium Arianespace. The H-II rocket will also serve as the mainstay of Japan's space program for the next two decades, paving the way for the possible development of the nation's own space shuttle.
"With the completion of the H-II rocket, we have built the foundation for our space activities," said Dr. Tomifumi Godai, executive director in charge of launching vehicles at the National Space Development Agency of Japan, or Nasda.
The rocket could also help Japan develop as a military power. Freed of restrictions that came with reliance on American rocket technology, Japan will be able to launch any satellites it wants to, including military ones. There has been some desire for the nation to have its own reconnaissance satellite, though there are no concrete plans for this yet.
But even as the gleaming new rocket sits on the launching pad here, there are still many doubts about whether the rocket will fulfill its purpose and about Japan's future in space.
The H-II program, which cost about $2.4 billion, has been bedeviled by problems, including an explosion that killed a worker, putting the initial launching at least two years behind schedule and raising questions about whether Japan will be able to maintain its record of never having failed in a satellite launching.
The H-II is technically ambitious: it weighs about half as much as an Ariane 4 rocket but can hoist the same 4,400-pound satellite into geostationary orbit. But it is also expensive. It will cost about twice as much to launch a satellite with the H-II as with a rocket from Arianespace, making it difficult or even impossible for Japan to compete successfully in the commercial launching business.
As for Japan's role in space, one of the main functions of the H-II is expected to be to launch the Hope, a small, unmanned space shuttle that would deliver supplies to a space station and then return to Earth and land automatically.
The maiden flight of the H-II rocket will be used to launch the Orbital Re-entry Experiment Vehicle, or Orex, a flying-saucer-shaped device that is essentially the nose cone of the envisioned shuttle. Orex will circle the earth once and then land in the Pacific Ocean 285 miles south of Christmas Island, testing the technology that will be used to protect the Hope from the heat of re-entry. It will become the first object to be retrieved by Japan after orbiting the Earth.
But while spending on the Hope is expected to begin in the next fiscal year, Japan is having second thoughts about the shuttle. This is in part because, much to Tokyo's annoyance, the American space station project, in which Japan is participating, has been continually revised, raising doubts about its future.
 
Recommendation of Panel
 An advisory panel to the space development agency last year recommended doing only preparatory research on Hope until the year 2000 and then deciding whether to build an operating vehicle. That means the shuttle won't be ready to fly until 2010, said Dr. Shigebumi Saito, an emeritus professor at Tokyo University and a former high commissioner of Japan's Space Activities Commission. Moreover, to be useful in transporting supplies to a space station, the weight of the shuttle would have to be twice the lifting capacity of the H-II, meaning the rocket will have to be improved, he said.
There are some other plans for space development as well. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry wants to do mining on the Moon. But that is considered even more of a long shot than the shuttle.
Still, even if some of the future uses for the H-II seem doubtful, to Japan, the important thing seems to be the development of indigenous technology. "This is fundamental to the way Japanese feel about national security and technology," said Richard J. Samuels, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass., who is writing a book about the development of Japan's aerospace industry.
Numerous Japanese companies have been involved in the rocket's development and will take part in the launching. The people manning the control room during a recent test were not wearing Nasda uniforms but their own company jackets -- Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries, Nissan and so on.
Japan had a late start in space and suffers some disadvantages. It did not put its first satellite into orbit until 1970, a year after the United States landed on the Moon. With restrictions on military technology development, Japan did not have missile technology to help in the development of rocketry.
 
A $1.4 Billion Budget
 The space development agency's budget of 160 billion yen, or about $1.4 billion, this yearis growing by 8 and 10 percent a year but is only one-tenth the budget of the United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration. (Japan also has a much smaller space agency, the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, which operates on a shoestring and specializes in scientific missions.)
Previous generations of Japanese rockets used technology bought or licensed from the United States. But that technology came with restrictions, including one that prohibited Japan from entering the commercial launching business.
Dr. Godai of Nasda said that Japan became interested in developing independent technology about a decade ago, when some Japanese satellites failed because of faulty American equipment. Because the inner workings of the American technology was shielded from Japan, the space development agency could not find out in detail what went wrong, which both annoyed and humiliated Japanese scientists. At the same time, the United States was growing concerned about the industrial threat from Japan, prompting Tokyo to worry that Washington would not be so free in licensing technology in the future.
But Dr. Godai said that the situation has now changed. The United States views the European rockets as more of a threat than the H-II. And space exploration is becoming so expensive that all nations have to cooperate. "We have shown that we have the capability of developing this rocket and we will work toward international cooperation from now on," he said.
 
Tricky Combustion Technique
 The key to the H-II rocket is the first stage LE-7 rocket, which uses what is known as staged combustion, a technique that is efficient but tricky. This kind of combustion has been used only in the United States space shuttle and in the Russian Energia engine.
To get high propulsive force in a liquid fuel engine, the liquid hydrogen fuel and liquid oxygen that allow it to burn must be pumped into the combustion chamber under high pressure. The question is how to provide power to the pumps.
In one relatively simple approach, part of the liquid hydrogen and oxygen are burned to power a turbine to drive the pumps. The products of this combustion are vented. But the drawback of this approach is that some of the precious liquid fuel is not being used directly to provide thrust.
In staged combustion, the fuel that is burned to power the pumps then continues into the combustion chamber to power the rocket, increasing the efficiency. But in order for this fuel to enter the combustion chamber, it must be under extremely high pressure during the first burning stage. And what happens in the first stage, known as a preburner, can affect the combustion chamber downstream.
It was such high pressures and tricky technology that contributed to a series of fires and explosions, including one during a pressure test in 1991 that blew out an eight-inch-thick door and killed an engineer. In 1992, a fuel leak set off another fire and explosion that forced a delay of another year in the maiden launching. But Nasda officials say those problems have now been solved by better heat treatment of materials and improved welds.
The choice of the staged combustion resulted in a rocket that needs less fuel and is very light relative to the size of the satellite it can lift into orbit. In theory at least, "light weight means lower cost," said Keiichiro Noda, associate senior engineer in Nasda's propulsion systems division.
But it is not clear that fuel efficiency matters as much as rockets as it does in Toyotas. In fact, the cost of the sophisticated engine might outweigh the savings from the fuel efficiency.
Dieter Brand, deputy manager of the Tokyo office of Arianespace, said the H-II rocket "is not only more sophisticated than Ariane 4 but also more than Ariane 5," a rocket that is under development and scheduled for its first launching in 1995. But Mr. Brand added: "We are not a research institute, we are a commerical company. We want something reliable and easy to use."
Other factors besides the technology will add to the cost of the H-II and possibly price it out of the market. One is the rise of the Japanese yen against other currencies. About a decade ago, when the project was started, a dollar was worth 240 yen and the contemplated price of the rocket, 16 billion yen, translated into $66 million. But at today's exchange rate of 111 yen to the dollar, the same rocket cost in yen translates to $144 million, roughly twice the price charged by Arianespace.
 
Limits on Launchings
 Yet another problem is that Japan will not be able to do more than two launchings a year. That is because Nasda is allowed to launch only during 45 days in summer and 45 days in winter as a concession to local fishermen, who fear the blastoffs scare away the fish.
So far, no other nations or companies have signed up to use the H-II to launch a satellite. "All our offers are neglected," said Hiroshi Imamura, a managing director of Rocket System Corporation, a venture owned by 75 Japanese companies that was formed to offer launching services using the H-II. The company hopes to do its first commercial launching in 1997. Until then, the launchings are booked with Government satellites.
Mr. Imamura said he hopes the cost can be pared between 30 and 50 percent, in part by reducing the inordinate amount of inspections performed on the first rocket. He said the biggest problem in attracting customers so far has been that the H-II rocket has not yet been proved.
"After the maiden launch, the biggest barrier will be gone," he said.

European Rocket Fails
 KOUROU, French Guiana (Reuters), Jan. 24 -- Europe's 63d Ariane rocket, carrying two French-made satellites worth more than $250 million, failed to reach orbit after being launched today, space officials said.
"The third stage stopped working in flight," said Charles Bigot, the president of Arianespace. The failure ended a string of 27 straight successful rocket launchings by the European consortium.
The rocket was carrying Turkey's first national satellite, Turksat 1, and Eutelsat 2 F-5 for the European Telecommunications Satellite Organization. Third-stage failures plagued early Ariane launches but had not been responsible for an failure since 1986. The third stage uses a mixture of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Rooting Against 4 Monkeys

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
SOME people call it the Super Bowl rematch "nobody wanted," but the Bills wanted it and so did everybody wearing a red-white-and-blue parka in Buffalo.
Some people still call the Dallas Cowboys "America's team," but in a nation crumbled by an earthquake, frozen by Arctic blasts, flooded by Midwestern rivers, wearied by the economy and terrorized by crime, the Bills are really America's team. 
 Not rooting for the Bills to get those three Super Bowl monkeys off their backs is like not rooting for yourself to win the lottery.
When the Bills line up for the Super Bowl XXVIII kickoff against the Cowboys in Atlanta on Sunday, they will be representing much more than the American Conference and the chapped citizens behind all those snowbanks on Lake Erie's shores. To the real world, the Bills will represent:
*All the salespeople who couldn't close their last three deals.
*All the unemployed who never heard back from their last three job interviews.
*All the waiters and waitresses who got stiffed by their last three customers.
*All the schoolchildren who flunked their last three tests.
*All the slot-machine players who tapped out the last three times they went to Las Vegas or Atlantic City.
*All the cops who couldn't make their last three collars stick.
But mostly, the Bills will represent themselves, all those players and coaches whose 57-19 record over the last four National Football League campaigns is forgotten, whose talent is tarnished by an 0-3 record in the Super Bowl, whose resolve is ignored because they haven't won "the big one."
Sadder still, the Bills aren't supposed to win "the big one" on Sunday either.
Even though the Bills dominated the Chiefs, 30-13, as soon as the Cowboys shattered the 49ers, 38-21, the point spread out of Las Vegas, Nev., had the Cowboys by 10, a rare double-digit line.
But remember that because bettors invariably are more attracted to the Cowboys, that line reflects the need for a price that would balance the money wagered, thereby assuring the vigorish.
Whatever the line, for the Bills to have a chance to win, Thurman Thomas must run free. As he did against the Giants three years ago with 135 yards in only 15 carries when the Bills would have won if Scott Norwood's 42-yard field goal kick had not been wide right. As he didn't do against the Redskins two years ago with only 13 yards in 10 carries after not being able to find his helmet on the sideline. As he didn't do against the Cowboys a year ago with only 19 yards in 11 carries.
But for Thomas to gallop, the Bills' offensive line must create the holes it did Sunday against the Chiefs as he rushed for 186 yards and 3 touchdowns on 33 carries.
"The difference was those five guys," quarterback Jim Kelly said of left tackles John Fina and Howard Ballard, guards Glenn Parker and John Davis and center Kent Hull. "They were opening holes you wouldn't believe."
In pro football's theory of relativity, where the coefficient of the foe changes with every game, those holes might not open so easily against the Cowboys' defensive line.
Another difference for the Bills might be the Georgia Dome itself. The roofed noise there might muffle Kelly's audible play-calling that was so effective against the Chiefs in the misty chill of Rich Stadium.
"When you're on the road, especially in a loud stadium," Hull said, "it's really hard to use our audible system. It's hard to communicate in the time you're allotted. When we're home, it's much easier to do that."
Three years ago Kelly's audibles in Tampa Stadium had the Giants holding their breath until Norwood's miss created a 20-19 loss.
But two years ago in the Metrodome the Bills never got rolling against the Redskins in a 37-24 loss. And in the Bills' biggest embarrassment, a year ago in the Rose Bowl, they were victimized by 9 turnovers (4 interceptions and 5 lost fumbles) as the Cowboys romped, 52-17.
Ever since, the Bills have been ridiculed for the three Super Bowls they lost instead of being respected for what they have accomplished in getting to those three Super Bowls and now a record fourth. In Buffalo, some people try to ease the pain by laughing at themselves.
"Do you know what BILLS stands for?" they joke. "Boy, I Love Losing Superbowls."
I seldom root. But because nobody deserves a fourth monkey on their back, I'm rooting for the Bills to win. Wouldn't 53-17 be nice?

HEADLINE: Japan: The Old Order Fights Back

 BODY:
It was high-order treachery when 17 old-line Socialists sabotaged Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's do-or-die political reform bill. But those who staged the ambush could yet turn out to be among its victims. The Japanese public is tired of corrupt money politics and is deeply angry at politicians who stand in the way of reform.
Meanwhile the Clinton Administration has not helped Mr. Hosokawa as he tries desperately to pass some version of reform. On Sunday, at the height of the crisis, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen suddenly showed up in Tokyo to press Washington's dubious demands for import quotas and immediate economic stimulus. 
 The legislation that lost an upper-house vote last Friday goes to the heart of Japan's political system and its U.S. relations. By giving more weight to urban consumers than to producer-oriented special interests, this electoral reform could open the way to a more democratic, less import-resistant Japan. It could also strengthen a new generation of more outward-looking, less bureaucracy-bound politicians, like Mr. Hosokawa himself.
The coalition still has a chance to win over enough votes to pass a reform bill this month. It will not be easy; and by urging Mr. Hosokawa to press ahead at once on divisive tax issues and fulfill arbitrary import quotas, Mr. Bentsen makes life much more difficult for him.
Right now, Mr. Hosokawa needs to focus all his political capital on keeping reform alive. That is the surest way to complete the destruction of the old, obstructive party system. The Socialists are already breaking up over ancient ideological quarrels. The Liberal Democrats, tarred with corruption, are not in much better shape. If he wins this battle, he could hasten the passage toward cleaner, more competitive politics.
The Japanese people have finally rebelled against a system that offends their ethical sensibilities and fails to serve their most basic needs. Their hopes for something better are embodied in the Hosokawa Government, as are America's hopes for a more open Japan.
The Clinton Administration should now be doing all it can to help a reformist Government survive in Tokyo, not burdening it with demands it cannot realistically meet.

LENGTH: 530 words

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton's Vital Signs

 BODY:
Presidents who pay too much attention to public opinion polls run the same risk as ballplayers who dwell on their batting averages: they waste time they should be spending on hitting and fielding. Still, President Clinton can be forgiven a peek at the most recent surveys marking the end of his first year. They suggest that his vital signs are stable. They also offer timely lessons as Mr. Clinton prepares for a State of the Union address tonight that will define his second year and possibly the rest of his Presidency.
The most powerful lesson is this: Bill Clinton stands highest when he trains his attention on a tightly focused agenda; he suffers most when he allows his staff to behave sloppily and self-servingly and when he indulges his natural inclination to move in a thousand policy directions at once. 
 That argues strongly for a legislative agenda addressing a few issues of broad concern: health care, of course, and also crime and welfare. Mr. Clinton has already laid political purchase to the crime issue, most memorably in his November speech to a black audience in Memphis. He must also reassert an interest in welfare reform, a campaign pledge he has done little to redeem.
He will not be speaking from weakness. Last week's New York Times/CBS News Poll gave Mr. Clinton a 54 percent approval rating. That compares favorably with his post-Watergate predecessors on their first anniversaries. Ronald Reagan had a 49 percent rating at this stage, Jimmy Carter had 51 percent. George Bush's 76 percent was an aberration arising from the invasion of Panama.
Mr. Clinton has yet to experience what polling professionals call "rally events" like the Persian Gulf war, which drove Mr. Bush's favorable rating to an astounding (and evanescent) 89 percent. Nor has he suffered calamitous declines, like the time in 1986 when Mr. Reagan's Teflon cracked to the tune of 20 points after people learned that he had tried to trade arms for hostages.
He has, however, endured bad moments. Six months ago he qualified as the most unpopular first-year President in 60 years. His 38 percent rating followed the bungled search for a suitable Attorney General, the putsch at the White House travel office, the haircut by Cristophe and Mr. Clinton's own acknowledgment of drift and disarray that reminded people of the more lachrymose moments of the Carter Administration. But starting in August with the passage of his budget bill, Mr. Clinton seemed to find his footing. He also found that when he took a strong stand, good things happened, like the North American Free Trade Agreement.
His surge in the polls coincides with a rise in the number of Americans expressing confidence in the economy. it is impossible to say how much he had to do with that; still, he should enjoy the moment and find ways to build on it, perhaps by reaching out with retraining programs to those who have been blindsided by the recession.
Yet his task tonight is as much psychological as it is programmatic: to show that he has finally learned what Mr. Bush never did, that a President's popularity is a sometime thing, best spent in a disciplined way on things that matter.

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE;
President Seeking $6.6 Billion For California Quake Victims

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton will ask Congress for at least $6.6 billion in emergency financing to help the victims of last week's California earthquake.
The White House request would add the full Federal bill for earthquake relief to the budget deficit, while the State of California would be asked to match just 10 percent of the total contribution, rather than the 25 percent that is usually required of states receiving Federal aid. 
 The speedy request for disaster relief and the willingness to relax the matching-contribution requirement offer new evidence of the White House's determination to be seen as sensitive to California's economic plight, which even before the earthquake had made the politically critical state the focus of special Administration attention.
 
Fiscal Battle Possible
 An initial request for the $6.6 billion will be sent to Capitol Hill on Wednesday, and Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said the figure was likely to grow. Mr. Panetta and other senior White House officials said they would oppose fiscal conservatives in Congress who had said that they would seek spending cuts to offset the disaster relief.
"We do not think victims of this kind of tragedy ought to be held hostage," Mr. Panetta told reporters at the White House today, warning that a battle over the issue would only delay getting the aid to those who need it most.
Together with the $897 million in emergency aid that was already budgeted and is being spent, the new request would put total Federal assistance for the California quake at more than $7.5 billion.
By comparison, the total Federal bill for last summer's Midwest floods now stands at just $4.6 billion. In 1991, the cost to Federal taxpayers for hurricane damage surpassed $8 billion, but that figure included both Hurricane Andrew, which struck South Florida and Louisiana, and Hurricane Iniki, which struck the Hawaiian island of Kuaui and led to Federal aid approaching $2 billion.
For the earthquake that damaged the San Francisco Bay area in 1989, the total Federal cost has now reached $2.9 billion; for Hurricane Hugo, which struck South Carolina earlier the same year, it was $2.8 billion. None of the figures were adjusted for the effects of inflation.
Rough estimates of the damage caused by the California quake, which measured 6.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion, killed 56 people and left up to 25,000 homeless, now range from $15 billion to $30 billion. White House officials held out no hope today that the Federal Government could cover anywhere near the total cost.
But they said the extensive damage inflicted by the earthquake on highways, water systems and uninsured buildings, all of which qualify for Federal assistance, would mean that Washington's share of the total cost would be proportionally higher than in the previous disasters.
 
Store of Electoral Votes
 After the 1989 earthquake in the San Francisco area, the Bush Administration chose not to exempt California from the requirement that a state contribute one dollar for every four in assistance provided by the Federal Government. That only added to ill feelings in the state toward the Bush White House, which went on to lose California in the 1992 election and with it the state's 54 electoral votes, or a fifth of the 270 needed to elect a president.
Today, Clinton Administration officials justified their decision to approve the waiver by pointing to the higher cost of the Los Angeles earthquake in comparison to the 1989 quake. But they acknowledged that the decision would add to an already high Federal bill.
In an interview, Christopher B. Edley, an associate director of the Office of Management and Budget, said: "We believe that the cost of the earthquake will be the single biggest in history in terms of Federal fiscal response."
By far the largest portion of the new aid requested by the White House would provide $3.5 billion in disaster relief through the Federal Emergency Management Agency for individuals' emergencies and the repair of public schools, roads, water systems and buildings.
 
Help for Schools
 Other disaster relief would include $1.35 billion for highways; $500 million for housing, including rent subsidies for low-income citizens left without a home, and $245 million for education, including money to help the schools cover the costs of transportation, food service and to keep after-hours care programs open longer.
Since Congress imposed rigid budget controls on itself in 1990, it has often waived requirements to offset new spending with cuts for natural disasters. That is the course the White House wants it to follow again in approving the new earthquake assistance.
But White House officials conceded today that doing so would add as much as $3 billion to the budget deficit this year alone. They said they expected be opposed by lawmakers, including Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, and Timothy J. Penny, Democrat of Minnesota, both of whom urged Mr. Clinton to insure that the relief measure had no additional cost for taxpayers.
Mr. Panetta, who is from the Monterey area, which was affected by the 1989 quake but not the one last week, insisted that it would be wrong to hold the latest earthquake and its victims to a new standard. That sentiment was echoed by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, and Administration officials and Congressional Democrats alike expressed confidence that the request would be approved.
In California, Gov. Pete Wilson welcomed the announcement of relief aid, but said he was concerned that the cost estimates are too low.
"If they have the wrong number based on a low-ball estimate, the state of California and the people of this state would be seriously shortchanged," Mr. Wilson said.
Other California politicians nevertheless expressed satisfaction with the size of the aid request, although Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat, described it as "a beginning, strictly a beginning."

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: The Overview;
Clinton Vows Fight for His Health Plan

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton offered a broad new defense of his health care plan tonight and vowed to veto any health insurance proposal that did not provide coverage for all citizens.
In a State of the Union Message that outlined Mr. Clinton's vision for domestic renewal without offering new legislative proposals or policy initiatives, Mr. Clinton said that the nation must now build upon the economic successes attained during his first year in office and that "our work has just begun." 
 "I want to make this very clear," Mr. Clinton said in a voice strained from many rehearsals. "If you send me legislation that does not guarantee every American private health insurance that can never be taken away, you will force me to take this pen, veto the legislation, and we'll come right back here and start all over again."
Mr. Clinton brandished a pen as he spoke.
 
Rousing Applause
 Mr. Clinton entered the House chamber to rousing applause at 9:10 P.M., grabbing hands and patting backs as he made his way to the lectern. In the hourlong speech, his first official State of the Union Message, the President also summed his goals for this year and reviewed the accomplishments of his first year in office.
He vowed to "guarantee health security for all, to reward work over welfare, to promote democracy abroad and to begin to reclaim our streets from violent crime and drugs and gangs, to renew our own American community."
He spent little time getting to the prime thrust of his remarks, stepping up his assault on the critics who say that only gradual change is needed from any health care plan.
 
Danger in Future
 "If we let the health care system continue to drift in its present direction, Americans will have less care, fewer choices and higher bills," Mr. Clinton said. "Our approach doesn't take care and choices away from people. It builds on what works today in the private sector."
Mr. Clinton has proposed an overhaul that would provide coverage for hospital, doctor and prescription drug bills, and require employers to pay 80 percent of the average insurance premium. The plan would be administered by regional purchasing alliances and financed in part by taxes on tobacco and large corporations.
In the months since Mr. Clinton unveiled the proposal, in another prime-time speech to a joint session of Congress, some of the initial public enthusiasm for the plan has faded as critics have attacked it. It has also been criticized by several influential members of Congress who have been lobbying for approaches ranging from a Government takeover of the system to an expansion of the tax deduction for medical expenses. Mr. Clinton seemed intent on restoring support for his plan.
After the speech tonight, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, assailed Mr. Clinton's health plan.
"Our country has health care problems, but no health care crisis," Mr. Dole said. He described the President's plan as "a massive overdose of government control."
Mr. Clinton, maintained, however, that the nation had been allowed to drift for too long.
 
Demand for Change
 "In 1992, the American people demanded that we change," he said. "We replaced drift and deadlock with renewal and reform."
He began the speech by evoking the memory of the former Speaker of the House, Tip O'Neill, who died just a few weeks ago and was revered by many of the lawmakers in the room. "In his honor, may we always remember who we are, where we come from and who sent us here," Mr. Clinton said.
Citing the passage of a the Brady bill, a measure that imposes a five-day waiting period on handgun purchases, Mr. Clinton then turned to the man who gave that bill its name, James S. Brady, the former press secretary who was seriously injured in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Brady shook his cane as the members of Congress gave him a standing ovation.
The most emotional moments of the speech came when Mr. Clinton spoke of taking steps to combat a crime wave that he said is rooted "in the loss of values, the disappearance of work, and the breakdown of our families and communities."
"We cannot renew this country when 13-year-old boys get semiautomatic weapons to shoot 9-year-olds for kicks," he said.
 
One Family's Story
 Before listing his goals on welfare, information technology and deficit reduction, Mr. Clinton paused for one of the personal stories with which Presidents have long sought to bring the questions of public policy closer to home.
Praising those in Congress and "the people who hold our feet to the fire," President Clinton said the work of Government was shared work.
He said his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton had received more than one million pieces of mail about health care, and he spoke of one letter, from Richard and Judy Anderson, a couple from Reno.
The Andersons, he said, ran up hospital bills of $120,000 after the husband lost his job. The couple, eventually filed for bankruptcy. Mr. Anderson wrote that no American should have to undergo such a crisis.
Mr. Clinton the said, "So if any of you believe there is no health care crisis, you tell it to those people." Pausing, he added: "Because I can't."
As he had done in September during his speech on health care, Mr. Clinton publicly thanked his wife for her help in preparing his proposal. She was sitting in the House gallery and rose to accept applause from the members.
 
Attacking Welfare, Too
 Setting a rough target for the beginning of another complicated legislative battle, the President said he would send a proposal to Congress this spring for a comprehensive revamping of the nation's welfare system. The proposal will try to reduce the incentives for teen-age mothers to set up their own households, he said.
He asked for welfare to become a "simple contract," and said that the Government would provide help in jobs, child care and welfare for up to two years but that welfare should be "a second chance, not a way of life."
He added: "If we value strong families, we can't perpetuate a system that actually penalizes those families that stay together. That's not just bad policy, it's wrong, and we ought to change it."
It is "inevitable and imperative," he said, to tackle both welfare reform and health care reform simultaneously. Linking the two, he said the nation must solve the welfare problem to pay for full health care coverage.
As he appealed to Americans to take more responsibility for what is ailing the country, Mr. Clinton's voice grew subdued for a moment as he made passing reference to his mother, who died earlier this month.
 
Issue Draw Applause
 "We can't renew our country until we realize that governments don't raise children; parents do," Mr. Clinton said. "Parents who know their children's teachers and turn off the television and help with the homework and teach their kids right from wrong -- those kind of parents can make all the difference. I know. I had one.
"And I'm telling you we have got to stop pointing our fingers at these kids who have no future and reach our hands out to them. Our country needs it. We need it. And they deserve it."
Indicative of the political power of the issue, Mr. Clinton was repeatedly interrupted by applause as he pledged a renewed focus on welfare. He said: "The people who most want to change this system are the people who are dependent on it. They want to get off welfare; they want to go back to work; they want to do right by their kids."
In another part of the speech that garnered prolonged applause, he said: "I know it will be difficult to tackle welfare reform in 1994 at the same time as we tackle health care. But let me point out at the same time that it is inevitable and imperative."
Earlier today, Mr. Clinton met with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who had alarmed the White House in recent weeks by suggesting on national television that the health care crisis the Administration has described does not compare to the welfare crisis.
Aides said that Mr. Clinton briefed Mr. Moynihan in the private Oval Office meeting about the contents of his speech but that he did not specifically address the critical comments Mr. Moynihan has directed at the White House. As chairman of the Senate Finance committee, Mr. Moynihan is important to the White House plans for health care and welfare.
During the speech, the President cited a list of promises kept, noting his Administration had begun to reduce the budget deficit and the size of the Federal Government, to make the Government more efficient and to redress the economic imbalances that he said had resulted from Republican Administrations, by raising taxes on the wealthiest Americans.
 
About Income Taxes
 "Let me repeat, only the wealthiest 1.2 percent of Americans will face higher income tax rates, and no one else will and that is the truth," he said to mixed cheers and boos and a partisan standing ovation.
Continuing a vigorous defense of his economic program, Mr. Clinton asserted that the deficit was now running 40 percent below previous predictions. He touted the low inflation rate, the low interest rate, all part of an economy that, he asserted, was coming back as a result of his policies.
Mr. Clinton edited the text by hand up until the final hours before its delivery tonight. Standing in front of aides, stenographers and political advisers this morning and again this afternoon, he worked from the 10th draft his speech writers had prepared.
Mr. Clinton voiced strong support for a Federal role in crime control, including an endorsement of portions of the crime bill that is now awaiting final passage in Congress. Tonight, for the first time, he endorsed a provision in the Senate-passed anti-crime bill that would mandate life without parole for criminals convicted of a third violent felony.
That proposal, which was attached to the Senate measure by Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, would apply only to crimes committed on Government property. But it offered the President an opportunity to highlight his commitment to crime control.
"Now, those who commit crimes must be punished," Mr. Clinton said. "And those who commit repeated violent crimes should be told: when you commit a third violent crime, you'll be put away and put away for good. Three strikes and you are out."
 
Labor and Management
 Mrs. Clinton was also accompanied by Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and John F. Smith Jr., the president and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, flanked the First Lady. Both are strong supporters of the Administration's health care proposal. In Mr. Kirkland's case, his proximity to Mrs. Clinton suggested the healing of a rift between organized labor and the White House that opened up after organized labor waged a bitter fight against the North American Free Trade Agreement.
White House officials said Mr. Clinton's goal tonight was not to be "adversarial or combative" toward members of Congress who have criticized elements of his domestic agenda but to state his goals clearly and forcefully.
But it is still clear that welfare will take a back seat to health care as the Administration outlines a series of what aides call building blocks that began with the enactment of an earned income tax credit for the working poor last year and will end with the introduction of a comprehensive welfare revision that would cut off benefits for recipients who have not obtained work within two years.
"If you try to pass welfare reform without health care reform, it's like trying to fill up a bucket with a hole in it," Vice President Al Gore said earlier today.
 
Welfare in the Spring
 But even on the most optimistic schedule, the welfare bill will probably not be introduced until late spring or early summer. Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton is concentrating on outlining the stakes for health care revision in the starkest terms possible.
On foreign policy, Mr. Clinton summarized the accomplishments of his recent trip to Europe and said the United States remained committed to supporting democracy movements abroad and curbing nuclear weapons, specially in Korea.
He referred only in passing to the role of the United States in the shaky peacekeeping efforts in Bosnia-Herzegovina and in other nations that, in the words of one senior White House official, are "ripping themselves apart."

HEADLINE: U.S. Said to Plan Patriot Missiles for South Korea

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is planning to ship Patriot antimissile batteries to South Korea, senior Administration officials said today.
The antimissile batteries were requested by Gen. Gary E. Luck, the senior American commander in Korea, and the move is supported by the Pentagon. President Clinton has not yet formally approved the request, but senior officials said he likely will. On Monday, the White House began consulting members of Congress about the move. 
 "I think there will be a positive decision," a senior official said.
 
Responding to a Threat
 In military terms, the case for sending the Patriots is straightforward. North Korea has threatened to suspend the armistice on the Korean Peninsula if the United States pushes for economic sanctions to put pressure on Pyongyang to end its nuclear weapons program. American military officers say the North Korean threat is probably a bluff, but it is one the United States cannot ignore.
If North Korea attacked South Korea, American intelligence officers said, it would launch its arsenal of Scud missiles at airfields and ports in South Korea to try to blunt air attacks and slow the pace of reinforcements. The Patriot antimissile batteries would improve the protection of those airfields and ports and reduce North Korea's ability to make a successful pre-emptive attack, the officials said.
 
Designed to Destroy Missiles
 The Patriot system is designed to protect airfields and other military bases by knocking the incoming missiles off course or destroying them in the air. The Patriots deployed in Saudi Arabia during the Persian Gulf war performed this narrow task reasonably well but were not effective in shielding large populated areas from attack.
One official said that "about three dozen" Patriot launchers would be sent to South Korea.
"It would make some sense to pre-position Patriots" in South Korea, said Brig. Gen. Robert G. Jenkins, the commander of the 51st Fighter Wing Command, which is based on Osan Air Base in South Korea.
Some former Bush Administration officials had been urging such a move. And before the crisis, American military planners had seen a need to place Patriots in South Korea as part of a general upgrading of American defenses there. The new tensions, however, while making the military need far more urgent, have made the diplomatic ramifications much more sensitive.
One senior American military official said some State Department officials had been wary of sending the Patriots to South Korea, apparently fearing the move could upset the talks with the North Koreans on ending Pyongyang's nuclear weapons program.
As a result, Administration officials had been discussing a plan under which the Patriots would be shipped to Japan. From there they could be quickly moved into South Korea in a crisis. But that idea was determined to be impractical and was dropped, Administration officials said.
 
Political Considerations
 Reflecting White House worry about how the delivery of the Patriots might be perceived at home and abroad, a senior official declined to say precisely when President Clinton is expected to formally approve the request for the Patriots or exactly when they would be sent.
On the one hand, the Clinton Administration does not wish to be seen as ignoring a request from military commanders for a weapon needed to defend American troops. The United States has 36,000 troops in Korea. The Administration's decision not to send additional armor requested by American commanders in Somalia exposed the White House to criticism and contributed to its decision to replace Defense Secretary Les Aspin.
Nor does the Administration want to create the impression that it is moving slowly to strengthen its military forces in South Korea, for fear of antagonizing North Korea.
On the other hand, the Clinton Administration appears apprehensive about taking an action that could be interpreted as reflecting pessimism about the talks on inspections of the North's nuclear sites. The Administration is also concerned that its action may create unease among Asian allies who have been urging a nonconfrontational approach. North Korea, which has issued a steady stream of bellicose statements, is also all but certain to denounce the deployment of Patriots as a provocation.
 
Nuclear Talks Stalled
 The talks over North Korea's nuclear program have made little headway in recent weeks, as Pyongyang has rebuffed some of the demands by the International Atomic Energy Agency for detailed inspections at seven officially disclosed nuclear sites. The Administration has said it will seek economic sanctions if the talks fail.
Worried that sanctions against North Korea could increase the risk of conflict, General Luck prepared a list of steps to strengthen American forces in South Korea. The steps included the delivery of Patriots.
The United States has already stepped up intelligence gathering over North Korea, as General Luck had requested. In addition, Administration officials say that any decision to impose sanctions will almost certainly be accompanied by other military measures the general has requested.
The United States still has Patriot systems in Saudi Arabia because American intelligence concluded that Iraq was hiding Scud missiles left over from the gulf war. But most of the Army's 44 Patriot batteries are in the United States and Germany.
The shipment of the Patriots is unlikely in itself to end the debate over whether the Clinton Administration is making adequate military preparations in case the talks fail.
In addition to sending the Patriots, some former Bush Administration officials say that Washington should also be taking other steps, such as sending an aircraft carrier to the region, stepping up military exercises and deploying additional aircraft.

HEADLINE: Japanese Stocks Post Solid Gains

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 26

 BODY:
About the only question left unanswered on the Tokyo Stock Exchange was: what political crisis?
After plummeting on Monday in response to the Government's defeat in a critical vote in Parliament and concerns over the deepening recession, the stock market shrugged off the worries on both Tuesday and today to post solid gains. The greatest source of support is coming from foreign investors. 
 On Tuesday, the Nikkei 225-stock index rose 295.12 points, or 1.6 percent, to 18,648.36 -- a smart rebound after Monday's punishing 954.19-point loss. And then again today, the Nikkei soared 489.85 points, or 2.63 percent, to 19,138.21. About 360 million shares were traded.
Brokers said that in trading today, stocks surged on foreign investor purchases and late dealer buying, pushing the Nikkei average above the psychological barrier of 19,000. Growing hopes that the Government may soon pass its political reform bills buoyed investors' sentiment, brokers said.
The market is still up by more than a thousand points since early last month, when overseas investors began pushing prices steadily higher.
 
 
Fears Appear Overblown
 Most analysts agreed that investors were likely to remain nervous, especially if it appeared that the Government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa would be forced to resign or to call a snap election, one possible outcome of the political upheaval. But they said the initial fears about sustained financial turmoil now appeared to have been overblown.
The market is anxious but not downhearted.
"What we saw today was a combination of steadying nerves and foreign buying," Geoffrey Barker, head of research here for Baring Securities, said of Tuesday's activity. "We're seeing orders coming in from London, the Continent and America.
"The essential question is whether you think there will be a cyclical turning point in the Japanese economy, even with the political questions. I do."
On the political front, there was some moderately hopeful news on Tuesday. Mr. Hosokawa's coalition Government and the largest opposition party, the Liberal Democrats, agreed to set up a joint committee to consider a compromise on the electoral reform bills that were defeated last Friday.
If there is a compromise, it is likely to be a heavily watered-down version of the bills, which are intended to clean up Japan's scandal-plagued electoral and campaign financing systems.
For several months those bills have held up action to revive the economy, so the sign of movement, even if the legislation is weakened, cheered investors.
The Government has promised to enact a large increase in public works spending and consider a large tax cut to stimulate fresh economic growth as soon as political reform is out of the way.
 
 
Foreign Investors
 But analysts say that the biggest boon to the stock market still appears to be foreign investors, not Japanese institutions, which remain concerned about the country's current economic plight.
Big mutual funds and other large institutions have invested heavily in Asian stock markets over the last two years, but most of that money has flowed into the emerging markets in Hong Kong, Bangkok and elsewhere. Japan, which is entering the fifth year of a strong bear market, has largely been bypassed.
Toward the end of last year foreigners decided that the pessimism in Japan was exaggerated, and that the run in other East Asian markets was running out of steam. The result has been a broad-based decision to reallocate some capital from those other markets to Tokyo, analysts say. That has been the chief source of firepower for the recent rally, and the recovery during the last two days.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: The Republicans;
Excerpts From the Republicans' Response to the President's Message

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Republican response to President Clinton's State of the Union Message, as delivered by Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader:
We know that America has the best health care system in the world, that people from every corner of the globe come here when they need the very best treatment, and that our goal should be to insure that every American has access to this system. 
 Of course, there are many Americans with a sick child or sick parent in real need, both in rural and urban America. Our country has health care problems, but not a health care crisis. But we will have a crisis if we take the President's medicine -- a massive overdose of government control.
How massive? My colleague Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, has prepared a chart of what the health care bureaucracy would look like under the President's plan, and I'd like to show you this chart. It's a great, big chart. It contains 207 boxes. It would take a long time to fully explain it, and frankly, I have difficulty understanding it myself.
Let me point out of some of the new bureaucracies that the President's plan will create. Way up here is the National Health Board. Over here is the Advisory Commission on Regional Variations of Health Expenditures. And here's the National Institute for Health Care Workforce Development.
Now, you and I are way down here, way at the bottom. I don't know why we're not at the top, but we're at the bottom.
Now, the President's idea is to put a mountain of bureaucrats between you and your doctor. For example, if you are a family member and want to receive care from a specialist or a clinic outside your own state -- let's say you live in Kansas and you want to go to Minnesota -- then you probably can't do it without asking for approval. And under his plan, information about your health and your treatment can be sent to a national databank without your approval. And that's a compromise of privacy none of us should accept.
Now, these just are two examples, but there are many, many more. Clearly, the President is asking you to trust the Government more than you trust your doctor and yourselves with your lives and the lives of your loved ones. More cost, less choice, more taxes, less quality, more government control and less control for you and your family -- that's what the President's Government-run plan is likely to give you.
Now, we can fix our most pressing problems without performing a triple bypass operation on our health care system. We can do it without the estimated $1 trillion gap -- yes, $1 trillion gap -- between the administration's own projections, their projections, of spending under the plan and the funds available to pay for it, and we can do it now.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The President promised a middle-class tax cut, yet he and his party imposed the largest tax increase in American history. This $255 billion tax increase was opposed by every Republican in the House and in the Senate. We hope his higher taxes will not cut short the economic recovery and declining interest rates that he inherited. . . .
Now instead of stifling growth and expansion through higher taxes and increased government regulations, Republicans would take America in a different direction, and we can do that through alternatives that reward risk-taking and the creation of new jobs, and they give our small business men and women relief from the heavy hand of government.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: The Republicans;
In G.O.P. Response to Clinton, Dole Denies There Is 'Crisis' in Health Care

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, tonight assailed President Clinton's health care plan as "a massive overdose of Government control."
"Our country has health care problems, but no health care crisis," Mr. Dole said in a nationally televised response to the President's State of the Union Message. Mr. Dole called for more modest steps toward universal health insurance than he has supported in the past. 
 In particular, he called for quick action on a plan that would include neither Mr. Clinton's call for employers to pay most of their workers' insurance costs, nor a measure backed by Republicans in the Senate -- one that he helped draft -- that would impose a requirement on people that they insure themselves.
He attacked Mr. Clinton's plan as too bureaucratic, saying "The President's idea is to put a mountain of bureaucrats between you and your doctor."
Mr. Dole criticized the President in other areas as well, from taxes to military spending. "The President and his Democrat majority" are wrong "on their entire approach to government," he said.
 
All-Out Assault
 On the best platform Republicans are likely to have all year, Mr. Dole made an all-out assault on the President. He mentioned cooperation only once, when he recalled that many Republicans had supported Mr. Clinton when he won passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which had been negotiated under the leadership of his predecessor, President George Bush.
Gone, at least for tonight, was the legislative Senator Dole, who often seeks compromise. Instead he was the combative, partisan leader who ran for Vice President unsuccessfully in 1976 and lost bids for his party's Presidential nomination in 1980 and 1988.
He was sounding an electoral trumpet for November, reflecting what Republicans had discussed at lunch today. They reminded themselves that their best moment in public opinion polls came last year when they defeated Mr. Clinton's economic stimulus program with a Senate filibuster, and gave the President not a single vote in either chamber for his deficit-reduction and tax measure.
Mr. Dole contended that the President's claims of a reduced Federal deficit were true only because "the largest tax increase in American history would decrease any deficit temporarily."
 
Security Cuts Criticized
 He said Mr. Clinton's plans did not involve serious spending cuts, except in one area. "The one place the President has cut drastically is precisely the wrong place -- national security -- slashed to the lowest levels since before Pearl Harbor," Mr. Dole said.
He said the nation "cannot afford to have a hollow military." And he added that the nation cannot "afford to let the United Nations dictate what is in America's national interest."
On crime, he did not so much challenge the President's record or his arguments, since he had not heard them when he prepared the speech. Instead he criticized "liberal Democrats" who he said had weakened previous Senate crime bills passed by the Senate. He demanded rhetorically to know whether Mr. Clinton would press the House to accept the toughest elements of the bill the Senate passed last November.
And he complained of "talk in the Administration of legalized drugs," a notion suggested by Dr. Joycelyn Elders, the Surgeon General, and promptly disavowed by Mr. Clinton.
On welfare, Mr. Dole again did not attack the President's specific proposals, which had not yet been put forward. Instead, he simply told the nation that "Republicans here in Congress and Republican Governors across the nation are fighting for changes that make work, self-sufficiency and reducing illegitimacy top priorities."
 
Pericles's Position Is Safe
 While Mr. Dole concentrated on substance, Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, the chairman of the House Republican caucus dwelt on its literary quality. "It was a workmanlike speech, but it was interminable," Mr. Hyde said. "The law of diminishing returns sets in after 45 minutes. Clinton will not push Pericles out of first place."
But another Republican leader, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, praised the speech, saying, "It had a kinship to how Ronald Reagan used to do it, introducing people in the gallery." But Mr. Simpson, the Senate's Republican whip, said the President failed to explain how he would pay for his proposals, although he said the President's welfare comments were "very appropriate."
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, the author of the Republican plan for universal health care, said he disagreed with the President's putting equal emphasis on health care and welfare. "Health care is more important than welfare," he said. "I think health care reform has to go first." But he added, "I don't think now is the time to talk vetoes."
Looking for a local connection, Representative Susan Molinari, Republican of Staten Island, said: "It was a wonderful speech. It's good to have the whole Congress applauding a member of the New York City Police Department," referring to Kevin Jett, a detective whose story Mr. Clinton told.
Mr. Clinton's only Republican backer on health care, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, said the speech would "turn back a real slide in enthusiasm" for the President's plan. He said he agreed with Mr. Clinton's assertion that Congress could pass major health care and welfare legislation this year.
Mr. Clinton's appeal for national health insurance also won predictable support. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who first pushed the concept in 1970, praised Mr. Clinton and said: "This is the year to finally make this long overdue reform a reality for every citizen in this land. I urge Congress to resist the temptation to blink and water down this essential change."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Appoints a New Head Of New York Power Authority

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Seeking to put the foundering New York Power Authority on a sharply different course, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo named S. David Freeman, who has brought radical innovations to several public power agencies, to head the authority yesterday.
Mr. Freeman, 68, is a former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, at which he abandoned or shut eight nuclear reactors, writing off billions in capital investment, to concentrate resources on several others and push them into operation. 
 He is now the general manager of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, which he took over in a crisis after voters had decided to shut its Rancho Seco nuclear reactor. He is widely credited with rescuing the district, through such steps as auctioning off the furniture in executive offices, buying up thousands of old and inefficient refrigerators and planting half a million trees near houses to reduce the need for air-conditioning and to cut the demand for power.
 
Record Fines Paid
 The New York Power Authority has recently paid record fines to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for violations at its two nuclear plants, both of which are on the commission's "watch list" of the worst-run plants in America. They are Indian Point 3 in Buchanan, near Peekskill, which has been closed for nearly a year, and James A. FitzPatrick, in Scriba, near Syracuse.
The authority, which provides a quarter of the electricity used in the state, fears that it will face tough competition in the wholesale electricity markets from independent power producers.
The power authority has also been criticized by outsiders for doing relatively little about energy conservation. The Sacramento Municipal Utility District, by contrast, has one of the most aggressive conservation programs in the country.
"David Freeman is vision incarnate," said Peter Bradford, the chairman of the New York Public Service Commission. "His vision in the 1970's is the conventional wisdom of the 1990's." A large part of that wisdom is that rather than producing more power, utilities should help customers use electricity more efficiently.
Mr. Freeman will replace Richard M. Flynn as chief executive officer of the power authority. Mr. Flynn, 62, whose resignation takes effect Feb. 1, has been criticized not only for the authority's business problems, but also for using the authority's airplane to fly between a summer home in Rhode Island and authority meetings or plants.
Mr. Flynn plans to head a private group, the Northeast Corridor Initiative, that will seek improvements in rail transportation in New York, New England and Canada.
As a White House official, Mr. Freeman advised President Richard M. Nixon that electricity consumption, which was doubling every 10 years, could not continue on that path, and as the head of a research group at the Ford Foundation he predicted in the early 1970's that all energy use would have to reach a plateau. He was bitterly denounced by energy companies for his prediction, but was proved right. In fact, after the 1973 oil shock, energy use stabilized at a level 15 percent lower than he had predicted.
His views were never universally popular. Yesterday Carl Goldstein, a spokesman for the United States Council for Energy Awareness, the nuclear industry's public relations arm, said: "I wish him luck. I hope he felt comfortable in that scenario last week." Mr. Goldstein was referring to a series of blackouts in the Middle Atlantic states, brought on by electricity shortages. The utilities traced the shortages to frozen coal piles, fuel barges stuck in icy rivers, and roads over which fuel trucks could not travel.
 
Avant-Garde Views
 Mr. Freeman's current views are still outside the mainstream. He is an aggressive supporter of electric vehicles, and is trying to incubate a new industry in Sacramento to manufacture them. He is also a backer of renewable energy sources, like windmills and photovoltaic cells. As head of the Tennessee Valley Authority, Mr. Freeman directed his efforts at projects that were environmentally benign and economically advantageous.
In choosing Mr. Freeman, Governor Cuomo also reorganized the authority. Since 1985, Mr. Flynn has been the chairman and chief executive officer of the authority. Mr. Freeman will be the president and chief executive officer. Mr. Cuomo has nominated Thomas G. Young, a former Mayor of Syracuse, to replace Mr. Flynn as chairman.
The power authority provides electricity to municipalities and government agencies, like the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Under direction from the State Legislature, it provides large blocks of very cheap power to upstate municipal utilities.
Mr. Freeman said in a telephone interview yesterday that one of the challenges would be to induce customers upstate to conserve electricity that costs them less than 2 cents a kilowatt-hour. Fostering conservation is easier in New York City or on Long Island, say experts, because power there costs seven or eight times as much.
He said he was "motivated to accept this job more by the opportunities than the problems," adding, "If all the job entailed was fixing the nuclear plants, I think there are a number of people in the country who they could have recruited for that."
In Albany yesterday, Senator James L. Seward, the chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, complained that Mr. Freeman had been selected with "only nominal participation and little input by the trustees of the power authority" and said that his committee would hold hearings on the selection process.
The Senate, which is Republican-controlled, does not have to confirm the president of the authority. That was done today by the trustees, at the behest of the Governor.
That vote was delayed today while Mr. Freeman and the authority worked out details of his contract. It is for three years, beginning March 1, and he will be paid $197,000 a year, a housing bonus of up to $3,000 a month and moving expenses.
Mr. Freeman said yesterday that his appointment was "almost poetic," coming after his last few jobs. He had been chairman of the T.V.A., which was established by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, and the Lower Colorado River Authority in Austin, Tex., which is known as the "little T.V.A.," and was now coming to manage what he called "the grandfather," the New York Power Authority, which was founded by Franklin D. Roosevelt when he was Governor of New York, and was the model for the T.V.A.

GRAPHIC: Photo: S. David Freeman (Matthew L. Wald/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: C.I.A. HEAD SURVEYS WORLD'S HOT SPOTS

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In a tour of the world's horizons from his perspective as Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey said today that his major concerns include the possibility of destructive hyperinflation in Russia, political and ethnic tensions that could fragment Ukraine and a military buildup in North Korea.
While none of these events pose an immediate danger to the United States, "the end of the cold war does not mean the end of conflict, nor the end to threats to our security and to that of our friends and allies," Mr. Woolsey said during testimony at a public session of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. 
 Mr. Woolsey said the C.I.A. is trying to sort out confusing and conflicting data on the Russian economy. He said the agency worries that "looser fiscal and monetary policies aimed at easing the pain of reform will unleash forces that could bring Russia again to the brink of destructive hyperinflation."
If that brink is crossed and inflation destroys Russian citizens' savings, he said, "it would be a very heavy blow at democracy and the political structure" that President Boris N. Yeltsin is trying to achieve.
 
Disillusionment in Ukraine
 In Ukraine, Mr. Woolsey said, independence celebrations have "given way to disillusionment as a result of economic mismanagement and political drift."
"Reform has been nonexistent," the C.I.A. chief said. "Energy shortages have become a way of life, the inflation rate for December was 90 percent, and nearly half of Ukraine's citizens are living below the poverty level."
Mr. Woolsey said a potential political crisis lies in a rising secession movement in Crimea, the only region of Ukraine where ethnic Russians are in the majority. Their clamor for reunification with Russia threatens to fragment the fledgling republic, he said.
North Korea, which has built one or two nuclear weapons, according to the C.I.A.'s most recent classified estimate, has vaulted to the top of the agency's agenda in recent months. Mr. Woolsey said the politically isolated Communist nation is likely to continue to produce, process and stockpile significant amounts of plutonium for use in building nuclear weapons.
 
North Korean Rockets at DMZ
 Mr. Woolsey also warned of "what North Korea calls its war preparations program, including improvements in military capabilities and continuing efforts to bring their economy and society to a heightened state of military readiness" at the expense of its people's social and economic needs. He said North Korea has deployed rocket launchers and artillery to sites close to the demilitarized zone that borders South Korea.
The appearance of the Director of Central Intelligence has become a new tradition in Washington, a practice peculiar to the post-cold-war atmosphere of openness, in which he testifies publicly, albeit circumspectly, and takes questions before his Congressional overseers. In exchange, his concerns about national security matters, including the threat of deeper intelligence budget cuts, become the subject of public debate.
Appearing with Mr. Woolsey, the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, Lieut. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr. of the Air Force called North Korea "the critical major military threat for the next few years." The general said North Korea was only one among several post-cold-war nations where military intelligence officers are confronted with "mysteries -- things that are not predictable, not even knowable."
Sounding a grim note on the subject of the spread of weaponry, Mr. Woolsey said that in the 21st century chemical and biological weapons may pose the kind of threat that nuclear weapons once did. An estimated 25 countries, some hostile to the United States, are trying to build nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, he said.
Iran, Mr. Woolsey said, continues its "ambitious multibillion-dollar military modernization program" and seeks to buy nuclear material and ballistic missiles. North Korea continues to export missiles with a range of 625 miles or more, posing a potential threat to the Middle East. Tracking the intricate underground networks of buyers and suppliers of weapons materiel is a daunting task, he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pondering Its Options As Japan Trade Talks Falter

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Despite last week's warning by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that Japan had to make more concessions on opening its markets, the latest round of trade negotiations between the two sides ended today with no tangible progress, American officials said.
"We are still very far apart; there is no real progress," said a senior American official who took part in meetings on Monday and today in Washington between the top Japanese and American trade negotiators. 
 Some American officials acknowledge that there are considerable risks in pressing the Japanese too hard because of current political turmoil in Tokyo. The Government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa came close to a collapse last week when its program for political change was defeated in Parliament.
The Japanese side, led by Deputy Foreign Minister Koichiro Matsuura, and the American side, led by a White House trade adviser, W. Bowman Cutter, are expected to resume negotiations in Tokyo next week after they consult with Government leaders.
American officials concede that they are now in a quandary, since it is becoming increasing questionable whether these "framework" trade negotiations will produce any significant results by Feb. 11, when President Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa are scheduled to review the talks at a meeting in Washington.
On the one hand, American officials say, the United States could intensify the trade dispute with Japan by introducing punitive trade measures -- as Secretary Bentsen hinted on Sunday in his meetings with Japan's leaders in Tokyo. The risk, however, is that in doing so, the officials may further undercut the already shaky Government of Mr. Hosokawa, whom American officials believe is ready to open Japanese markets if he can get his political house in order.
On the other hand, these officials say, they could try to paper over the differences some more, hoping that Mr. Hosokawa's Government stabilizes and, in the long run, will be able to make concessions. But such a move, they say, may play into the hands of those Japanese officials who oppose making concessions to Washington and are looking for ways to buy time.
Such a delay could be politically embarrassing to President Clinton, who promoted the framework talks six months ago at an economic summit meeting in Tokyo as a breakthrough and the vehicle through which his Administration would do what no other has done: broadly open Japanese markets, with quantifiable proof that results are being achieved.
For now, the mood in the Administration is to hang tough and not accept a face-saving compromise, even if it creates some problems for Mr. Hosokawa. "We have had several meetings in the last couple of weeks, with all the top people in the Administration," a senior American negotiator said, "and everyone is resolute on doing what it takes to get real change out of Japan -- no matter how long it takes. If they continue to come up with a disappointing package, we are not going to disguise that. We like Mr. Hosokawa, and we think he is the future in Japan, but not to the degree that we are ready to describe something that is a mouse as a lion."
 
Accord May Come Yet
 Based on past actions, American officials say, any Japanese concessions will probably come only on the eve of the President's meeting with Mr. Hosokawa. Still, these officials say, it is hard to see at this point how enough progress can be made before Feb. 11 to produce anything beyond a cosmetic agreement, which, they insist, Washington will not abide.
The American negotiators have demanded that Japan open its market in Government procurement -- particularly its purchases of telecommunications and medical equipment -- as well as those involving insurance, autos and auto parts. They also demand that Japan agree to some kind of measure of progress in opening these markets. The Japanese have resisted such indicators, saying such an approach would be managed trade.
In addition, the United States wants Tokyo to stimulate its domestic economy, possibly with a large tax cut, so there will be more money to import goods from the United States, and help reduce Japan's trade surplus, which could reach $60 billion this year. But the Japanese Finance Ministry is resisting any large economic-stimulus program that might involve substantial deficit spending.
