HEADLINE: For Every Ingredient There Is a Season

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
"A GREAT restaurant in the old days was one where you could get anything at any time of year, but that's no longer true," said Michael Romano, chef at Union Square Cafe, at a meeting of chefs last fall to promote the use of local, seasonal and organic produce. "What counts now is what is freshest, most locally available and seasonal."
It's a very old idea that suddenly seems radically new. 
 So new that most chefs still serve pretty strawberries in December (or for Valentine's Day) regardless of how numb they taste. Similarly, while the luscious, year-round vine-ripened tomato remains an elusive grail for chefs and consumers alike, many have such a tomato habit that they are willing to make do with pale, cottony slices alongside the mozzarella. And at Morton's of Chicago, the steakhouse chain that recently opened a restaurant in Manhattan with a standard, national menu, Lauren Malis, the catering manager, said with pride, "Asparagus is always in season here."
But this attitude is far from universal these days. Since the beginning of the 1990's, menus have increasingly taken on truly seasonal colors and flavors, making use of the freshest, most flavorful and, frequently, locally produced ingredients, because these are the ingredients that often produce the best-tasting dishes.
This dedication to seasonal produce did not happen overnight. It began in the 1970's, when chefs started using produce imported from Europe and wondered why haricots verts and baby vegetables could not be grown here. A partnership between chefs and farmers developed. At the same time, health considerations increased produce consumption and environmental concerns began to favor local farming.
Jimmy Schmidt, the chef and owner of the Rattlesnake Club in Detroit, says that lately he has seen more chefs in tune with the seasons. "As people get into sustainable and organic choices, they have to work closer with farmers, and that has led chefs to do more than just call the purveyor like in the old days," he said.
Mr. Schmidt is the chairman of Chefs Collaborative 2000, a coalition of influential chefs that is urging the food industry to use locally grown, seasonal ingredients.
It takes determination. Those vine-ripened tomatoes, juicy peaches and sweet ears of freshly picked corn from nearby farms might be a cinch in summer, but what are chefs caught in winter's hammerlock doing now? Those who have temporarily banished fresh tomatoes and asparagus from the kitchen are discovering how well roasted root vegetables, wilted kale, satiny winter squash soups and dried fruit compotes complement the braised meats and thick seafood chowders that suit the weather.
At the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., a course in ingredients emphasizes seasonality. "We have taken a stand to support the farmers and purveyors in this region," said Charles Rascoll, who trains instructors. Lately, the classes have emphasized kale, root vegetables, mushrooms, cabbages and the like. "Even when they are not locally available, they are still what you usually find in January," he said.
The Griswold Inn in Connecticut relies on local supplies year round. For the last four winters, it has featured a menu of "Connecticut Bounty," including squashes, apples, meats and seafood from the region.
"We have worked with growers and the State Agriculture Department," said Dwight Doolittle, the chef. Butternut squash bisque or oysters stewed with winter vegetables have replaced summer's chilled soup and sole in summer garden sauce.
Some of the late fall and winter vegetables, including bitter greens, sweet roots like parsnips and assertive rutabagas and cabbages, are acquired tastes. But now, American chefs in fine restaurants feature them not only because they are seasonal, but also because they are different and a bit challenging, much the way French chefs dote on organ meats.
Susan Goss, one of the partners in Zinfandel, a new restaurant and market in Chicago where the menu now has hearty, wintry flavors and not a raspberry is in sight, said some people who go out to eat are impressed when a restaurant has raspberries in winter and expect that sort of thing. "But it's really harder to find local farmers to supply the seasonal things we want," she added.
Similarly, Clyde's Restaurant Group in Washington works with local growers whenever possible. "We've become better at it than we were five years ago, when we started, and the farmers are better at it, too," said Tom Meyer, the executive chef for the company, which owns eight restaurants in Washington. "Admittedly, it's tough in winter, but economically you're better off."
Once you consider the price of asparagus and berries out of season, or the quality of fresh corn and tomatoes in January, it's easy to see why chefs are starting to prefer kale, turnips and apples and hard to understand why more home cooks are not following suit. One contributing reason is that supermarkets do not promote seasonal and local items, preferring to advertise "firm slicing tomatoes" shipped from afar. Often, the buying systems in these large chains do not allow for purchases from smaller, local purveyors. Last week in Manhattan, only one of four chain markets on the Upper West Side was selling Swiss chard or kale, and none had celery root.
And if you assume that being in a warm climate removes any notion of seasonality from the menu, think again. "We're just as seasonal down here," said Robbin Haas, the chef at Colony Bistro in Miami Beach. "Our seasons are the opposite of yours. I take a lot of stuff off the menu when I can't get good quality. When our strawberry season is over, I don't serve them."
But the strawberry and tomato habit dies hard. Jonathan Eismann, a transplanted New York chef who is now a chef for and partner in Pacific Time, a Miami Beach restaurant, said some of his customers would not hear of having a salad without tomatoes. "Our tomato season is ending here, so I'll have to make do with what I can get from elsewhere," he said. "In France, they just stop using stuff that's out of season," he continued, adding, "I'm starting to agree with that, but it takes a big change in attitude."
Slowly, the change is coming. Alain Ducasse, the Michelin three-star chef from Monte Carlo, Monaco, summed it up by saying, "The 70's and 80's were the era of the chef and the recipe, but in the 90's, the quality of the ingredient is what counts."
Increasingly, quality depends on chefs working with local farmers, which not only is good for the food on the table, but also promotes local agriculture, cuts transport and encourages production of more perishable organic produce. Last year, the Greenmarket program in New York City published a directory to help its food producers sell wholesale to restaurants, caterers and stores.
"It's been growing year by year," said Barry Benepe, the director. "I was surprised to see places like Lespinasse in the Hotel St. Regis buying from us."
Seasonality is psychologically satisfying. In "The Pursuit of Pleasure," the anthropologist Lionel Tiger said, "There's a seasonality, a scarcity, a harvest, a time for the perfect lingonberry or langoustine or corn or shad roe or oyster."
Some people may still enjoy hefty lamb shanks in air-conditioned restaurants in July and want gazpacho apres-ski. But today, restaurants are offering other choices, and consumers may also begin making them.
"To rely on the same ingredients all year does not inspire the chef," said Mr. Rascoll of the Culinary Institute of America. "For us, the most wonderful thing is being conscious of the seasons, taking advantage of what each one offers, and waiting for the first asparagus in spring."
Tired of Winter? Not With These Dishes

 
Butternut Squash Bisque
(Adapted from the Griswold Inn)
Total time: 45 minutes

 1 large butternut squash, peeled, seeded and diced
 1 large shallot, peeled and diced
 1 large onion, peeled and diced
 1/2 teaspoon white pepper
 1 teaspoon nutmeg
 1 teaspoon minced garlic
 1 bouquet garni (parsley sprig, bay leaf, sprig thyme, 5 peppercorns wrapped in cheesecloth)
 4 cups chicken stock
 1 tablespoon unsalted butter
 2 tablespoons flour
 1/2 cup half-and-half
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
1. Combine the squash, shallots, onion, pepper, nutmeg, garlic, bouquet garni and chicken stock in a large saucepan. Cook over medium heat until the squash is tender, about 20 minutes. Drain, reserving the liquid, discard the bouquet garni and puree in a food processor.
2. Melt the butter in a heavy saucepan. Whisk in the flour, and cook over low heat for 5 minutes, whisking constantly. Gradually whisk in the reserved cooking liquid, and bring to a boil; then, stirring constantly, add the squash puree.
3. Stir in the half-and-half, and season with salt and pepper. Garnish each serving with a sprinkling of freshly ground nutmeg.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 160 calories, 6 grams fat, 20 milligrams cholesterol, 75 milligrams sodium (before salting), 5 grams protein, 25 grams carbohydrate.
 
Smashed Potatoes, Celery Root and Roasted Garlic
(Adapted from Ciao Europa)
Total time: 30 minutes

 1 head garlic
 1 teaspoon extra-virgin olive oil
 1 pound golden potatoes, peeled and diced
 1 pound celery root, peeled and diced (rutabaga can be used)
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
1. Preheat oven to 450 degrees. Slice the top off the head of garlic, brush the top with oil and wrap in foil. Place in the oven, and roast until golden brown, about 20 minutes.
2. Meanwhile, bring a pot of salted water to a boil, add the potatoes and celery root and cook until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain. Return the potatoes and celery root to the pot.
3. Squeeze the soft garlic cloves out of the head, and add to the pot. Smash the ingredients together with the back of a spoon or a potato masher until well-blended. Season with salt and pepper. Reheat briefly and serve.
Yield: 4 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 140 calories, 1 gram fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 25 milligrams sodium (before salting), 3 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate.

Penne With Swiss Chard and Cauliflower
(Adapted from Tom Meyer)
Total time: 30 minutes

 4 tablespoons olive oil
 1 cup diced onion
 1 head cauliflower, cored and separated into very small flowerets
 Salt to taste
 1 pound penne
 4 large cloves garlic, sliced thin
 1 pound Swiss chard, rinsed and roughly chopped
 1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, or to taste
 4 ounces imported pecorino romano, freshly grated.
1. Bring 4 quarts of water to a boil.
2. Heat the oil in a large skillet, add the onion and cook over medium heat until golden and beginning to brown, about 15 minutes.
3. Once water is boiling, add cauliflower and some salt, and cook for 3 minutes. Remove cauliflower with a slotted spoon and set aside. Set aside 1/2 cup of the water.
4. Add the penne to the boiling water, stir it and let it cook for about 8 minutes, until al dente.
5. While the penne is cooking, add the garlic to the skillet and cook for 2 to 3 minutes, until lightly browned; then, add the Swiss chard and cook, stirring, until it wilts, another 3 minutes or so. Stir in the cauliflower and reserved cooking liquid and the red pepper. Season with salt.
6. When the penne is done, drain it, add it to the skillet and toss with the vegetables over low heat. Serve at once, dusted with cheese.
Yield: 6 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 490 calories, 15 grams fat, 20 milligrams cholesterol, 415 milligrams sodium (before salting), 20 grams protein, 20 grams carbohydrate.
 
Seafood Pie
(Adapted from Zinfandel Restaurant)
Total time: 3 hours

 3/4 cup flour
 1/3 cup stone ground cornmeal
 1/4 teaspoon salt, and more to taste
 8 tablespoons cold unsalted butter
 2 1/2 tablespoons cold water
 2/3 cup dry white wine
 36 small mussels, scrubbed
 1 pound monkfish, diced
 1 cup diced, peeled parsnips
 1 1/3 cups diced onion
 2/3 cup diced carrot
 2/3 cup diced celery
 1/2 cup slivered dried apricots
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/4 cup milk.

 1. Combine the flour, cornmeal and 1/4 teaspoon salt in a food processor and pulse to blend. Cut 6 tablespoons of the butter in 1/2-inch bits, scatter them over the flour mixture, and pulse until the mixture is uniformly crumbly. Sprinkle the water over this mixture, and pulse again, about 25 to 30 times, until a ball of dough forms. Shape it into a flat disk, wrap it in plastic and refrigerate 2 hours.
2. Place the wine in a saucepan, bring to a boil and add the mussels. Cover and steam 5 to 8 minutes, until they open. Remove the mussels from the pan, reserving the liquid. Shuck the mussels into a bowl. Mix with the monkfish, and refrigerate.
3. Bring a saucepan of water to a boil, add the parsnips and blanch for 4 minutes. Drain.
4. Heat the remaining butter in a heavy skillet. Add the onion, carrots and celery, and cook over medium heat until nicely browned, about 20 minutes. Add the reserved liquid from the mussels, the parsnips and apricots. Place 1/2 cup of this mixture in a food processor, and puree it; then, return it to the skillet. Stir in the mussels and fish, and season with salt and pepper.
5. Divide this mixture among 4 small souffle dishes, each about 12 ounces, or place the mixture in a 6-cup souffle dish or baking dish.
6. Preheat oven to 400 degrees.
7. Roll out the dough, and cut 5-inch circles if using individual dishes, or roll it to cover a single baking dish. Moisten the edges and place it over the fish, pressing the moistened edges down on the edge of the dish to seal. Cut a couple of slits in the top, brush with the milk and bake about 20 minutes, until lightly browned.
Yield: 4 main-dish servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 600 calories, 25 grams fat, 115 milligrams cholesterol, 200 milligrams sodium (before salting), 30 grams protein, 55 grams carbohydrate.
 
Pear Bread Pudding
(Adapted from Jimmy Schmidt)
Total time: 2 hours

 3 large, ripe but firm Comice pears, peeled, cored and sliced
 Juice of 1/2 lemon
 1 cup sugar
 2 1/2 teaspoons cinnamon
 2 1/2 teaspoons nutmeg
 1 cup dry red wine
 2 cups milk
 Pinch of salt
 5 large eggs, beaten
 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
 1/2 cup dark rum
 4 cups dried whole wheat bread in 1/2-inch cubes
 6 sprigs fresh mint for garnish
 Whipped cream (optional).

 1. Toss the pear slices with the lemon juice; then, place them in a saucepan with 1/2 cup of the sugar, 1 teaspoon each of the cinnamon and nutmeg, and the wine. Cook over medium heat until wine is reduced so it just coats the pears.
2. Preheat oven to 325 degrees.
3. Scald the milk in a saucepan. Remove from the heat, and stir in the remaining sugar and the salt. Mix the eggs with the vanilla, rum and remaining cinnamon and nutmeg, and gradually whisk into the milk.
4. Place the bread cubes in an 8-inch-square baking pan 2 inches deep. Pour the egg mixture over the bread and press down so it absorbs the liquid. Place the baking pan in another pan. Add boiling water to come halfway up the sides. Bake 20 minutes.
5. Spread the pear mixture over the top, return to the oven and bake 20 minutes longer.
6. Cool on a rack about 30 minutes, but serve warm. Garnish each serving with a sprig of mint and, if desired, serve with whipped cream.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving (without cream): 390 calories, 8 grams fat, 190 milligrams cholesterol, 220 milligrams sodium, 10 grams protein, 60 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Sheila Rule 

 BODY:

Feliciano Anniversary
Long before there was the term world music, the Puerto Rican singer and guitarist Jose Feliciano was blending musical styles from the global jukebox. His goal, he says, has always been to "get the races closer to each other."
"My influences are not only in Latin music, but in rock-and-roll and, of course, black music," he said from his home in Weston, Conn. "I didn't learn to sing from Frank Sinatra or Jack Jones, whom I consider great singers, but my influences were people like Sam Cooke, Ben E. King, Ray Charles. I think I related to those singers more because we all suffered. I was born in extreme poverty and, like them, I had my own minority things to deal with, one of which is being blind. I had to really develop my skills before I became famous because at every turn, there was a 'no.' " 
 Mr. Feliciano's skills have won him six Grammy Awards, and his latest album, "Latin Street '92" (Capitol/ EMI Latin), has been nominated this year for best Latin pop album. He is performing his special blend of jazz, pop, Spanish and classical music through Sunday at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village, the neighborhood where his career began in coffee houses 30 years ago.
To mark this anniversary, Mr. Feliciano plans to record a live concert album and a double-album set of new music and old favorites. A pay-per-view concert is to be broadcast on Sept. 30.
A professed radio addict, he credits that medium and, in a roundabout way, classical music with helping him in his craft. "I learned everything I did through radio," he said. "That's how I learned to play the guitar. It was my teacher until I was 16. I had wanted to become a classical guitarist at that time, until I saw a lot of classical musicians starving. I said, 'I better learn to sing.' "
 
MTV and Violence
 MTV wants to make it cool to be nonviolent.
In a national telephone survey of 800 people from 16 to 29 years old last month, the network found that violence had replaced jobs and the economy as the most significant problem facing young people. Some 45 percent said they had been personally affected by violence and 44 percent of men claimed to own a gun. Of teen-agers who did not own a gun, 48 percent were considering buying one in the next year, and two out of three high-school students felt they could easily get a gun. Drugs were considered the leading cause of violence, followed by the economy and unemployment, lack of moral values, the breakdown of the family, and gangs.
"The faces on the covers of magazines or in the news when the story is violent is a young face," said Judy McGrath, president and creative director of MTV. "These are the people considered the perpetrators and the victims. We felt that it was our responsibility to try to use MTV to show the complexity of this from their point of view and to let them have a forum to discuss it on MTV. At one point it looked impossible to make voting cool, but we figured that since we succeeded at that, maybe through innovative ideas we can make nonviolence cool."
Ms. McGrath said that within the next two months, the network plans to begin a weekly program that is "sort of a 'Meet the Press' or 'McLaughlin Group' for twentysomethings" with writers, athletes, musicians, thinkers and others who appeal to MTV's audience.
"We realized we didn't have a forum to discuss some of the issues that young people are interested in," she said, "and felt that maybe if there was a place where Rev. Calvin Butts and Axl Rose and Dr. Dre could talk, it would be helpful. You could talk about everything from what happened to Nancy Kerrigan to carjacking."
The network is also planning documentary-style public service announcements, special programs and local events. It has also asked animators to come up with ideas that approach the issue of violence from different points of view.
MTV itself has often been criticized for what is seen as the programming of videos with violent or offensive content, such as "Beavis and Butt-head," a cartoon program whose two heroes take outrageous stands on social issues. But Carole Robinson, a spokeswoman for the network, calls the criticism a "major bad rap."
"People make assumptions about our programming based on what they think about rock-and-roll or based on what they see on other video outlets and assume that it's MTV they're watching. We have very strict program standards and we do not air videos that glorify violence or contain gratuitous violence, and we will continue to view everything we do with an eye toward that."

HEADLINE: Health Reform -- "Now!"

 BODY:
Bill Clinton had one overriding task in his State of the Union address last night: to re-ignite a fire under the proposal for health care reform that he has chosen as the defining issue of his Presidency. Victory will not come easily. Bitter battles lie ahead in Congress and the country. But no one who heard his demands for immediate action -- "now, not next year or the year after . . . now!" -- or his threat to veto any legislation that falls short of universal coverage can fault him for squandering the chance to state his case, plainly and passionately.
Like other Presidents before him, Mr. Clinton could not resist a prideful review of his first year. Nor could he resist offering a menu of other proposals. Wisely, however, he devoted most of his energies to the big things that seem now to matter most to the American public -- which, besides medical care, include the economy, welfare and crime. And in so doing, he deftly expropriated at least two issues -- welfare and crime -- that the Republicans had hoped to use against him and the Democrats in the midterm. 
 On the economy, Mr. Clinton celebrated what appears to be a gradual recovery, but he promised retraining for those who have been blindsided by the recession. He pledged to seek welfare reform -- a subject on which he has rarely been heard since the lavish promises of his campaign -- and said he would have a bill emphasizing work over welfare ready for Congress's inspection by late spring.
And he spoke at length about crime and violence, combining calls for stronger penalties for repeat offenders, a debatable proposition, and needed help for local law enforcement with an eloquent appeal for the restoration of personal and community values. Without these, he said, little progress can be made against the pathologies of poverty and addiction that underlie the murder epidemic.
Yet in the end it was health care he had come to talk about, and for good reason. In the four months since he set forth his plan, the health care debate has generated more confusion than clarity, and Mr. Clinton needed desperately to wrench back the initiative from his critics in both parties and the major interest groups that had mobilized against him. Knowing that to succeed he must bring those critics along, he shrewdly indicated a willingness to listen to all competing ideas. But he refused to sacrifice the fundamental principle of universal coverage.
One distressing characteristic of this Administration is that it tends to lose focus, requiring Herculean last-minute rescue operations, as in the fight over the budget and Nafta. Mr. Clinton now seems ready to focus on health care. His Presidency pretty much depends on it.

HEADLINE: In America;
Are We Awake Yet?

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Is there reason for hope, or is that naive?
Is the country really waking up to the enormity of its problems of crime and violence, or is this just another phase, driven by the media and lasting only until we are diverted by a killer blizzard, or a celebrity sex scandal, or a surprise locker-room attack by a Buffalo hitperson to the knees of Dallas Cowboy Emmitt Smith? 
 A serious national effort to combat crime has never been needed more than now. Americans are being murdered, raped, beaten, robbed and otherwise terrorized in numbers that suggest an extraordinary evil has been loosed upon the society.
No one is immune, not even toddlers or infants; and no place is exempt, not even schools or houses of worship.
The reality is more horrible than most fiction writers are capable of imagining. The Children's Defense Fund has released a report that says nearly 50,000 children and teen-agers were killed by firearms in the United States between 1979 and 1991. More than 24,000 of those deaths were homicides, the remainder being suicides and deaths from firearm accidents.
A child growing up in the U.S. is 15 times more likely to be killed by gunfire than a child growing up in Northern Ireland. An American child or teen-ager dies from gunshot wounds every two hours.
The only thing more remarkable than those statistics is that the violent deaths of so many young people could occur without a frenzied national outcry, a collective expression of anguish and outrage.
Perhaps that is occurring now.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that crime has become the nation's biggest concern. The major media outlets are top-heavy with stories and special reports about crime. The politicians, irresistibly drawn to the twin lures of opinion polls and television cameras, are flexing their rhetorical muscles.
But we've been here before. Ten years ago President Reagan trumpeted "the most sweeping anti-crime bill in more than a decade." At a White House press conference he promised to provide "long-overdue protection to law-abiding Americans" and "to put an end to the era of coddling criminals."
That was followed by the most violent, crime-ridden decade in the nation's history.
This time could be different. The key will be whether the politicians and other leaders are willing to avoid the notion of simplistic solutions. Crime is an incredibly complex issue and no real breakthroughs can be accomplished by knee-jerk responses of the right or the left.
Obviously something is wrong with a criminal justice system that regularly releases murderers in five and a half years and rapists in less than three. And there is something wrong with a society that can't seem to corral -- and keep corralled -- repeat violent offenders.
But there is also something wrong with a society that takes huge segments of its juvenile population and condemns them to a hideous world of ignorance, fear, alienation and criminal neglect. Something has to be done for children who, at ages 10 and 11, are making detailed plans for their own funerals.
For years we have had advocates of harsh punishment on one side and those who want to attack the root causes of crime on the other. It is past time for each side to listen seriously, and in a spirit of good will, to what the other side has to say.
Beyond the toll of lives lost and pain endured, crime in America costs hundreds of billions of dollars every year. Getting even a modest handle on crime would have an enormous positive effect on society as a whole, including the economy and the continuing problems of health care and welfare.
Crime is the real crisis in America. But doing something about crime also means doing something about drugs, about guns, about jobs and about values. It will require the effort not just of politicians, but the rest of America as well, including educators and the clergy, community and civil rights leaders, and ordinary citizens, especially parents and others who care for young children.
There's also the media, of course, which can be helpful by shifting some of the emphasis from the sensational crimes to the less entertaining search for solutions.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Can We Afford So Many Unskilled Immigrants?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Anthony Lewis claims in "The Politics of Nativism" (column, Jan. 14) that Julian Simon showed in The Wall Street Journal last year that immigrants do not take the jobs of the native born and that the average immigrant family pays $2,500 more in taxes annually than it receives in public services. 
 Professor Simon and Mr. Lewis are clearly wrong on both accounts. George Borjas, a national researcher, wrote in the National Review for Dec. 13, 1993, that Mr. Simon's calculation was quite wrong. Mr. Simon has both immigrants and natives running a surplus. Since welfare programs are supposed to redistribute income from some groups to others, both cannot be running a surplus.
Mr. Lewis overlooks other soundly based estimates of public service costs. For example, the Rand Corporation, hardly a nativist anti-immigrant group, found that each permanent Mexican immigrant in California had a public service deficit of more than $1,000 annually in 1982.
My own recent national study found that the annual after-tax deficit of post-1970 immigrants, both legal and illegal, exceeds $2,000 per immigrant -- a total cost of more than $42 billion. Comparatively, the native born had a surplus on public services after taxation.
This is not surprising. Data from the 1990 Census show that the poverty rate of post-1970 immigrants is 42 percent higher than that of the native born. An immigrant's probability of receiving public assistance, adjusted by the amount of assistance received, is 44 percent greater than that of the native born. High welfare usage, combined with low earnings (meaning low taxes), means that immigrants must run a public-service deficit that is financed by the native born with low welfare and higher earnings (meaning higher taxes).
Professor Simon's long-held belief that immigrants do not displace Americans in the labor market has been repudiated by a number of careful studies in recent years. A consensus is developing (Huddle, Altonji and Card, Walker, Ellis and Barf) that for each six to seven immigrants, one unskilled or blue-collar job is lost to Americans. As Richard Bean of the University of Texas recently showed, slow growth areas are particularly prone to labor displacement. As in California during the 1990's, many native born, according to Randy Filer in a National Bureau of Economic Research study, end up fleeing the region to avoid job losses and falling wage levels.
Although immigration is more than dollars and cents, we still must be more aware of the affordability issue of large-scale unskilled immigration from the third world. No doubt, however, pro-immigration advocates such as Dr. Simon and Mr. Lewis will be willing to dig a little deeper into their pockets during income tax season to help offset our national budget deficit.
 
DONALD L. HUDDLE
Houston, Jan. 18, 1994
The writer is professor emeritus of economics at Rice University.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION: News Analysis;
Economic Safety Zone

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
According to the polls, President Clinton stepped before the nation tonight with his political strength back where it stood when he was inaugurated a year and five days ago, before Zoe Baird, before tax increases, before Cristophe's haircuts, before Somalia and Haiti.
A big reason, the polls indicate, is "the economy, stupid." 
 Economic recovery can give a jet-assisted take-off to a politician; in only seven months, it has lifted Mr. Clinton from the worst approval rating for any President since World War II so early in his term. But a foundering economy can pull a politician back to earth with sickening swiftness; it dragged George Bush down to defeat less than two years after his sweeping triumph in the Persian Gulf.
The President has reached a first-anniversary safe harbor. He outlined what he termed "a hopeful beginning," and it certainly met the two traditional criteria for proclaiming the State of the Union to be sound: no Americans involved in shooting wars abroad, and prosperity for most at home.
 
Treacherous Era
 But who brought about this recovery? Can it be sustained? And even if it is, more or less, will the voters be thinking mostly about their pocketbooks a year, two years, three years from now, or will crime or health care or an unforeseen foreign crisis prove to be the principal preoccupation?
As he has before, with mixed success, the President set an activist's social agenda beside calls for economic restraint, asserting that "there's much more to do" but promising to submit "one of the toughest budgets" ever.
This is a potentially treacherous era for any politician. Mr. Clinton holds office at a time of vast transition. Look in any direction -- to the economy or to diplomacy, to the long-neglected realm of social policy, to Asia or Europe or Latin America -- and everything is shifting. It takes well-honed instincts and more than a little luck to keep afloat in such complex times.
Outside his safe harbor, trouble lurks for the President. There is the minefield of the Whitewater case, the investigation of which will last months if not years. At the moment, the public seems uninterested, even a little irritated that reporters and political opponents keep bringing up the subject. But a stream of revelations, if one materializes, could change that.
 
An Uneasy Majority
 There are the storm clouds looming over Russia, whose leadership and basic direction are in doubt, and over Korea, where conflict is not impossible. A majority of Americans describe themselves to the pollsters as uneasy at the thought of Bill Clinton coping with a major international crisis.
What threatens Mr. Clinton most is the specter of failure on health care. His threat tonight to veto any plan that did not cover everyone showed that Mr. Clinton understood a root political reality: having driven health care to the top of the political agenda in 1992, he must deliver in 1994 or 1995.
It also showed that he realized how hard it will be to do so. In the last six months, important figures on Capitol Hill have made his job more difficult; with two Senators as influential and as different as Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, saying that there is no national health care crisis, some sizzle has gone out of the President's appeals.
Figures indicating that health care inflation is already slowing, partly in response to political pressures over the last couple of years, do not help either. Nor do rival plans that have attracted broad Congressional support.
 
Treading a Thin Line
 Finally, the President's threat showed that contrary to his claim tonight to have broken Congressional gridlock, he knew he must still fight vote by vote for his major measures, though his party controls both houses of Congress.
But if Mr. Clinton has demonstrated anything in the last year, amid his foreign policy mishaps and his trouble with appointments, it is an ability to focus on a problem just when it seems he will not, and to snatch a victory on an important issue at the last minute by the narrowest of margins. He did it on the North American Free Trade Agreement, with a lot of Republican help, and he did it on his economic package, with none.
Those were substantial achievements, and there were others, as the President did not hesitate to remind those hearing him: gun control, national service, a family leave plan and a new voting registration law.
But health care is the big one for him, from a political point of view. Without it, he might win another term, but he would have to be lucky on the economy, and he has already been extraordinarily lucky once on that.
 
Some Credit Given
 It is now clear that the economic recovery really started in the last quarter of 1992, the very quarter in which Mr. Bush was defeated. After a couple of upward revisions, the Government's figures show that something of a boom was under way, with growth at 5.7 percent, but the figures did not show that then, and most voters did not believe it. Through much of that year, only 10 to 15 percent of the public thought things were improving.
In the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, almost a third of those interviewed said the economy was improving, and many gave Mr. Clinton some credit. But people are evenly split on whether he is handling the economy well.
Mr. Clinton has heard the critics who accuse him of promising the moon and taking credit for the sun and the stars, too. He said tonight only that "our economic program has helped to produce" the lowest interest rates in two decades and a surge in investment, job creation and auto sales.
A year ago, after all, he argued that economic recovery required a short-term stimulus program of $30 billion in additional spending. Congress turned him down and recovery happened, anyway. That's enough to make even this self-confident President a little hesitant about explaining how it all works.
It is not clear that the main reason for lower interest rates is Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction program. Many economists believe that interest rates tend to be set globally, and many others would give the Federal Reserve Board more credit than Mr. Clinton. A few would even credit poor Mr. Bush.
It is probably true, though it is hard to prove, that coming to office as the first Democrat in 12 years, Mr. Clinton had to demonstrate to the markets that he was not just another tax-and-spend liberal, who would let the deficit grow relatively freely, if he wanted to keep rates down. A failure even to make a start on deficit reduction would surely have upset Wall Street.
But the basic explanation for what has happened is the natural corrective process that has taken place, maybe nudged ahead a little by Mr. Bush, a little more by Mr. Clinton. Herbert Stein, one of President Richard M. Nixon's main economic advisers, has always said (less loudly when he worked in the White House) that the business cycle was more important than any President's acts.
 Because of a production error, two pictures with the continuation of the article carried identical captions in some copies. The picture at the left showed Mr. Clinton being greeted as he arrived in the House chamber.

HEADLINE: Russia Policy: A U.S. Riddle

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's policy toward the former Soviet Union is being undermined, slowly but surely, by the takeover in Russia, Belarus and Ukraine by politicians advocating populist economics that American officials believe will lead to financial ruin and political turmoil.
Only two weeks ago President Clinton traveled to Moscow and Minsk to deliver his message: more economic reform will lead to more Western aid. The leaders there nodded in agreement and the White House pronounced the visit a rousing success. 
 But no sooner did Mr. Clinton depart than one piece of bad news after another came rolling in from Moscow and Minsk -- everything from the ouster of Russia's key economic reformers to the toppling today of the liberal President of neighboring Belarus.
 
No Reformers, No Reform
 A White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, tried to put the best face on these sharp reversals, responding with the mantra that "we're more interested in the policies than in the personalities" and that "President Yeltsin, as you know, reassured the President that he remains committed to reform."
Yet the fact is that virtually all of the Cabinet members left standing in Russia, Belarus and Ukraine are dedicated to policies that run completely counter to the economic advice President Clinton gave those countries just two weeks ago. It's hard to support reform without reformers.
"I think the news since the President's Air Force One plane took off from Russia has been unremittingly bad," said Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
"The reformers have been leaving, and the Government is being dominated by those people who are skeptical about free markets and want to go on supporting the big state industries. I for one will find it very difficult to support aid for Russia if the Central Bank there continues to pour money and credit into supporting these inefficient state-run industries."
 
Debate on Who Lost Russia
 Behind its public facade of supporting policies, not personalities, the Administration is also scrambling to figure out what to do and bracing itself for what is already being whispered about: a debate on who lost Russia.
What makes influencing events in Russia so difficult, say Administration officials, is that the main problem there is not economics. It's politics. That is, President Boris N. Yeltsin understands the economic advice the West is giving him, which goes like this: The only way for Russia to develop a market economy is if it has a currency that is convertible and stable -- so that banks will be prepared to make loans at reasonable interest rates, so that Russian exporters will be willing to bring their profits back into the country without worrying that their earnings will be eroded by inflation, and so foreigners will be ready to invest there.
The only way to get to that stage is for Russia's Central Bank to stop printing so many rubles. The only way to get to that point is if the Russian Government can close its budget deficit, now running about 9 percent of its gross domestic product. And the only way to accomplish that is if the Government stops subsidizing unprofitable state industries and farms, many of which produce products that sell for less on the world market than the cost of the raw materials that go into them.
This is where economics ends and politics begins. To close such factories and farms would require laying off thousands and thousands of Russians, at least until new businesses sprout up to re-employ them.
The new Government, dominated by conservatives like Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, Central Bank Chairman Viktor V. Gerashchenko and Agriculture Minister Alexander K. Zaveryukha, is not ready to risk the political reaction that such draconian policies would involve -- especially in light of the last election. That was why key reformers Finance Minister Boris Fyodorov and First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar quit.
 
'Voters Have Spoken'
 "The Russian voters have spoken," said Dimitri Simes, Russian affairs expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "The Administration is, on the one hand, praising Russian democracy and Russian democratic elections. On the other hand, it is pressuring Yeltsin to adopt policies that were supported by less than 15 percent of the Russian people -- who voted for the Russia's Choice party, led by Gaidar."
Senior Administration officials say they are trying to deal with this situation by holding to a two-track policy. One track is to keep shining a light on the path of real economic reform that President Clinton laid out in Moscow. American officials hope that after this new Russian Government dabbles in populist economics it will return to its senses and bring back the reformers.
The United States will keep its offer on the table to Mr. Yeltsin's Government: Adopt real economic reform and the United States will galvanize the Group of Seven industrialized democracies to come up with real money to support it.
The other track is to continue pressing ahead with the $4.1 billion in direct assistance already approved by the Congress. That money is not going to the Russian Government but to support various projects on the ground, from small businesses to housing for soldiers, to energy development, to technical advice on subjects ranging from democracy to accounting. These are the "ground-up" projects that the Administration hopes will plant the seeds of capitalism, no matter what the Government in Moscow does.
But this two-track approach may not be sustainable for long.
"I think that is a phoney distinction," Mr. Hamilton said. "If you have hyperinflation again in Russia, all bets are off. If you have hyperinflation it doesn't matter if you supply them $10 billion or $1 billion. You have to have the fundamentals in line."

HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS HINT AT NEW FLEXIBILITY OVER HEALTH PLAN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Administration is willing to compromise on important elements of President Clinton's health plan, Federal officials said today.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told business executives that the Administration was willing to make some concessions on the structure of the purchasing groups through which most Americans would obtain medical coverage under the President's proposal. 
 The Administration, he said, will consider increasing the number of companies that could serve as their own health insurers, bypassing the huge purchasing groups known as regional health alliances.
The issue is not merely technical. The officials who drafted the plan under the direction of Hillary Rodham Clinton said the purchasing groups would not work effectively unless most Americans were enrolled in them. But gaining the support of business, or at least tempering the opposition, could be crucial to the plan's passage.
 
Business Leaders Pleased
 Mr. Bentsen's comments, at a conference co-sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers, pleased business executives, many of whom contend that they can control health costs better than the alliances proposed by President Clinton.
The Secretary's conciliatory comments came just 12 hours after Mr. Clinton took a firm position on another aspect of his proposal in his State of the Union Message, saying he would veto any health care legislation that did not guarantee coverage for all Americans.
Under the Clinton plan, employers would have to buy health insurance for their workers, paying at least 80 percent of the premiums. Very large companies could provide their own insurance, but those with 5,000 or fewer employees would have to obtain such coverage through the alliances.
"I know that this is a major issue for you," Mr. Bentsen told the business leaders today. "You think that the 5,000-employee threshold for joining regional alliances is too high. I understand you want it reduced to 500. We hear you. We're willing to discuss this and the other details of our plan."
But he said, "We can't agree to so low a threshold that everybody opts out and only the smallest companies and individuals remain in the alliances."
Moreover, he said: "I used to run an insurance company. I know how these things work. To hold down premium costs, it's critical that the alliances be large enough so that risk can be spread." Otherwise, he said, the alliances would not have enough economic power to negotiate big discounts from doctors and hospitals.
 
Flexibility on Timetable
 In discussions today with members of Congress, Administration officials said they were also willing to consider changes in their timetable for achieving universal coverage. Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, said after a meeting with the President, "It's possible you will have some kind of a phase-in." And the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said the Administration was willing to discuss that matter with lawmakers.
Many business executives said they preferred a bill introduced by Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee and Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, both Democrats, who seek more modest changes in the health care system. Their bill would encourage employers to provide insurance to employees, but would not require it.
"The Clintons deserve a clear and convincing victory, but not with their plan as written today," said Mr. Cooper, who also spoke at the conference. "Our plan can achieve universal coverage on the same timetable, by 1998, without an employer mandate. Government coercion should be a last resort, not a first resort."
Mrs. Clinton has said the Cooper bill is defective, in part because it contains no explicit guarantee of universal coverage.
Supporters of abortion rights assailed the Cooper bill today, saying it did not guarantee coverage of abortion. The National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League and 39 other groups concerned about women's rights sent letters to members of Congress urging them to withhold or withdraw support for the Cooper bill, which they described as "a vehicle to discriminate against women."
These objections could chill enthusiasm for the Cooper bill among moderate Democrats who support abortion rights. But there were no immediate defections from the Cooper camp.
The Clinton bill defines a wide range of benefits that all health plans would offer. These include "services for pregnant women." While the bill does not define such services, Administration officials have repeatedly said abortion is included.
By contrast, the Cooper bill would create an independent Federal agency to recommend a uniform set of health benefits, and Congress would then vote yes or no on the package as a whole.
Mr. Cooper said the letter reflected "a White House effort to split our coalition." But Kate Michelman, president of the abortion rights league, said, "This was not coordinated with the White House."
In an interview, Mr. Cooper said: "Our bill does not address abortion or any other specific benefit. The bill is neutral on the subject. Our co-sponsors include both proponents and opponents of including abortion in the benefits package."
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, said he saw no inconsistency in his being a strong supporter of abortion rights and a co-sponsor of the Cooper-Breaux bill.
"The bill is drafted in such a way that people who are pro-choice can be comfortable signing on as co-sponsors," Mr. Lieberman said in an interview. "But ultimately, I believe, this question of coverage for abortion services will be decided on the floor of the Senate and the House."
Some supporters of the Cooper bill have suggested that women who want insurance for abortions could pay an extra premium for such coverage if abortion was not included in the standard package of benefits.
But Ms. Michelman said: "That proposal is unacceptable and unworkable. It would discriminate against one service -- abortion."

He conferred with Jerry Jasinowski, left, head of the National Association of Manufacturers, before addressing the group. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Federal regulators and lawmakers want to restrict the compensation paid executives and trustees when mutual savings and loans sell stock to the public or merge with banks. [Page A1.]
The nation's recovery is being hailed by some economists for its noninflationary growth. Although the recovery has skipped some regions and has frequently not increased jobs, these economists argue that it is a model expansion because it has been achieved without a big tax cut or a burst of Government spending -- traditional tools of stimulative policy. HEADLINE: G.O.P. Stance on Health Turns to No-Crisis View

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
After months of struggling to find a position on health care, the Republicans now have a party line: there is no crisis.
"Our country has health care problems, but no health care crisis," Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said in his nationally televised response to President Clinton's State of the Union Message on Tuesday night. 
 Representative Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, the ranking Republican on the House Education and Labor Committee, said after Mr. Clinton's speech that all the nation's health care system needed was fine tuning.
In talking points issued to its members before the President's speech, the Senate Republican Policy Committee proclaimed: "The President insists on calling health care a crisis, but public opinion surveys indicate that the vast majority of Americans are satisfied with their own health care."
It added, "The real crisis in health care is the one President Clinton's one-size-fits-all plan would create."
 
'Common Sense' Advice
 The Republican National Committee, in its pre-speech advice to party members, emphasized the desirability of finding "common sense solutions that can be enacted now" in contrast to Mr. Clinton's proposal for universal health insurance, which would be much harder to pass. It said, "Clinton proposes health care that is always there, but what he is prescribing is Government that's always there."
No position in politics is permanent. The Republicans might well fall back to some of the more conciliatory positions they took in the past if their new position sells badly to the public, in the way that President George Bush's efforts to insist that there was really nothing wrong with the economy in 1992 convinced voters that he was the problem.
The Republicans have changed tack because they found that they were not getting very far on the year's biggest issue by saying, in effect, Yes, there is a crisis, but the President is taking the wrong way out.
And for all the talk of compromise that Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, showered on Republicans, especially on moderate senators, members of the minority party saw little movement their way and had little sense that they would end up getting much credit for any bill that emerged.
 
Vague Party Line
 The party is not in lock step. Some Republicans, like Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, will say -- if asked -- that there really is a health care crisis. Mr. Chafee's complaint on Tuesday night was over Mr. Clinton's threat to veto any health plan that did not include universal coverage that could not be taken away.
But if there are political risks in just going along, more or less, there are also dangers in arguing that there is no crisis when 84 percent of the public, in a mid-January Gallup Poll for the Cable News Network and USA Today, said there was.
William Kristol, the Republican strategist who came up with the no-crisis position, said Republicans ought to contradict the notion that there is a crisis no matter how widely it was held, because it was a superficial answer to a poll question, not a serious perception. "No risk, no glory," he said.
At the center of the Republican dilemma is Mr. Dole, who sounds different notes from time to time, sometimes saying universal coverage must be legislated, sometimes saying that all that is needed is to announce universal coverage as the nation's eventual goal.
 
Politics of 1996
 Mr. Dole may be seeking to solidify his party behind him for a third run for its Presidential nomination in 1996, but he insists he is not thinking about that.
But one thing he plainly is trying to do is unify the Senate Republicans behind him. And although only one of the 44, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, has signed on with the President's proposal, there is a wide range of thinking in the party today, expressed in at least four different bills.
For most of last year, Mr. Dole was involved with Mr. Chafee's legislation, the most sweeping of all the Republican bills and one that if it did not quite promise universal coverage -- as the Clintons diplomatically said it did -- promised to try to get to universal coverage. Mr. Dole negotiated on the terms of the bill and insisted on one key step in loosening its rules -- by saying membership in an insurance purchasing alliance must be voluntary, not mandatory.
He won that point, but then ended up as a co-sponsor of the other major Republican bills, too. And on Tuesday Mr. Dole proposed an approach that would be less generous than any of them. His argument was that steps like barring insurance exclusion of pre-existing conditions or allowing self-employed individuals to deduct all of their premiums from their taxes could be done quickly because everyone wants them and that the tougher issues could be left for later.
The strategy to deal with only issues on which there is widespread agreement sounds more like an argument for Republican unity, behind Mr. Dole, than a serious proposal for legislating. Just last week, Mr. Dole told The Boston Globe that he did not want to support only popular ideas and leave the harder issues for future battles.
A key to Mr. Dole's strength is the threat of a filibuster, which would mean that it would take 60 votes to get legislation through the Senate. He has not directly threatened a filibuster, but his sometime Democratic ally, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, has repeatedly said that compromises sufficient to find 60 votes are essential.
Mr. Moynihan, chairman of the Finance Committee, has also joined the Republicans in asserting there is no crisis in health care. He did that on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," and then retreated on the Charlie Rose Show, which has a much smaller audience, saying that the nation had excellent health care but that on "health care costs, you've got a crisis."
But Mr. Moynihan's fundamental argument, and Mr. Dole's, is that 60 votes will be needed to break a filibuster. Today, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, challenged that expectation and in effect dared the Republicans to obstruct the bill.
He told a committee hearing, "The nation deserves a vote, an up or down vote, on all the key issues."
He also said: "As to a filibuster, American people won't tolerate it. The people of this country will not accept a filibuster on health care."
And Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, the committee's senior Republican and a moderate who hardly ever crosses Senator Dole, joined in, saying, "I am very confident there won't be a filibuster."
She added, "There is a genuine desire to work together to put a constructive health care plan forward."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
'New Democrats' Giving Liberals a Cold Shoulder

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
As Bill Clinton leans ever more urgently into a centrist agenda that urges an overhaul of the welfare system, the passage of tough anti-crime legislation and a strong defense, he has left a forlorn band of liberals standing on the sidelines, fighting among themselves.
Some social progressives are tattered and isolated, fretting together in think tanks and policy-study groups about the tough new punishment provisions in the Senate crime bill, the plan to end benefits to welfare recipients after two years and the huge military budget. 
 Some of their former standard-bearers, people like Walter F. Mondale, the Ambassador to Japan, are now members of the Clinton Administration.
Others are members of Congress who have embraced the pragmatism of the new President. They look for potential gains within Mr. Clinton's economic and social policy agenda.
 
Defining 'New Democrats'
 Right now, they are all earnestly debating what it means to have a President who is a "new Democrat."
In political circles, this is taken to mean that Mr. Clinton is stealing the march from the Republicans, who shut the Democrats out of the White House for 12 years.
But he is doing it under new rules of politics. Although he has made some reductions in the Pentagon budget, they fall far short of what liberal theorists in Congress and elsewhere say he could be doing in a world without a cold war. But maintaining a relatively fat defense budget allows him to fend off attacks from Republicans about his commitment to international security.
There is little money left over for favorite liberal projects.
"Providing jobs for welfare recipients sounds good, but it's not in his budget," said Robert Borosage, director of the liberal Campaign for New Priorities. "Education for every kid, but there's no attempt to even begin to address the savage inequalities in our schools."
 
Scope of Problems
 Michael H. Shuman, the director of the Institute for Policy Studies, said, "The scope of the problem is enormous, and the scope of the solutions Clinton has put on the table so far is small."
The Institute for Policy Studies, a liberal research organization, published a report last week that gave Mr. Clinton an average grade of C for his first year in office. In it, Mr. Shuman calls the President's performance a terrible disappointment, and Barry Commoner, the environmentalist, said the Clinton-Gore Environmental Protection Agency was indistinguishable from the Reagan-Bush agency.
But Mr. Borosage, Mr. Shuman and others are waging an uphill intellectual battle when they try to criticize Mr. Clinton. Stanley B. Greenberg, the White House pollster, maintains that most Americans who identify themselves as liberal support Bill Clinton. And liberal Democrats like Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts and Senators Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Tom Harkin of Iowa reject the notion that there is any such thing as a new Democrat at all.
"It's completely nonsensical," Mr. Wellstone said.
"Mark me down as pragmatic," Mr. Harkin said. 'I've always been for a lot of these issues. You can't say the health care reform package he sent up here to Congress is centrist."
In ways large and small, these traditional Democrats have proved far more loyal to the Clinton White House than have the President's old colleagues in the middle-of-the-road Democratic Leadership Council.
"What the liberals have to accept is the limits," said Al From, executive director of the Democratic Leadership Council. "What the conservatives have to accept is that it is going to cost money."
Mr. Clinton's advisers said that traditional Democratic coalitions have been shifting for decades. The 1960's debates on civil rights are now 1990's debates on race that are as much about economics as access.
And the trade union movement, which has long been the bastion of liberal ideals, has faded in membership and clout. The passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was bitterly opposed by labor unions and many liberal Democrats, cast this decline in the starkest possible light.
 
Vanishing Democrats
 Many other traditional Democrats can no longer claim the constituencies they once owned. Polls show that many black voters, who were often written off as knee-jerk Democrats, are in fact more in line with conservative thinking on issues like crime and welfare. Using this evidence, Mr. Clinton has moved to nullify some of the race-baiting that once obscured arguments on welfare and crime.
This trend does not faze Mr. Shuman.
"The White House calculation is that when people go into the polling booth and, facing the Republican Neanderthal and Ross Perot, that they will vote for Bill Clinton even if they have to hold their nose," Mr. Shuman said. "There is some truth to that. But my point is, Clinton did not win by a landslide and simply with the absence of the liberal leadership stumping on his behalf, raising money and mobilizing constituents, he could lose."
But this White House has never had an easy relationship with the most liberal elements of the Democratic Party, and many of Mr. Clinton's political advisers remember that some of their harshest critics sat on their hands or endorsed candidates like Jerry Brown and Mr. Harkin during the 1992 primaries.
Mr. Harkin is now, well, pragmatic, about the whole thing.
"There has been a 20-year campaign to paint liberalism as a bad word, and liberalism as old-fashioned," Mr. Harkin said. "And it worked pretty well. I see some hope under President Clinton that we will define what these terms really mean."

HEADLINE: Awaiting Quake Aid, and Riot Aid, Too

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26

 BODY:
On battered streets where vacant lots display the unhealed damage of the 1992 riots, earthquake survivors in South-Central Los Angeles are again struggling to recover from disaster, even as public sympathy dwells on their wealthier neighbors in the San Fernando Valley.
Far from the epicenter and the limelight in this new catastrophe, these residents of the inner city stand patiently in long lines at disaster relief centers or sit on newly broken porches as they wait for Federal loans to be approved. 
 Though the area around the Northridge section, about 25 miles away at the earthquake's epicenter, suffered the most serious destruction, the quake caused millions of dollars of damage in the South-Central area.
Along Adams Street, at businesses in the Baldwin Hills Crenshaw Plaza, at the state's only black-owned bank, the Founders National Bank, and at a half-dozen of the storefront churches that serve the community, shattered glass, fallen walls and broken foundations display the broad reach of the earthquake.
 
Damage Up to $12 Million
 "Damage has been piled upon damage," said Councilwoman Rita Walters, and the toll continues to rise as building inspectors make their way through the area. In the last four days, she said, the estimate of damage to her district, which includes about half of the South-Central area, rose to $12 million from $4 million.
Nick Delli Quadri, the senior structural engineer with the city's Department of Building and Safety, said nearly 1,000 structures were damaged in the area, with 800 dwellings declared unsafe.
Michael Gruett, a senior building mechanical inspector for the city, said many buildings in South-Central Los Angeles were built before strict building codes went into effect and therefore suffered extensive damage to foundations, supporting walls and chimneys.
At the First A.M.E. Church, the largest church in the area, the Rev. Cecil Murray said the church was sheltering 175 quake survivors and expected to feed 1,000 over the next 10 days.
"There is no way of knowing the full extent of the damage in all areas of South-Central," he said. "We can only guess, but for instance, five black churches have been shut down because of damage."
Though the earthquake hit hardest in the distant northern areas of the city, he said, there was an "emotional epicenter" in the South-Central area, where people continue to be battered by unemployment and a shrinking economy.
Some people waiting for disaster aid at a newly opened office of the Federal Emergency Management Agency expressed a familiar grievance that the city's poor black residents were being overlooked.
"We are the neglected, the overlooked," said Courtney Williams, 30, who is unemployed. "They feel the black community is not as important as the valley. I am quite sure they are going to be taken care of in the valley before we are."
Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas, who represents part of the area, also said he felt that the outside world had been slow to turn its attention to the South-Central area, but he noted that 2 of the 16 FEMA disaster-aid centers and two shelters had been opened there.
 
Comparing the Aid
 Although he has complained that promised relief for the riots has been slow to arrive, he argued that the two disasters could not fairly be compared.
"There is a decidedly different set of dynamics that operate here," he said. "The matter of racial justice or injustice and the matter of the criminal justice system is not at stake here. What we are dealing with now is God's justice."
The Clinton Administration has moved quickly to address the damage of the earthquake, setting up relief centers and tent cities, skipping bureaucratic steps in issuing 18-month rental vouchers for low-income housing and speeding the arrival of the first Federal funds and asking Congress for $6.6 billion more in disaster relief. Officials have estimated that the earthquake caused $15 billion to $30 billion in damage.
The White House aid proposal would ask California to match just 10 percent of the total contribution, rather than the 25 percent that is usually required, in a sign of the Administration's sensitivity to the state's economic difficulties and its political importance.
By contrast, the Bush Administration moved more slowly with relief assistance after the riots in April and May of 1992, in which damage citywide was estimated at $1 billion. Half a year after offering an "action agenda" that won bipartisan support, President George Bush vetoed a bill that included major elements of his relief package. These were a plan for enterprise zones to attract new business to the area and $38 million in tax credits to encourage low-income housing.
 
Riot Aid in Private Hands
 The Bush Administration promised a total of $1.2 billion in riot relief, but nearly two years later only about $600 million has actually been paid out, said Linda Griego, a former Deputy Mayor who was the chief city liaison to the Federal relief effort and remains active in city government.
For his part, Tom Bradley, then the Mayor, turned over the major riot-reconstruction responsibility from government hands to a private consortium, Rebuild L.A., and appointed as its head Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner.
In the end, lacking the clout of a government agency, that group fell short of early hopes. When Mr. Ueberroth resigned under heavy criticism last May, his organization said it had won about $500 million in commitments from corporations for relief.
But much of that money was pledged for donated equipment, buildings or support for training programs, rather than the hoped-for creation of enterprises that would bring jobs to the area. And the numbers have been criticized as inflated, including a number of factories or supermarkets already in planning stages, or projects situated far from the hard-hit areas.
 
Less Charged and Value-Laden'
 Sherry Bebitch-Jeffe, a political scientist at Claremont Graduate School, said several factors separated the disasters and the government responses to them: the differences in style of new administrations, both in Washington with Mr. Clinton and in Los Angeles with the new Mayor, Richard J. Riorden; the fact that the earthquake epicenter was in a more affluent, politically influential area, and the fact that an earthquake is not as politically and philosophically divisive as an inner-city riot.
"The riots were framed in sociopolitical terms, which are always politically dicey," Ms. Bebitch-Jeffe said. "This disaster is far less charged and value-laden."
Deputy Chief Bayan Lewis of the Los Angeles Police Department, who is the interdepartmental coordinator of local relief efforts, said that he knew South-Central residents were angry about the slow response to the riots and that he had seen "a very different response this time."
"The Federal Government moved in here much more quickly," he said. "We were offering to open up the disaster-assistance centers probably before we were even ready for them. For the riots the response was much, much slower. The citizens are left with a bitter taste because they are in a section of the city that has not felt any renovation after the riots."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

METRO DIGEST
 
INQUIRY ON SOLARZ ENDS WITHOUT CHARGES
A Justice Department investigation of former Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn ended without charges, but the White House indicated that it was not yet prepared to nominate him as Ambassador to India. A9.
 
HARDEST CHOICES SHIFT TO PATIENTS
New technology offers medical patients a fantastic explosion of information and treatment possibilities. But it has also increasingly required patients to make decisions that tear at their very souls. A1. 

NEW YORK CITY
 
HOSPITALS CHAIRMAN TO REDUCE STAFFS
The chairman of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation said that he would eliminate 1,300 jobs immediately through a combination of attrition and layoffs to help close an unexpected $160 million budget shortfall. A1.
 
TENSION PERSISTS IN CROWN HEIGHTS
Crown Heights, Brooklyn, divided by antagonisms long before it was torn by violence in the summer of 1991, is a neighborhood that continues to operate under the strains of suspicion and anger, poverty and fear. A1.

Hints of the mental and spiritual world of the defendants, one involving powerful strains of anti-Americanism and hatred of Jews, emerged as lawyers debated what evidence should be allowed in the remaining days of the World Trade Center bombing trial. B4.

HEADLINE: Mayors Uneasy On Plan to Shift Aid for Transit

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
A Clinton Administration budget proposal for a 25 percent reduction in mass transit operating subsidies received a cool reception today from many mayors and city officials. They said the plan would force them to increase subway and bus fares and curtail routes and services.
The proposal in the Administration's draft budget would reduce the current $800 million a year in Federal mass transit operating subsidies to $600 million. It would earmark the remaining $200 million for capital improvements, meaning that the money would be spent more slowly on such things as equipment. Cities had been using the $800 million to subsidize fares. 
 "We view the Federal role as more one of supplying the capital than of subsidizing riders," said Brian Cudahy, a spokesman for the Federal Transit Administration.
Mayors and other city officials, interviewed at the winter session of the United States Conference of Mayors, acknowledged today the need for new equipment for their aging mass transit systems. But they said that cutting the operating funds would undermine the use of the systems by placing a greater financial burden on inner-city residents who are the least able to pay.
 
Compared With G.O.P. Plans
 Although reluctant to criticize President Clinton, some of the officials noted that the proposal seemed more in keeping with the views of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, conservative Republicans who had repeatedly sought to reduce the operating subsidies. The officials said they were pleased, however, that Mr. Clinton had abandoned his earlier proposal to phase out the transit aid program over three years.
The Administration proposal is opposed by Senator Frank J. Lautenberg, the New Jersey Democrat who heads the Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation and is one of the gatekeepers on Federal money for transportation.
"Operating assistance is a critical element in efforts to keep transit fares affordable," Mr. Lautenberg said in a letter this month to Leon E. Panetta, Director of the Office of Management and Budget. "Reasonable fares are central to ongoing efforts to enhance the attractiveness of mass transit to commuters and relieve budgetary pressures many Americans are experiencing due to unemployment and downward pressure on wages."
But other Congressional leaders say the proposed reduction in mass transit operating funds is an equitable tradeoff for an increase in money for the nation's highways, which is also proposed in the draft budget. These leaders include Representative Norman Y. Mineta, the California Democrat who heads the Committee on Public Works and Transportation. Mr. Minetta agrees with the Administration that capital funds are more important than operating subsidies, an aide said.
 
Aid to the Affluent Cited
 Some Congressional leaders say the operating subsidies wrongly benefit affluent mass transit riders as well as those who are poor. They cite the Red Line of the Washington Metro system, which serves a prosperous area of the city and its suburbs. These leaders want Federal transit aid earmarked for those who really need it.
The Administration proposal would have its greatest impact on smaller cities like Albany and Peoria, Ill., which receive 40 percent to 50 percent of their mass transit revenue from the Federal Government. Cities like New York receive about 5 percent of their mass transit revenue from the Federal Government. But even representatives from the nation's largest cities expressed concerns about the proposal.
"Whether it's service cuts or increased pressure on the fare, it's the wrong thing to be doing at a time when we're struggling to increase ridership," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman and chief executive officer of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Under the proposal, the New York metropolitan area would lose $23 million a year in operating subsidies out of the total of $90 million it now receives, Mr. Stangl said, adding, "I don't think it's at all in the national interest, and it's certainly not in our interest." In the years ahead, $23 million would be shifted to capital spending grants under Mr. Clinton's proposal.
Mr. Stangl's views were echoed at the mayors' conference. Mayor Norman Rice of Seattle, a Democrat, said: "It will hurt, especially at a time when we're trying to get people out of their cars. If we don't get that Federal help, it's going to be hard to reduce pollution and traffic congestion."
 
Mayors Voice Objections
 Samuel Halloin, the nonpartisan Mayor of Green Bay, Wis., which receives 40 percent of its mass transit revenue from the Federal Government, said the Administration proposal "would make it very difficult to continue" the area's mass transit system. "It would place a much greater burden on our property tax," he said, "and I'm not sure that could be justified."
Mayor Mike Bergin of Waterbury, Conn., a Democrat, said: "Connecticut's cities do not have the resources to offset that cut. Those dollars will have to come from somewhere, and the people who use mass transit are the people who can least afford it. Mass transit is most needed in the urban areas, which are most in need."
Mass transit operating subsidies are the big loser in the President's draft budget, which would increase money for highways, aviation and railroads. The overall mass transit budget would remain the same, $4.6 billion.
