HEADLINE: Atlanta Journal;
Boosterism Isn't Gone With the Wind

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Sure, the Super Bowl rematch of Dallas and Buffalo has all the magic of Bucknell versus Colgate. And, yes, there is the spectacle of blacks and whites haggling over the Confederate battle flag as if the Civil War were still going on.
But four days before Super Bowl XXVIII and 905 days before the 1996 Olympic Games in the City Never Too Busy to Preen, Atlanta is reveling in its status as a city on the rise, sometimes to the point of forgetting that it is only the host, not the show. 
 "You have 750 million people around the world that will see the Super Bowl -- and Atlanta -- on television," gushed Spurgeon Richardson, president of the Atlanta Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Watching the games last weekend, you'd just hear, 'Atlanta! Atlanta! Atlanta!' It just puts chills up and down your back."
Self-promotion has a long and honored tradition in Atlanta, which, 31 years after being burned to the ground by Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, had bounced back far enough to promote itself to the world at the Cotton States and International Exposition of 1895. Still, the booster virus seems to be mutating at a record rate as Atlanta increasingly finds itself in the national spotlight.
The Atlanta metropolitan area led the nation in job growth last year. And a recent Louis Harris survey of international executives placed the city first by a wide margin as the most favored location in the United States for expansion or relocation.
Of course, Atlanta has also led the nation in violent crime in recent years. If the Super Bowl had been held here last week, it would have taken place in a city where a freeze had broken enough ancient water mains that showers and baths were forbidden. And more than a few people have begun to wonder: If the 100,000 visitors to the Super Bowl have taken up all the hotel rooms for 85 miles, what happens when two million people show up for the Olympics?
But this is not a week for such trifles. Besides, officials like Mayor Bill Campbell and Billy Payne, president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, are working overtime touting the city's ability to handle what comes.
"They're going to see Atlanta, and they're going to say, 'Wow, what a beautiful city!' " said Jim Breedlove, of the Super Bowl Host Committee. "It's a combination of the old and the new and the modern, and it works."
Not all visitors are dazzled. Some seem puzzled that Atlanta's most-talked-about attractions seem to be its state-of-the-art adult entertainment parlors, especially popular with conventioneers. And some black officials and clergy are still promising to picket the Super Bowl on Sunday because the Georgia Dome will fly the state flag, which incorporates the Confederate battle flag.
"It signifies that Georgia is still a very racist state," said State Senator Ralph David Abernathy 3d, son of the former civil rights leader.
Charles Lunsford, of the Sons of Confederate Veterans, shot back: "This is part of a much broader national attack on everything relating to the Old South. We see it as oppression and censorship of our people."
And, partly because of the mythos of the South, some visitors are finding Atlanta to be more bloodless and neutered than they had expected.
"We're cowboys and culture, and we're comfortable with it," said Bud Kennedy, a columnist with The Fort Worth Star-Telegram as he pored through Atlanta's promotional literature. "I guess they're trying to say Atlanta is a place with a lot of shiny glass buildings where businessmen in tassled loafers make cellular phone calls from their cars."
But even The Dallas Morning News, in a city that itself is no slouch at hype, published a news article this week rather enviously reporting that Atlanta seems to have become what Dallas wants to be. And experts say there is substance as well as hype to the upbeat mood here.
"Lord Keynes said one of the things economists never give enough weight to is psychology," said Richard Nathan, an urban expert at the State University of New York at Albany, referring to the economist. "Attracting events like the Super Bowl or the Olympics makes people feel good about where they live. So it's not just puffery. It's real."
Even Atlanta's critics often end up seduced.
Pearl Cleage, a local playwright and author who grew up in Detroit, said Atlanta was the only place she had ever been where poor people sounded like the Chamber of Commerce when they talked about the city. And sometimes, she said, that reflects a place unwilling to confront its problems.
"I think the willingness to pretend is a major problem in Atlanta," she said. "You have meetings of powerful black people and powerful white people, and you can almost see them breaking out in a cold sweat, just trying to pretend. You know, 'Everything is O.K. Everything is O.K.' "
But, Ms. Cleage added, whenever she gets away, as she did this week to Northampton, Mass., something strange happens. "I was away for a week, and I said: 'Oh, my God, I need to go home. What am I doing up here? These people aren't talking about anything. Plus, their weather's terrible.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite the gala mood that pervades Atlanta, the Super Bowl host, this week, there is haggling over the use of the state flag, which incorporates the Confederate battle flag. The flag was raised on Tuesday outside the Georgia Dome, where the championship game is to be played on Sunday. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Earthquake Sends Crime on Vacation

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Now the good news from the Great Quake.
On any given normal day in Los Angeles, the police make roughly 500 arrests, about a third of them for major crimes like murder, rape and robbery. 
 But these are not normal days in Los Angeles, especially when it comes to policing.
In the 10 days since the quake, the total number of arrests made in the city hardly equals one day's work in the pre-quake days, about 500 in all -- or roughly 50 arrests a day.
Why?
"We've tripled the number of officers patrolling the streets," explained Lieut. John Dunkin, the chief spokesman for the Los Angeles Police Department.
Normally, there are about 700 officers out on patrol during each shift. But since the quake, about 2,000 have been working every shift.
And at times they have been augmented by several hundred National Guard troops, though most of them are now gone since looting has not been a serious problem.
"It's proof of what we've always argued," Lieutenant Dunkin said. "You put enough officers on the street and you'll get results in cutting the crime rate. We put a lot of officers in areas that were hard hit, but we also put extra officers most other places because there was a bit of damage just about everywhere."
Did the quake have any special impact on the criminal mind?
"Nope," Lieutenant Dunkin replied. "There was no significant increase or decrease in any particular kind of lawbreaking, only the decrease in crime over all."
Now the bad news.
Starting tonight, the number of officers patrolling will return to pre-quake levels except in the hardest-hit neighborhoods, mostly in the San Fernando Valley.
 
Small Talk About Big One
 Last week's quake was a major quake by any reckoning, registering 6.6 on the Richter Scale, among the worst ever to occur in Southern California. But it wasn't what Californians like to call the Big One.
The Big One is the quake that scientists say is lurking out there somewhere, sure to cut loose at some point because of the steady buildup of earthly forces beneath the West Coast as gigantic plates of rock shift and bump about. The prediction is that the Big One will unleash 200 times more energy than last week's quake, or will hit at least 8.3 on the Richter scale.
But when?
With every aftershock from last week's quake -- and there have been thousands of them -- new rumors spread, feeding on the gossip at the water cooler and the uninformed chitchat over lunch and, of course, running rampant on talk radio.
Get ready. Maybe not today. Maybe not tomorrow. But soon.
One rumor had a seismologist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena packing up the family van and heading off for safer turf.
Concerned that such rumors were adding to the jitters already manifest all over the city, disaster officials asked seismologists for an informed reading about the Big One.
Back came an assessment, sent to all government officials and news outlets. The finding: There will be a Big One, but nobody -- nobody -- can predict when with any degree of accuracy. Aftershocks follow every quake and typically diminish in both frequency and strength, which is what is happening here this week.
 
Homelessness Redefined
 The city of Santa Monica, perched in liberal wealth and sunny beauty on the Pacific bluffs west of downtown Los Angeles, has long been a place of refuge for the homeless. Sometimes referred to as "the People's Republic of Santa Monica," it has a policy, hammered out in heated argument, of not running off the down-and-out.
A noble approach. But not so noble that good fortune smiled down on Santa Monica when the quake occurred.
Like many parts of greater Los Angeles, Santa Monica took a pretty good hit. And when the disaster aid centers opened, among the first in line were the homeless.
They were turned away, told that since they had possessed nothing to begin with, they had lost nothing, and therefore would get nothing.
"We have to get people back to their pre-existing state," explained Kathleen Maher, a Red Cross worker.
To which one homeless person, Ken Nelson, replied, "The politicos must realize that it is almost impossible to distinguish between the national disaster homeless and the natural disaster homeless."
 
Most Stay Put
 The Great Quake was only the latest disaster to strike Los Angeles.
First came recession, followed by riot, followed by fire, followed by rain and mud. For many, the California dream has become a nightmare.
Still, even in the aftermath of the hardest blow of all, most Los Angeles residents say they plan to pick themselves up and rebuild, not pick up and leave.
True, job recruiters report some problems persuading new workers to move here. True, moving companies report an increase in demand for vans for out-of-state moves or moves to parts of the state less prone to earthquakes.
But these are the exceptions, a new poll by The Los Angeles Times says. It found that only about 1 of every 30 Angelenos planned to flee.
Robin Rees will not be among them.
"I'm California born and raised, and I'm not going anywhere -- except to a new apartment," she said this morning, standing in front of her old, quake-demolished apartment in the city's Northridge section atop the epicenter of the quake.
She was clutching a bouquet of paper roses, given to her by a grimy fireman who had recovered it in what was left of her mangled apartment. Everything else that the fireman had been able to recover rested at her feet, in two black garbage bags.
"Life in California is good, whatever else happens," Ms. Rees said. "I can pick up and start again. I will pick up and start again."
She poked a shoe at one of the sacks.
"Anyway," she added, looking up and flashing a grin, "I'm a Valley Girl. Like val gals are different. Right?"

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
An ugly subject: the prejudice against hiring homely people.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
DO blondes have more fun? Social scientists have yet to nail down the answer. But economists now have good reason to believe that blondes make more money -- or at least the trim, attractive ones do. New studies show that men and women (with any hair color) who are rated below average in attractiveness by survey interviewers typically earn 10 to 20 percent less than those rated above average.
One is tempted to write off the results as proof that idle econometricians are the Devil's helpers. But the findings from Daniel Hamermesh of the University of Texas and Jeff Biddle of Michigan State are complemented by other research showing that obese women are also at a considerable earnings disadvantage. And they could figure prominently in the very serious business of deciding who is protected by the three-year-old Americans With Disabilities Act. 
 Professors Hamermesh and Biddle based their estimates on surveys detailing the earnings, skills, work, race and family background of some 7,000 individuals. Interviewers also ranked the interviewees' attractiveness on a scale from one ("strikingly handsome") to five ("homely"). Those rated below average earned 7 to 10 percent less than average, while attractive men and women both enjoyed a 5 percent earnings premium.
The two economists anticipated the skeptics' questions. Yes, interviewers do seem to agree on the beauty rankings. Yes, it is true that better-paid workers can afford better clothes. But independent statistical tests suggest that this effect does not distort the results. Nor is it likely that attractiveness ratings are a proxy for race or social class; the family background information included in the equations separately accounts for this effect.
The Hamermesh-Biddle evidence of discrimination is mirrored in studies of the impact of obesity. Steven Gortmaker and colleagues at Harvard found that the 5 percent most overweight in a sample of 10,000 did less well in life, even when those with chronic health problems related to obesity were eliminated from the sample. Fat women lived in households with, on average, $6,700 less in yearly income.
Sanders Korenman, the director of the University of Minnesota's Center for Population Analysis and Policy and Susan Averett of Lafayette College think this effect largely works through the marriage "market" rather than the job market: Obese women are less likely to be married, and those who are married are likely to have spouses with lower earnings. Still, their own analysis show a residual relationship between earnings and obesity.
While researchers are certain that unattractive people are victims, they can only speculate on why. Employers may avoid them for the same reason racists avoid co-workers with different skin color. But it is also possible that attractive people are better workers because they have greater self-confidence and leadership abilities.
Then, too, there is the chance that the earnings disadvantage reflects customers' preferences. If, for example, clothes shoppers are more likely to buy from svelte salespeople, retailers otherwise indifferent to looks would have incentives to discriminate.
By the same token, almost everyone agrees that prejudice against unattractive people is reprehensible. But there is no consensus that employers should be obliged to hire unattractive people if they are actually less productive. And even if employers are morally obliged, legal scholars still think some forms of prejudice are worse than others. "We didn't fight the Civil War to end discrimination against ugly or fat people," says Michael Horowitz of the Manhattan Institute.
Mr. Horowitz is surely right about Washington's motives for defending Fort Sumter in 1861. But it remains a matter of dispute what Congress had in mind in the Americans With Disabilities Act in 1990. Charles Shanor, a professor of law at Emory University, notes that the law defines disability as "a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities." Garden-variety fat is thus not a disability, he argues. Nor, by the same token, would a homely appearance be.
But a Federal appeals court did uphold a Rhode Island's jury award of $100,000 in back pay to a healthy 300-pound woman under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 -- the law on which the Americans With Disabilities Act is closely modeled. The judge ruled that even if the impairment did not "substantially limit" a major life activity, the fact that she was perceived as handicapped qualified her for protection.
Where the dust will settle is anyone's guess. On the one hand, courts have generally been reluctant to label a common condition unrelated to trauma or disease as a disability. On the other, there is now solid evidence that homeliness does affect earnings and is thus a liability in the workplace.
What's more, the Rhode Island judge linked the concept of disability to "an immutable condition that one is powerless to control." By this standard, Mr. Biddle argues, "if you can win on obesity, you should be able to win on ugly."

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs 12.66 Points As Utility Stocks Rebound

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
A rally in utility stocks and a decline in interest rates helped the stock market to an advance yesterday. Telephone, retail, bank and tobacco issues also climbed.
Long-term interest rates, as reflected in the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, fell amid expectations that the Federal Reserve Board would leave interest rates unchanged for months. That view was supported by a Fed governor, John P. LaWare, who said that inflation was not accelerating and that consumer prices might rise just 2.5 percent this year. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.66, to 3,908.00, ending a two-day decline.
A turnaround in the Dow utilities average, often used as an interest-rate barometer, helped push the rest of the market higher, said Joseph DeMarco, managing director of equity trading at Marinvest, a unit of HSBC Asset Management.
 
Utility Index Up 3.49
 The 15-stock utility average rebounded 3.49 points, to 221.46, after falling Monday to its lowest level in more than a year. "Maybe that's a sign of a bottom in the utility index, which would help support, to some degree, the level of the market," Mr. DeMarco said.
The Nasdaq combined index gained 2.41, to 788.80, led by increases in MCI Communications, Nextel Communications Inc. and Oracle Systems.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500 index climbed 2.28, to 473.20. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by almost 4 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was 304.7 million shares, down from 326.1 million on Tuesday.
Among the utilities, Public Service Enterprise Group rose 3/4, to 30 3/4; American Electric Power was up 3/4, to 35 7/8; Pacific Gas and Electric rose 1/2, to 33 1/4, and Peco Energy, formerly Philadelphia Electric, added 5/8, to 28 1/8.
Traders said the direction of long-term rates might be influenced more by the release of fourth-quarter gross domestic product statistics tomorrow than by Treasury note auctions yesterday and Tuesday.
"Maybe people are feeling rates can work downwards from these levels," Richard Meyer, head of institutional trading at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said.
The G.D.P. report is expected to show that the economy grew at an annual rate of 5.4 percent in the fourth quarter of 1993, the fastest rate since late 1992, according to a Bloomberg Business News survey of 17 economists.
"The economy is doing reasonably well," Jim Benning, a trader at BT Brokerage, said. "I don't think there's a big threat for interest rates to go significantly higher for at least six months or a year."
 
Effect of Clinton Address
 As for profits, Alan Ackerman, executive vice president at Reich & Company, said, "There's still a feeling that earnings will be good and dividends will increase," although some investors were concerned that President Clinton's State of the Union address on Tuesday night might translate into more spending and higher taxes.
Analysts said the address mighthave helped stocks by convincing many investors that the Administration's legislative agenda is likely to be watered down.
"The Republicans are going to give Clinton a real hard time this year," Mr. Benning said.
The advance of the Dow industrial average was fueled by Bethlehem Steel, up 1 5/8, to 23 1/4; J. P. Morgan, up 1 3/8, to 69 3/4, and Sears, Roebuck, up 1 7/8, to 53 7/8.
Bethlehem Steel said its fourth-quarter loss widened to $2.78 a share, from 69 cents in the period a year earlier. Excluding restructuring charges, the results were better than some analysts had estimated.
I.B.M. dropped 1 7/8, to 56 3/8. Its chief financial officer, Jerome York, said the company would report at least break-even results in the current quarter. Some analysts were expecting the company to report earnings of 15 cents a share, according to Zacks Investment Research.

HEADLINE: Senator Asks End to Threats Against China

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
A leading Democratic voice on trade in the Senate says the policy of annually threatening China with trade sanctions is ineffective, harmful to the reform process in China and should be permanently scrapped this June if China meets the Administration's demands.
Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who chairs the Senate subcommittee on international trade, said in a speech prepared for delivery on Thursday that if the Clinton Administration actually carried out its threat to withdraw China's trade benefits it would be like dropping "the equivalent of a nuclear bomb" in terms of the economic and political fallout. 
 Senator Baucus has long opposed using tariffs as a tool to influence China's behavior. His state, Montana, is a major exporter of wheat to China. But his remarks echo a view emerging from the Administration itself in recent weeks, and suggest that a new consensus could be forming among Democrats on China policy. Most Republicans are already opposed to linking trade status to human rights.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen also suggested during his visit to Beijing last week that if China could meet the Administration's human rights conditions, set out in an executive order last June, then the White House would then be prepared to scrap, once and for all, the annual threat to withdraw preferred trading status on the basis of China's human rights record. Most-favored-nation status allows China to export its products to the United States at the lowest possible tariffs.
Supporters of a policy change argue that trade with China is now so economically important to the United States, and so important for encouraging political reform in China, that if Washington ever actually had to carry out its sanctions threat the effects would be disastrous for both American business and Chinese reform.
One reason both Mr. Baucus and Mr. Bentsen are speaking out now is in the hope of influencing China by holding out the carrot of permanent de-linking of trade and human rights issues.
Still, there are many on Capitol Hill who have doubts about the proposal. "There is developing a view that we need to look at the question of whether M.F.N. is still a way to achieve our goals," said Representative Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who chairs the House Foreign Affairs Committee. "But I don't think Congress is there yet. If you drop M.F.N., what do you put in its place to influence China?"
In a speech prepared for the U.S.-China Business Council, Senator Baucus says that unless there is more overall progress by China on the human rights front, the Clinton Administration will have no choice but to carry out its threat to withdraw trade preferences from China in June, when it comes up for annual review.
If trade preferences are withdrawn, Mr. Baucus says, average tariffs on Chinese goods would rise from 8 percent to 40 percent.
"It would become almost impossible for China to export to the United States," Mr. Baucus says. "China would retaliate immediately. Our trade with China, except for smuggled textiles, would disappear."
United States exports to China are valued at about $9 billion a year, Mr. Baucus says. He estimates that the cancellation of this trade would affect about 180,000 American jobs.
"Perhaps even more troubling are the implications of revoking M.F.N. for reform in China," Mr. Baucus says. "Nothing can set freedom back farther than revoking M.F.N."
"M.F.N. is an outdated tool," Mr. Baucus said. "The core M.F.N. law, the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, is a cold war law dealing with the right of Soviet Jews to emigrate. It is an anachronism."
He says that if China violates American trade laws, then the United States should retaliate with specific sanctions, as it did recently with textiles. Human rights abuses, he says, should be answered with canceled high-level contacts, public censure or revocation of American support for World Bank loans to China. In sum, he says, the United States should attempt to influence China's human rights, trade and arms control policies without aborting the overall economic relationship.

HEADLINE: Senate Report Says Agencies Plotted to Favor Contractors

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The Defense Department, the Postal Service and other agencies devised elaborate practices of circumventing Federal law, a Senate report says, so that hundreds of millions of dollars in Government business could go to favored companies.
The practice, called off-loading, deprived taxpayers of competitive bidding that could have cut the cost of some contracts by as much as 50 percent, the report says. 
 The Associated Press obtained a copy of the study by the Senate Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management.
Off-loading occurs when one agency, faced with spending limits or tough rules on competitive bidding, finds a second agency with looser contracting rules. The first agency specifies a favored contractor, who is then hired by the second agency to do the work.
The report said that $260 million in improper or questionable contracting had been routed through the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Energy Department, NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and the Volpe Research Center at the Transportation Department.
 
Submarine Work at Issue
 It is not clear whether the law was actually broken. The Federal Economy Act makes off-loading legal under narrow circumstances. One agency can hire another when the second agency has already contracted for the same goods and services; this could lead to cheaper items through bulk buying. The practice is also permitted when the second agency has special expertise in ordering particular items.
One contracting example cited in the report involved classified research in the Non-Accoustic Anti-Submarine Warfare Office in the Pentagon..
The office contracted for research through an electric utility, the Tennessee Valley Authority. The Defense Department's inspector general found that the anti-submarine office took this route, in part, to "obtain the support of a specific contractor without having to advertise or compete the program."
The utility entered into an agreement with ESG Inc., described in the report as "a tiny company made up of just a few employees, who did none of the required research themselves."
ESG then subcontracted out 96 percent of the work, without competition, "to subcontractors selected by the Anti-Submarine Warfare office."
Ordered by Pentagon officials to end the relationship with the utility, the anti-submarine office rerouted the contract through the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which in turn contracted with the utility and ESG.
The anti-submarine office spent $21.9 million for the contract. And it paid a $1.1 million "brokering fee" to the utility for its management services.
And $2.8 million in expenditures were questionable, the Senate report said, including "fees for corporate jet travel, in-room videos, liquor."
Commenting on the findings, the subcommittee's chairman, Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said: "We're not talking about an occasional slip-up here. We're looking at a governmentwide, systematic end run around the procurement rules."

HEADLINE: Crown Hts. Tension Persists Despite Healing Effort

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
Crown Heights, divided by antagonisms long before it was torn by violence in the summer of 1991, is a neighborhood that today continues to operate under the strains of suspicion and anger, poverty and fear.
The sensitive state of affairs in the Brooklyn neighborhood exists despite considerable efforts to promote healing between its black and Hasidic residents. The Crown Heights Coalition, a collection of elected officials and neighborhood representatives formed after the unrest two and a half years ago, has been called ineffective, even irrelevant, by some blacks and Jews in Crown Heights, and it is struggling merely to remain intact. 
 Other formal attempts at conciliation, including a council set up to foster communication between the police and residents, have met with failure.
A dispute has also erupted over plans for the traditional Caribbean Labor Day Parade, an event that this September will fall on the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah. And unease between the police and black residents, present to one degree or another for decades, continues as investigators intensify their operation and neighborhood mothers complain that their sons are being harassed.
"The constant boiling, the simmering, the distrust, the tension," said Thad Owens, a black resident who heads Tenants for Better Housing in Crown Heights. "It's still here."
Crown Heights, then, appears to be much as it was before the rage and regrets of August 1991: split, mistrustful, poor and emotionally charged. And few are hopeful that the Federal civil rights investigation announced on Tuesday by United States Attorney General Janet Reno will ease tensions or solve problems.
"There can be no healing through this in Crown Heights," said the Rev. Gary P. Rogers, pastor of St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church on Brooklyn Avenue. "No matter what Ms. Reno does, no matter if another young member of this community is tried or convicted, it isn't going to make for better living for the African-American or Hasidic communities."
"That there is no common ground is a given," said Rabbi Joseph Spielman, one of the prominent Hasidic leaders. "I'd have my head in the sand if I said otherwise. Left alone, we could bearably get by."
That isolation, deemed an underlying source of the neighborhood discord that exploded in 1991, was supposed to be addressed by the Crown Heights Coalition. Formed by Borough President Howard Golden, the coalition issued a long report in August 1992, complete with page upon page of recommendations, including cultural sensitization programs for the police and a modest job training plan, as well as others for expanded day-care services and the protection of neighborhood housing.
 
'Has Made a Difference'
 A study of those initiatives conducted six months later found only checkered successes.
"No one is even going to pretend that we have solved all the issues and problems, many large ones that have been allowed to fester for years," said Edison O. Jackson, the president of Medgar Evers College and a co-chairman of the coalition. "But the coalition has made a difference."
Still, within the neighborhood of 207,000 people -- 80 percent of whom are black, 7 percent of whom are Hasidic, and 25 percent of whom receive some form of government financial assistance -- there is a sharp difference of opinion.
"The real problems are economics, and the coalition wants only to work with people they can control," said Mildred Scott, the former head of the 71st Precinct Community Council and a local school board member.
"The black community doesn't have anything to call its own but its churches and its funeral parlors, and the parlors are doing a better business lately," she said. "The coalition came out with a booklet of solutions that don't work. It was designed to keep people quiet, to keep the peace. But there is no peace."
 
'A Cynical Proposition'
 "The coalition was a cynical proposition from the start by people who have been around the block," added Mark Griffith, a local businessman who a decade ago headed a failed civil rights initiative in Crown Heights. "The very structure of the coalition insured that it wouldn't mean much to the people in the streets. I don't know if it was dishonesty on the part of these people or a lack of imagination."
The Hasidic perspective on the coalition is no brighter.
"Basketball games together, that's baloney, that's not real," said Rabbi Jacob Goldstein, the longtime chairman of Community Board 9. "We won't be dating and dancing together, and that won't solve our problems."
Rabbi Spielman, a powerful figure among Hasidic residents whose mere attendance at coalition meetings has been erratic of late, complained: "The people who are leaders in the streets aren't at the table. And should they be? Their answer is that the way to solve the problems of Crown Heights is to get the Jews out. They think they'd have a Garden of Eden if the Jews left."
Clearly, Crown Heights remains a deeply divided neighborhood, although there has been no repeat of the days of violence in August 1991.
 
A Sign of Strain
 Another sign of the strain was the angry collapse of the Precinct Community Council, a police outreach effort in which near-physical altercations and factional political fighting broke out, resulting in the council's effective dissolution.
Also, a proposal by Representative Major Owens for a five-year conflict resolution program, one that would be run by a committee of mediation specialists from outside the neighborhood, has not been endorsed by the Hasidim.
Then there are the tensions over the Caribbean parade. The celebration along Eastern Parkway has been a tradition for 26 years in Brooklyn, organized by the city's Caribbean population. It attracts more than 1 million people. This year, Labor Day falls on the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah, when thousands of Hasidim pour into Crown Heights to celebrate the Jewish New Year.
Members of the Jewish leadership, saying the parade will disrupt preparations for a solemn religious observance, asked the police to intercede with Caribbean-American residents to hold the event a day earlier. The Caribbean leaders were and are outraged.
"We're trying to coexist, and they go behind our backs," said Carlos Lezama, the parade committee chairman. "It was very blatant, very provocative. It may go to court. But we're not moving."
Rabbi Shmuel Butman, an official with the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council, said: "Moving one day -- that's a big ordeal? We're not trying to destroy the parade."
The efforts to achieve understanding between the police and the young black population in the aftermath of the 1991 unrest appear imperiled. The Police Department, which has conducted 10,000 interviews since the 1991 killing of a rabbinical student, Yankel Rosenbaum, has increased its activity since a state grand jury was empaneled earlier this month. And officials say the effort will remain intense as Federal investigators press their civil rights investigation.
"The concern is that our sons are being harassed," said Van Plummer, a black Crown Heights mother. "My son hasn't been brought in. But I'm quite sure they will be coming to my door soon enough."
The police, more than a year after the failed prosecution of Lemrick Nelson Jr. for the Rosenbaum killing, face the pressure of trying to solve an explosive and exasperating case.
"Has there been improvement in communication between police, the Jewish community and the black community?" asked Officer Calvin Bent, the community affairs officer for the 71st Precinct. "I don't know. There have been efforts."
The police effort involving Henry Rice dramatizes the potential for unease. Mr. Rice, a 24-year-old candidate for the police force who works for the National Conference of Christians and Jews, was questioned over two days last month by Brooklyn detectives who insist that Mr. Rice was a witness to the killing. A third meeting with prosecutors last week left Mr. Rice convinced that he will be subpoenaed to appear before the Federal grand jury.
"I don't think the investigation is the reason black youth feel harassed by the police in Crown Heights, but it ain't helping," Mr. Rice said. "And I'm shocked at Reno's decision. What this all means is that there is going to be more upset."
The prospect of another trial provokes some of the most disturbing dialogue on the streets of Crown Heights. The Hasidim say they are eager for justice. Many black residents, convinced that the black life lost on the night of Mr. Rosenbaum's killing on Aug. 19, 1991, was minimized, return again and again to the subject of Gavin Cato, the 7-year-old who was crushed to death by a car traveling in a Hasidic motorcade that night.
"It is not easy for the people here, but another trial has to be done," said Isaac Bitton, a Jewish man who was beaten up along with his son during the 1991 unrest. "Emotionally, we have to go through it."
Others treat the specter of further dramatics in the case more grimly.
"If another trial happens and someone is found guilty, I think there will be riots again," said Walter Cato, the older brother of Gavin.
And so Ms. Reno takes over a difficult case in a troubled neighborhood.
"It's bad political theater that has been played out and that will be played out, and so it's all very familiar," said Mr. Griffith, the local businessman. "To be collecting facts and making a case more than two years after the incident, it's difficult to believe people have hopes of having the truth come out. Or that there is even interest in the truth."

HEADLINE: Thinking Globally;
A Little City Trolls for Trade

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J.

 BODY:
With new trade agreements breaking down the barriers between continents and nations, consider the case of East Orange. After decades of economic malaise, this city is making an unlikely pitch to be a center of global commerce.
East Orange, one of the New York area's oldest commuter suburbs, has no large manufacturers, holds little appeal to office developers and has not had the success of other New Jersey suburbs in luring business from Manhattan. 
 What it does have is a high concentration of African-American residents, including about 2,000 immigrants from the West African nation of Ghana. And it was these residents, including E. K. Sam, a software designer, who helped push the extraordinary international venture of a trade mission linking New Jersey and Ghana.
"There are a lot of opportunities in developing countries," said Mr. Sam, who is president of SIU Software Solutions, based here. "They have often been overlooked by American business, to its own detriment."
The mission to Ghana for two weeks in September has produced these results so far: a $57 million contract, nearly completed, to shore up part of Ghana's eroded coast line, several bids by New Jersey companies to sell computer equipment in Ghana, agreements to import pineapples and other food from Ghana and a student exchange agreement between Upsala College here and the three universities of Ghana.
 
For Love of Country
 "I worried that we would be perceived as just a small town," said Cardell Cooper, the Mayor of East Orange, a city of 72,000 people wedged between Newark and Montclair. The Mayor, who was among 44 people in the trade mission, said all but $20,000 of the $250,000 cost of the mission was paid by companies that participated. East Orange put up $5,000; $15,000 came from the state.
Now, Mr. Cooper said, "We've established a great opportunity and I hope this gets the attention of the White House."
Although Presidential laurels may be premature, East Orange's early success in Ghana reflects the economic power of cities that can call upon the cultural links of their own immigrant populations.
"One lesson is that ethnic groups can bring a lot to the table, and they will do so for the love of their native countries as well as the United States," said Phil Ferzan, the director of the New Jersey Division of International Trade, who traveled to Ghana with the East Orange mission.
 
A Main-Street Influence
 Mr. Ferzan said that trip has already produced better results than any of the other four missions New Jersey has sent abroad since 1990, to Russia, Italy, Japan and Mexico.
Fully 95 percent of East Orange's residents are African-Americans, Mayor Cooper said, giving it a higher percentage of residents of African descent than any United States city besides East St. Louis, Ill. And while most people here are natives of the United States, East Orange has been a magnet for immigrants for more than two decades.
Most obvious, particularly along the city's Main Street business district, is the influence of its immigrants from the Caribbean. Scattered along the commercial strip are such businesses as Dalies West Indian Restaurant, Hacotrans Le Caurrier D'Haiti, a travel agency, and a clothing store that promotes itself as "Things Jamaican."
Although less prominent on Main Street, East Orange's immigrants from Ghana have been growing rapidly in numbers and political influence. They come from a nation where the government has been revamped over the last two years by democratic reforms and where economic development has outpaced most of West Africa.
Mr. Sam said people from Ghana, who have also established enclaves in Brooklyn and Newark, are attracted to East Orange because of its large homes and suburban tranquillity and because they can share some of the cultural and tribal traditions of their homeland here, including feasts and elaborate rituals to accompany births and deaths.
 
Suggestion of a Queen
 With its peculiar amalgam of West African culture and suburban life, people here say East Orange has an advantage in wooing business in Ghana. Their trade mission was suggested first by visitors from Ghana to East Orange.
They included two of Ghana's most powerful tribal leaders, Osagyefo Nana Kuntukununku II, king of the Akyem people, and Nana Doua II, queen of Akuapem State, both of whom have visited since 1992 during diplomatic forays.
By lucky cultural coincidence, many of East Orange's immigrants are members of Queen Doua's tribe, including Mr. Sam's wife, Philomena, who emigrated from Ghana in 1986 and who operates a store here that specializes in colorful kente cloth and other Ghanaian fabrics.
"My greatest goal is to promote African culture here," Mrs. Sam said. Her efforts were given a major boost by Queen Doua, who had been expected to make a brief stopover in East Orange, but instead stayed for two weeks and encouraged business people here to pursue new trade links with her country.
What followed was a grass-roots effort, orchestrated by the Sams and other Ghanaian immigrants, to sell New Jersey on the idea of a trade mission to their homeland. After winning the support of Mayor Cooper and others in East Orange, and then of the Governor, Jim Florio, the group enlisted business people from across New Jersey.
The group went prepared with gifts. East Orange Day care centers, hospitals and the city's library donated medical supplies, toys and books.
Mayor Cooper said the group was far from the only trade mission trying to lure business in Ghana; others from China, Japan and several European nations had been courting the country aggressively.
 
Breakthrough on a Contract
 But it became clear to the New Jerseyans that they had made a good impression by their third day in Ghana, when Jerry Rawlings, who has been Ghana's President since 1979, met with them for over three hours to discuss Ghana's economy and trade.
"We expected a few minutes and a photo opportunity," said Mayor Cooper, whose offices here are now strewn with clippings from Ghanaian newspapers that covered his group's travels in their country. After meeting with Mr. Rawlings, the group was invited to meet with several of his Government's senior officials for trade and economic development.
By far the biggest beneficiary of the mission has been Breakwaters International of Flemington, N.J., an eight-year-old engineering companythat installs huge concrete offshore reefs, and had been vying with several foreign companies for work on a severely eroded and densely populated stretch of Ghana's coast.
"The trade mission created an atmosphere that made this happen for us," said Richard Creter, Breakwaters' president. Although a final contract has not been signed, he said the company has letters of intent from President Rawlings's administration to proceed with a $57 million contract.
That would mean the creation of 300 jobs in New Jersey, he said, where cranes and other construction equipment would be manufactured for the Ghanaian project.
Other trading agreements that result from the trip are expected to be smaller. A Matawan company hopes to import a species of Ghanaian pineapples that it hopes to market as a sweeter alternative to those from Hawaii. Mr. Sam's company is negotiating with Ghana's electric utility to provide computerized billing services. A Morristown computer company has put in its bid to provide Ghana's first "800" telephone number service.
Perhaps the smallest of the new trade links is between Ghana and Mrs. Sam, who is preparing a vacant storefront next to her kente cloth boutique to be used as a distribution center for dried casava, okra, palm oil and other foods from Ghana. She said she expected a ready market among West African immigrants throughout New York City and its suburbs.

HEADLINE: In the Shadows of the Casinos

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIGANTINE, N.J., Jan. 13

 BODY:
Fortune smiled for so long on this coastal island city, a bedroom community to Atlantic City's casino industry, that it was perhaps inevitable that things would take a turn for the worse, like a gambler's hot streak that suddenly turns cold.
Brigantine, just 1,000 yards across the Abesecon Inlet from a gambling resort that draws 32 million visitors a year, has been transformed over the last 15 years by Atlantic City's success, growing from a sleepy island of summer visitors and retirees into a bustling community. 
 The population doubled to some 13,000 as blackjack dealers, cocktail waitresses and others bought or rented houses or condominium units that sprouted on former marshlands at the southern end of the six-mile-long island. In the 1980's real-estate boom, longtime residents sold modest saltbox cottages for two or three times what they had paid for them.
While Atlantic City's 12 casinos, which handled $3.3 billion in revenue last year, were largely recession-proof, Brigantine's overbuilt housing market was not. Prices have tumbled in the last few years and unsold new houses remained vacant or were rented at rock-bottom prices.
 
Locking Doors Now
 The reduced rents brought on by the slump in the housing market attracted lower-income families seeking to move from high-crime neighborhoods in Atlantic City. County social services workers began placing welfare recipients in empty apartments in some of Brigantine's newest housing, and these poorer newcomers placed strains on the island's only public school and forced taxes higher even as property values shrank.
At the same time, more police officers were added to serve the growing population as crimes like thefts and burglaries grew. "When we bought a house in Brigantine six years ago it was a place where people didn't lock their doors at night," said Marilyn Munsart, who moved here with her husband, Herbert, a retired certified public accountant, in 1987. "That's sadly no longer true."
The Munsarts moved to Florida last year and still cannot sell their Brigantine home, which they estimated was worth $195,000 in 1989. "We put it on the market at $131,000 or best offer and didn't attract a single bid," Mrs. Munsart said in a telephone interview from Florida.
"The casinos and the transients they attracted are killing what had been a lovely island."
 
'Value Always Comes Back'
 Though that view is widely shared in Brigantine, in the eyes of many others it is an exaggeration brought on by the stresses of uncertain times.
Councilman Jim Frugoli, who represents the Fourth Ward near the inlet, where a rainbow-shaped bridge connects the island with Atlantic City, compares the nervousness of property owners today with the mood that gripped the island when a March storm flooded the island in 1962, when there were only several hundred year-round residents.
"Back then you could've picked up any property for peanuts," he said. "The value of beautiful seashore land always comes back."
But no one disputes that the relaxed pace of the pre-casino days will be difficult to re-create in the island's enlarged role as appendage to Atlantic City's continual growth.
 
The Pull of Casinos
 Atlantic City plans to add 3,680 new hotel rooms within two years at a cost of $559 million, raising the number of casino hotel rooms to nearly 18,000. Rooms are being added in anticipation of the opening of the city's new convention center in 1996.
Some Brigantine businessmen, noting that the only way on or off the island is over the bridge to Atlantic City, would like to see more done to attract tourists. One of them is Joe Mazza, owner of the Pirate's Den, a small restaurant near the island's north shore where development ends and government preserves lock the coastal marshes and woodlands in a natural state for the next 20 miles.
"Visitors come here and see the beaches and the natural beauty and can't believe it's the Jersey Shore," said Mr. Mazza, who moved here five years ago from Philadelphia.
"But you can't stumble across Brigantine. You have to be directed here and the casinos don't want their customers to get away from the slots and the crap tables for even one hour," he said with a nod in the direction of the casino hotel towers in the distance.
 
'Intimidated by Change'
 There used to be 300 hotel and motel rooms in Brigantine, but today there are fewer than 100; many of the older places were torn down or converted to condos. The island has also lost its only man-made tourist attraction: a structure built on a pier called Brigantine Castle, which included a haunted house and food booths.
"The voters shut down the place years ago because they didn't want outsiders riding a bus out to Brigantine and walking around the streets," Mr. Mazza said. "They're so intimidated by change."
The pull between what used to be and what could be, for better and for worse, underlies almost every conversation about Brigantine.
Ron Luciano, a 49-year-old card dealer and supervisor who works 8 P.M. to 4 A.M., has lived in Brigantine for 15 years and says he wouldn't live anywhere else. "I'm 10 minutes away from work and have the freshest air in the country," he said this week as he played on the beach with his preschool-age daughter.
 
Screening Students Closely
 But he says he worries about the newcomers "moving into subsidized housing at the south end of Brigantine" and overcrowding at the public school, even though a $14 million addition is planned.
"My daughter's going to the Catholic school, that's for sure," said his wife, Maria, who met her husband when she visited Atlantic City for a game of blackjack and ended up marrying the dealer.
Mayor Philip J. Guenther, who is vice principal of discipline at Atlantic City Senior High School, said Brigantine officials are trying to crack down on multiple families moving into single apartments, a growing practice. And school officials are screening pupils more closely to confirm that they actually reside in the city, an effort that recently removed more than 100 Atlantic City children from the local school, the Mayor said.
"Our biggest challenge is to make co-existence work between old-time homeowners and short-term transients," he said. "We want a healthy mix of residents and at the same time want to insure that we prevent a deterioration of housing stock that makes values drop."
Local officials say the surest way to make that happen is for the economy to revive and to revive the second-home market to prop up the price of 2,354 condo units and 1,700 multifamily apartments built in Brigantine through the 1980's.
He and others here figure it's only a matter of time before Brigantine's luck changes and the community is once again dealt a hot hand.

HEADLINE: Police Appeal for Help in Girl's Disappearance

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITCHFIELD, N.Y., Jan. 26

 BODY:
Frustrated in their two-week effort to find the remains of Sara Anne Wood, the 12-year-old who disappeared last summer, the state police today made an unusual plea for help from anyone who was on vacation in the Adirondacks on Aug. 18.
The police asked anyone on vacation at that time to check their home videos for pictures of the light blue Ford Econoline van that Lewis Lent Jr., the suspect in Sara's abduction, was driving then. Such a picture would provide evidence that the authorities say would help them bring charges against Mr. Lent, who told the police that he abducted Sara as she was walking her bicycle here and that he buried her in the woods near Raquette Lake. 
 The police have been searching for Sara's remains in the Raquette Lake area since Jan. 10, mostly in adverse weather, including temperatures as low as 42 degrees below zero. The search continued today, but so far, the police have found nothing.
At a news conference today at the state police command center for the Sara Anne Wood case, Maj. C. Allen Pylman outlined a possible route Mr. Lent could have taken from the site of the girl's disappearance to the Adirondack Mountains.
 
Hoping for Evidence
 Authorities believe he left Litchfield, a suburb of Utica, on Route 8 going south, took Route 20 east, and then Route 28 north to Raquette Lake, Major Pylman said.
"If we can put him on this route at a time period after 2:30 P.M.," Major Pylman said, "that will provide us with a critical piece of corroborative information as far as the investigation is concerned.
"Granted, this is a long shot," he continued. "I'd be the first one to admit that. But if we can jog someone's mind" it might lead to "an important piece of evidence."
The Herkimer County District Attorney, Michael Daley, said the appeal had nothing to do with the search at Raquette Lake.
"The purpose of this appeal is to strengthen or establish a criminal prosecution," Mr. Daley said. "This appeal is directed at trying to obtain evidence that can be used at some later date in a criminal prosecution."
Mr. Lent, a former janitor at a movie theater, has been charged with the attempted abduction of a girl in Pittsfield, Mass., and the slaying of Jimmy Bernardo, 12, who was abducted in Pittsfield on Oct. 22, 1990, and whose body was found in Newfield, N.Y., 10 miles from Ithaca, a month later.
Mr. Lent has not been charged in the disappearance of Sara because the authorities say they have little evidence linking him to her disappearance,other than his own statements. But the police have said he provided information in his statements that they believe only the kidnapper could have known.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Longer Treasuries Pare Losses

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Government securities recovered yesterday, with longer maturities paring about half of their losses for the week. With no economic news on the calendar, traders and dealers focused on the five-year note auction.
Prices were generally higher, with the only downturn coming after the results of the note auction were released. Some traders said the $12 billion sale of five-year notes was disappointing. Market expectations called for a yield of 5.09 percent, while the auction came in at a high yield of 5.10 percent. 
 But Ronald R. Reuss, senior vice president and chief economist for Piper Capital Management, said the auction, while slow, was not bad. And dealers had to be happy later in the day as the yield on the new five-year noted dropped to 5.06 percent, which meant profits for them as the price, which moves in the opposite direction, climbed higher.
The $12 billion auction of five-year notes was $1 billion larger than December's auction, when the high yield was 5.19 percent.
 
Yield Drops to 6.30%
 By late in the day the price of the 30-year bond was up 15/32 , to 999/32 , for a yield of 6.30 percent, down from 6.34 percent on Tuesday and back to the level at the end of trading on Monday. The 10-year note, another closely followed security, was up 5/32 , to 1009/32 , for a yield of 5.71 percent.
The market reacted more to the note auction than to President Clinton's State of the Union address. Traders said the address did not provide any significant new information on the Federal budget and deficit outlook.
Next Wednesday the Government is scheduled to announce the size of its February auction of 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. This will be the first auction of 30-year bonds since August. Last year the Treasury cut the annual sales of 30-year bonds by about 40 percent and moved from an auction four times a year to two times a year.
While the calendar of economic events was blank yesterday, today's releases offer traders and investors something to digest. The Labor Department issues the weekly jobless claims numbers while the Commerce Department reports on durable goods orders for December.
Tomorrow the preliminary fourth- quarter estimate for the gross domestic product is scheduled..
MMS International, a Wall Street research firm, expects durable goods orders to register a 1 percent increase in December.
 
Estimates on G.D.P.
 In an interview with CNBC, a Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said poor weather and the California earthquake were not enough to undermine growth. He said he saw fourth-quarter 1993 gross domestic product near 5 percent, with the first quarter possibly lower.
Mr. Reuss of Piper Capital said the economy was looking good, adding that he expected a G.D.P. growth of 5.5 percent in the fourth quarter, followed by a slowing to a pace of 2.5 to 3.5 percent in the first six months of 1994.
He said that if the economy slowed to such a pace this year, inflation would not pick up and it was unlikely that the Federal Reserve would have to raise short-term interest rates soon to curb growth and inflation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Yen After Trade Talks Stumble

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against most leading currencies yesterday and suffered its biggest loss against the Japanese yen after trade talks between the United States and Japan faltered.
Meanwhile, gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery rose $3, to $384.60 an ounce. 
 The dollar began falling against the yen in Asian trading on news the United States and Japan ended two days of trade talks, aimed at opening the Japanese market to foreign goods, without agreement. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 110 yen, down from 111.05 yen on Tuesday.
 
 
'Stumbling Blocks'
 An American official said that "substantial stumbling blocks" hindered further talks, casting a cloud over the planned Feb. 11 meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan.
Japan gave the meeting a more positive spin, stating that some progress was made and it was determined to strike a pact.
But Japanese officials reiterated their opposition to measuring progress on the trade front with numerical targets, which Tokyo considers managed trade but Washington views as necessary for compliance.
Jittery traders dumped more dollars on reports that Fred Bergsten, an influential private economist, would advocate a target range for the dollar of 90 yen to 110 yen in a speech scheduled tomorrow. Mr. Bergsten is director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, and some currency traders believe he has President Clinton's ear.
Moreover, Mr. Bergsten's comments hit a chord with dealers fearful that deadlocked talks would encourage the United States to advocate a strong yen to redress the trade imbalance.
"Market focus is shifting back to political tension between the U.S. and Japan over the trade issue, which played a key role in pushing down the dollar today," Tetsya Ogura, customer dealer at Nippon Credit Bank in Tokyo, said.
The dollar also fell to 1.7442 marks in New York, from 1.7515 marks late Tuesday, after the German currency posted gains against other European currencies. And the British pound closed in New York at $1.4950, up from $1.4945 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Smooth Landing for Economy

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
For the first time in 30 years, the United States economy has pulled itself out of recession without benefit of a significant tax cut or burst of new Government spending. And although the recovery has skipped some regions and left many workers still without jobs -- as President Clinton noted in his State of the Union address -- others have hailed it as a model expansion with noninflationary growth and falling unemployment.
Achieving a noninflationary recovery has been something of a Holy Grail in economic policy circles for decades. While cutting taxes and increasing spending have proved useful in temporarily increasing economic growth, that growth often seemed to be coupled with the seeds of higher inflation. 
 In the recoveries of the 1960's and 1970's, for example, the price of extra stimulus to the economy was higher inflation. Some economists argued that monetary policy would have done the job better, but many others doubted that monetary policy alone would suffice.
 
Potent Recovery Tool

To some economists, the biggest lesson of the nearly three-year-old recovery is that monetary policy -- and particularly lower interest rates -- can be a potent tool for pulling the economy out of recession, perhaps as potent as the traditional tools of fiscal policy: the tax cuts and Government spending used by Presidents from John F. Kennedy to Ronald Reagan.
Other economists caution that the effectiveness of monetary policy depends in part on the particular circumstances. Monetary policy alone might not have been sufficient if the economy had been as sick as some people had feared. Pent-up consumer demand, renewed consumer confidence and growth in third-world export markets, all not directly tied to monetary policy, added to the economic momentum.
Others also argue that the noninflationary nature of the current recovery owes as much to the weakness of the rest of the world as it does to the particular magic of monetary policy.
Nonetheless, there is a new respect for the powers of monetary policy -- and for the success of the Federal Reserve Board's low-interest-rate strategy. The Fed, which had raised rates by three percentage points in late 1989 to ward off inflation, has since brought rates down to the lowest they have been in 20 years.
"In a period when fiscal policy is frozen, monetary policy can do it," said Benjamin M. Friedman, an economist at Harvard. "The recession didn't turn into a depression and we got through the recession without financial fragility causing some kind of rupture. If that's what you mean by soft landing, then that's what we've had, and the credit goes largely to monetary policy."
That does not mean that Presidents are likely to become converts to the monetarist creed -- the notion that the money supply and interest rates are the biggest influence on the economy's short-run ups and downs. Tax cuts and spending have a voter appeal that monetary policy simply does not offer and George Bush arguably lost his job because he would not cut taxes in 1991, at a time when many thought he should be taking a more activist approach to reviving the economy.
And it is certainly possible that the announcement of a fiscal stimulus plan early in the recovery could have helped to restore consumer confidence sooner, though at the risk of frightening financial markets. In the absence of clear signals that the Bush Administration was prepared to assist the economy, people may have been less sure that the recovery would continue and kept their spending in check.
Unlike a tax cut, which puts money in paychecks, or public works spending, which employs people directly, some of the workings of monetary policy are indirect and far removed from the average household pocketbook, low mortgage rates aside.
But willing or not, as long as the deficit remains big enough to worry voters, Presidents may be forced to let the Federal Reserve do the heavy lifting, while they focus on micro-measures -- extending jobless benefits or shifting dollars around -- that have little discernible effect on the overall economy but are good public relations.
"For the foreseeable future, administrations have no choice but to rely on the good graces of the Fed," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
While there may have been little choice, many economists, including some inside the Bush and Clinton Administrations, were worried that monetary policy by itself would not work. One of the key lessons of the Great Depression was that interest rates could be pushed down to zero and people would still not borrow or spend if they believed the economy would not expand and they could lose their jobs.
 
Stagnation Was Expected
 So it was with a sense of history that many economists in recent years feared that the economy would keep on stagnating.
In fact, however, exports helped shore up the economy in the first year of recovery. And last year, housing, cars and business investment -- spending that is sensitive to interest rates -- provided most of the growth. A necessary part of that spending, however, was renewed consumer confidence. When that began to rise, it helped spur spending, especially on big-ticket items.
The result has been a recovery that has added 2.5 to 3 percent to the gross domestic product annually, has whittled unemployment to 6.4 percent from 7.8 percent and has kept inflation -- a shade under 3 percent last year -- at bay.
"In addition," said Robert Giordano, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs, "we didn't end up with a higher structural deficit, which would only have worsened our long-term problems."
The widespread doubt that lower interest rates alone could cure the economy of the ailments it had developed over the long, strong 1980's expansion was hardly surprising. Every recovery in the last 30 years was aided by a jolt of deficit spending. Monetary policy did ignite the 1982 recovery, but tax cuts gave it a big push. President Gerald R. Ford gave consumers tax rebates in 1975. And President Richard M. Nixon cut income taxes after the 1970 recession.
 
Debt Is Refinanced
 As it turned out, however, lower rates were just what a debt-heavy economy needed. Low rates inflict their own pain, on the incomes of retirees and other investors in money market funds for example. But in the last two years, consumers refinanced more than $1 trillion in mortgage debt and most corporations have replaced nearly all their high-cost debt with cheaper funds. That has freed up billions of dollars for spending that formerly went to pay interest.
Equally important, lower rates helped ease strains on the banking system. "Because the recession was limited, the number of bank failures and bankruptcies was limited, too," Professor Friedman said
In the last year, lower rates have given spending a sharp increase. They made people richer by causing the price of stocks and bonds to rise. And they created a strong incentive for car buyers and home buyers to do their buying now. Car, van and truck sales roared back this year and single-family home sales and new housing starts are at their highest level since the late 1970's.
Monetary policy also stimulated the economy by keeping the dollar cheap, as investors could get higher returns on their money overseas. And a cheaper dollar helped keep exports growing solidly during the first two years of economic recovery. Lower short-term interest rates also helped nudge down long rates as investors shifted from low-yielding money market funds into higher-yield bond funds -- though slow growth, low inflation and the brighter deficit picture also contributed.
 
Offset for Higher Taxes
 Lower rates also helped offset some of the drag from higher taxes. One reason that rates had to be driven so low was that Washington was actually raising taxes and cutting military spending during the recession and early in the recovery. While Washington had certainly not left off deficit spending, the point is that it was not doing more of it.
"Certainly, the Fed went a lot further than anyone thought would be necessary but ultimately it more than offset the 50-mile-an-hour headwinds that Greenspan was always talking about," Mr. Steinberg said, referring to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed. "As rates came down, it was enough to offset the deflationary forces in the economy."
Nonetheless, neither economists nor policy makers are inclined to say "never" when it comes to using fiscal policy. The economic recovery has been only about half as fast as past expansions and it took much longer than usual for the economy's job machine to warm up. Unemployment did not start to come down and job growth did not take hold for a year and a half into the recovery. "For a lot of policy makers the recovery was unacceptable," said Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, "If you were a resident of Southern California or New York, you wouldn't look back at the last couple of years with equanimity."
 
Confidence Called Key
 Alicia Munnell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Economic Policy, agreed. "Once confidence is restored, and investors believe that we're not going to let the deficit go up in good times as well as bad, then you could use some countercyclical policy."
"But," she added, "the most important thing right now for the financial markets and everyone else is that this Administration and Congress are committed to paying for their expenditures."
Michael J. Boskin, who as President Bush's chief economic adviser suggested that the Bush Administration consider a tax cut of $50 billion to $75 billion, thinks that this is not all bad.
"I wouldn't want to say under no circumstances ever would you want to use fiscal policy," he said, "But I do believe it is a clumsy tool. It's hard to enact. It's hard to do quickly. Its effects are uncertain."
