HEADLINE: Anytime is Bedtime

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS

 BODY:
WHEN Edith Wharton gave her "Age of Innocence" character Mrs. Manson Mingott a first-floor bedroom hard by the entrance hall of the lady's Fifth Avenue mansion, she insured that Mrs. Mingott's society friends were properly shocked. In direct defiance of Victorian mores -- the bedroom then was a sanctum sanctorum, tucked away upstairs and free from intrusion -- the obese Mrs. Mingott's bohemian quarters were considered scandalously convenient.
A century later, the attitude that a bedroom is just another room, to be used and enjoyed by all, is heartily endorsed by Min Hogg, the editor in chief of The World of Interiors, a British interior decorating magazine. In her London apartment, Ms. Hogg can often be found in her bedroom, dining supine. While she nestles informally against an upholstered headboard, her drop-in guests eat from trays perched atop several thin cotton gauze comforters from India. 
 "I can't see the point in going home, having a bath and getting dressed again just to go out and eat," Ms. Hogg said. "It seems such a waste of energy."
As the traditional boundaries between public and private spaces continue to blur, the bedroom and the primary piece of furniture it shelters have been transformed in the United States into a $16 billion industry for 1993, up $2 billion from the previous year. The bedroom, once a sacred preserve dedicated to leading the weary occupant toward a healthful 40 winks, is becoming a multipurpose enclave for eating, working and playing -- solo, a deux or en famille.
"The bed is the heart of the home, where the entire human drama is enacted," said Alecia Beldegreen, the author of "Bed" (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, 1991), a lavish tribute to the one home furnishing that, she said, constantly nourishes, whether you're asleep or not. "It's where we play, we work, we convalesce, we make love, we give birth, we die."
Ms. Beldegreen's book and at least nine others currently celebrate the sensual pleasures of the bed. Enticingly operatic bedroom displays with luxurious banks of pillows and goose-down comforters have become a standard component of everyday life, whether they are glimpsed in catalogues, on the cover of glossy design magazines or in the windows of shops from coast to coast.
"Just think about it: a bed with two dozen ruffled pillows," said Jeffrey Bilhuber, a New York City interior decorator. "My God, it would take you 45 minutes just to make it every morning."
While display coordinators are quick to note that store displays aren't to be taken literally, consumers continue to be titillated, if not inspired. "Copying beds like these would cost you a fortune," said a coordinator at a Manhattan department store, referring to his own hyper-accessorized creations.
Indeed, a tour of New York stores last week disclosed single displays ranging in price from $1,747.50, at Ad Hoc Softwares on West Broadway in SoHo, to $5,898, at Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue at East 58th Street.
One of the most costly examples is Ralph Lauren's lush, wintry "Russia" collection, which was directly inspired by his clothing for women. The designer layers a twin-size bed with soft black velvet and wool and cotton paisleys. From the cotton sheets ($15 each) to the cavalry twill throw edged with faux Persian lamb ($2,930), the total look will set you back $5,135. (The collection has already sold out at Macy's.)
Home Furnishings Daily, an industry publication, says that the $16 billion that Americans spent in 1993 to dress their bedrooms includes almost anything made of fabric, from quilts to picture frames.
Quilts, throws and duvet covers (a term that entered the American vernacular only about five years ago) were the stars of retailing, according to a national survey that will be released in the Feb. 14 issue of Home Furnishings Daily. Quilts, a $425 million business driven by the ever-increasing interest in the American country look, experienced a 25 percent jump last year, while sales of duvet covers rose by 16.6 percent and throws by 40 percent.
Pillows alone were a $792 million market, up from the previous year's $510 million. The tucked-in bedspread, considered by many consumers to be too strait-laced, has lost a significant market share for the last three years against the rumpled and casual look of the down-stuffed duvet.
Paradoxically, despite the rise of what some may call "comfort porn," it appears that the average American is doing everything in bed but sleeping. As Juliet B. Schor, a professor of economics at Harvard University, explained in her best seller, "The Overworked American: The Unexpected Decline of Leisure" (Basic Books, 1992), studies of sleep patterns, conducted in laboratories, show that a majority of adult Americans are operating on a "sleep deficit," getting as much as 90 minutes less sleep a night than they should for optimum health and job performance.
According to the Better Sleep Council's monthly newsletter, women have shorter periods of deep sleep than men, a condition that makes them more vulnerable to chronic exhaustion and stress-related health problems. Sleep-deprivation research also shows that the average working woman sleeps about 20 minutes less a night than the average working man, and as much as 50 minutes less if she has small children to care for.
Consequently, for sleep-deprived people, the bed has become the ultimate form of escapism, said Faith Popcorn, the founder of the Brain Reserve, a Manhattan-based market analysis company. She won a niche in the market-research pantheon when she codified one of the hottest behavioral trends in the 80's with a snappy, insouciant label: cocooning.
"We are looking at an entirely new trend, what I call 'pleasure revenge,' " she said. "We're sick of being so good -- smoking less, eating less, being monogamous. It's time for a safe indulgence, and a beautiful bed that's beautifully equipped fits into the whole escapist scenario."
Apart from its marketing potential, the beautiful bed scenario may have a strong psychological basis. "It's the eternal contest between fantasy and reality," said Dr. Barbara B. Seruya, a Manhattan clinical psychologist who specializes in qualitative market research. "People's perceptions are dictated by their own inner needs, and dressing a bed may symbolize, even compensate for, a person's desire for what he or she can't get enough of: sleep."
The iconographing of the bed isn't really new, said Ms. Beldegreen, the author, who likes to work at home, in bed, with her papers and books spread out around her. She explained that in the 18th century, it was fashionable for women to play hostess while stretched out on a bed or chaise longue. And since Roman times, all sorts of creative people have been famous for working in bed. While in bed, Rossini composed operas, Proust wrote much of "The Remembrance of Things Past," Winston Churchill governed Britain. Mark Twain sometimes used a cigar-box lid as a writing board while working in bed, Fantin-Latour painted and Philippe de Rothschild ran his renowned Chateau Mouton vineyard and translated hundreds of Elizabethan poems into French.
Mel Byars, the author of "The Chairs of Frank Lloyd Wright" and a co-editor of a forthcoming book, "50 American Industrial Designers" (Preservation Press), said: "Talking on the telephone, watching television, writing, listening to compact disks, eating takeout -- I live in my bed.".
What would make the situation absolutely ideal, he wistfully added, would be an adjustable bedside computer terminal that would allow him to edit manuscripts without having to relinquish his reclining position. "In a perfect world, I wouldn't have to get up to do anything," he said.
 
Pillow Talk
 IN the truly elegant bedroom, dressing the bed is just as de rigueur as undressing to get into it. But if your notions of bed-making come strictly from the Girl Scouts -- or boot camp -- the vocabulary of this domestic activity may seem as tangled as the sheets after a nightmare.
Following is a glossary of bedding terms to put the mind at rest. A caveat: Despite standardization in the industry, sizes vary among makers (higher-priced European specialty shops tend to cut their linens bigger), so always measure before you shop.
 
BEDSPREAD: Becoming extinct, now that more people are favoring the "open bed," on which pillows and coverings are proudly displayed rather than hidden.
BLANKET COVER: Like a bedspread, only less wide and chicquer. It usually goes under, rather than on top of, the pillows, and hangs down far enough to cover the mattress.
BOLSTER: A decorative cylindrical pillow that lies across the entire width of the bed. It can be either open-ended or tied at each end like a bonbon. The French call it a traversin and even sleep on it.
BOUDOIR (OR BREAKFAST) PILLOW: Small and rectangular, 12 by 16 inches, it is used either decoratively or for sleeping. Especially good for children, or maybe for a cat who likes to cuddle with its owners.
DOG BONE: This small pillow, also called a peanut, is shaped like its namesakes, though it is a good deal softer. About 13 inches long, indented in the middle and designed to support the neck.
DUVET: Meaning "down" in French, it is a synonym for "comforter," used by Europeans and by Americans who wish to make their sleep habits appear more Continental.
DUVET COVER: The same as a comforter cover. It is designed like a huge pillow case with an open end secured by a zipper, buttons or Velcro. Usually made of cotton or some other washable fabric, it saves mightily on dry cleaning bills if you like to eat in bed.
DUST RUFFLE: A skirt for the bed. Hemlines here don't vary much: the idea is to cover the space from the box spring to the floor.
ELBOW PILLOW: Do a lot of thinking in bed? About 8 by 10 inches, this little prop will support your elbow as you ponder, chin in hand.
EUROPEAN (OR CONTINENTAL) SQUARE: A large pillow 26 inches square. A fixture on European beds, it's good for leaning back on while you write your novel, Colette-style.
FEATHER BED: Like a mattress-size pillow filled with down, a European luxury goes between the mattress and the sheet. It gives the only sinking feeling most people love.
NECK ROLL: Not a gymnast's trick, but a pillow meant to support the neck. Shaped like a cylinder, it's 6 to 8 inches wide and 16 inches long.
(PLAIN OLD) PILLOW: Nobody needs a definition, but you might want to know the sizes. Standard, 20 to 21 inches by 26 to 27 inches; queen, 20 by 30 inches; king, 20 to 21 inches by 36 to 38 inches.
PILLOW SHAM: It's not a fake anything. It's like a pillowcase, but has a decorative flange on all sides and a slit in the center at the back. (Strictly speaking, pillowcases open at the end.)
THIN QUILT: Meant to double as a blanket and a bedspread, this very thin coverlet is quilted with a little polyester filling to make it warmer and sturdier than a sheet. LAUREL GRAEBER

HEADLINE: For Kitchens: the Good, the Odd, the Silly

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
One's first impulse is to applaud the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, sponsor of the annual International Housewares Show here, for honesty. In the huge four-day exhibition last week, the trade group gave the name "Design Oasis" to the one small display that showed off prize-winning product concepts by industrial design students.
Visitors were clearly intrigued by student prototypes like a small microwave oven with an expandable cooking space and rounded, heat-saving design that gave it the whimsical eye-appeal of early radio. Other innovations included a plastic picnic cart that folds out into a table and a portable toaster powered by natural gas. 
 Of course, the trade group did not really mean to imply that the acres of displays surrounding the design exhibit were, comparatively speaking, a desert. But the truth is that what consumers want for their homes changes slowly, and merchants try to stay in step.
That stability was reflected in the show's landscape despite the bustle created by 50,000 or so buyers and sellers who converged on the McCormick Place exhibition center. For most exhibitors, change comes in nuances like new colors, slightly different shapes, new prices or changes in advertising strategy. Here is an arbitrary review of some that stood out.
"WE DID IT BUT NOW WHAT" AWARD Technology fans loved the Welbilt Corporation's Breakfast Express, the first appliance able simultaneously to fry eggs, toast bread and brew coffee or tea. It took Japanese manufacturing experts nearly four years to come up with a device that met the specifications of Welbilt, America's largest importer of bread-making machines. That's longer than microchip makers spend on a new generation of semiconductors or Detroit takes to come up with a new automobile.
Clearly, it's attractive to everyone who doesn't have a toaster, coffeepot and stove and doesn't worry about cholesterol. But who will buy it at a suggested retail price of $399? It could sell well among the subclass of the well off who lack servants and want breakfast but can't cope with making it.
"ANYTHING FOR A LAUGH" AWARD The pitch for 3M's new Scotch Brite "Never Scratch," the first wool soap pad for cleaning Teflon and other nonstick cookware, was centered on a "blues" singer who consented to go by the name Soapy Waters and showed no apparent embarrassment belting out lyrics like these:
My baby's in the kitchen scouring pots and pans,
I hear her scream in agony, steel splinter in her hand.
You know it's hard to watch my baby hurt so much
When all she's ever wanted is a soap pad with a delicate touch.
"THE EGGPLANT THAT ATE CHICAGO" AWARD The Rubbermaid booth at the housewares show does not actually double in size each year, but the variety of products the company fashions out of plastic expands continuously. The growing range of sheds and storage units alone makes one wonder how long it will be until the company, based in Wooster, Ohio, starts signing up other exhibitors to put their entire displays inside its products.
Honorable mention in this category to the General Housewares Corporation's Oxo International unit, which started out designing distinctive ergonomic handles for gadgets like peelers and has expanded into garden tools. Presumably, the product-line expansion will run out of momentum before ballplayers are seen striding to the plate with Oxo-designed bat handles. Or will it?
"NAME GAME" AWARD With Farberware and Braun plunging into the iron business and Pillsbury's Betty Crocker group seemingly intent on licensing its name in every kitchen segment short of garbage disposers, the drive to leverage famous brand names was as fierce as ever.
The most inspired one-two punch was thrown by Moller International, which assigned the architect Michael Graves the task of creating a high-class tea kettle and related items for adults based on Mickey Mouse. Mr. Graves gave Moller elegant but unmistakable mouse-ear handles for its $100 kettles and trays. The motif continues in sugar bowl, creamer and mug and coaster set -- but no lunch pails.
" 'TIS A GIFT TO BE SIMPLE" AWARD Many Shakers would no doubt have been pleased to see so many manufacturers of ready-to-assemble furniture offering products inspired by their simple, practical designs. Unlike many other 19th-century religious sects, the Shakers strove for and admired commercial success.
There's nothing simple, though, about the economic forces driving the industry, so one wonders what the Shakers would think on closer inspection of how their legacy is faring. The ready-to-assemble industry relies heavily on manufacturing abroad that is sustained by low wages and, in some areas, environmentally questionable tree-harvesting practices. To keep prices low, manufacturers also offer furniture lines that consist of wood veneer or printed paper over plywood laminates, particle board or other wood substitutes.
"We'll do it whichever way our customers want," said Scott Whittall, national sales manager for Southern Enterprises Inc. of Dallas. That is just what buyers from department stores and catalogues like Spiegel expect to hear, of course. The-customer-is-always-right rule makes life simpler commercially if not spiritually.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Kozyrev & Talbott

BYLINE: WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Two relatively young and sophisticated men, both setting policy at their nations' foreign ministries, have changed their positions radically in the past few months. Their shifts reveal much about the deterioration of Russian-American relations.
One is Strobe Talbott, longtime friend and Oxford roommate of Bill Clinton's. He stepped down from the power and prestige of Time magazine columnist to handle President Clinton's dealings with the nations of the former Soviet Union, and was recently named Deputy Secretary of State. 
 Although he was widely blamed for being the impetus behind Clinton's unfortunate choice for Defense Secretary last November, his friends charge that the current finger-pointing is the handiwork of David Gergen, who Talbottites claim was himself the leading advocate of the withdrawn nominee. The Clinton inner circle is not a happy band of brothers.
But the serious, urbane Talbott (to use Time's old, two-adjective style) has learned more than the art of White House infighting. To his credit, he has exhibited a refreshing willingness to reverse a position when it is shown to be mistaken, which we can hope may lead to a re-examination of his whole accommodationist Weltanschauung.
Little more than a month ago, Talbott reacted to Russian voter dissatisfaction with reformers' "shock therapy" by talking up "less shock, more therapy." That was a terrible blunder; it encouraged Boris Yeltsin to follow his go-slow instincts, undermining reformers and endangering Russian economic recovery.
That American position was modified when Clinton went to Moscow to promise "more reform, more support"; Talbott apparently thought that bought a Yeltsin commitment to continue reform. He was misled; reformers were double-crossed and the power shifted to the old apparatchiks.
Just as the invasion of Afghanistan awakened the accommodationist Jimmy Carter to Kremlin realities, the sellout of the reformers awakened Clinton and Talbott. Last week, the Deputy Secretary-designate made a 180-degree turn: in tough testimony to Congress, Talbott warned that aid to Russia depended on reform, and that reform had to come first. It was an epiphany.
Meanwhile, half a world away, another high-level diplomat was undergoing his own profound change. Short, boyish Andrei Kozyrev used to be a Certified Good Guy. His April Fool's Day speech last year alerted the world to the danger of militant Russian nationalism. Unafraid to ad-lib in English, he wowed those who interviewed him then with his good sense and good humor and support of a new Russian respect for its neighbors.
But in Moscow last month, a harder edge was evident: he had just won his election in Murmansk, a military area, by talking tough about the "near abroad." When I asked about the withdrawal of 13,000 Russian troops remaining in Latvia, he switched the subject to what he called discrimination against 11,000 retired Russian soldiers and their families living there (many in confiscated homes, infuriating native Latvians).
That was the new, disturbing Kozyrev. Two weeks ago, he seemed to carry that hard line to an extreme, in a speech telling Russian diplomats "we should not withdraw from those regions that have been the sphere of Russian interests for centuries."
As nervous Balts went ballistic, the Talbott State Department spokesman promptly said "we don't accept" that old-style hegemony. That rebuke caused a Kozyrev flunky to bluster about "mass media . . . deliberate distortion of the minister's pronouncements" and for Kozyrev to lash out at Latvia for "massive and crude violations of human rights" of the well-off colonists -- but also to call in the U.S. Ambassador to assure him troop withdrawal would take place this year.
Both Russians and Latvians are waiting for Talbott to suggest a compromise of letting a few hundred Russian troops rent the Skrunda early-warning radar facility for four years; when he does, I hope Latvia grabs the deal to get occupying troops out. Nor would it hurt for Latvians to assure long-resident Russian-speakers of ultimate first-class citizenship.
Kozyrev has taught Talbott to begin to toughen up; we can hope that Talbott will now teach Kozyrev to drop his crowd-pleasing, phony-tough attitude.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Journal;
Crime Crusaders On Parade

BYLINE: FRANK RICH

 BODY:
The good news is that it's no longer the economy, stupid. Crime now leads the pollsters' hit parade of hot issues.
The bad news is that most politicians will now do for crime what they did for the economy: pander to the public by offering quick fixes to postpone the complex process of halting what the unglib Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan calls "the manifest decline of the American civic order." 
 "Three strikes and you're out" is the sound bite du jour, embraced by imperiled incumbent governors as diverse as Pete Wilson and Mario Cuomo. This pleasing panacea -- mandatory life sentences without parole for three-time violent felons -- meshes well with the grandiose prison-building program pushed by the Republican Presidential hopeful Phil Gramm.
Who will be punished first by the costly construction of these mammoth "regional prisons"? Who else? The economy, stupid.
But the most simplistic approach to crime may be the campaign against television violence that has become the pet crusade of Senator Paul Simon and Representative Edward J. Markey, with cheerleading asides from Janet Reno. Last week the cable television industry responded to Senator Simon's threats of "legislative solutions" -- longhand for censorship -- by drafting a plan for rating violent programming. There's also talk of a V-chip, a gizmo that would allow parents to block violent programs by pushing a button, much as Colgate's Gardol protected my generation of American youth from tooth decay.
Assume for argument's sake that Senator Simon's debatable premise is accurate -- that television violence spawns real-life violence. If so, what good will ratings and V-chips do?
Not much. The same derelict or absentee parents who now let children watch television indiscriminately are unlikely to lay down the law according to ratings. Even those who push the V-button will block only a tiny percentage of tube violence.
In a typical oversimplification, Senator Simon, whose research about television does not seem to extend to watching it, defines his target as "entertainment violence," glossy Hollywood bloodbaths that can be easily identified, R-rated and V-vanquished. But violence permeates television as thoroughly as it does society. News coverage of the Bobbitt case, the Long Island Rail Road slaughter and the Menendez trial can desensitize and terrorize unsupervised young viewers as much as the made-for-TV movie versions to come.
And what about the bloodless violence on talk shows like "Geraldo"? Cartoons? Trash tabloid "news" programs?
Senator Simon is trying to put his finger in a dike that has already burst. Cable will soon offer 500 channels, many of them spewing fresh garbage. Given the proliferation of violent video games (with their own new ineffectual ratings) and coming innovations in the expanding cyberspace of entertainment technology, ratings and V-chips will quickly be roadkill on the information superhighway.
Only an enormous bureaucracy could fulfill Senator Simon's goal of creating an "independent monitoring committee" to evaluate this tonnage of media. By suggesting that someone like Walter Cronkite or John Chancellor might head such a monitoring force, Mr. Simon tells us more about his own gullibility before television imagery than about the medium's present realities.
The real way to end television violence and pressure its most irresponsible show-biz purveyors is not with gimmicks that challenge common sense and the First Amendment. Parents and other concerned citizens must instead say that they are mad as hell and aren't going to watch it anymore. Television programs with low ratings are canceled. Cable channels with few subscribers vanish.
Responsible parents already make these choices, and, as President Clinton put it Tuesday night: "Governments don't raise children. Parents do." But as the President also said in making his own powerful Moynihanesque comments linking crime to the collapse of the American family, too many children lack such parents.
Television can't fix that, and television won't change until America fixes itself. Senator Simon's crusade, already overcovered by the wary industry it attacks, is escapist fare that diverts attention from social reconstruction and crime-busting, the urgent tasks at hand.

HEADLINE: Credit Union Placed Millions With Seized Spanish Bank

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
The U.S. Central Credit Union, which provides financial services for the country's 13,000 credit unions, acknowledged yesterday that it had deposited $255 million in uninsured accounts in Banco Espanol de Credito months before the Spanish Government seized the institution last month.
On Monday, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee, sent letters to U.S. Central and to the National Credit Union Administration, the Federal agency that regulates credit unions, asking whether the credit union was "risking taxpayer monies by investing" in Banesto, as the Spanish bank is known. 
 Staff members of the banking committee said yesterday that the concerns of Mr. Gonzalez went well beyond U.S. Central, the linchpin of the Corporate Credit Union Network, which functions like a central bank for credit unions. The committee, they said, would ask the Federal Reserve to determine whether American banks other than J. P. Morgan & Company had been involved with the Spanish bank. J. P. Morgan had created an investment partnership that held an 8 percent stake in Banesto.
Responding to Mr. Gonzalez's query, credit union officials said yesterday that the Banesto investment, whatever hindsight might show, was made in the name of diversity and safety. "We pursue a diversification strategy that takes us into the highest-rated banks in the world," said Glenn Carter, the chief financial officer of U.S. Credit. "Of the top 25 in the world, one is in the United States, of the top 250, 30 are in the United States."
Last summer, he said, U.S. Central made deposits of $10 million to $50 million, at maturities of three to 12 months, the last of which will mature on June 9. Mr. Carter declined to specify the interest rates on those deposits other than that they were at "fair market value, reflective of market levels at the time."
When those deposits were made, Banesto enjoyed top ratings for its short-term debt from ratings agencies like the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service. Those were among the data that Mr. Carter consulted. S.& P. lowered its rating on the Banesto debt on Dec. 13, two weeks before the Spanish Government appointed a new board and four months after U.S. Central made its last deposit in Banesto.
As recently as last Friday, Mr. Carter said, a $10 million deposit matured and its principal and interest were paid by Banesto. And he said Spanish Government officials had said publicly, and the board of Banesto had stated in writing, that the American deposits were secure and would be fully repaid.
Mr. Carter of U.S. Central said his credit union, which is based in Overland Park, Kan., had assets of about $27 billion, of which 15 to 30 percent was invested with foreign banks, "the bulk of that in the United States in branches of foreign institutions."
 
Deposits Restricted
 The 13,000 credit unions that accept money from individuals are permitted by law to deposit their money only in United States Treasury securitiesor other Government-backed instruments. Their excess funds are deposited in what are known as "corporate credit unions," of which there are 43, and which are permitted to deposit money overseas. These 43 regional or state credit unions, in turn, deposit their excess funds in U.S. Central.
Robert Loftus, a spokesman for the National Credit Union Administration, said only four corporate credit unions had deposits overseas, none of them in Banesto.
Aides to the House Banking Committee said yesterday that in addition to the specifics of the U.S. Central deposits, committee members were concerned about why the corporate credit unions were permitted to operate under less restrictive requirements than those imposed on banks and savings and loan deposits.
The Senate voted in 1991 to impose higher capital standards on corporate credit unions, but the House did not.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the U.S. Central Credit Union's deposits in a Spanish bank misstated the scope of the organization's membership. U.S. Central helps administer a network providing financial and investment services for 90 percent of the nation's 13,000 credit unions, not all of them.

HEADLINE: At Last, Maybe, A Vision

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is professor of American history at Columbia.

 BODY:
Theodore Roosevelt once said that a good political speech is "a poster, not an etching." More important than fine details are broad, bold themes that stand out from a distance. But through most of American history, State of the Union Messages -- even Theodore Rove almost always been more like etchings than posters, often dreary, seldom memorable.
In recent years, only Ronald Reagan -- who, like Theodore Roosevelt, always claimed to prefer "banners of bold colors" to "pale pastels" -- managed to transcend the genre. With "American heroes" seated prominently in the visitors' gallery, teary references to acts of courage and sacrifice, evocations of families and neighborhoods and communities and buoyant descriptions of America as "once again alive with hope and opportunity," "a soaring eagle, proud and free," Mr. Reagan transformed his State of the Union addresses from lists of policy achievements and goals into evocations of national values and myths. They were an essential part of his effort to attach moral weight to his conservative agenda. 
 Bill Clinton, a man as enchanted with the details of policy as Mr. Reagan was bored with them, nevertheless delivered a State of the Union address Tuesday night more evocative of Mr. Reagan's bursts of symbolic oratory than the legislative report cards of other predecessors.
To be sure, Mr. Clinton boasted of economic and fiscal successes; he promoted his flagging health care proposals; he spoke at surprising length about welfare reform -- an issue many had assumed would remain on the back burner until after the health care debate; he made modest (and only partly convincing) claims of diplomatic achievements.
But most striking was his effort to make those goals seem part of a coherent whole: to persuade the American public that he does not just have ideas, but also an idea -- that in addition to specific policy proposals he has a vision of how the future can and should look.
There is good reason for him to do so. Mr. Clinton came into office with an exceptionally frail mandate in an exceptionally adversarial political climate. He was despised by the right, only tentatively embraced by the left and harried from all directions by Ross Perot. He stumbled through his first few months watching his already weak public support crumble in the face of a string of missteps and misfortunes. Even now, with some considerable successes behind him and his popularity much enhanced, he faces considerable public skepticism.
Unlike at least four of the last five Presidents, Mr. Clinton believes in the capacity of Government to do good. But he has inherited a political climate in which relatively few Americans seem to agree with him. For 40 years, the cold war not only imposed a coherent framework on American foreign policy, it also helped legitimize two generations of domestic initiatives, as part of the nation's effort to justify its position as leader of, and model to, the world. The cold war is over. In the 1950's and 1960's, the assumption of permanent affluence made it seem possible for the nation to undertake great tasks without having to absorb great sacrifices. That assumption is in a shambles.
The belief in progress -- in the possibility, even desirability of social improvement -- is probably as frail today as it has been at any moment in our history. On what, then, can an activist President base his hopes for a reinvigorated Government?
In a speech in Chapel Hill last fall, the President experimented with a framework for his programs reminiscent of the New Deal and the Great Society: the idea of security. The American people face a future of insecurity and instability, he said, and it is up to Government to make them feel that they can weather the inevitable changes that await them with some minimal confidence. His trade policies would contribute to economic security, his health care proposals to medical security, his anti-crime initiatives to personal security. Government would again be the protector of its citizens as they entered an age of uncertainty.
It was an intelligent speech, and in another time it might have generated real excitement. But amid the disenchantment and cynicism of the 1990's, the theme sounded somehow hollow. And the President, perhaps realizing that, made only oblique reference to it Tuesday night.
He turned instead, with what seemed genuine emotion, to things that were staples of Mr. Reagan's speeches. He spoke about social problems rooted in "the loss of values, in the disappearance of work and the breakdown of our families and our communities." He cited the role of "churches and other good citizens" in helping to solve social problems. He insisted that individual acts of heroism are still possible in the face of apparently overwhelming social forces. He spoke above all about family -- and, in an apparently spontaneous moment, of his own mother, who died earlier this month.
Ronald Reagan, and many other conservatives, used such symbols as a rebuke to liberals. They cited the strength of communities, families and churches as evidence of the irrelevance of Government and the importance of unleashing individuals from its shackles.
Mr. Clinton has been trying, slowly and tentatively, to enlist the same symbols behind his own activist agenda. Americans, he said, have revealed the "better angels of our nature" in their responses to flood, earthquake, fire and storm. And they can do so as well in attacking our "deepest problems" -- not by relying solely on individual acts of generosity and courage but by joining in an effort to make Government an ally of change and progress.
The President was, in other words, trying to do more Tuesday night than boast of his accomplishments and jump-start his health care plan. He did those things effectively, but he was also trying to reclaim from the right a moral language that liberals have -- in recent years, at least -- largely abdicated. He was continuing the effort he began with his speech on crime in Memphis last November to rescue liberalism from the symbolically barren, socially fragmented world it has inhabited for a generation, and to link it to a popular yearning for values and community.
No recent President has been better than Bill Clinton at explaining policies; he can talk intelligently for hours about the details of legislation and programs. But on Tuesday night, he seemed to recognize that a firm grasp of policy is not enough. Without a poster, as Theodore Roosevelt understood, there will be little interest in his etchings.

HEADLINE: Two Black Lawyers' 'Crazy Idea' That Worked

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
From the beginning, H. Jesse Arnelle and William Hastie knew it sounded crazy: They would close their lucrative solo law practices and create a minority-owned corporate law firm, one of the first in the nation, committed to cost effectiveness in its management and diversity in its hiring policy. And they would turn the firm into a multimillion-dollar operation, with six-figure annual billings and corporate clients like the Coca-Cola Company, Levi Strauss and the Chrysler Corporation.
"It was a crazy idea because there weren't any real models," said Mr. Hastie, noting that most minority-owned law firms specialize in litigation, civil rights, criminal defense, family and personal injury law. 
 Now, about nine years later, the firm with no models is the model, with six partners, 30 associates and offices in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Sacramento, New York, Philadelphia and Cherry Hill, N.J. Its client list reads like a Who's Who of corporate America: the Eaton Corporation, the G.T.E. Corporation, First Federal Bank of California, E. I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., Bank of America and others.
"You're aren't going to find at a majority firm better lawyers or better economics," said Joann M. Russell, the associate general counsel for Levi Strauss. "And the diversity at Arnelle & Hastie is not just a diversity of color, but of ethnicity and gender. That is real important to my company."
The firm's success is built on a few tenets: keep the practice small, keep costs down and keep going after clients, taking advantage of all contacts and any programs that promote the interests of minority lawyers, like those developed by the National Bar Association in 1976, the American Bar Association in 1988 and the California Bar Association in 1990.
 
Fee Flexibility Helps
 "We're extremely aggressive about pursuing clients, particularly in the context of the various programs concerning minority counsel and lawyer diversity," Mr. Hastie said.
In a branch of the law that tends to generate higher incomes than other kinds of law, the firm is flexible about fees. "We frequently offer alternative fee structures to clients," Mr. Hastie said, "charging on a flat fee basis for a matter, a blended rate that combines our lowest and highest hourly rates, or incentive rates, where we offer to take a much lower hourly rate than our normal, with an agreement that if we achieve a certain level of results we get a bonus; if not, we're stuck with a huge discount on our hourly rate."
He added: "We tend to be about 10 to 15 percent under the costs of what big firms charge, and by big I mean a 200-plus-lawyers firm." He declined to disclose his firm's total annual billings.
The law firm that has emerged answers several corporate needs. "Some corporate counsel now are considering sending a higher proportion of their work to smaller firms, which frequently have better cost structures," John Morris, editor of The American Lawyer, explained. "So to the corporate counsel, hiring minority firms, which are generally smaller, may kill two birds with one stone: save the corporation money and encourage the development of minority lawyers."
Both Mr. Arnelle, who is 60, and Mr. Hastie, who is 46, came to their partnership with connections in both government and the private sector. Mr. Arnelle graduated from Dickinson School of Law in Carlisle, Pa., in 1962, Mr. Hastie from Boalt Hall School of Law at the University of California at Berkeley in 1971. Both had performed some corporate work in public finance and banking, but they had specialized in litigation.
Mr. Arnelle, who comes from a modest family background, was hired by R. Sargent Shriver in 1963 to be associate director of the Peace Corps in Turkey.
 
The Taste of Silver
 Mr. Hastie describes himself as having been born "if not with a silver spoon, then a silver-plated one." His father, William H. Hastie, who is dead, was the first black appointed to a Federal appeals court judgeship. He was also a dean of Howard University law school and a Governor of the United States Virgin Islands. Mr. Hastie's sister, Karen Hastie Williams, is a civil rights lawyer and former budget official under President Jimmy Carter.
Mr. Arnelle and Mr. Hastie had known each other for several years when both lived in the San Francisco area. When Mr. Arnelle decided to start the firm, he compiled a list of lawyers with whom he felt he could work; Mr. Hastie led the list.
It was a formidable undertaking. "Most corporations have not been willing to entrust very important business to minority firms," said Pauline Schneider, a black partner at Hunton & Williams in Washington and head of the American Bar Association's accreditation committee.
Jack Crump, executive director of the National Bar Association, the black law organization, said minority lawyers seldom have the money to set up the kind of offices necessary for a corporate practice or the contacts needed to pursue such a practice.
Mr. Arnelle and Mr. Hastie started in 1,500 square feet of space in the Ferry Building in San Francisco with a card table, a telephone and a list of contacts. Today, that office has expanded to 13,000 square feet on several floors, while their contacts have generated clients who give them ever larger, more lucrative, shares of their legal work.
Mr. Arnelle, who is on the board of trustees of Pennsylvania State University, knew executives who were graduates of the institution. "William Schreyer, the C.E.O. and chairman of the board of Merrill-Lynch, was on the board, and his was the first call I made from that card table," Mr. Arnelle said. "He just was so positive about the possibilities, you can't imagine how I felt after making that very first corporate call." Merrill-Lynch and Company eventually became a client.
 
Corporate Connections
 Mr. Hastie also brought corporate connections. He had once sued Levi Strauss over a stockholder issue. Though he did not win the case, he got to know the company's lawyers. Levi Strauss became another client.
Guy Rounsaville, chief counsel and corporate secretary of Wells Fargo Bank, which hired Arnelle & Hastie, said the two lawyers "are two very dynamic individuals and are extremely well thought of in the San Francisco community and in the legal profession." Mr. Arnelle is on the company's board.
Drucilla Ramey, executive director and general counsel of the Bar Association of San Francisco, credits the firm's corporate appeal to the civil rights litigation background of many of its lawyers. "They are crack litigators," Ms. Ramey said. "They're used to litigating against huge law firms on the other side with limited resources. Corporations hire them now because they have a phenomenal track record as lawyers."
Still, by the end of the firm's first year, they say they were running a deficit. Then came the RJR Tobacco Company, which picked Arnelle & Hastie as one of its corporate counsels on the recommendation of James Cole, associate general counsel for the Clorox Company and a classmate of one of the tobacco company's lead counsels. Arnelle & Hastie started turning a profit.
Over the years, Arnelle & Hastie has attracted experienced lawyers from other firms. "Partially that is because you've got to have real experience and judgment," Mr. Hastie said. "We can't build the traditional pyramid law firm because we don't have the time."
And the firm needed the resources to convince clients that it could service all their corporate law needs. For example, Mr. Hastie specialized in employment law, but it was clear that the firm needed an expert in public finance, specifically bond work for cities or municipalities. It also needed someone young who would not command a high salary.
"We found such a person in Bill Lofton, but he needed back-up, so for the first year or two of our public finance practice, I acted like the associate," Mr. Hastie said. "That included inputting documents into the computer because we didn't have money to pay overtime to secretaries. I was under his direction because he was the one who knew."
Mr. Lofton, who had been a senior associate with the well-known public finance law firm of Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe, was 28 years old at the time. He joined Arnelle & Hastie, where he is now a partner, for 60 percent of the salary he was earning plus incentives.
"I did it because hopefully I was going to make a lot more money," Mr. Lofton said. "But as important is that I thought there ought to be at least one first-rate large law firm in the country that is owned and controlled by African Americans."
Arnelle & Hastie's success has made it difficult to maintain the very diversity that makes it unusual: the raiders have become the raided. The firm already has 14 alumni, many of whom were lured away to work for corporations. That is why the partners, who at one time were black, female, Asian, Hispanic and white, are now all black and all male, Mr. Hastie says.
Stephen Melikian, who is white and a former partner at Arnelle & Hastie, now works for Nossaman, Guthner, Knox & Elliott. His race was never an issue in the firm, he said, but the the work was overwhelming. "When you have six partners you all have to chip in," Mr. Melikian said. "At a small firm that is growing, it really takes a lot of time and energy."
Mr. Melikian said he had young children and wanted to spend more time with them. He still does business with Arnelle & Hastie, however. "They have extremely good results with clients," he said. "And if you look at people based on results and repeat business, then they're doing very well."

GRAPHIC: Photo: H. Jesse Arnelle, left, and William Hastie closed their solo practices to create a minority-owned corporate law firm committed to frugal management and a diverse hiring policy. The firm generates six-figure annual billings and includes blue-chip companies among its clients. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SENATE URGES END TO U.S. EMBARGO AGAINST VIETNAM

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In a strong bipartisan vote intended to make it easier for President Clinton to end decades of rancor with a former enemy, the Senate voted today to urge that the trade embargo against Vietnam be lifted soon. The White House had supported the measure behind the scenes.
After an emotionally charged debate about the lessons of the Vietnam War and the fate of missing servicemen, the Senate, by a 62-to-38 vote, agreed with the bill's chief sponsor, John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat and Vietnam veteran, who said it was time "to put the war behind us." 
 Although the resolution is not binding, Administration officials said today that it would certainly make it easier for Mr. Clinton to take the politically sensitive step of ending the 19-year embargo, closing a chapter on a war in which 58,135 Americans died.
 
'A Seminal Event'
 "The vote will give the President the kind of political cover he needs to lift the embargo, and I expect that relatively soon," said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican and a sponsor of the bill, who was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for five and a half years. "I think it's a seminal event in U.S.-Vietnamese relations."
A consensus emerged among senior Administration officials last month to lift the embargo, but they decided that action would be put off to take political soundings around the country and determine how much backlash there would be. Administration officials acknowledge that this is a particularly sensitive issue for Mr. Clinton because he, like thousands of Americans in his generation, avoided military service during the Vietnam War.
 
2,200 Americans Missing
 Today's resolution aimed to show the President that lifting the embargo has widespread political support and is not a betrayal, as some veterans groups argue, of servicemen missing in Vietnam. Forty-two Democrats and 20 Republicans voted to lift the embargo; 14 Democrats and 24 Republicans voted against.
Last summer, President Clinton indicated he would lift the embargo if Vietnam cooperated in providing the fullest possible accounting for the more than 2,200 Americans missing in Indochina.
Now, the question in the Administration is not whether the embargo will be lifted, but how soon, though some officials say the President needs to do some more explaining to veterans' groups and families of missing servicemen.
The White House regarded the vote as useful in calling attention to the progress that Vietnam has made in meeting the conditions set by the Administration, officials said. But they said they did not expect Mr. Clinton to follow the Senate recommendation immediately.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokeswoman, said, "We certainly welcome the Senate's sentiment." But she said the Administration was still considering whether Vietnam had made sufficient progress toward providing information about P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s and on other fronts for full relations to be restored.
Many veterans' groups and family groups opposed today's resolution, arguing that Vietnam has not done enough to resolve the cases of missing Americans.
 
American Legion Opposes Move
 "The American Legion is both disappointed and concerned," said John F. Sommer Jr., the executive director. "However we are not going to give up the fight. Vietnam has not cooperated by a long shot."
Defying the intense lobbying by these groups, the Senate approved a resolution that said Vietnam's cooperation has increased significantly over the last three years in resolving the cases of missing Americans. The resolution also noted that senior American military officials feel that lifting the embargo will accelerate efforts to account for prisoners or war and missing servicemen.
Republicans in the Senate split almost evenly on the vote, with some convinced that Vietnam was making strenuous efforts to provide information on missing servicemen. Other Republicans appeared ready to use lifting the embargo as political ammunition against the Democrats.
 
Complaints From Businesses
 Many companies have quietly told Republicans and Democrats that the embargo is hurting American business as Vietnam opens its economy to the outside world.
Senator Robert C. Smith, a New Hampshire Republican who has been a strong opponent of lifting the embargo, said today: "We should not reward Vietnam with improved relations until we know they have unilaterally provided all the documentation they can from their archives. At this time, they have not even come close."
Demonstrating how emotional the issue is, he called today's vote "immoral and incomprehensible."
The bill's sponsors argued that Vietnam might stop cooperating if President Clinton did not lift the embargo.
 
'Incentives to Respond'
 "You cannot expect the Vietnamese to go on and on helping us forever and receiving nothing in return but the cold shoulder of two decades of wholesale embargo," Senator Kerry said. "In the last two years, Vietnamese cooperation on the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue has accelerated dramatically because we engaged them and because we offered them incentives to respond."
Rejecting suggestions from some service families that supporting the resolution was unpatriotic, the bill's backers noted that the main sponsor, Mr. Kerry, was wounded three times in Vietnam and was awarded a Silver Star and a Bronze Star; the other principal sponsor, Mr. McCain, was a P.O.W. Another sponsor was Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat and Medal of Honor winner who lost his right leg below the knee in Vietnam.
Senator Kerry and Administration officials vigorously denied that the Administration had stage-managed today's vote with the aim of clearing the President's way to lift the embargo.
 
Links to White House
 Administration officials and supporters of today's resolution said Senator Kerry was in regular contact with the White House's political staff on the resolution. A senior White House official said President Clinton had not sought to dissuade Senator Kerry when he told them he planned to bring the matter to a vote. But he said the White House had nothing to do with initiating the gambit.
Senator McCain said, "The White House staff felt it was very important to pass this, given the problems that the President's lack of military background gives him on this sort of an issue."
Today's resolution also sought to press Vietnam by stating that as Washington and Hanoi move toward normalizing relations, Vietnam should "demonstrate further improvements in meeting internationally recognized standards of human rights."
The resolution was proposed as an amendment to the State Department authorization bill.
In defending today's resolution, Senator McCain said he was relying on the view of two well-positioned military officials -- Adm. Charles R. Larson, Commander of United States forces in the Pacific, forces, and Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and Mr. Clinton's envoy to Vietnam.
Mr. McCain said they believed that "lifting the embargo will enhance their ability to make progress on the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue."
Senator Kerry noted that the Vietnamese have turned over 67 sets of remains last year -- the most since the war ended in 1975. He also noted that investigators have been given access to Vietnamese archives.
"The time has come for us to replace the hostility and mistrust of the last 19 years with reconciliation and reconstruction," Senator Kerry said.
Supporters of the embargo argued today that removing it would leave no levers to press Hanoi to continue cooperating. But Senators Kerry and McCain argued that there are many ways to press Hanoi, like continuing to withhold diplomatic relations or threatening to restore the embargo.
Last year, the Administration took several steps toward improving relations with Vietnam. In July, it gave the green light for the International Monetary Fund and other international institutions to lend money to Vietnam. In September, it began allowing United States companies to bid for contracts financed by loans from the I.M.F. and other international organizations.

HEADLINE: Japan's Leader Broadens His Battle to Win Reform

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Struggling to salvage his proposals for political reform and avert a collapse of his Government, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa took the extraordinary step today of appealing for popular support and international pressure to force Parliament to endorse a broad realignment of the electoral system by Saturday.
Direct pressure from Japan's largely apolitical citizens has never been a major factor in decision-making here. But Mr. Hosokawa began a counterattack to reverse his defeat in a key vote last Friday by borrowing a tactic from American politics. He called for voters to launch a telephone, fax and write-in campaign to force the Parliament to accept his proposals to reshape Parliamentary election districts and curb campaign contributions. 
 To increase the pressure, Mr. Hosokawa said that a package of measures to revive the recession-bound economy would be held hostage to the electoral legislation, which has been debated now for five years. He also suggested that he was willing to resign, and perhaps call a snap election, if the bills are killed.
 
Courting the Foreign Press
 Equally unusual was the fact that his aides went out of their way to invite members of the foreign press corps to hear his speech, in an apparent attempt to enlist international opinion.
Mr. Hosokawa said that unless the reform bills were passed this week, in some form, "it is perfectly clear that Japan will completely lose the trust of the international community." He has said that his ability to settle simmering trade disputes with the United States and to open the Japanese economy rest on his success in the current struggle.
"It is in the fifty-odd hours we have remaining that we must show the world that Japan has become a mature democracy whose people are able to make wise decisions," Mr. Hosokawa said, alluding to the end of the current session of Parliament at midnight on Saturday.
The reform measures would impose new ceilings on political contributions to candidates and parties in response to a series of bribery and corruption scandals that led to the Liberal Democratic Party's fall after nearly four decades in power.
 
Redrawing Districts
 In addition, the measures supported by the Prime Minister would increase the number of urban districts in Parliament and reduce the number of rural districts. The bills would also change the current system, in which three to six members are elected in each district, to single-seat districts.
The theory, which even the Liberal Democrats accept in principle, is that the new districts would stop members of the same party from running against one another, and thus make campaigns turn on policy differences rather than money. The main objections have come from some Socialists and members of smaller parties who claim that minority voices would not be represented.
In his speech today, Mr. Hosokawa offered to compromise on the bills, but his appeals and threats indicated that he was prepared to force a showdown.
Mr. Hosokawa's counterattack and the growing feeling here that Japan is on the cusp of major political changes were due in part to speculation that the bribery scandals that led to the effort to clean up the corrupt campaign-financing system were about to claim several powerful new victims.
The press has been filled with reports that Seiroku Kajiyama, a former Justice Minister and one of the most conservative members of the Liberal Democratic Party -- and a staunch opponent of electoral reform -- may be arrested soon on charges that he accepted an illegal contribution.
 
L.D.P. Faces More Defections
 Mr. Kajiyama's arrest would hurt the Liberal Democrats, who governed Japan for 38 years until a split last summer. The indictment of the party's former kingmaker, Shin Kanemaru, and the defection of several dozen younger members because of differences over electoral reform put Mr. Hosokawa's coalition in power in August.
The party is under enormous pressure because dozens of younger members support Mr. Hosokawa's reform proposals and are threatening to quit if the party's leaders refuse to strike a deal with the Prime Minister.
"Today, the wind is blowing against the L.D.P. again," said Yuriko Koike, a member of Mr. Hosokawa's Japan New Party. But she said it was still not clear that the Government would manage to get its reform legislation passed by the session's end. In fact, a multi-party committee failed today to hammer out a compromise.
Mr. Hosokawa went so far as to offer to virtually adopt the Liberal Democrats' version of the reform bills.
Although both bills are supposed to clean up electoral corruption, the Liberal Democrats' version is far less rigorous. For instance, corporate contributions to individual members of Parliament would still be permitted.
But the actual impact of the bills has rarely been the principal focus of this titanic battle for Japan's political future. Mr. Hosokawa appears to be calculating that by embracing both reform packages he can force a wedge between those Liberal Democrats willing to embrace change and those who staunchly oppose it.
If the Liberal Democratic Party is split again, the balance of power could shift to the cluster of parties in the center, breaking up the cold war division between the Socialists on the left and the Liberal Democrats on the right. Already, many of the more left-wing members of the Socialists -- which is part of Mr. Hosokawa's coalition -- have been driven to the brink of quitting the party.
The strategy now, according to Eichiro Ishida, the chairman of the Clean Government Party, another coalition partner, is to get through some form of the bills this week, and then amend them later.
Mr. Hosokawa succeeded in passing his bills through the more powerful lower house last November, but was stunned with an unexpected defeat in the upper house last Friday. Currently, a 20-person committee from both houses is debating a compromise. If it succeeds, the new bills would have to be passed by a majority of both houses.
If that method fails, Mr. Hosokawa can go back to the lower house and seek a two-thirds majority. That frightens the Liberal Democrats because it could encourage young rebels who have been eager to follow Mr. Hosokawa to finally make the break.
"I think we should create an environment that supports these people by coming up with a compromise that is as close as possible to the L.D.P.'s bills," said Shigeru Ishiba, who left the Liberal Democrats several weeks ago. "Then we would create widespread public support, which would leave the L.D.P. helpless."

HEADLINE: Belarus Says Aide's Ouster Won't Stop Reform

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Belarus Foreign Ministry called in foreign diplomats in Minsk today to reassure them that the country's commitments to denuclearization and a market economy were unchanged by the ouster on Wednesday of Stanislav S. Shushkevich, a non-Communist reformer, as chairman of Parliament and ceremonial head of state.
The removal of Mr. Shushkevich by Parliament, on dubious charges of corruption after two years of battling for early elections and economic reforms, leaves Belarus in the hands of the same Communist Party officials who ran it before the collapse of the Soviet Union in December 1991. 
 Mr. Shushkevich, 59, was also considered an outspoken advocate of Belarusian independence from Moscow, which had ruled Belarus since 1772. His opponents, including the longtime Prime Minister, Vyacheslav F. Kebich, who survived a similar vote, favor ties to Russia that are much closer, almost a reunion of the two states.
President Clinton met with both men two weeks ago to thank Belarus for agreeing to scrap its 81 SS-25 nuclear missiles and to give support to faster economic reform and early parliamentary elections, seen as an effort to prop up Mr. Shushkevich.
 
Fear of New 'Empire'
 Senior Western diplomats in Minsk expressed concern before Mr. Clinton's visit that a reunion of Russia with Belarus could start an "imperial reconstruction" that Washington and the West did not want to see.
In Minsk today, the head of the opposition in Parliament, Zyanon Paznyak, said the removal of Mr. Shushkevich represented "a creeping Communist coup aimed at eliminating Belarusian statehood and imposing a dictatorship under Kebich."
Mr. Shushkevich, a physicist who once helped teach Russian to Lee Harvey Oswald, was succeeded by his deputy, Vyacheslav Kuznetov, a conservative former Communist.
Yuri V. Khadipa, the deputy chairman of the opposition Belarus National Front, said: "Now the last stage of the reconstitution of the Russian empire will begin with the induction of Belarus into the ruble zone. This move will prop up factories of the former Soviet military-industrial complex, which no one needs."
Having already forced through a military alliance that calls on Russia to defend Belarus and its 10.7 million people, Mr. Kebich is a prime proponent of an economic union that would subordinate Minsk's financial policies to Moscow's in return for cheap energy and the use of the Russian ruble. He recently agreed upon such a union with his counterpart, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who is due to come to Minsk next week to iron out details.
Belarus is heavily dependent on Russia for energy and contracts, and its unreformed economy is experiencing 50 percent monthly inflation.
Minsk-based diplomats said the return to dominance of Soviet-era managers in Moscow had an obvious impact in Belarus, though they stressed that the Communist-dominated Belarusian Supreme Soviet, first elected in March 1990, has been trying to oust Mr. Shushkevich for months. They almost succeeded in July, but he was saved then by Mr. Paznyak and the opposition.
But this time, after more months of trying to balance between Mr. Kebich and Mr. Paznyak, Mr. Shushkevich ran out of supporters, many of whom were angered at his failure to protect two Cabinet allies who were removed from office on Tuesday.
This monetary union, which would cost Russians many millions of dollars if the ruble is exchanged one for one for the weaker Belarus currency and if debts between state enterprises are canceled, was one of main factors cited by Yegor T. Gaidar, the architect of Russia's economic reforms, when he quit Mr. Chernomyrdin's Cabinet, followed this week by the Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov.

HEADLINE: 18,000 Investors Submit Claims to Prudential

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
About 18,000 investors have submitted claims so far to a fund established by Prudential Securities to compensate hundreds of thousands of customers for losses suffered because of fraud in the sale of limited partnerships, according to a report by the fund's administrator.
The tally of claims underscores the big task Prudential faces in complying with the terms of its October settlement with securities regulators that required it to set up the $330 million fund. The report also provides details of what investors making claims stand to receive. 
 As many as 325,000 claim forms were sent in recent weeks to customers who invested in the partnerships.
The 18,000 claims were submitted as of Jan. 17, the last day accounted for in the quarterly report of the administrator, Irving M. Pollack. The speed of that response, coming before Prudential's Jan. 18 deadline for mailing out claim forms, reflects the urgency for investors -- many of whom were elderly -- in getting their money back.
 
First Offers of Settlement
 According to the report, filed late last week in Federal District Court in Washington, Prudential sent out its first 25 offers of settlement last Friday. None of those offers have yet been accepted or rejected, the report said.
In the case, securities regulators charged that Prudential misrepresented the safety and liquidity of the highly risky partnerships. Under the settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the administrator must file quarterly reports on fund performance with Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene.
In his report, Mr. Pollack has determined that customers who were unsuitable partnership investors or who were deceived will receive out-of-pocket costs -- minus benefits from the investment -- plus interest. The benefits include distributions, tax deductions and the remaining value of the investment.
The interest rate paid will be the yield equivalent of a one-year Treasury bill, annualized for each year the investment was owned. For example, an investor who still owned a partnership purchased in 1982 would receive a varying rate of interest for each year it was held, ranging from 12.61 percent in 1982 to 3.46 percent in 1993.
The cost of the partnership scandal is showing on Prudential's bottom line. The firm reported yesterday that its 1993 earnings of $145 million were essentially unchanged from the previous year. That came as a number of other brokerage houses were reporting record earnings after Wall Street's biggest year ever.
The comparative earnings sluggishness appeared largely to be a result of the costs of the scandal. During the year, Prudential set aside $430 million in reserves, which were used to finance the settlement fund.
But Prudential showed a number of signs of financial health. For the year, revenues were up 13 percent, to $3.4 billion. Assets grew 11 percent, to a record $151 billion. The firm also opened more than 20,000 new accounts each month and increased its number of brokers by 230.
During the fourth quarter, Prudential's revenues were up 18 percent from the comparable period in 1992. The firm, which is not public, did not provide full earnings for the fourth quarter, although pretax earnings from continuing operations were $154 million, more than double the total in the quarter a year earlier.
Meanwhile, the scandal has led securities regulators to examine how other Wall Street firms marketed limited partnerships, a booming business in the 1980's. In recent weeks, the S.E.C. has sent requests for information to about 10 firms that were among the top sellers of the investments, Wall Street executives said.
The requests are not part of any active inquiry into the activities of any particular firm or partnership, but rather an effort by the S.E.C. to learn more about the way such investments were sold in recent years, people involved in the situation said.
Similar requests have been made in the past. For example, shortly after questions arose last year about political contributions by municipal bond dealers, the S.E.C. sent requests for information across Wall Street to learn more about those practices.

HEADLINE: Forecast Is New Clinton Weapon In Debate Over Balanced Budget

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The White House today seized on a striking new set of Congressional projections showing shrinking budget deficits to reinforce its argument that there is no need for a Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget.
Still worried that the amendment could win Congressional approval in a vote as early as next month, President Clinton's top economic deputies hailed as evidence of their progress an estimate by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office that the deficit would drop to $171 billion in the fiscal year 1995 -- $113 billion less than the analysts predicted last January. 
 The Congressional office praised the President and Congress for having made "dramatic" progress in reducing the Federal deficit, and Mr. Clinton's aides immediately described it as vindication of their arguments that discipline, not law, was what would best bring the deficit under control.
"You don't need a constitutional amendment," said Leon E. Panetta, director of the Office of Management and Budget. "What it takes is real leadership in this country, and that's what's being provided by this President."
 
Cautious Clinton Estimates
 The Congressional estimate for next year's budget deficit was even more optimistic than the $180 billion figure put forward by President Clinton last week, a rare instance of a sitting Administration being more cautious than the independent analysts. The Congressional Budget Office also said the 1994 Federal deficit would drop to $223 billion, $68 billion less than it projected just a year ago.
But the Congressional analysts also projected that barring any major change in Government spending, including for health care, the deficit would begin to climb steeply again by the end of the decade, and the White House pointed to those figures to answer criticism of its efforts to overhaul the health care system.
"Ask the fellow who has to write the checks," said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who joined Mr. Panetta at a White House briefing. "The message is simple: with health care reform, we get the deficit headed down. And without it, it shoots right back up."
By any measure, however, the Congressional forecast brought good news for the Administration by depicting a deficit that is shrinking steadily in the short term, something not seen by the Government for decades.
Part of the reason for the better outlook lies in improvements in the economy and low interest rates, which allow the Government to spend less on poor people and collect more revenue from businesses and taxpayers, thereby narrowing the budget gap. But the Congressional Budget Office gave credit for much of the improvement to the narrow passage by Congress last summer of Mr. Clinton's economic package.
It said that "difficult step" by Congress and the President "seems likely to achieve the desired outcome -- significantly lower deficits than were projected a year ago." The budget plan approved last summer included nearly $500 billion in deficit reduction over five years, with that total almost equally divided between income tax increases for the wealthy and freezes in existing Government programs.
The 1995 fiscal year does not begin until Oct. 1, and Mr. Clinton will not introduce his budget for that year until Feb. 7. But Mr. Panetta sought today to underscore the Administration's pledge that it would abide by strict fiscal discipline and said the budget would show cuts in spending for 7 of the 14 main Federal departments.
With that emphasis on restraint, the White House is trying to steal the wind from efforts by supporters of a balanced budget amendment to push it through Congress, which has grown more receptive to the idea since the 1992 campaign.
Mr. Clinton has consistently opposed such an amendment as unnecessary, and has said that what is needed is leadership to make tough choices on Federal spending.
The amendment, which would require Congress to balance the budget by the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, 1998, was only narrowly defeated by the House last June. A Senate vote was put off last November until next month.
