HEADLINE: 30 Years Later, 3d Trial Begins in Evers Killing

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Exactly 30 years after the start of his first inconclusive trial on the charge of murdering the civil rights leader Medgar Evers, Byron De La Beckwith, a lot older but no less outspoken in his white supremacist views, went on trial today for the third time.
The case is being heard in the same Hinds County courtroom that it was 30 years ago, amid the same brass sconces, chandeliers and intricately carved eagle pediments that survived a 1986 renovation. 
 The first witnesses were even the same. Mr. Evers's widow, Myrlie, took the stand to describe in a strong, clear voice the events of midnight June 12, 1963, when "a horrible blast" sent her running to the door of her home, where she found her husband lying in a pool of blood, his keys clutched in his hand.
"The children ran out and they cried out: 'Daddy! Daddy! Please get up, Daddy!' " she testified, but Mr. Evers, 37, had been fatally shot.
As she spoke, the 73-year-old Mr. Beckwith, a former fertilizer salesman whose fingerprints were found on the scope of a rifle believed to be the murder weapon, appeared unmoved.
Perhaps as much as any other event, the slaying of Mr. Evers in the turbulent coming of age of black Americans' fight for civil rights helped galvanize the movement, focusing national attention on the atmosphere of terror that prevailed in the South during that era.
In his opening statement, the prosecutor, Bobby DeLaughter, tried to convey the sense of that distant time to the jurors, most of whom were small children at the time of the slaying. Mr. DeLaughter told of Mr. Evers's pivotal role as the N.A.A.C.P.'s Mississippi field secretary, who led voting rights protests and drives to integrate public accommodations and schools.
"Medgar Evers was the focal point of everything that this defendant hated," said Mr. DeLaughter, an assistant Hinds County District Attorney. Mr. Beckwith, he told the jurors, was "a self-proclaimed, rabid racist" who in letters to newspapers, public statements and pamphlets dating from the 1950's had made clear that his "mission was to purge society of anyone and anything that was for integration."
As a result, the prosecutor said, Mr. Beckwith killed Mr. Evers. "His life was snuffed out by a bullet aimed by prejudice, propelled by hatred and fired by a coward -- a back-shooting coward at night," Mr. DeLaughter said.
The courtroom also echoed with the same protestations of innocence that Mr. Beckwith made 30 years ago. Then as now, Mr. Beckwith maintained that he was more than 90 miles away from Jackson in his home town of Greenwood when the shooting occurred.
One of Mr. Beckwith's two court-appointed lawyers, Merrida Coxwell, told the court: "By the time this case is over you will see that it was physically impossible for Byron De La Beckwith to have killed Medgar Evers. You're going to find that the state can't prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Mr. Beckwith killed Mr. Evers."
But much has changed since that day 30 years ago when Mr. Beckwith's first trial opened. Absent was the smiling visage of Mississippi's Governor at the time, Ross Barnett, who shook Mr. Beckwith's hand and clapped him on the back in a show of support that was shared by much of white Mississippi. Also absent were the all-white, all-male juries that deadlocked in two trials in 1964. Sitting in the jury box now were eight blacks and four whites, with seven of these jurors women.
Security was tight. Spectators, who had been required to obtain identification cards before entering the courtroom, stood solemnly in line to pass through metal detectors.
"I was 23 years old when it happened and so young," said Thomasine McClendon, a 53-year-old black woman from Jackson who had come to watch. "I remember it, and remember it hitting us hard, but I was so young. I'm here to see justice finally served."
Brenda and Carl Dixon, a white couple from Pearl, also said that they had come to see that "justice is done." They said they did not know who had killed Medgar Evers, but, Mr. Dixon said, "somebody did and this ought to help us find out who it was."
 
Old Wounds and Old Pain
 But for many people, black and white, the case is a source of ambivalence. Many whites say it needlessly reopens old wounds that have been salved, if not completely healed, by political and economic advances made by black Mississippians.
Among blacks, Mr. Beckwith's guilt, while never legally established, has long been a matter of moral certainty that, along with dozens of other cases of unpunished violence against blacks, has graphically defined the era of racial terror and white intransigence that was Mississippi in the 60's.
Many blacks say the new trial gives the state a chance to cleanse its soul. But some wonder aloud whether a failure to convict Mr. Beckwith this time would do subtle damage to the legacy of the 60's. Reuben V. Anderson, the first black justice on Mississippi's Supreme Court, said he sensed that history itself and a world view were on trial along with Mr. Beckwith. "There are tremendous technical and legal obstacles to a case like this, and while the prosecutors are among the best in the state, won't the state look bad once again if they can't convict him?" said Mr. Anderson, who left the bench three years ago to practice law in Jackson.
The third prosecution of Mr. Beckwith had its beginnings in 1989, when published accounts of the files of the Mississippi Sovereignty Commission, a now defunct state agency that had been created to support the maintenance of segregation, showed that its officials had helped screen potential jurors in Mr. Beckwith's two trials. Looking into the possibility of jury tampering, the Hinds County District Attorney's Office instead found new witnesses.
 
A Costly Boast
 The new witnesses fell into two categories: those to whom Mr. Beckwith was said to have boasted that he had killed Mr. Evers and those, many of them black, who said they had seen Mr. Beckwith in Jackson on the evening of the shooting, assertions that contradicted two white Greenwood, Miss., police officers who had provided Mr. Beckwith with his alibi when they testified that he had been seen in Greenwood, two hours away.
In court today, Mr. Beckwith looked dapper in a gray chalk-stripe suit, but the passage of three decades was apparent. His hearing aid sat on the table in front of him, its wire trailing to his ears, and he mostly sat silently, rarely reacting to what was said. Thirty years ago he took copious notes throughout the trial and constantly huddled with his lawyers over strategy.
Before he was re-indicted in 1990, Mr. Beckwith was living in Signal Mountain, Tenn., where he flew a Confederate flag from his front porch and regularly talked with those he met of his hatred of blacks and Jews.
After testimony ended for the day Mrs. Evers, who had seemed unshakable on the witness stand, told of the flood of bitter memories when Mr. DeLaughter showed her a picture of her husband's body.
"It was afterward that I cried," she said. "I pride myself of being tough, but it was emotional."

HEADLINE: Battle With Echoes: Floridians Fight a Power Line

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: THONOTOSASSA, Fla.

 BODY:
Out here in Tampa's back yard, where suburban sprawl thins into rural spread, the residents of Hillsborough County are wrestling with the Florida Power Corporation over its plan to string 40 miles of high-voltage power line across the flat landscape.
In many ways it is a perfectly prosaic conflict between development and environment, pitting just another local coalition of property owners, residents and county officials against just another company with "power" as its middle name. 
 But it also typifies a broader, long-running debate nationwide over where to put energy projects, a subject deeply worrisome to some of the nation's energy experts. The experts in the Government estimate that the demand for energy is growing at an annual average of a quadrillion British thermal units, or B.T.U.'s, enough to allow every person on the planet to bring a bathtub of ice water to a boil.
 
Worry Over Energy Supply
 Government energy analysts say the disputes over sites for energy sources point up the necessity of balancing the need for energy with responsibility to the environment. Unless that balance can be achieved, they say, the disputes could choke off supplies.
"It seems evident that siting is becoming more difficult for all types of facilities," the Energy Department said in a recent report. "Failure to act decisively to ameliorate siting constraints will seriously impact our ability to achieve key energy, economic, and environmental goals."
The decade-old debate in Hillsborough County is just what the report was talking about. The power company contends that the high-voltage line is needed to insure that 1.5 million customers in central Florida are not threatened with power blackouts.
Opponents say the power company is afraid to reconsider an alternative route a few miles to the south because the utility would again have to win state approval. The opponents contend that the power company could not convince the state that the high-voltage line is needed, as it did 10 years ago. The utility now has an unused power line with 80-foot towers along its right-of-way. It wants to replace the line with one capable of carrying 500,000-volt currents on towers twice as tall.
After the state approved the high-voltage line, opponents took their battle to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. Those who live along the power line's path are worried about the possible health hazards of being exposed to electromagnetic fields. Some researchers assert that electromagnetic fields can bring on various forms of cancer. The opponents are also concerned about a loss of property value.
They found an ally a half-hour beyond the housing tracts, where the power line would cross an extraordinary parcel of land: the 14,000-acre Two Rivers Ranch. Its owners have preserved it for decades, balancing pasture with wilderness.
 
Rich Wildlife Habitat
 The ranch, which includes crystalline springs and meandering streams that provide much of Tampa's water supply, offers a rich wildlife habitat. A power company biologist who walked the six-mile stretch of ranch that the power line would cross recorded scores of rare, threatened or endangered species: bald eagle, wood stork, gopher turtle, sand-hill crane and alligator among them.
The power company says it has designed the project to minimize the effects on wetlands and wildlife. For example, it proposes to avoid road construction by using helicopters to remove cypress trees and to install the steel towers in their place.
Opponents, including Nancy Fleming, an organizer of the Citizens Coalition for Responsible Power, and Robert Thomas, the scion of the family that owns Two Rivers Ranch, are hoping that the Federal Government will stop the project on the basis of environmental damage. The project would include the filling of wetlands on the ranch and in other rural areas.
In recent interviews, both Mrs. Fleming and Mr. Thomas said the utility's proposal for planting power lines was flawed. "There was no consideration whatever -- not for wetlands, not for families, not for anything," Mrs. Fleming said.
As a result of the opposition, the Hillsborough County Commission appealed the project's Federal permit to the Environmental Protection Agency. The county is also weighing legal actions, said John Dingfelder of the county attorney's office.
In response to the county, Robert Perciasepe, the E.P.A.'s assistant administrator for water quality, asked Edward Dickey, the assistant secretary for civil works of the Army Corps of Engineers, to review the permit issued to Florida Power last year by the corps' regional office. The office has jurisdiction over wetlands. Mr. Dickey's decision on whether to let the permit stand is scheduled to be announced next week.
Florida Power had convinced the corps that innovative construction techniques would limit the filling of wetlands to the areas just around each tower: a total of seven-tenths of an acre for all the towers that would be built in wetlands.
 
Pattern of Fights to Come
 Mr. Perciasepe disputed that contention. He said the project "would impact 241 acres of valuable forested wetlands, an aquatic resource of national importance."
The power company's fight follows patterns that energy officials and environmentalists see occurring around the country. In December, the Energy Department published a 184-page study by a working group assigned to come up with ways of avoiding conflicts over proposed sites for all kinds of energy projects, including stringing transmission lines, laying pipelines, building power plants, refineries and dams, digging coal mines, setting up drilling rigs, and creating windmill fields.
The group cited a Government report estimating that from 1990 to 2010, there will be a need for 2,200 new coal mines, 170 new coal-powered generating plants and 300 new plants burning municipal solid wastes.
Although electricity use is expected to grow even faster than other forms of energy consumption, the Government is unable to predict the need for high-voltage power lines like the one that has riled Hillsborough County residents. But the Government report did predict that concerns about wetlands and electromagnetic fields might arise around many proposals for power lines.
What can be done to stave off such collisions? The Energy Department is not sure, but it is seeking ideas for reaching consensus among interested parties and government agencies early in the planning instead of at the end.
 
Ranch Seeks Coexistence
 At Two Rivers Ranch, the managers are working with state agencies and private companies to develop a local network of "greenways." These would be common corridors on which roads, water pipelines and perhaps even power lines might be built with minimal effect on the ranch. At the ranch, the Thomas family raises only a fraction of the number of cattle it could and brings in extra money by offering horseback riding and breeding, hunting and canoeing.
Florida Power, however, has its doubts about the "greenways" proposal. "There is no magic route," said Teresa Guarcello, the company's environmental specialist. "We would have just as much opposition to any other route."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Bracing For Losses in Tourism

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27

 BODY:
When Alvin Dollar of Atlanta told his wife that he was headed for Los Angeles to attend a convention and asked if she wanted to come along, her reply was an emphatic "no!"
Mrs. Dollar said she feared another earthquake. 
 Mr. Dollar didn't, and today he found himself enjoying the sunny, noisy, thrill-filled delights of one of the most popular entertainment parks in the Los Angeles area, Universal Studios Hollywood.
"I didn't want to be the chicken," Mr. Dollar said as he headed for a ride called "Back to the Future."
 
A $20-Billion Business
 Tourism is a $20 billion-a-year business in Los Angeles, which tourist officials say makes it one of the biggest businesses in the city. But in the aftermath of the Jan. 17 earthquake, city officials are deeply worried that in the coming months there may be a lot of "chickens" when it comes to tourism here.
There were times today at the Universal Studios park when no one stood in line to buy an entry ticket. For that matter, most of the ticket booths were closed, although park officials said January is a slow month anyway.
One quick survey commissioned this week by the Los Angeles Convention and Visitors Bureau concluded that the loss in tourism income here in the next year could exceed $300 million, resulting in layoffs for more than 9,000 of the 400,000 people who work in the industry.
The survey did not turn up any major cancellations of conventions or major sports and entertainment events; Disneyland, for example, reported no major falloff in business. But the survey did find a few long-term as well as short-term hotel cancellations, some based on the incorrect assumption that the quake had caused major damage to the city's tourist attractions and convention services.
 
More Cancellations Likely
 Moreover, based on the tourism industry's experience after earlier natural disasters and man-made disruptions, the survey predicted more cancellations.
"No question we're going to be hurt," said George D. Kirkland, president of the bureau. "For all that's happened, the truth is that we are basically still a fully operational city, with some buildings and highways badly damaged, yes, but only a few major buildings and only a few spans down in an entire 500-mile freeway system. That's the message we have to get out to overcome the psychic damage that goes along with the physical damage. And we intend to do it."
One major concern is that the earthquake might result in the cancellation of future conventions and events in the city's convention center, now the largest on the West Coast and one of the largest in the country since the recent completion of a $500 million expansion.
Typically, city convention centers are major catalysts in generating tourist dollars.
While the predicted losses in money and jobs here may seem statistically small, they would add significantly to the economic problems that have afflicted Los Angeles in recent years as Southern California has been whipsawed by the national recession, rioting, brush fires and torrential rains.
Tourism losses from the riots and looting that swept Los Angeles in the spring of 1992, for example, were estimated at $500 million, the Convention and Visitors Bureau said.
 
1.5% Loss in Revenue Likely
 Before the earthquake, the region had been anticipating a 2.6 percent rebound in tourism revenue as the economy strengthened and memory of the riots, fires and rains diminished. Now, if the survey pans out, the city will end up with a loss of tourist revenue of at least 1.5 percent.
And there is more bad news: Los Angeles will probably not be the only place where tourism suffers because of the quake.
State officials expect the earthquake to have an aftershock effect on tourism throughout California, which is the top tourist destination in the country. In fact, tourism is the second largest industry in California, after agriculture, bringing in $54 billion annually.
"After the 1989 quake that hit San Francisco there was a major fall-off in tourism all over the state, especially in Los Angeles," recalled John Poimiroo, the state's director of tourism. "Unfortunately, there's no reason to think the same thing won't happen all over again this time, with San Francisco suffering, too, from the economic aftershock."
 
Confident of Rebounding
 Still, Mr. Poimiroo, who was in Los Angeles and at Universal Studios today for some meetings on how to promote California tourism, is confident that business will rebound.
In the first few days and weeks after the earthquake that struck the San Francisco Bay area on Oct. 17, 1989, he said, tourism in that city declined by almost 20 percent. In Los Angeles, the falloff was almost 15 percent.
"But within a few months, things were coming back pretty strong in both places," Mr. Poimiroo said. "And after a year or so things were almost normal again. I expect just about the same thing to happen this time around."
In an effort to offset any impressions that California, and in particular Los Angeles, may be down and out when it comes to tourism, state and city tourist officials plan special national advertising campaigns. But the campaigns may be limited unless the State Legislature and City Council here can be persuaded to put up extra money.
Last fall, a task force appointed by Gov. Pete Wilson to study tourism in the state estimated that it would take more than $15 million in advertising to stem the loss in tourism resulting from the economic downturn and the natural and man-made disasters that had hit the state. Now, after last week's quake, it presumably will require an even larger advertising campaign.
But state and local officials say they not only cannot come up with $15 million, but will also have difficulty coming up with $3 million.
 
Federal Aid to Be Sought
 "Things are very tight," said Mr. Poimiroo said. "We're going to put on a campaign, but to pay for it we're going to have to pool our resources. And we're also going to ask the Federal Government for some help. We've got to do more."
Julie Meier Wright, the state Secretary of Trade and Commerce who was here with Mr. Poimiroo for the tourism meeting, put it more bluntly.
Even before the earthquake and all the other disasters hit California, she said, the state was loosing tourist dollars because it was not advertising enough. Although the state ranks No. 1 in tourism in the United States, she said, its tourism advertising budget ranks 16th.
"Our budgets in recent years have been up and down and erratic," she said. "And certainly they've been insufficient. We've been slipping in market share."
 
Earthquake Ride Closed
 Whatever the case and despite the earthquake, Rudi Salandanan showed up in Los Angeles this week, a tourist who traveled here from the Philippines. Today he was out at Universal Studios Hollywood, ready to ride, a dream come true for the Los Angeles Convention and Visitors Bureau and the California Division of Tourism.
He was making his way toward the earthquake ride when he learned that it had been closed -- for public relations reasons, according to park officials.
"But that's what I came all this way for!" he exclaimed with angst in his voice.
Universal's earthquake ride measures a bone-rattling 8.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion. Last week's real event was a wimpy 6.6.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Begins Talks to Keep N.F.L. Offices in New York

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration said yesterday that it had begun talks with officials of the National Football League about offering financial incentives to keep the league's office in New York City.
Officials of the N.F.L. -- whose lease on their executive offices, at Park Avenue and East 54th Street, expires in February 1995 -- said yesterday that they had looked at possible sites in Westchester County where they could move their headquarters and 250 employees. 
 Although the N.F.L. office represents a relatively small work force, the presence of a major sports organization has symbolic importance for the city, which is home to major basketball and hockey offices as well.
Moreover, for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the discussions represent a significant first attempt at negotiating incentive packages with organizations and companies to remain in New York, a critical element in his quest to revive the city's economy. It comes after the decision of several companies last year to move some or all of their work forces out of New York City.
During the mayoral campaign last year, Mr. Giuliani was harshly critical of former Mayor David N. Dinkins for allowing too many companies to leave the city, despite the offer of financial incentives. On the other hand, some officials, including Mark J. Green, the city's Public Advocate, have criticized the use of incentives, which typically include tax breaks, as a huge loss of future tax revenues. They contend that the city is subjected to a game of corporate bluff on the part of executives who may have no real intention of leaving New York.
John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, would not discuss any details of the talks, but said that the city was eager to keep the N.F.L. in New York. "It represents 250 jobs, but we don't want to lose those jobs," he said. "They are a prominent internationally known organization and we feel we can help them find the right space."
Mr. Dyson, who met with Neal Austrian, the league president, in the N.F.L.'s office, said the discussions included "a smorgasbord of incentives," and added: "We explained to them a number of alternatives we could help them with. Right now, we are just at the beginning of the process."
Greg Aiello, a spokesman for the N.F.L., said the league's officials expected to make a decision with the next three weeks. He said that officials had looked at office space throughout the metropolitan region, including in New Jersey and Connecticut, but that they have narrowed their search to a site in Westchester and three in midtown Manhattan. Mr. Aiello said the league was looking to obtain 130,000 square feet of office space.
The league headquarters has been in New York City since 1960, when it was moved from Bryn Mawr, Pa., a Philadelphia suburb, under Commissioner Pete Rozelle.
In 1992, the United States Tennis Association moved its headquarters from Manhattan to Harrison in Westchester County, relocating about 100 employees from the Manhattan site and two other offices in Princeton, N.J., and Jericho, L.I.

HEADLINE: From Recession, California Is Emerging Into Earthquake 'Boomlet'

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28

 BODY:
With damage estimates from the earthquake running as high as $30 billion, and people all around Los Angeles still edgy over the aftershocks rumbling underfoot, it comes as little surprise that a wide variety of service businesses -- from the mundane drywall contractor to the more exotic massage therapist -- are being besieged.
Local newspapers are full of classified advertising promoting "earthquake-safe chimneys," "seismic rehabilitation" and "professional estimates" for the Federal Emergency Management Agency's aid applications. Desperate commuters, intent on slicing time off drives that have been tripled because of damaged highways, have cleaned out the inventories of motorcycle dealerships. 
 And retailers, restaurateurs and entrepreneurs, emerging from the initial shock of the disaster, are holding earthquake sales and promoting products tied to the quake -- things like espresso "earthquake shakes" to "I survived the quake" T-shirts.
"It's going to be a boomlet," said Jack Kyser, chief economist of the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County, a private nonprofit business association. "This is a jump start for a construction industry that has hit bottom and was moving sideways. And it certainly can't hurt retailers and other small businesses that can assist some way in the recovery."
 
A Help, but Not Enough
 Nonetheless, economists said that the gains for the regional economy, fueled by the expectation of as much as $7.5 billion in Federal aid, will still not be enough to lift Southern California out of its three-year recession. At best, they said, the rebuilding will allow the region to keep from falling into deeper economic troubles and will postpone the recovery that many had been predicting for this year.
The damage in the San Fernando Valley, where the earthquake was centered, and other parts of Los Angeles is so pervasive that it may well outweigh whatever aid comes from the state and Federal governments.
Indeed, some businesses and homeowners may choose not to rebuild, and the largest public projects -- the highways, the hospitals and the schools -- could take years to complete. The overall cost of doing business in Los Angeles could increase if residents are charged higher taxes to finance the repairs.
There have also been concerns that some people have been profiting unfairly from the misfortune of others. In the days following the quake on Nov. 17, some service stations reportedly doubled their prices and some convenience stores were reported overcharging people for essentials like batteries and water.
More recently, some officials have warned that building owners may be using earthquake damage as an excuse to evict renters so then can convert their property into high-priced condominiums. In some parts of the San Fernando Valley, displaced homeowners who are searching for apartments have complained about higher rents being charged for vacant units.
 
A Contractor Sting
 And on Wednesday, the Contractors State License Board conducted a sting operation from a damaged home and arrested four uncertified contractors who had bid on home repairs.
Still, the post-earthquake boomlet is benefiting many, and the evidence can be seen from Wall Street, to the union halls of Los Angeles to front yards of ranch homes in Northridge.
Lawrence Horan, a senior building analyst with Prudential Securities in Manhattan, said there was a small increase in the stock prices of publicly traded construction companies in the days after the earthquake, as traders "anticipated that there would be people buying and rebuilding new homes." Shares of the Standard Pacific Company, a home building concern, rose to 125/8 , an increase of 15/8 , by the end of last week, although it had dropped slightly to 107/8 by the end of today's trading.
One of the country's largest demolition companies, Penhall International Inc. in Anaheim, has been working round the clock since the day after the earthquake, clearing more than 30,000 cubic yards of concrete from three damaged superhighways. Roger C. Stull, the company's president, said that these jobs for the California Department of Transportation will easily bring more than $1.3 million, and he has added 60 employees to the company's payroll of 500.
 
Work to the Max
 "It's loaded us up with work to the maximum," Mr. Stull said. "Before we were running at 60 to 65 percent of capacity, and now we're over 100 percent. We don't have one free piece of equipment left."
In downtown Los Angeles and the San Fernando Valley today, the Carpenters Union halls were bustling with activity. Members who had been driving taxis and flipping hamburgers to survive the recession before the quake suddenly found themselves again making $23.80 an hour.
Mike Aragon, a contractor in the San Fernando Valley, had also been struggling to get by for the last two years, remodeling kitchens and repaving garden walks. For the last week, however, he has done a brisk business in damage assessments, conducting about 20 at $100 each.
There has been a boom here in the sales of glass, earthquake preparedness kits and construction supplies. The Home Depot store in Canoga Park has been crowded all week, selling 250 water heaters a day (at $134) and 120 generators for the week (at $545) as against the usual 25 heaters and two generators, said Bob Barnett, the manager.
The economic activity, however, extends past constuction workers and earthquake supplies. At Altmans Winnebago in Van Nuys the sales lot is nearly empty after 30 of the motor homes were rented in one day and 20 more the next day.
The renters cannot stay in their homes, or are afraid, so they park the motor homes in front, said Tom Lander, the dealership's general manager.
And the massage therapists, chiropractrors and biofeedback specialists at the Los Angeles Healing Arts Center on the city's West Side have been booked solid since the quake, said Daniel Bienenfield, its executive director. "Right now people need a tactile connection," he said. "They need their hands held."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Jump in Late Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of long- and intermediate-term Government securities rose sharply yesterday afternoon after initially slipping in response to the morning's reports on jobless claims and December durable goods orders.
The economic reports, particularly the one on durable goods, were worrisome because they provided more proof that the economy was picking up steam, which bond traders and investors fear may lead to rising inflation. But other analysts believe that the stronger growth has already been discounted in bond prices. 
 Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Associates, a bond market research firm in Princeton, N.J., did not offer any single reason for the afternoon spike in bonds, which moved the price of the 30-year issue from 999/32 to 9928/32 near the close of the New York cash market. "If you asked a hundred people you'd probably get a hundred different answers," he said. "The market was already firm going into the afternoon and just picked up momentum."
 
 
Still in Trading Range
 By late in the day the price of the 30-year bond was up 20/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.26 percent, from 6.30 Wednesday but well within the trading range it has been locked in since early December.
In shorter maturities, the new two-year issue was trading at a price to yield 4.10 percent, a basis point under its auction high yield of 4.11 percent. There was strong demand for the new five-year note auctioned Wednesday, pushing the yield down to 5.03 percent, well under its auction high yield of 5.10 percent.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for Donoghue's Money Report in Ashland, Mass., said that the December durable goods numbers were very good and indicated that "business investment is going along at a good clip."
Durable goods orders were up 2.2 percent for the month. Excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders were up 2.6 percent.
New jobless claims for the week that ended Saturday fell to 309,000 from a revised 365,000 in the previous week. The decline came after three weeks of rising claims.
Analysts said the reports of the last several weeks were difficult to read because of the impact of severe weather across the country, particularly in the Northeast, and the earthquake in Los Angeles. The decline in the recent week may be a result of the fact that a lot of people could not get to offices to make their claims.
"You really have to look at a trend," Mr. Frank said. "If over the course of a month the trend continued it would mean something is in the works."
A report on the growth rate of the economy in the fourth quarter, which is scheduled to be released today, is expected to show strong growth in the last three months of 1993, Mr. Frank said.
"But the market will be looking at the individual components as we go forward this year, such as inventories and inflation indicators," he added. "The only thing that would surprise the market now is that the numbers would show a slowdown, and I can't believe that is happening."
In the weeks ahead the market will have other areas of interest to focus on, such as the testimony of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, before Congress in February on the nation's economic outlook and the central bank's interest-rate policy. Coming up at the end of next week are the monthly employment figures, one of the most closely watched economic reports.

HEADLINE: Stocks at Another High in Busy Day

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The stock market pushed to record highs yesterday amid very heavy trading as investors were attracted by prospects for sustained economic growth and low interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 18.30 points, to 3,926.30, its 10th record closing so far this year. The Standard & Poor's Index of 500 stocks rose 3.85 points, to 477.05, also a record. 
 Prices were also strong in the broader market, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 4.08 points, to 792.88, less than two points below its all-time high set on Jan. 21.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 346.5 million shares, with 1,329 stocks rising and 784 falling.
"The stock market is making a case for the 'best of all possible worlds' forecast," said Kevin Bannon, chief investment officer at the Bank of New York. There is, he said, "a growing belief that the economy will grow enough to produce decent growth in corporate profits, but not so much that you have to worry about rising inflation and rising interest rates."
Fresh evidence of the economy's health is expected today, when the Commerce Department reports on economic activity in the fourth quarter. Predictions that gross domestic product -- the sum of all the goods and services produced in the country -- would exceed 5 percent after inflation were widespread.
"It will be an unpleasant surprise to the market if the gain is below 3 percent," said Mark Kimsey, manager of global equity research at Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Kimsey noted that demand from foreign investors had been strong. Many who earned large profits last year in Asian markets, where prices rose 50 percent or more, now see greater opportunity in the United States, where the S.& P. 500 index rose less than 10 percent last year.
 
Expectations of Growth
 Expectations of sustained economic growth helped lift a variety of stocks labeled as "cyclicals" because their performance is often tied to the ups and downs of the business cycle. Procter & Gamble's report yesterday of record earnings was not enough to lift its price above the previous day's close of 58 5/8, but it did help convince investors that strong profits are likely at other companies whose sales are closely tied to the general health of the economy and consumer spending.
General Motors, up 1 1/4, to 59 7/8, and Ford Motor, up 1 7/8, to 66 3/4, both benefited from expectations of a healthy economy, as did many other manufacturing companies. Housing-related stocks were also strong, with the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, rising 3 1/8, to 87 3/4. Among retailers, J. C. Penney rose 2 5/8, to 53 1/4.
The other catalyst for yesterday's gains was the performance of the bond market, where prices rose modestly despite reports of a large rise in durable goods orders and a decline in initial claims for unemployment. Because both reports were signs of a strong economy that on other days might have led to lower bond prices and fears of higher inflation, the fact that the bond market improved was especially significant, according to some traders.
Timothy Heekin, a managing director in charge of equity block trading at Salomon Brothers, the giant bond-trading firm, noted that the improvement in the bond market was the catalyst for strong gains among "interest-sensitive stocks like banks, insurance companies and utilities which were lagging the market until recently."
Banking and insurance company stocks have been weak until the last few days because of worries that rising interest rates would reduce the value of bonds they hold as investments. Electric utility stocks, because of their high dividends, tend to trade in the same general direction as bond prices.
Although there is an expectation among some instititonal investores that bond yields will fall below 6 percent once again, Mr. Heekin noted that bond traders were attributing much of yesterday's gains to the short-term trading strategy of a large securities firm that had been a heavy seller of bonds recently, but yesterday was a buyer as it sought to cover its short positions.
Among other issues, McDonnell Douglas rose 2 5/8, to 111 1/2. Israel decided to spend $1.8 billion on its F-15I jet fighters, instead of Lockheed's F-16's. Lockheed was unchanged at 63 3/4.
Telefonos de Mexico gained 2 1/2, to 71 3/8, on signs that political tensions were easing in Mexico. Intel was the most active Nasdaq issue and it gained 5/8, to 64 1/4.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Hit 8-Week Low As Investors Turn to Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices tumbled to an eight-week low yesterday as weakening inflation signals prompted investors to shift their money from precious metals into stocks.
The slide in gold prices set off heavy selling by computer-guided commodity funds and eroded traders' confidence in a near-term rebound. 
 "This is beginning to test the resolve of gold's friends," Dinsa Mehta, chief bullion dealer at Chase Manhattan in New York, said.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery plunged $7.20, to $377.40 an ounce, the lowest daily settlement since Dec. 2. March silver skidded 16 cents, to $4.98 an ounce, a seven-week low.
 
 
Bond Market Advance
 The selloff came late in the session as the Treasury bond market advanced, despite seemingly strong economic reports. Such data often send bond prices lower. Stocks also surged.
Rapid growth is associated with rising inflation, which tends to diminish the value of securities that pay a fixed rate of return. Investors typically buy precious metals as a hedge against inflation.
"You had a roaring stock market, a roaring strong bond market -- I think that added to the weakness in metals," William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch Futures in New York, said.
Contributing to the disinflationary scenario were lower grain and crude oil prices.
Gold has fallen $16.80 since peaking on Jan. 20 at $394.20 an ounce in the last of several unsuccessful runs at the psychologically important $400 level.
"This market is going to test the nerves of its supporters," Mr. Mehta said. "I wouldn't be surprised if the price erodes another 10 or 15 bucks before we move back up again."
He said some gold bugs were beginning to question the market's long-term potential. But Mr. O'Neill said gold and other commodities typically slumped in midwinter.
 "I think the markets are setting themselves up for a good near-term buying opportunity at some time in February," he said.
On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures prices ended mostly lower amid profit taking and heavy selling on the cash market by grain dealers.

HEADLINE: Viking and Spender Near Settlement

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
In the face of a barrage of negative publicity and a troublesome lawsuit pursued in Britain by the poet Stephen Spender, Viking has tentatively agreed to alter passages of David Leavitt's recent novel "While England Sleeps," people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.
Mr. Spender contends that the novel, the story of a love affair between two men in the late 1930's, is little more than a thinly disguised, and objectionably salacious, retelling of parts of "World Within World," his 1951 memoir. 
 "The book is being withdrawn and will never appear again in this form anywhere in the world," said one participant in the negotiations, who, like the others involved, would only speak anonymously.
If a settlement is reached, Mr. Spender will withdraw his claim and Viking might well have to destroy any unsold copies of the book. More than 30,000 copies have been printed in the United States, but in Britain the novel was recalled from stores, with just a handful of copies sold, when Mr. Spender filed suit in October. The book is still scheduled to be published in paperback in the United States.
 
A Remaining Issue
 Several people who are taking part said yesterday that the negotiations were nearing completion but that the two sides were still arguing over an important and very sensitive issue: how to go about altering "While England Sleeps" in a way that would satisfy Mr. Spender and still be acceptable to Mr. Leavitt.
"You have substantial literary issues at stake here," one participant said. "You're dealing with different reputations and different egos. What if the manuscript comes out totally gutted? Will Spender have to sign off on the new product?"
Another participant said that a final settlement was expected within a week but cautioned that hitches could arise at any time. But, he added, both sides had agreed that no new copies of the current edition of the book would be printed, and that the old, unsold copies may well have to be pulped.
Such a course is highly unusual in publishing, where publishers try hard to back their authors in such disputes and are loath to destroy books, for reasons of economics, principle and publicity. The most famous example in recent years was in 1983, when Random House recalled and destroyed 58,000 copies of a biography of the late Barbara Hutton because it contained misinformation about a Beverly Hills doctor.
 
A Difference in Nations
 In this instance, Viking has had to contend both with Mr. Spender's formidable literary reputation and with British laws that seem much more sympathetic to Mr. Spender's claims than to Mr. Leavitt's defense.
In his suit, Mr. Spender says that passages in "While England Sleeps" bear an unsettling resemblance to passages in "World Within World," Mr. Spender's account of his life between 1928 and 1939. He also said, in court papers filed in London in October, that Mr. Leavitt's work was a "distorted adaption" and would "tend to sensationalize and trivialize my work."
Mr. Spender's suit is based on two claims: that Mr. Leavitt had breached Mr. Spender's copyright, and that the American author had unfairly violated Mr. Spender's "moral right" to his own work, much in the way that a painter might contend that his moral right had been violated if someone reproduced parts of his painting in a new and offensive painting.
Martin Garbus, a First Amendment specialist in New York who is a lawyer for Viking, said, "You're allowed greater leeway in America than in Great Britain." Mr. Garbus would not comment on the specifics of the impending settlement, but said that the courts in England take a much stricter view of creative and literary ownership rights than those in the United States.
"The British courts would tend to look at the similarities between the two works, while the American courts look at the differences," Mr. Garbus said. "There's more of a recognition in America that if you have a mother-son conflict, it doesn't mean you necessarily went back to 'Oedipus.' "
 
An Unacknowledged Debt
 Mr. Leavitt, 32, has said that he was inspired by Mr. Spender's book and that at one point he considered acknowledging his debt to Mr. Spender in a preface but was dissuaded by an in-house lawyer at Viking. Mr. Spender, who is to turn 85 at the end of next month, did not learn of the similarity between Mr. Leavitt's novel and his memoir until he was asked about the subject by a reporter from The Washington Post. He said in a telephone interview from his London home yesterday that he was gratified that a settlement seemed near.
"I don't think a writer should steal material from another writer and use it, really, to bad purposes, so in a way I'm vindicated," Mr. Spender said. "If young writers think that it's perfectly all right to imitate other writers, I'm against that. I think it's an important case not just for me but for other writers."
Mr. Leavitt was traveling yesterday and could not be reached. His agent, Deborah Karl of Wylie, Aitken & Stone, said that she would not comment, either.
Mr. Spender said he had never sought monetary damages in the matter. And he added that he bore no particular grudge against Mr. Leavitt, whose previous books include "Family Dancing" and "The Lost Language of Cranes."
"I think it's the publisher's fault more than the writer's because publishers ought to have editors who are aware of this kind of thing," Mr. Spender said. "I suggest that sometimes editors don't read the books they publish, and then they get some young person into great trouble."
No one at Viking in New York would officially comment on the matter. Paul Slovak, a spokesman for Viking in New York, referred calls to Alan Kaufman, an in-house counsel, who said he could not discuss the case. Rosie Glaisher, a spokeswoman for Viking U.K., said in a statement from London, "As far as we are concerned, negotiations with Sir Stephen Spender's lawyers continue, and there is nothing for us to say until these are complete."

HEADLINE: Fred Friendly Honored In Broadcasting Awards

 BODY:
A Gold Baton, the highest honor in the Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards, was presented to Fred W. Friendly, the former CBS News producer, for lifetime achievement in broadcast journalism in a ceremony last night at the university.
The annual awards, given for outstanding reporting in television and radio news, included 12 winners of Silver Batons for work in 1992-93. Among those winners were CNN for its coverage of fighting in Bosnia, the ABC News program "20/20" for a report that reconstructed an Army surgeon's efforts to save the life of an American soldier wounded in the Vietnam War, and the PBS series "Frontline" for a report on the financing of Presidential campaigns. 
 A second PBS series, "The Pacific Century," about the growth of economic power in Asia, also won a Silver Baton.
Two independent productions were also honored: "Fallen Champ: The Untold Story of Mike Tyson," produced by Barbara Kopple and broadcast on NBC, and "Harry Bridges: A Man and His Union," about the leader of the Longshoremen's Union, produced by MW Productions
 
5 Decades in Television
 Mr. Friendly was honored for his five decades of contributions to broadcast journalism, including more than 80 televised seminars on the media and society produced by Columbia University. Mr. Friendly remains the Edward R. Murrow Professor Emeritus at the Columbia School of Journalism. Mike Wallace of "60 Minutes" was the host of the event.
Christiane Amanpour, a correspondent for CNN, was singled out for her coverage of Bosnia and accepted the Silver Baton for the network.
Five television stations and one radio station also were awarded Silver Batons. KRON-TV in San Francisco won for a documentary on the 10th anniversary of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. Wisconsin Public Television was honored for a special broadcast on women and the 1992 election.
WTVJ in Miami won an award for its extensive coverage of Hurricane Andrew. WBFF in Baltimore was honored for three programs on urban violence. WPLG in Miami was awarded a prize for eight reports on a secret anti-Castro group operating in the Florida Everglades.
WBAI/Pacifica Radio won the single radio honor for a program based on the massacre of Timorese by Indonesian troops.

HEADLINE: The New Pinball: Music, Lights, Voices

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
TWO rolls of quarters into the Addams Family pinball machine at the Broadway Arcade, I knew something was horribly wrong. The ball was traveling too fast for me to keep up. I was spazzing out with the flippers. The constant backtalk from the machine, the flashing lights, the loud sound effects and the complicated "play field" were throwing me off. My scores were so low I began worrying that some nearby teen-agers might notice and begin snickering.
There was no getting around it. I was a middle-aged man playing a young man's game, and very poorly at that. I began to wonder if my driver's license should be revoked. 
 Once it was different. In my early 20's, like many other college students, I invested too much time and far too many quarters following the trail of the silver ball. My wife was an enthusiast, too, and we would play together at a diner in Bloomington, Ind., that had some great machines.
I'd take the left flipper, my wife would take the right, and we would spend blissful hours shooting down the horseshoe targets of the Sheriff or the very similar playing-card targets in Drop-a-Card. For a change of pace, we'd steer the ball toward the thrill-packed elevated rails of Roller Coaster.
In a way, pinball set the pattern for our married life. In an atmosphere of constant bickering and mutual blame, we lurched forward to ever higher scores. One magic night, we broke the house record on the Sheriff. In addition to giving us a free hamburger, the manager put our names up over the grill along with the other record-holders. Life was sweet.
In the last 20 years, however, pinball has changed almost beyond recognition. Anyone who doubts this can drop in at any New York City arcade or visit the international tournament of the Professional and Amateur Pinball Association, more commonly known as PAPA, which will start next Friday morning at the Park Central Hotel in Manhattan.
The bold can pay a tournament entry fee, step right up to the flippers and compete in the appropriate skill category. In the qualifying rounds, players will do their best against Judge Dredd, Jurassic Park, Tales From the Crypt, Indiana Jones, Creature From the Black Lagoon, Twilight Zone, Wipeout and Streetfighter 2.
In the finals, three new machines will be unveiled: The Who's Tommy, Popeye and World Challenge Soccer. The fourth machine in the finals will be one that is just now hitting the arcades, Star Trek: The Next Generation. The top prize is $4,000, making PAPA the most lucrative of the pinball tournaments. Be warned. Anyone who has been away from pinball for a while will find the new games bewildering. They are more complex, and the ball moves faster. In a terrifying mode of play known as multi-ball, as many as six silver orbs are released in a swarm. The sport has succumbed to hyperinflation, with points now scored in the millions and even billions.
The themes are different, too. Most of them are tied to films or television series, and they present a kind of story line.
"In Star Trek, I'm part of Star Fleet; I want an increase in rank, and I'm out there doing missions with the crew," explained Roger C. Sharpe, the director of marketing at Williams, the largest of the three major American pinball companies. "With the Addams Family, you want to get the fortune, and you have to go through the vault. It's just like the movie."
In pursuit of the Final Frontier, players of Star Trek undertake as many as eight missions, and the machine provides some serious hardware to carry them out. Using Probe Launchers, players can fire balls and photon torpedoes to repel an attack by the Borg ship, a menacing presence at the top of the play field. A wire loop-the-loop carries balls at warp speed throughout the galaxy.
There's a lot of noise and visual flash to go along with all this. On the "back glass," the part of the machine where the score appears, dot-matrix displays generate scores, messages and dramatic scenes. The machines blast out music and sound effects. They also talk back. They cajole, applaud and taunt, often in strangely familiar voices.
That's Arnold himself saying "I'll be back" and "Hasta la vista, baby," as a skull with hellish red eyes flashes wildly in Terminator 2. In the Addams Family, that's Raul Julia saying, "Thank you, Thing," when a hand reaches out from a box, grabs the ball and pulls it back for storage.
 
A Counterattack
 There's a simple reason for the big conceptual change in pinball machines: video games. In the 1970's, video swept the land, and for a time it looked as though pinball would disappear. From the outset, video games offered characters and drama, even if it was only Pac-Man eating little blips. The games played faster, so the customer had to feed more money into the machines. In the early and mid-1980's, pinball's share of the coin-operated amusement market fell to as low as 5 percent.
Faced with extinction, the pinball makers adapted. They cut back the number of balls per game from five to three, to shorten playing time, and offered one game for a quarter instead of three (the newer machines now cost 50 cents a game). They introduced new technology as soon as it became available for more exciting sound, light and special effects. They began to weave story lines into game design and borrowed the video approach of having the player ascend through increasingly difficult levels of play.
Gradually, pinball made a comeback, while the weaknesses inherent in video games became apparent with time. "In 1988, attitudes changed," said Steven Epstein, the owner of the Broadway Arcade and the president of PAPA. "Video became stale and repetitious. The graphics were better, but the game play was stagnant."
In 1992, according to Vending Times, an industry newsletter, pinball produced net revenues to their operators of $2.26 billion, or a little more than a third of the coin-operated entertainment industry's $7 billion. In 1992, video accounted for revenues of $2.7 billion.
 
Universe of Excess
 In today's pinball, the governing esthetic is more. More lights, sound and action. More stars, more special effects.
Take Tommy, an irresistible case study, because it's a pinball machine based on a musical about pinball.
The manufacturer, Data East, packed in 21 pieces of music from the Broadway show, with vocals by members of the original cast, and elements of the stage sets, notably a World War II bomber and a motorized mirror. (When the ball hits the mirror, the machine goes deathly silent, and an eerie voice calls out "Tommy . . . Tommy.")
The game has more than two dozen play modes, in which different features with different scoring payoffs light up. In Fiddle About mode, for example, the player tries to hit a flashing target that moves across the play field. The piece de resistance is Tommy mode, a clever reference to the fact that Tommy, the pinball wizard, is "deaf, dumb and blind." In Tommy mode, a metal fan pops out and covers the flippers, so that the player has to operate blind.
There's some evidence that the designers went well around the bend on this one, and that too much thinking about pinball can do peculiar things to the mind.
"When you go into multi-ball, the game changes," said Joe Kaminkow, the vice president for research and design for Data East and head of the Tommy design team. "It's like it morphs, and takes you back to a different era of pinball. You hear bells chiming and ringing."
Small wonder that pinball machines now carry movie-style credit lines at the bottom of the play field for sound, music, art design, concept, software, dot-matrix display and mechanics.
 
First, the Script
 The development of the machines has an oddly Hollywood feel to it as well. The process, which takes a year or more, begins with film scripts. Mr. Kaminkow says that he reads 15 to 20 scripts a week, looking for a good pinball story. (Needless to say, he is writing his own script as well.)
Once a licensing agreement is reached (with the studios and stars retaining strict control over the use of likenesses and voices), designers produce the equivalent of a rough cut, which they modify during the first testing phase. In phase 2, machines are placed in test sites at malls and arcades and, based on customer feedback, undergo further refinement. In Manhattan, the Broadway Arcade gets machines well before the rest of country because the companies use Mr. Epstein as a sounding board.
Finally, the machines go into general release. "Think of it like a movie," said Gary Stern, the executive vice president and general manager of Data East. "We make positives of a game model and distribute it. Each game, moving from location to location, has a four- or five-year economic life, and every three or four months we have another one."
Some machines never reach the general public. Mr. Kaminkow has a sideline in making custom machines for favored clients, like Joel Silver, a film producer known for his high-decibel tirades. Mr. Kaminkow designed a machine that incorporates events from Mr. Silver's life and makes use of his famous voice.
"When you push the flippers, he screams," said Mr. Kaminkow, who built one of Mr. Silver's favorite lines into the soundtrack: "Repeat after me, '11 double E,' because you're going to be selling shoes in this town!"
 
Effective Bait
 The added complexity of the new machines makes excellent economic sense. Tantalized players wind up investing many quarters just to figure a machine out.
On the Internet computer network, a pinball club of about 100 hard-core members devotes hours to arcane discussions of strategy for different machines. Some members generate handbooks of up to 50 pages on a single machine.
That way madness lies. I took the experiential approach. At the arcade, I bonded with Arnold, grew fond of the electric chair in the Addams Family and took manic delight in hitting the bloodshot-eyeball targets in Tales From the Crypt.
But the machine that really pulled in my quarters was a humble little game called Tee'd Off. It was a golf game, with an intriguing pitch-and-putt ramp and an exploding volcano. Its main character is a gopher that runs from hole to hole and taunts the player nonstop with remarks like "You look like you need some serious help," "Did anybody ever teach you how to play this game?" and "In case you didn't notice, you just blew it," or, succinctly, "You're lousy." After a well-executed shot, it would say, "Amazing," but the tone was sarcastic and, I felt, unacceptable. The running commentary was punctuated by little nyuk-nyuk chuckles.
I came to hate the gopher. As quarter after quarter disappeared, and the razzing continued, I made a vow: No matter how long it took, no matter how much money I spent, I was going to stomp that little rodent.
It took about $40. Gradually, a few of my dormant skills returned. I never figured out all the rules of the game, but with time, I began winning free balls with fair regularity. (New York law does not allow the awarding of free games.)
Then, on one punishingly cold afternoon, I entered what pinball players call "the zone." As though briefly endowed with supernatural powers, I was able to keep each ball in play for several minutes, racking up big-time scores. In multi-ball, instead of flailing randomly, I would trap two balls on one flipper and play the third ball with the free one, a major strategic advance for me. In one blissful moment, I sent the ball straight into the hole where the gopher was hiding, evoking a startled cry: "Hey, you got me." In the end, my score was nearly half a billion points. Man had triumphed over machine, and over a darned annoying little pest.
The funny thing is, two quarters later, the gopher hadn't changed his attitude.

LENGTH: 420 words

HEADLINE: The Mayor's Badly Aimed Ax

 BODY:
In announcing his wrongheaded -- and hardheaded -- decision to eliminate New York City's minority contracting program, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani at least had the grace to say that one could disagree with his view that there is no need to remedy past discrimination.
Mr. Giuliani manifestly dislikes remedial action, or he would not have struck down one of the most socially beneficial and cost-effective programs of its kind anywhere. Since it was started by the Dinkins administration in 1992, companies owned by minorities or women have gotten contracts worth $270 million. 
 No one has argued that their work was inferior. Moreover, the rules were so carefully drawn that the program became a model of economic development for small business. Unlike Federal affirmative-action programs, the city's did not require a set percentage of contracts to go to minority companies and thus make it possible for some incompetent ones to slip in under the quota. Instead it placed all bids in the same competitive pool and simply allowed businesses owned by minorities or women to win with bids that were up to 10 percent higher than the lowest majority-owned company.
The administration's own figures make the case against the Mayor's abolition order. The program cost the city only $2.7 million in added contracting expenses, plus costs for settling lawsuits by non-minority contractors who challenged it. Yet in only two years, female- and minority-owned companies almost doubled their share of city business, from under 10 percent to 17.5 percent.
The Mayor says he is not hostile to minority businesses. Indeed, he says he will encourage the city to give them 20 percent of its business. How will he make that happen? The answer is that old Republican time-buying promise of a community development bank.
This is supposed to be an administration of smart budgeteers. But there is no community banking plan backed by tax money that is going to double minority and female participation in city business at a cost anywhere near as modest as $3 million. The mystery then is why smart budget-makers would wipe out a cost-efficient program that works for a goal Mr. Giuliani endorses.
One unattractive explanation is that Mr. Giuliani as Mayor has decided to play to the exaggerated sense of white embattlement that helped him as a candidate. Perhaps politics was not the reason, but if the decision had been made on budgetary merit, economic benefit or healthy community values, it would have gone the other way.

HEADLINE: Defense Time Bomb

 BODY:
Many Americans still treat the defense budget as a symbol of strength. Politicians therefore spend more money than necessary to shield themselves from charges of weakness. President Clinton brandished the budget as a shield in his State of the Union address when, with surprising fervor, he drew the line against further cuts.
But the defense budget is more than a symbol; it is a set of multibillion-dollar programs. Some of them are essential to American security. Others are wasteful vestiges of the cold war. Mr. Clinton's instinct for self-protection could limit his ability to cut unnecessary programs. Even worse, it could put him under severe pressure to increase a defense budget that is already unreasonably high. 
 Last year the Pentagon completed a "bottom-up review," which proceeded from the premise that the U.S. should prepare to wage two regional wars simultaneously. The review recommended force levels comparable to those established in the Bush Administration. As Mr. Clinton must know, these force levels -- which Congressional Republicans are sure to support -- will end up costing far more than his proposed $260-billion-a-year budgets over the next five years. In short, the bottom-up review is a time bomb that threatens to blow the lid off the Clinton defense budget.
There are three ways for the President to defuse it. One, which Mr. Clinton has unfortunately rejected, is to reduce the force levels in the bottom-up review to a more reasonable level. A second, which William Perry, his nominee for Secretary of Defense, favors, is to rely on managerial efficiencies. That will not suffice. A third way, which Mr. Perry has only hinted at, is to defer acquisition of costly new weapons. That would maintain today's oversized force structure but it would keep spending under control by relying on the Pentagon's existing inventory of weapons.
The Pentagon has plenty of programs to cancel, starting with Milstar, the communications satellites designed for fighting a nuclear war; the overpriced and underperforming C-17 transport plane; the multi-role fighter, and a new aircraft carrier. It can also cut back purchases of new aircraft like the F-22 stealth fighter.
Critics may cry foul if Mr. Perry chooses to cancel weapons in order to hold the line at $260 billion. But they cannot accuse him of weakening America, because most of the weapons the Pentagon already has can outperform any in the arsenals of the rest of the world. Nor will he have to short-change readiness. And research and development can preserve what is essential in America's defense industrial base -- its technological edge.
The trouble is that reduced procurements will shrink defense industries and bring more layoffs. That may make it hard for many in Congress to vote for cuts. But sooner or later Congress will have to realize that America's security also rests on productive investment in other sectors of the economy. What's surprising about Mr. Clinton's pledge to hold the line on cuts is that he, more than anyone, has preached the need to shift priorities.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Whistling Past Weimar

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
President Clinton was impressive when he talked about domestic issues in his State of the Union address because he connected. When he told of Americans who were sick or needed family leave, he related to their pain. More than that, he seemed to be drawing from his own life, his own hopes and hurts.
How different it was when he turned to foreign affairs. One felt that his heart was not in it, that he was going through a mechanical recitation of claimed achievements. It was as if he dealt with those things because he had to as President, not because they engaged his deepest moral or political concerns. 
 The points he made showed his lack of focus on foreign policy. To call his comments shallow would be a compliment. In their blithe optimism they seemed strangely -- scarily -- disconnected from reality.
He said the advance of democracy elsewhere was the best way to insure our security, and that was why we had supported the democratic reformers in Russia. He applauded Congress for backing his initiatives to help Russia.
But the reformers are out of power in Moscow. When Mr. Clinton was there at the summit just two weeks ago, President Yeltsin said he would be "resolute and radical" on economic reform. Since then he has in fact been weak and reactionary, giving up reform to please the Communists and extreme nationalists in the Duma.
The prospects for Russia look grim. Its new Government has promised to pour money into the hopeless old state industries -- money that can only come from the printing press. That means the economy will be at risk of hyperinflation, the condition when a currency becomes worthless.
Weimar Germany is the classic example of what hyperinflation can do to a society. In such a situation demagogues wait in the wings to preach that dictatorship and nationalism are the answer. And Russia has its demagogue today in Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the fascist who did so well in elections to the Duma.
Mr. Clinton and his foreign-policy team have made Russia their dominant interest. And they have made support for Mr. Yeltsin the basic, almost unquestioning premise of their policy.
Thus the Administration did not object when Mr. Yeltsin asserted a special Russian right of influence in the "near abroad," the other former Soviet republics. It rejected urgent appeals from Poland and other East European countries for membership in NATO because that might be politically difficult for Mr. Yeltsin, offering them instead the essentially meaningless "Partnership for Peace."
The Russocentric -- or Yeltsin-centric -- policy looks like a disaster today. Russia is a potential source of great danger: a huge country, with thousands of nuclear weapons, heading for economic chaos and who knows what social disorder. Yet President Clinton continues to talk as if all were well.
In his State of the Union speech Mr. Clinton also said that Europe now had the "possibility of becoming unified for the first time in its entire history, based on the simple commitments of all nations in Europe to democracy, to free markets and to respect for existing borders."
Respect for existing borders? When Serbian forces misled by nationalist demagoguery have destroyed Bosnia, a member state of the United Nations? What world is Mr. Clinton in? Does he know that European unity is frail and fraying, that Europe and the United States have no credibility as guarantors of security after our failure to stop Serbian aggression?
That leads to another point. Mr. Clinton spoke compellingly about a sick little girl whose father spoke to him in the White House. But he said nothing in the State of the Union, and he has said nothing elsewhere, about the six little children who were killed while at play in Sarajevo last week by deliberate Serbian shelling of civilian areas.
The world is a frightening place now. The only way for this country to deal with it is to stick to principles: to put down aggression on the continent where we have long committed ourselves to maintain peace and order, Europe; to approach a turbulent Russia not with weakness but with a clarity and firmness that Russians will respect, and above all to open our eyes to reality.
