HEADLINE: Crossroads for China;
With Democratic Stirrings Among Chinese, U.S. Is Pressing Beijing on Crucial Choices

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Under enormous pressure from the Clinton Administration, China faces a series of decisions that could result in greater freedom of expression and guarantees of basic human rights that Chinese leaders have long considered a potential threat to the survival of Communist Party rule.
Already there seems to be a new surge of democratic activity. 
 Late Wednesday, 11 dissidents daringly signed a two-page statement calling for the release of Qin Yongmin, a young pampleteer dispatched by the Public Security Bureau last month for two years of hard labor. His crime was urging nonviolent political change in a "peace charter" written in November.
 
Vowing to Speak Out
 He joins thousands of others still imprisoned in China for the nonviolent expression of their political and religious beliefs. In his absence, his colleagues have vowed to continue speaking out.
Wei Jingsheng, China's most famous democracy campaigner, who emerged last fall from 14 years in prison, carried on a one-man free speech movement this week by giving interviews to foreign journalists on democracy issues despite threats by the secret police to muzzle him.
These stirrings can only be expected to grow.
The pressure to open the system up still further has come from President Clinton's threat to cancel China's low-tariff access to the American market unless Beijing makes "overall significant progress" in human rights, including freedom for significant numbers of political prisoners and Red Cross access to labor camps and detention centers.
The Administration also wants China to loosen its emigration restrictions and to stop jamming foreign news broadcasts into the country, and to come to terms with the long-simmering independence movement in Tibet.
Top Communist Party officials, including President Jiang Zemin, have said China is "going to make an effort" this year to respond to Mr. Clinton's requirements. If carried through, these decisions will disprove the conventional wisdom that China's leaders are paralyzed with indecision as they await the death of the senior leader, Deng Xiaoping.
It is too early to say whether China will expand on the initial steps it has taken or promised in recent meetings with Secretary of State Warren Christopher and other American officials.
But if China complies with the American demands, the relaxation of repression could well reinvigorate the democracy movement that has been largely dormant in China since it last erupted in the spring of 1989, only to be crushed in Tiananmen Square.
 
Next Few Months A Critical Period
 Interviews with China scholars, Western diplomats and economists suggest that the next few months are critical to determining the future course of Chinese politics.
By threatening to force open China's closed and intolerant political system, Mr. Clinton has confronted the country's leaders with a hateful dilemma.
Cancellation of China's favorable trade status could result in a catastrophic setback for its remarkable economic expansion, although such a move would also hurt American businesses that have been eager to invest in China.
But if China accepts the human rights challenge, its Communist leaders may set themselves on a path to extinction. The collapse of Communist rule, many Chinese leaders fear, could ignite social chaos, even civil war.
"The fear of social chaos is never far below the surface in their planning and thinking," a senior Western official, who works closely with top leaders on economic and development issues, said this week.
Between the extremes, a middle path for political reform in China seems possible, but it is seldom debated, since the Communist Party considers power sharing another form of suicide.
Many economists say the key to China's uninterrupted expansion lies in the United States, where China sold as much as $40 billion in goods in 1993, a phenomenal leap from $2.5 billion in sales just 10 years earlier.
Thus, when the history of China at the end of the 20th century is written, it will have to be asked whether this group of colorless Communist cadres, the successors of Mao and Deng, nurtured or undermined the largest economic expansion in China's history.
 
Is the Leadership Capable of Acting?
 To protect this vast export market in America, China must change, President Clinton says, and there are several basic questions about that change. First among them is whether the Chinese leadership can make tough decisions, or whether it is too paralyzed by factional rivalries as it awaits the death of Mr. Deng, who is 89 and in declining health.
The conventional wisdom for some time has been that China's leaders are seized by an abundance of political caution. This analysis holds that no leader wants to appear as having made concessions to the United States, especially on human rights or democracy issues, for fear of losing out in any power struggle with hard-line factions after Mr. Deng's death.
Two previous Chinese leaders, Hu Yaobang in 1987 and Zhao Ziyang in 1989, lost their jobs by showing sympathy for democratic reform.
But over the last several months, Chinese leaders seem to be paving the way for some major new decisions on human rights.
For the first time in 45 years, they have entered detailed discussions with the International Committee of the Red Cross about opening Chinese prisons. Such a decision would allow Red Cross workers to visit any political prisoner and determine if he or she was being tortured or mistreated.
Last week in Paris, the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, told Secretary Christopher that China would for the first time give detailed information on the list of 235 Chinese political prisoners compiled by Washington last fall. This information exchange is the prelude to what President Clinton hopes will be a large-scale release.
A Hong Kong human rights campaigner, John T. Kamm, said this week that China might have already quietly released between 30 and 60 political prisoners whose names were among the 235.
There are also some signs, Mr. Kamm says, that China is putting greater numbers of political prisoners on "medical parole."
While considered promising, these developments merely lay the groundwork for the much tougher decisions ahead, principally the full release of the remaining prisoners and protections against future arrests.
Some decisions have been made, but Clinton Administration officials say they are not enough.
Last week, China agreed to tighten an agreement to prevent products made by prison labor from being exported to the United States. And China made major concessions to the United States this month to strike a new textile agreement, which for the first time permits United States customs inspections on Chinese soil.
These steps have done nothing to dismantle the security apparatus that suppresses free expression and keeps the Communist Party in power, but they show that China's leaders are capable of acting.
Earlier this month, Qiao Shi, the head of China's Parliament and a former chief of the country's security services, toured several European capitals, where he said China needed to learn from Western countries how to establish a rule of law to protect its citizens.
The Justice Minister, Xiao Yang, has been talking about the need for China to train tens of thousands of lawyers in this decade to represent companies and citizens in court.
The sincerity of these statements will be tested in the months ahead.
 
Will Rights Gains Be Reversed Later?
 But another question is whether, even if Chinese leaders make major decisions to improve human rights conditions, they will they stick to them.
A decision by the Politburo to respond fully to President Clinton's human rights challenge could open China's more than 1,200 prisons, labor camps and detention centers to international inspection and could lead to the eventual release of hundreds, if not thousands, of political and religious prisoners.
However large the exodus, this tiny but potent population of free-thinking opponents of Communist rule, set loose in the sea of 1.2 billion Chinese, could well form the nucleus of a new democracy movement in China and Tibet.
Given China's past record for releasing handfuls of political dissidents while arresting dozens or even hundreds of others in a given year, many human rights officials say the Communist leadership cannot afford a wholesale release of political prisoners.
China's most famous dissident, Mr. Wei, said this week that because China did not yet follow the rule of law, it could easily roll back any concessions it made on human rights.
"The Clinton Administration has to be alert not to be cheated," Mr. Wei said. "If you do not exert continuous pressures, the Chinese Government will very soon take back what it has said."
But as Mr. Wei's release has demonstrated, the Communist state has not collapsed under the force of his free speech.
It is also certain that if President Clinton rewards a bold step by China on human rights by lifting the conditions on trade relations, a sudden relapse by China would set off a storm of indignation in Congress. It would also be likely to lead to trade sanctions.
The United States Ambassador to China, J. Stapleton Roy, said in a recent interview, "It is impossible for a country like the United States to have normal relations with a country that resorts to overt suppression of its own people."
 
Would Democracy Lead to Civil War?
 If China releases its political prisoners and tolerates a new era of democratic debate, will Mr. Deng's prophecy that democracy will only lead to chaos and civil war come true?
In the four and a half years since the Tiananmen massacre, and after a great deal of soul searching, student leaders and supporters of democratic change have asked whether a significant victory was frittered away because the students could not decide how and when to end their long siege of central Beijing. That siege lasted lasted almost continuously from mid-April to early June 1989.
The military assault on the night of June 3-4 and its bloody outcome followed many abortive attempts at compromise. The explosion of violence sent China into a spasm of withdrawal and repression that lasted for three years before it began to thaw.
It was clear in the aftermath that the student protesters in Beijing did not necessarily represent the vast majority of Chinese, especially the 800 million peasants of rural China. Most Chinese, while interested in democracy, crave stability and prosperity above all else, even under authoritarian rule.
Today, it is unlikely that another mass democracy protest could occur. The Government can now deploy a rapid-reaction armed police force to stop any protest in its early stage.
It is widely believed among Western and Asian diplomats that if the death of Mr. Deng brings thousands of Chinese into the streets either to praise or to protest his rule, they will be greeted by a martial-law response, especially at the entrances to Tiananmen Square.
By all accounts, the Chinese people do not want another Tiananmen-style confrontation. But many Chinese believe that the country could tolerate a greater degree of political openness now. Perhaps because Mr. Deng remains opposed to it, the authorities seem unwilling to experiment with a more open political environment.
 
National Priorities: Growth and Stability
 A final question surrounding the pressures confronting China is this: If China does make major decisions on human rights, what does it say about its national priorities?
Over the last two years, China's leaders have established as their overarching national security goal the need to sustain rapid economic growth for the next two critical decades.
During this period China faces a population surge to 1.5 billion or more before its population growth is expected to stabilize as a result of the one-child-per-family population control policy that has been in force since 1979.
The numbers are daunting. There are more mothers of childbearing age in China than there are people in the United States. Because its base is so large, China's population adds the population of Texas, about 17 million people, every year.
China's economy has to grow rapidly just to stay even with the demands for jobs, food and housing of this population, many economists point out. China's natural resources are under mounting pressure. Hundreds of cities are short of water, and arable land is shrinking under the encroachment of deserts and development. Per capita, China now has less arable land than Bangladesh.
These stark realities belie the image of China as an upstart Asian superpower, fattened by prosperity and harboring military or expansionist ambitions in the region.
Many Chinese say that what their country desperately needs is internal stability, peace on its borders and peace in Asia so it can run the gantlet of its troubles in the years ahead.
If so, China needs foreign technology and foreign markets to fuel the engine of its growth.
A new national strategy focused on growth and stability is one that may finally subordinate all of the ideological debates left over from the Maoist era. Such a strategy may also be able to accommodate a new commitment to human rights.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chinese dissidents, Xu Wenli, left, and Wei Jingsheng, were interviewed in Beijing on Tuesday. They said they knew Western pressure on their Government had advanced rights in China: It got them out of prison. (Associated Press)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: Finding Windfalls in Quake's Rubble

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The earthquake last week virtually destroyed Carlos Lara's apartment, and at first, living with his family in the back of his 1979 Oldsmobile, he lamented his misfortune. But now he concedes the disaster has allowed him to reap a windfall in Government housing aid.
The filthy $400-a-month Hollywood tenement where the Laras lived before the earthquake was a hangout for crack dealers and the scene of a fatal stabbing. But because Mr. Lara is broke and unemployed, he qualified for a Federal program that moves poor disaster victims into apartments that would normally be beyond their means and pays most of their rent for 18 months. 
 As a result, the Laras moved into a spacious two-bedroom apartment today with a skylight, balcony and underground garage -- housing far nicer than their previous homes.
 
Many Are Waiting
 While the need of people like the Laras is evident, the ease and speed with which they were accommodated contrast sharply with the cases of about 40,000 other needy Los Angeles residents unaffected by the earthquake who have been waiting for months, and in some cases years, for non-emergency Federal housing aid.
As a consequence, the $100 million low-income-renter program financed by the Clinton Administration has touched off a debate over how the Government is treating the disaster victims. Some of those who have been waiting months and years have telephoned Federal officials to complain, and at least one Congressman has criticized the Federal largesse, charging that too many of the beneficiaries are illegal immigrants.
Also generating disputes here is the emergency food stamp distribution effort for earthquake victims. Federal and Los Angeles officials say it has attracted dozens, perhaps many more, opportunists making fraudulent claims because restrictions have been eased.
After reports of widespread abuses, and of incidents of food stamp lines becoming unruly, local and state welfare officials said today that though they would continue to accept applications, they intended to stop issuing the stamps for three days to restore order and to investigate reports of fraud. Federal officials would not confirm those reports.
Los Angeles County welfare officials said they had received reports from several of the 29 county food stamp centers that people who did not suffer earthquake damage had nonetheless applied for benefits. Others have applied for food stamps at more than one center or by standing line repeatedly at the same center, the officials said.
Abuses have become easier because emergency procedures have eliminated much of the normal screening. Applicants can claim that they suffered earthquake losses and that they meet low-income standards without showing proof.
The housing program that helped Mr. Lara, known as the Section 8 low-income housing assistance program, is also allowing applicants to "self-certify" in the same way, though officials said they had encountered no evidence of fraud in that program.
 
Disruption, Not a Change
 The earthquake added new inconveniences to the daily grind of poverty for thousands of poor people like the Laras, in some cases destroying the buildings in which they lived, but in many cases did not radically change their fundamental living conditions. Still, the aftermath has proved a bonanza for many by allowing them to qualify for newly generous Government aid programs.
The Clinton Administration has promised $6.6 billion in earthquake aid, and the shift to Government generosity has invigorated public officials dispensing aid here with a renewed sense of mission.
The change also has produced enthusiasm among some beneficiaries, but it appears to bewilder other victims unaccustomed to such generosity. "They told me they'd give me a loan, but I said I can't pay you back," said Mary Magdalena Vasquez, who was applying for earthquake assistance today at an aid center in Hollywood. "They said we'll have a check out to you in 10 days."
Some of the 40,000 poor people whose applications for the Section 8 low-income housing assistance have been backlogged for years have been calling the Los Angeles Housing Authority to complain that they have been leap-frogged by earthquake victims. And one Republican representative is criticizing the emergency processing procedures.
"When all is said and done, we're going to have spent hundreds of millions helping illegal aliens who shouldn't be eligible," said Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a Republican who represents beachfront communities in Orange County. "Its not fair and its going to lead America to ruin."
A prominent Hispanic businessman, Fernando Oaxaca, ridiculed Mr. Rohrabacher's criticism.
"This is painful to listen to, if you think of all the misery that's been suffered," Mr. Oaxaca said on a radio news program. "This idea of withholding the intravenous needle until you show your green card is just crazy."
The original Section 8 housing program was not an emergency relief effort but a permanent antipoverty program, part of the Housing Community Development Act of 1975. Under it, beneficiaries pay 30 percent of their adjusted income toward rent and the Government pays the rest. Since many beneficiaries have tiny incomes, the Government often pays 90 percent or more of the rent.
Before the quake there were 31,000 Los Angeles households receiving long-term Section 8 aid, said Marshall Kandell, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Housing Authority. Four years ago, the authority allowed new applicants to sign up for a waiting list during one three-week period and 80,000 persons applied. Today, 40,000 applicants are still waiting, Mr. Kandell said.
After the earthquake, Housing Secretary Henry Cisneros used $100 million from his department's budget to establish an emergency addition to the Section 8 program that will pay for rental assistance for 10,000 earthquake victims like Mr. Lara for 18 months. Mr. Cisneros also urged Federal and local housing officials to be flexible in the processing of applicants.
"Our goal was to get people into housing the fastest way possible," Mr. Cisneros said in a telephone interview today. "It may be that some people that were doubled in crummy apartments before are going to be better off now. If we can better some people's lives for 18 months, well, that's the business I'm in."
As of Thursday night, nearly 8,245 Angelenos had applied for emergency Section 8 aid, 4,724 had been given certificates allowing them to seek rental housing and about 82, like Mr. Lara, had moved into new apartments, Mr. Kandell said.
In neither the ordinary Section 8 nor the earthquake Section 8 program do Government officials make any attempt to verify applicant's citizenship, Mr. Kandell said.
Unlike the food stamp program, Mr. Kandell said that so far no applicants for Section 8 assistance had been found to be falsifying income or other data.
For Mr. Lara, an unemployed 49-year-old laborer who came to Los Angeles from Sinaloa, Mexico, 15 years ago, the expedited procedures were a wonderful turn of luck after the earthquake rattled him, his wife, Maria, and his two boys out of a roach-infested Hollywood apartment, where he was paying $400 monthly.
When he applied for rental assistance, Mr. Lara said he was amazed to hear Government officials urge him to find an apartment that was flawless, so that it would pass a Government inspection.
The apartment he found rents for $750 and he will pay $105. Over 18 months, the Government will pay $11,610 in rent subsidies for Mr. Lara.

HEADLINE: Aides Say Giuliani Plans to Cut 14,000 to 18,000 Jobs by 1995

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Faced with a $2.3 billion gap in the next fiscal year's budget, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to eliminate 14,000 to 18,000 city jobs over the next year and a half by offering payments to certain workers to quit, administration officials said yesterday.
The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that the administration had already identified 5,500 positions to be cut. It intends to identify for elimination another 5,000 to 6,000 jobs by late April, when Mr. Giuliani presents his executive budget for the 1995 fiscal year, which begins in July. 
 The rest of the reductions would come later that year, the officials said. The total reductions would be roughly 6 to 8 percent of the work force paid entirely from city funds, or 216,000.
It is not clear what will happen to workers who do not accept the severance package, the details of which were not disclosed. But officials warned that if the administration did not force out enough workers, it would have to resort to attrition or layoffs.
The proposal would try to entice workers to leave jobs identified by the administration as unnecessary by using $200 million from a surplus fund of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. In return, the administration would pledge not to refill four out of every five jobs eliminated.
Stanley Hill, the executive director of the city's largest municipal union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, reacted angrily to the proposal, complaining that the Mayor's office had not notified the union, as promised. He said that such deep reductions would have a marked impact on the city's services and its workers.
 
Impact on Services and People
 "It's a lopsided way of doing business that workers should be given the burden of closing the budget deficit," said Mr. Hill, whose union represents 125,000 municipal workers. "Not only is there no question that this will have an impact on services, but they do not see the impact on the people who will suffer because they have to do without."
Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission, who has served as an adviser to the new administration, welcomed the proposal to reduce the city's work force, though he said it remained to be seen if the severance package would prove enticing enough.
He said that if the $200 million were divided among, say, 12,000 workers, the packages would average about $17,000 -- or less than a third of the average municipal salary of $56,000.
"I think if it's part of a larger strategy for reducing the work force and if it's something that is not going to impose future obligations on taxpayers, then it's something that should be seriously considered," said Mr. Horton. He outlined ways to reduce the city's work force by 30,000 jobs over four years at a retreat in Westchester County this month that was attended by senior mayoral aides.
The details of the proposal come as Mr. Giuliani is finishing a preliminary budget plan, to be unveiled on Wednesday, that would eliminate or consolidate agencies, cut administrative costs and sharply reduce spending in most departments.
The plan will offer a first glimpse at how Mr. Giuliani intends to keep his promises to reduce the size of government and create "new approaches" to manage what is left, all without raising taxes or drastically cutting services -- a feat that independent budget monitors say appears virtually impossible.
Some of the greatest savings in the plan are expected to come from virtually across-the-board cuts in the city's agencies, from 5 percent to as high as 10 percent of their budgets. Those cuts will total more than $1 billion, or nearly half the deficit, one aide said. While it is not yet clear how much of an impact those cuts will have, there are indications they could be substantial enough to be felt by many New Yorkers.
Speaking broadly yesterday about his strategies in the plan to be released next week, Mr. Giuliani said, "I expect there will be a big reaction against this." He added, however, "There aren't any other options."
While independent budget monitors have expressed skepticism that the city's budget can be balanced without new taxes or painful cuts, Mr. Giuliani and his aides have expressed hope that they can do so by reducing municipal fat and by improving the way the city delivers services.
"We can give the citizens of New York a pretty good bang for the buck -- in terms of services -- and still have a balanced budget," Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said. "I don't want to say there won't be pain, but I think we can keep it to a minimum."
For Mr. Giuliani, the city's first Republican Mayor in a generation, the proposal to reduce the work force by so many jobs will become his first major challenge with the powerful municipal unions, which are almost certain to resist drastic, essentially involuntary cuts. And his success could define his ability to streamline government, as he pledged during the campaign, and still maintain services important to voters.
 
The Faster, the Fewer
 The administration officials said yesterday that their goal was to eliminate the 14,000 to 18,000 jobs as quickly as possible in order to maximize savings in the first years of Mr. Giuliani's tenure and thus possibly avoid further job reductions later, when Mr. Giuliani could be closer to seeking re-election.
"In essence," one official said, "the faster we can reduce a position, the more money we're going to save and ultimately the fewer positions we have to reduce."
The severance offers, in the form of cash payments, would begin in mid-March so that as many of the jobs as possible would be cut in the current fiscal year, which ends in June. The officials said the plan was not an early retirement package since that would require state legislation.
The officials said they did not know the payments per worker. That and other details will be ironed out by Randy Levine, the Commissioner of the city's Department of Labor, in talks with the municipal unions.
They said the jobs to be eliminated had been identified by commissioners as ones they could do without, while other jobs could be cut by putting government operations up for private competition. The severance packages would be offered only to workers whose jobs the administration hoped to eliminate as unnecessary, and not, for example, to police officers.
 
Layoffs or Attrition by June
 If the administration does not achieve enough reductions, the officials said, additional jobs will be eliminated through layoffs or attrition, starting as soon as June.
Mr. Hill declined to comment specifically on the proposal because he had not been given any details. He did say, however, that the administration had started its first negotiations with the unions very badly by leaking details of the proposal to reporters before informing union officials.
"I think he's playing a very dangerous game," Mr. Hill said.
The final preparations of the preliminary budget plan Mr. Giuliani will release on Wednesday are still under way, and aides cautioned that while while many decisions had been made, the plan would evolve over the weekend. Its details have remained secrets among the Mayor's senior aides, who say they hope to minimize outrage over specific cuts in some departments and programs by unveiling the plan -- and its cuts -- as a whole to show that whatever pain it has is spread equally.
The administration also hopes to minimize the sort of lobbying by interest groups and constituencies that has already begun. The administration's plan to cut part of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, for example, led 27 members of the City Council to sign a letter vowing to resist any reduction of the department's power to protect the rights of consumers.
 
Ignoring Minority Concerns
 And yesterday, the 22 members of the council's Black and Hispanic Caucus held a news conference to criticize the Mayor for ignoring their concerns as he prepared his plan.
"We're not going to sit back and let services that we know affect our communities be tampered with," the group's chairwoman, Priscilla A. Wooten of Brooklyn, said, adding that the members would challenge Mr. Giuliani's proposal when the Council takes up his executive budget in May.
The Mayor and his aides have gone to great lengths to underscore just how serious the city's budget gap is. They have said the $2.3 billion shortfall is the worst a new administration has ever had to close, though other administrations have sought to portray their budget problems as the worst ever.
Still, Abraham M. Lackman, the Mayor's budget director, said that for the first time since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the city's budget would not grow or would grow very little from the previous year because of a drop in revenue from city property taxes.
The current budget, for the fiscal year that ends in June, totals $31.6 billion, of which $21.7 billion comes from the city's revenues. The new budget "will have de minimus growth or none at all," Mr. Lackman said.
 
Merging Responsibilities
 The proposed reductions that have already provoked strong reactions are those to cut back the Department of Consumer Affairs and the city's Human Rights Commission. Other proposals expected in the plan would fold the duties of the Taxi and Limousine Commission into the Police Department, while the responsibilities of the Department of Telecommunications, which regulates the cable industry, would move to the Department of General Services.
Aides to Mr. Giuliani also said that the plan would outline a change in the Mayor's office itself, eliminating or consolidating the roughly 40 agencies, commissions and offices that oversee an array of policies and programs.
One mayoral aide said that the elimination of the constituency affairs offices -- the Offices of African-American and Caribbean Affairs, European-American Affairs, Jewish Community Affairs, Latino Affairs and Lesbian and Gay Community Affairs -- would eliminate 19 jobs and save about $700,000 a year, mostly in salaries and benefits.
The administration is also seriously considering whether to sell off some or all of WNYC, the radio and television stations operated by the city. And Mr. Giuliani said this week that he would turn over two of the city's municipal hospitals to private nonprofit groups next year and contract with businesses to collect parking tickets and other fines.
 
Saving on Overtime Costs
 The plan is expected to include other measures to save money, including steps to control overtime among the city's police, fire, corrections and sanitation workers. Overtime costs in those agencies has repeatedly exceeded budgeted amounts -- by a total of $100 million for the current fiscal year -- because of unexpected emergencies, increases in sick leave and failures to achieve savings through productivity.
The officials also said yesterday that the plan would propose decreases in two taxes over the first 18 months and more tax cuts in the second two years. More tax cuts might be considered if the economy picks up, they said, declining to specify the taxes under consideration. The Mayor has said he favors cuts in the city's taxes on hotel rooms over $100 and on the rent that businesses pay for commercial office space.

HEADLINE: Asserting Croatia Invaded, Bosnia Appeals to U.N.

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Bosnia's Government appealed to the United Nations Security Council today to take action against neighboring Croatia, accusing it of mounting an invasion. A confidential United Nations report appeared to support the Bosnian contention.
"Open military intervention by the armed forces of the republic of Croatia is being carried out against the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina," the mostly Muslim Government said in its appeal to the Council. It called for an immediate emergency session of the Council and appealed to it to take measures under Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter. 
 Chapter 7 allows the Council to call for the use of force to defend a United Nations member state. Bosnia and Herzegovina was admitted to the United Nations in 1992.
 
Intervention Called Obvious
 "This intervention has become obvious, not even disguised," said Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic of Bosnia, asserting that 25,000 to 30,000 Croatian Army troops and a large number of tanks are in the country, fighting alongside the Croatian Defense Council, the militia of the Bosnian Croats. In recent months, Bosnian Government forces have driven the Croatian Defense Council out of a significant portion of central Bosnia.
In May 1992, the United Nations imosed an economic embargo on Yugoslavia, which now includes only Serbia and Montenegro, for arming and supporting nationalist Serbs in Bosnia. United Nations officials confirmed earlier this week that Yugoslav Army contingents have recently crossed into Bosnia.
Asked if the United Nations should impose economic sanctions on Croatia, Mr. Silajdzic said it was up to the Security Council.
The latest reports of intervention in Bosnia by Croatian and Yugoslav army units highlight a new level of cooperation between the Serbian and Croatian Governments, which are pressuring the Bosnian Government to accept a European Union-sponsored partition plan that would cede 70 percent of Bosnia's territory.
 
Warning From Croatia
 Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, warned weeks ago that his country would intervene militarily in Bosnia if the Bosnian Army continued to move against Croatian militia forces that overran several swaths of central Bosnia last spring.
But on Jan. 5, the United States representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, visited Croatia and warned its leaders not to get involved in the war.
United Nations officials here refused to discuss the Croatian troop buildups.
"We have heard some rumors about it," the chief military spokesman of the United Nations, Maj. Idesbald van Biesenbroeck, said tonight. "We don't have any firm proof of Croatian Army presence in Bosnia. I really can't believe that the United Nations military force wouldn't be aware of it."
But a confidential United Nations situation report, dated Jan. 23, asserts that "more evidence of H.V. involvement in Herzegovina has been found, but it has been restricted to personnel and vehicles." The abbreviation refers to the Croatian Army.
[At a briefing in Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, a senior United Nations officer confirmed that there was clear evidence that an estimated 3,000 regular Croatian Army soldiers had been sent into Bosnia. He also said that the peacekeeping command had "no conclusive evidence of unit level" involvement of the regular Yugoslav Army in the fighting in Bosnia, saying that with identifying insignia removed from his uniform, a Yugoslav Army soldier would be indistinguishable from a member of the Bosnian Serbs' militia.]
 
U.N. General Expresses Shock
 In one of his final interviews as commander of the United Nations military forces in Bosnia, Lieut. Gen. Francis Briquemont expressed shock that the international community had not taken punitive action against Croatia.
"Units of the Croatian Army are fighting in the region of Gornji Vakuf," General Briquemont told Reuters two weeks ago. "There has been no international community reaction to Croat actions.
"Roso is a Croatian Army general," said General Briquemont, referring to the Croatian Defense Council's commander, Gen. Ante Roso. "We have Croatian Army units, officers and generals fighting in Bosnia. What is the reaction of the international community? Croats are blocking convoy routes, blocking Mostar. What is the reaction? I cannot understand this lack of reaction."
In a detailed statement before an open meeting of Bosnia's Government, Defense Minister Hamdija Hadzihasanovic said 10 Croatian Army brigades, about 5,000 troops, were on Bosnian soil in the area of Prozor and Gornji Vakuf.
The Defense Minister said sizable Croatian Army contingents were also fighting in the city of Mostar as well as on the south bank of the Sava River near the village of Orasje.
 
Italian Journalists Killed
 A Croatian shell killed three Italian television journalists today in the part of Mostar controlled by the Bosnian Government, a United Nations official here said.
The Defense Minister said the Croats are using airplanes and helicopters for reconnaissance, to drop supplies and to move troops, in violation of the no-flight zone imposed by the United Nations.
Also today, Britain suspended its involvement in the relief convoy operation in Bosnia after a gang of gunmen in the Bosnian Government-controlled city of Zenica abducted three British civilian aid workers, killing one and wounding the others, United Nations officials here said.
It was the first instance of abduction and murder involving United Nations aid workers since the war began 22 months ago.
"We want the authorities to restore law and order," said Ron Redmond, spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. "If this kind of thing continues, we are not going to be able to operate."
Mr. Redmond said he did not know whether the incident would prompt United Nations relief officials to halt aid deliveries to the area.
"People are desperate because they're hungry," Mr. Redmond said. "The situation is very dangerous for that reason."

HEADLINE: Japanese Public's Ardor Over Vote Reform Fades

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 29

 BODY:
After a five-year struggle to enact election and campaign finance reform laws, the Japanese people seem to regard the prospect of the passage of a package of bills with skepticism, a bit of cynicism and some modest hopefulness.
A compromise package of bills that was agreed on early today would create new election districts and make them single-seat constituencies, as opposed to the current multiple-seat districts. The bills would also modestly tighten campaign finance laws and stiffen penalties for violations. 
 Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and his coalition partners have promoted the package as the prelude to a new kind of political system that will place more importance on policy debates than cash gifts.
 
Other Problems to Solve
 But most people seem impatient to get on to other problems, like the economy; a package of measures to stimulate growth has been shelved until the reform issue is resolved. What emotion once existed about pervasive corruption has eased.
"People are disappointed rather than angry at this point," said Mayumi Takasaki, 19, a student.
The lack of emotion was evident in the response to the Prime Minister's plea on Thursday, when he called on voters to telephone or fax their representatives and demand action. While common in the United States, this tactic is all but unheard of in Japan, and thus underscored Mr. Hosokawa's goal of defining himself as a new kind of populist.
But officials in the Prime Minister's office said on Friday that there had been about 20 calls from people eager to express their opinions, "a few more than usual." The other parties said much the same thing.
The Tokyo Metropolitan Police said there had been one political demonstration on Friday.
The news media have carried such a steady diet of stories on the issue, along with accounts of the latest arrests of senior politicians, that people interviewed around the city seemed strikingly well informed, but less than passionate.
 
It's the Economy
 The overwhelming sense was that the toppling of the Liberal Democratic Party last summer after 38 years in power was a more important event, and that further changes were likely to play themselves out over a long period of time.
"I wish they would hurry up and settle this, finally," said Yukihisa Hashimoto, 33, an office worker who happened on another rally in front of Shinbashi Station in central Tokyo. "I want them to tackle reflating the economy. That's more important."
"But I can't say I'm angry," Mr. Hashimoto added. "I had heard that the politicians were doing these kind of corrupt things for a long time."
While many Japanese describe such tepid comments as a product of the nonconfrontational Japanese character, politics has not always been so bloodless here.
During the 1960's and early 1970's, student radicals regularly took to the streets and defied the conservative power structure and its tear gas. The renewal of the security treaty with the United States in 1960 caused student riots.
"Students are a large group that can express its opinions freely, and at one time they played an important role in politics, but they have become very conservative and interested in the status quo now," said Ikuo Kabashima, a professor of politics at Tsukuba University, who has conducted opinion surveys for years. "They are interested more in themselves, really. They don't see a connection between their lives and politics. That's true of a lot of people."
 
More Distrust Than Anger
 He added: "What anger people felt when the corruption scandals were first publicized is gone. By now it's not so much anger as just a general distrust of politicians."
That is not to say that opinions are uniform, of course. Kii Nakamura, chairman of Japan Housewives Association, a large consumer group, said she wanted the bills killed because they had been watered down too much in the final dealmaking phase.
Akio Motoki, 22, a college student who hopes to begin his first job next year, was one of those who said he was willing to accept half a loaf now as a way of breaking the deadlock.
"This is a crucial moment," he said. "We cannot miss this chance. Passing these bills is a prerequisite for other changes. Until we get this cleared up we cannot move on."

HEADLINE: Shea & Gould Partners Vote to Close Law Firm

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
One of New York's best-known law firms, Shea & Gould, announced yesterday that it would break up.
The 80 partners voted Thursday night to dissolve the 200-lawyer practice, said a management consultant hired by the firm, Bradford W. Hildebrandt of Somerville, N.J. Mr. Hildebrandt said he had recommended the decision, which came on a show-of-hands vote, because of serious discord among the partners. 
 A partner in the firm, Lawrence J. Lipson, said "irreconcilable differences" led to the breakup.
"It's not for any economic reason," he said. "There is no reason for this business to dissolve except that some partners could not live with others."
Yesterday, some employees gathered for what amounted to a wake in the law firm's offices on the 46th floor in the Exxon Building in midtown Manhattan, and some staff members threw darts at an outsized photograph of Thomas E. Constance, the chairman of the firm.
Rumors that a large contingent of Shea & Gould lawyers planned to defect to another firm had been circulating for several days. The New York Law Journal reported Thursday that Shea & Gould had been discussing a merger with Greenberg, Traurig, Hoffman, Lipoff, Rosen & Quentel, a 200-lawyer firm based in Miami.
Several people from Shea & Gould said yesterday that those negotiations were continuing, and it was not clear what would happen to the firm's lawyers -- either partners or associates -- in the aftermath of the breakup.
The Law Journal said that five partners had departed in the last month, including Lauren J. Wachtler, daughter of the former Chief Judge of New York State, Sol Wachtler. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's daughter, Madeline, also worked at Shea & Gould but left more than a year ago.
The firm was founded 30 years ago by the man for whom Shea Stadium was named -- William A. Shea, a confidant of governors, mayors and corporate chieftains from the 1940's until his death in 1991 -- and Milton S. Gould. Now 84, Mr. Gould had been moving toward retirement in the last couple of years, although he was in court yesterday, arguing a case.
 Mr. Shea and Mr. Gould were an odd match, a unlikely pairing of "blarney and chutzpah," someone once said. Shea & Gould was known across a wide variety of legal disciplines, and its influence was such that it was considered a powerhouse from back rooms to board rooms and from back rooms to board rooms and from City Hall to Albany and Washington. It represented both the Yankees and the Mets, as well as banks like Apple, Crossland and Marine Midland and the Toys "R" Us retail chain.
But the firm ran into turbulence even before Mr. Shea's death in October 1991. He was known more for his leadership skills than for his legal prowess, while Mr. Gould was a canny courtroom strategist. Together they made a formidable leadership team. But the longer they remained at the top, the more frustrated their younger partners became.
"They lost a whole generation of lawyers because they wouldn't let go," one former partner said last night.
Mr. Gould had passed much of the responsibility for the firm's management to younger lawyers, but some partners -- accustomed to years of strong management by the two older men -- chafed under the new arrangements. Cliques and factions formed around legal disciplines, age groups and clients, balkanizing the firm, some members said.
No one group or alliance of one or two lawyers was strong enough to gain control over the whole firm.
Mr. Hildebrandt, a well-known consultant to the legal profession, was hired to try to bring some unanimity to the firm, but ultimately concluded that it was too factionalized to continue as a unified entity.
"A law partnership is a fragile arrangement at best," The Associated Press quoted him as saying. "It's like a marriage. You can have very good and talented people together, but if they disagree, at some point it doesn't work."
A person close to several of the partners was told that Mr. Hildebrandt had convened a meeting at one point at which he told the partners: "You don't have an economic problem, you have a personality problem. You hate each other."
 
Closing on March 31
 Mr. Hildebrandt, who had been hired to try to smooth out some of the disagreements, said that Shea & Gould would close its doors on March 31 and that outstanding cases would be handled according to clients' wishes. In some cases, partners will take the work with them when they go to other firms.
"There will be an orderly windup of business affairs," he said.
Several lawyers at Shea & Gould described the shutdown as a "divorce" and said it was different from what happened to Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, another large Manhattan firm. It crumbled and went into bankruptcy in 1987.
But unlike Finley, Kumble, Shea & Gould had been doing well lately, several employees said. Shea & Gould had difficulties because of the real-estate slump and the firm's own expensive lease. The lease, in Rockefeller Center, almost led to the firm's demise a few years ago, but Shea & Gould managed to renegotiate the terms.

HEADLINE: Columbia U. May Be Sued In Sex Case

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN

 BODY:
Setting a precedent for sexual-harassment cases, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has ruled that a woman can sue her employer, Columbia University, under Federal civil rights laws for sexual harassment, even though she could not show that she suffered economic harm. The ruling reversed a lower court decision.
The woman, Sharon Karibian, who started as a secretary in the university's fund-raising office, said her supervisor, Mark Urban, forced her into a violent sexual relationship, in exchange for which, she said, she received promotions and pay increases. Mr. Urban conceded that the relationship had existed, but said that it had been consensual.
 
Rights Are the Same
 Typically, Federal courts have considered cases in which the worker has refused to comply with advances and was subsequently punished. This case, Karibian v. Columbia University, is unusual, a three-judge panel said, because the worker submitted and was rewarded accordingly. But the court emphasized that the legal rights of employees are the same, whether or not they accede to sexual advances. 
 "The focus should be on the prohibited conduct, not the victim's reaction," Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin wrote.
The trial judge, Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan, dismissed Ms. Karibian's case because she had not proved that she had suffered an economic loss as a result of her relationship with Mr. Urban.
It also dismissed her claim under another type of sexual harassment case known as "hostile work environment," because, it said, she had not followed the university's formal grievance procedures for such complaints.
Elizabeth L. Koob, who represented Ms. Karibian, said the lower court had "focused on what the victim does as opposed to what the supervisor has done, and almost encourages supervisors to become more aggressive so women will submit and employers won't be liable."
 
Significant for Employers
 But the Second Circuit also disagreed with the trial court's ruling on the hostile work environment question, and its opinion earlier this week, which Ms. Karibian's lawyers said has been echoed by other appeals courts, could be significant for employers.
An employer does not have to be given notice through a formal grievance procedure to be held responsible for its senior management, the court said. In essence, the Second Circuit has put a greater burden on employers to prevent harassment by high-level supervisors. In contrast, an employer may be held liable for sexual harassment by co-workers or low-level supervisors only if there is no grievance procedure available or the employer knew of the behavior and did nothing.
Other Federal courts have held that employers must have been given notice to be held liable for the actions of their employees.
But, wrote Judge McLaughlin, if a jury agreed with Ms. Karibian that her supervisor forced her "to endure a prolonged, violent and demeaning relationship," then, he said, "Columbia is liable to Karibian because Urban abused his delegated authority to create a discriminatorily abusive work environment."
A lawyer for Mr. Urban, Clifford M. Solomon, was unavailable for comment.
While she was a student in Columbia University's general studies program in 1987, Ms. Karibian contends, Mr. Urban, her supervisor at the university's Telefund office, repeatedly invited her to bars and ultimately coerced her into a violent sexual relationship. Many of the terms of her employment, including hours and raises, were conditional on her responsiveness to Mr. Urban, she said.
In September 1988, Ms. Karibian said, she took the matter to Columbia's confidential Panel on Sexual Harassment and then to the university's Equal Opportunity Office. What remains in dispute is whether they dissuaded her from pressing her claim or whether she did not want them to pursue it. She claims that in 1989 she also told another supervisor.
Ms. Karibian continued to receive promotions and raises.
In 1990 Ms. Karibian again met with a woman representing the Equal Opportunity Office and an investigation began. Eventually Columbia University dismissed Mr. Urban, although the reasons are not clear, and laid off Ms. Karibian.
A spokesman for Columbia, Fred Knubel, said: "The university disagrees with the decision because it departs from prior law." Its options include going to trial, offering to settle with Ms. Karibian, and appealing to a full panel of the Second Circuit or to the Supreme Court.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 The economy surged at a 5.9 percent annual pace in the final quarter of 1993, the best performance in six years. The broad advance was mainly driven by sectors of the economy that are responsive to low interest rates, including housing and cars, and was accompanied by low inflation. [Page 35.] 
 
Companies
 The law firm Shea & Gould will close because of irreconcilable differences among its 80 partners. The firm, founded 30 years ago, is one of the best known and most prestigious in New York City, with about 200 lawyers. [35.]
 BankAmerica will buy Continental Bank of Chicago for $1.9 billion in cash and stock, creating a bank with $209 billion in assets, second only to Citicorp, the nation's largest. [35.]
 Aetna Life will take $1.28 billion in charges against earnings. It will also cut 4,000 jobs, abandon a loss-plagued part of its investment business and pay for higher than expected losses in its workers compensation insurance business. [35.]
Green Point Savings Bank went public in the largest initial public offering of a bank or savings institution in the last 20 years. The offering of $804 million in stock came just hours before a critical deadline. [35.]
R. H. Macy has filed a motion to preserve its right to sue Federated over the sale of the Bullock's and I. Magnin stores to Macy in 1988. Macy will cut 700 jobs in its West Coast unit.[37.]
Federated Department Stores hired Harold D. Kahn to head its Abraham & Straus chain, a move considered ironic by the retail industry because Federated wants to merge with Macy. [37.]
Big oil companies saw fourth-quarter earnings surge, in part because of a plunge in crude oil prices. [37.]

International
 A small Polish television broadcaster beat out bigger rivals, including Time Warner and Capital Cities/ABC, to win a license for the country's first private national network. The company, PolSat, has attracted the interest of Rupert Murdoch. [37.]

Markets
 Stocks surged to record highs in a second day of heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.13 points, to 3,945.43, a gain of 30.95 points for the week. [36.]
Bond prices rose sharply after a Government report showed inflation under control despite brisk economic growth. [43.]
The dollar closed higher in a sharp turnaround from an earlier selloff overseas. [46.]
Soybean prices tumbled, hog and pork belly futures soared, and crude and heating oil fell. [46.]

Your Money
 Variable annuities may be the rage in retirement saving, but investors should look again at individual retirement accounts, which carry the tax sizzle of annuities at a lower cost. [33.]
Convertible securities can be a defensive way to play the stock market. They have a higher yield than a company's stock, but can be exchanged into a fixed number of shares. [33.]
Investors can avoid the charges of switching within a family of mutual funds by using two money market funds, one for transferring in and out of a family's no-load funds and another for cruising its no-load universe. [33.]
A small-company growth fund aims to take advantage of the edge that small stocks, despite their volatility, have had over their larger brethren. [33.]

HEADLINE: Economy Grows 5.9% In Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Surpassing most expectations, the economy surged at a 5.9 percent annual pace in the final quarter of 1993, the best performance in six years, the Government estimated today.
The impressively broad advance was driven mainly by sectors of the economy responsive to low interest rates, including housing and cars. And it was accompanied by low inflation, making it unlikely, analysts said, that the Federal Reserve will soon yield to any urge to nudge rates up. 
 "Good news -- and great news," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Chemical Bank, referring to the pair of growth and price results.
 
 
White House Takes Credit
 The Clinton Administration was quick to hail the Commerce Department report and to claim credit for what Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's chief economic adviser, called an economy "squarely on a path of sustainable growth." She pointed to progressive improvements that in 1993 lifted the economy from "jobless recovery to, I would say, expansion with job creation."
This was the 11th straight quarter of rising output since the official end of the latest recession in early 1991, and it raised growth for the full year to 2.9 percent. This compared with 2.6 percent in 1992 and was the best since 1988, President Ronald Reagan's final year in office, when the economy's output of goods and services grew 3.9 percent.
Bond and stock markets advanced smartly after release of the figures. Stock prices reached new highs as measured by several indexes, including the Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at a record 3,945.43, up 19.13 points. [Page 36.]
Investors clearly focused on the low inflation numbers. The Government's fixed-weight price index for gross domestic purchases, measuring prices paid by residents of the United States, rose at a 2.1 percent rate in the fourth quarter, compared with 1.8 percent in the third quarter. For the full year, the rise was 2.9 percent, the smallest increase since 1986.
But the G.D.P. deflator, which captures shifts in which goods are purchased as well as price changes, rose a slim 1.3 percent for the quarter and was just 2.2 percent higher than in the fourth quarter of 1992, the slimmest rate increase since the 1960's. This showed that price-conscious consumers were changing their shopping patterns to seek the best values.
 A second piece of upbeat news today was another hefty increase in consumer confidence. The University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment jumped in mid-January to 94.3, the highest in more than four years. The December reading was 88.2. The expectations of consumers, widely watched as a key to future spending -- consumers account for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity -- climbed to 86.4 from 78.8, according to subscribers to the university's report.
 Although private analysts typically accuse Presidents and candidates of exaggeration in interpreting economic statistics, few expressed doubt that the expansion had become solidly self-sustaining and that inflation showed little sign of revival.
They also agreed with the Administration that the fourth-quarter burst in growth was too strong to be repeated, benefiting as it did from a statistical rebound from last summer's floods and drought as well as from an end to model change-over problems that cut production at the General Motors Corporation.
"There is sufficient spending momentum to attain around 3 percent G.D.P. growth in the first quarter" and possibly beyond, said Richard Aspinwall, chief economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Considerable dispute remained about how much credit the Administration deserved for the economic revival, with many economists contending that the economy would have righted itself without deficit reduction or other Government action. Some suggested that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was due the most praise, since his power over monetary policy is far greater than the Administration's ability to control fiscal policy.
 
 
 
Still Mourning Stimulus Plan
 For their part, Administration officials were unwilling to concede today that even in hindsight they might have been lucky to have failed in their attempt to obtain a $30 billion economic-stimulus package. Robert E. Rubin, a senior counselor, told reporters that passage of the deficit-expanding measure would have given the economy still more momentum.
 Almost nobody, in or out of Government, expects a repeat of the pattern a year ago when growth nearly vanished -- sliding to a rate of less than 1 percent -- after a 5.7 percent surge in the fourth quarter of 1992, a period that included Mr. Clinton's election and a Christmas shopping spree by consumers.
Sharply higher confidence, the return of respectable job growth, strong orders for factory goods, low oil prices and low interest rates are some of the factors thought more than sufficient to offset the drag from higher taxes, weak military spending and lackluster prospects for exports.
"There's little chance that the first quarter will collapse as it did last year following a strong Christmas season," said David Orr, chief economist at the First Union Corporation, a large banking company in Charlotte, N.C. "There is enough momentum in the housing and motor vehicle pipeline to generate 3 to 4 percent real G.D.P. growth in the first quarter," he said.
 
 
 
Lift From Auto Industry
 According to Lewis Alexander, chief economist at the Commerce Department, about 1.5 percentage points of the economy's growth in the final three months of last year, or about a quarter of the growth, was attributable to an end to production problems in the automotive industry. Another four-tenths of a point stemmed from the aftermath of Midwestern floods and a Southeastern drought.
Without these factors, growth would still have been about 4 percent, with investment by business in new plants and equipment maintaining a torrid pace.
Producers' durable equipment purchases soared at a 24.6 percent pace in the quarter, more than twice the third-quarter gain, raising the full-year 1993 advance to 16.2 percent.
 Analysts said this reflected how American industry, taking advantage of low interest rates and falling computer prices, was busy substituting machinery for labor, whose costs continue to rise significantly, particularly for medical care and other benefits.
A sizable portion of this equipment is made abroad, however, contributing to a surge of imports that took some of the glow off a strong rise in exports, economists said.
Consumer spending on cars, furniture and other durable goods rose at a 14.3 percent rate to account for about half of the 4 percent overall increase in total consumer spending for the quarter, the report showed. Benefiting from an uptick in interest rates that stirred fence-sitters to action, home building jumped at a 31.7 percent rate, the best by far for the year.
Mr. Alexander, the Commerce Department economist, said he could as yet make no worthwhile estimate of the effect on first-quarter activity of severe winter weather and the Los Angeles earthquake, but observed that lost or deferred business would be at least partly offset by increases in output by utilities, the costs of snow removal and rebuilding efforts.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the fourth quarter of 1993 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: Behind the Tinted Windows;
Life Styles of the Middle Class and Obscure Now Include the Occasional Limousine

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LINDENHURST, L.I.

 BODY:
On a Wednesday evening, a stretch limousine glided through the crowded streets of Manhattan, stopping at some of the usual destinations of the rich and famous in New York: Bergdorf Goodman, the Plaza and Tavern on the Green.
But behind the tinted windows of this particular 24-foot-2-inch vehicle, snuggled in the leather seats and sipping highballs from the limousine's bar, were not stars of screen or stage, scions of oil fortunes or up-and-coming Wall Street traders. 
 It was George and Patricia Nolde of Lindenhurst, a retired New York City police officer and his wife, who had just finished their annual winter pilgrimage to the city in a style that more and more suburbanites now favor for their occasional nights out on the town.
 
High Life Without Pitfalls
 The Noldes' brush with the high life reflects a trend that has proved to be one of the few bright spots for the limousine industry during a stubborn regional recession. Limousine companies have found a lucrative market in suburbanites wanting to spend a special night on the town without having to deal with traffic, parking costs, crime and other pitfalls of the traditional journey into New York City.
After the Noldes spent the afternoon and evening seeing the sights, the white limousine stopped in front of the couple's home of 26 years, a three-bedroom brick colonial in a neighborhood of pizzeria owners, retirees and Civil Service workers. The chauffeur jumped out, opened the door and helped Mrs. Nolde out. As she beamed and said, "So this is how the other half lives," Mr. Nolde shook his head and wondered aloud whether any neighbors were watching.
The bill came to $315, and neither doubted that this Christmas present from Mr. Nolde to his wife was worth every penny.
 
A Birthday Party
 Couples are not the only ones making use of limousines for jaunts to the city. One Long Island company recently chauffeured a birthday party of 13-year-olds to see the tree at Rockefeller Center, followed by ice cream sundaes at Rumpelmeyer's, because of the parents' concern about walking with a group of children through the streets of Manhattan. James Gleason of J.S.G. Limousine in Merrick had three consecutive nights last month with groups of seven people going in for dinner and a play or a concert and who wanted to drink.
Several companies mentioned husbands who insisted that their wives use limousines to go into the city to do their Christmas shopping so they would not be toting armfuls of shopping bags among the crowds.
Wayne Smith, executive director of the National Limousine Association, said that a typical limousine company will get 10 to 15 percent of its business from "regular working people from the suburbs" who hire them for a trip to the theater or a sports event, a marked change from the 1980's.
 
Cocktails Without Fear
 "This is part of the security-crime syndrome that we're going through," Mr. Smith said. "These people want to do dinner and the theater, and with a limousine, they know that they're going to be left off at the front door of the restaurant, the department store, the show or whatever and will have someone watching them as they go in."
The use of limousines has also been spurred by the new consciousness about drunken driving, he said, adding that people no longer feel comfortable about driving into the city and having a few cocktails.
Limousine operators say the cost is not so high when shared by three or four couples, who might otherwise be traveling into the city in two cars and paying for gas, parking and cabs. This way, they said, everyone can be together for a trip that they may take only once a month or a few times a year.
The increasing use of limousines by middle-class customers comes as the industry grapples with the erosion of its traditional client base, which in the 1980's was dominated by business executives and entertainers. In the recession, with companies laying off employees, these once blue-chip riders now see the long limousines as sending the wrong message in a time of budget cutting, and now prefer vans or town cars.
Limousine rates have remained relatively steady at about $45 an hour for a six-person vehicle. As a result, middle-class people are not only using limousines for trips to the city, but also for weddings, bachelor parties and even to pick up newborn babies from hospitals.
 
Who's Inside?
 Limousine operators say a major attraction for suburban riders is the glitz, the 15 minutes of fame.
Jim Powers, the owner of Allstar Limousine Service in Lindenhurst, who says that about 20 percent of his business is "average people" going to the city, said: "It's prestigious and makes passengers feel important. People on the street see the plates, the limousine, and think it must be some kind of star inside."
"Plus, you get the safety, convenience and all the amenities," he said. "You stretch back and relax with a drink. You can't do that on the Long Island Rail Road or in your car."
Last month, one of Mr. Powers's cars carried two couples and two children for a visit to Santa at Macy's, followed by the show at Radio City Music Hall, a visit to the Christmas Tree at Rockefeller Center and dinner.
A minute or two after getting into the limousine in Lindenhurst, Frank Schiraldi, 35, a technical director of television programs, and his girlfriend, Connie DiVirgilio, 35, a secretary, popped the movie "Aladdin" into the car's videocassette recorder. Their sons, Nicholas, 5, and Michael, 8, were soon sprawled out, transfixed by the video, and not to be heard from again until the hourlong ride to the city was over.
"If we were driving in ourselves, the kids would be driving us crazy," Ms. DiVirgilio said, explaining that Mr. Schiraldi would be turning around every five minutes to warn them to be quiet. It would not be a good start to a fun day in the city, she said.
"That's why I like taking these things," added Mr. Schiraldi, who regularly takes the train into the city for work. "This way, I don't have to drive, and it's more of a day out."
As he spoke, the Long Island Expressway resembled a parking lot, but neither he nor anyone else in the back of the limousine seemed to notice. When the car emerged from the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and stopped at a light, another passenger, Tim O'Neill, pointed to a man with a squeegee who walked right past them without trying to wash the windshield.
"You don't need to worry about a homeless guy coming up to you this way," Mr. O'Neill said. "Homeless guys don't come up to limousines."
 
The Safety Factor
 Mr. O'Neill, who works for a tuxedo rental business, goes into the city a few times a year from his home here, almost always by limousine. Safety is a factor, he said.
"I wouldn't go on the train or walk around the city like this," he said, referring to a full-length leather coat he was wearing. "Four or five years ago, people were getting stabbed for these coats."
"Take a train or drive in and you're a target," he said.
Such concerns about crime can be taken to extremes by some riders, particularly those who rarely venture to New York. Robert Kelly, a driver for Allstar, said he had a number of passengers who would order him to lock the doors as soon as they climbed into the car from dinner or the theater in Manhattan.
"You get some very paranoid people from Long Island," he said. "They don't want to go into a strange cab, they don't want to walk four blocks, they don't want to deal with the subway. It's a security thing."
Mr. Nolde, the former policeman who first used a limousine three years ago, is not scared of New York. Now 51, he works as a private investigator for insurance companies and is often in some of the worst parts of the city investigating claims.
 
Close Calls
 But he and his wife, both of whom grew up in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, admitted that they liked the added safety and security of the limousine, recounting past visits to Manhattan during which they had close calls, from an unpleasant (albeit harmless) brush with a panhandler to Mr. Nolde's returning to a parking lot, only to find the attendants gone, his car doors unlocked and the keys underneath the visor.
With the limousine, Mr. Nolde can unwind and forget about the darker side of the city.
He recalled the trip he and his wife took to Broadway in November for their 25th wedding anniversary, a present they received from family. When they left "Phantom of the Opera," he saw the driver waiting outside with the door open. Mr. Nolde put his hand in his coat, pretending he had a gun, and put his arm around his wife, rushing her to the car, saying "Get in, get in."
Mrs. Nolde laughed. "Everyone was watching, saying, 'Who is that? Who is that?' " she said. "They thought he was my bodyguard."
The next day, she was happily back to clipping coupons, and he was at work, serving subpoenas. "I don't want to be rich, and I've never been deprived," she said. "Every once in a while you just got to treat yourself."

HEADLINE: Images and Action Weighed at Democrats' Retreat

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PINEY POINT, Md., Jan. 28

 BODY:
More than 100 House Democrats ended their annual retreat here today after two days of pondering how to pass and sell an ambitious domestic agenda topped by health care, and how to get the credit for it from a public that holds Congress in low regard.
Democratic leaders said they were convinced that the American people wanted and expected an overhaul of the health care system, despite the second-guessing of the interest groups and assertions from some Republicans that there is no health care crisis. 
 "I'm optimistic," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader. "I think the American people want it, and I think the Republican argument, that this is not a problem, is not shared by the American people."
Mr. Gephardt also contended that the recent slowing in the growth of health care costs was a result of the prospect of an overhaul of the system, and not a sign that the problem was solving itself.
 
Obstacles Facing Overhaul
 Still, Democrats are keenly aware of the stumbling blocks to revamping one-seventh of the American economy. The Democratic caucus is itself divided among three plans, including a "single payer" bill, modeled after the Canadian system of national health insurance, in which the Government would pay the bills.
The other two plans are both versions of managed competition, which relies on a blend of market forces and regulation to hold down costs: President Clinton's plan, which would promise insurance to everyone and would require employers to help pay for it for their workers; and a more conservative version of that approach sponsored by Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee, which would not require employers to pay but also stops short of universal coverage.
Representative Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, told reporters today that he expected the final bill passed by Congress to "be closer to the Clinton plan than any other bill that is out there now." But support for rival plans has proved to be more enduring than many had expected.
Administration officials braved icy weather to come and cultivate this caucus, which assembled near the southernmost point of the eastern shore of the Potomac River in Maryland. President Clinton flew down by helicopter for a private meeting with the Democrats this afternoon.
After the meeting, Mr. Foley said the President had emphasized his desire to work with Congress to achieve his domestic initiatives and believed that all wings of the Democratic Party could transcend their divisions to push through health care and other major programs.
The Speaker said the President spoke for about 15 minutes, then answered questions for another 20 to 25 minutes, including one question on whether it was possible to make deeper cuts in military spending. "The President was pretty firm about that," Mr. Foley said, adding that he had reiterated his opposition to deeper cuts than already proposed by the Pentagon.
There was some apprehension here, with many of the members getting the first full taste of the potential opposition to health care overhaul during the holiday recess. Even aside from the orchestrated efforts of interest groups, many members reported a wave of questions from the public at large.
"The euphoria has subsided and we're into the question period," said Representative Dan Glickman, a Democrat from Kansas. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, said the most difficult questions were coming from people who were fairly satisfied with their current coverage. "How are we going to explain to a majority of my constituents, who have worked hard and invested in a plan that they're not terribly unhappy with, that they should jump into the abyss of the unknown?" he asked.
Much of the time here was spent on the image of Congress and its members. These sessions, which were private, focused on what many members find to be a frustrating phenomenon: even as the President's ratings climb, even after what many lawmakers and outside analysts considered a strikingly productive session last year, the ratings of Congress remain low.
Democratic leaders said they were considering several steps to try to improve the image of Congress, including passing a measure that makes clear that Congress is not exempt from the laws it passes, like occupational safety and health laws. This is a favorite charge of conservatives.

DEMOCRATIC STAFF SHAKE-UP
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee has announced a senior staff shake-up to bring several veteran party hands on board for the 1994 election year.
Among the hirings announced by David Wilhelm, the party chairman, were Robert L. Watson as deputy executive director. In 1992, Mr. Watson pleaded guilty to conspiracy and was fined $10,000 for his role in disclosing a tape of an illegally recorded phone conversation involving then-Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia.
Mr. Wilhelm also announced that Edward H. Lazarus, a partner in a prominent Washington polling and consulting firm and veteran of numerous Democratic campaigns, would become his assistant for strategic communications, and that Donald R. Sweitzer, a veteran consultant with close ties to organized labor, would replace Craig Smith as assistant to the chairman for political affairs. Mr. Smith is expected to take a White House job.
