HEADLINE: 2 Banks Set $1.9 Billion Merger

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
In a move to expand its corporate banking business, the BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the Continental Bank Corporation for $1.9 billion in cash and stock.
The merger is unusual because Continental, which is based in Chicago, specializes in dealing with medium and large businesses and does not serve consumers. BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, has a vast consumer-banking business in Western states and in Texas. But it also has a major corporate-banking business throughout the country and overseas, especially in Asia. 
 In the last year, BankAmerica has tried to increase its corporate-banking operations, which will be combined with those of Continental and will be based in Chicago.
 
A Limited Expansion
 BankAmerica's chairman, Richard M. Rosenberg, said the company had no plans to offer retail banking services through Continental or to acquire other banks in the Midwest.
The merger will reinforce BankAmerica's position as the nation's second-largest banking company, after Citicorp. Continental has assets of $23 billion, but BankAmerica said it would cut Continental's balance sheet in half by selling its securities holdings. Thus, the combined company's assets would total about $200 billion, shy of Citicorp, at $216 billion.
Continental was one of the country's 10 largest banks in the early 1980's, having grown rapidly in lending to large companies. But a string of bad oil and real estate loans in the Southwest led it to the brink of failure, and the Government rescued it with a $1 billion bailout in May 1984.
Since then, Continental has sold its small consumer-banking operation to focus on serving medium-sized corporations under the direction of its chairman, Thomas C. Theobald, a former Citicorp executive who had lost the battle to be chairman of that company. Mr. Theobald will now leave the bank.
"I have 34 years in the banking business, and that is enough," he said, adding that he would look for a new business to run. "I have learned over the years, the more entrepreneurial a position I'm in, the more fun I have."
Mr. Theobald, who at the end of 1993, owned 188,627 Continental shares and options on a million more, stands to make a profit of more than $20 million on his holdings.
Mr. Theobald said Continental agreed to be acquired by BankAmerica because it was finding it harder to keep up with ever-larger competitors, especially with relatively little capital left after the bailout. "We didn't have the capital to carry ourselves to the 90's," he said. "We didn't have the international network called for by the economic integration around the world, and we were not prepared to make the investments in technology that were necessary."
BankAmerica's wide international network is especially strong in Asia. And it has the capital and credit rating that Continental lacks.
One reason Continental lacked capital was that its strategy was never popular with investors and it was the only major bank whose stock sold below book value. That allowed BankAmerica to get a relative bargain, paying about 120 percent of book.
BankAmerica will pay Continental shareholders $939 million in cash and 21.25 million shares of stock, giving the deal a combined per-share value of $37.50. Continental's shares surged $6.125 to close at $34 yesterday. Bank-America's shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $45.375.
BankAmerica will buy back $500 million of its common stock in the open market. As a result, the transaction is not expected to reduce its earnings per share.
Consolidation of operations will result in the elimination of a total of 500 to 800 full-time jobs from both companies, in the United States and in five Latin American cities. BankAmerica has 96,000 workers worldwide and Continental, 4,200.
Continental will be renamed Bank of America Illinois and will be headed by its current vice chairman, William Goodyear.
 
A Big Motivation
 BankAmerica hopes that its corporate-banking business will get a lift similar to that given the Chemical Banking Corporation from its merger with Manufacturers Hanover. After that merger in 1992, the combined bank became the biggest lender to large companies in the United States.
Corporate banking has been out of fashion among large banks in recent years as they have devoted themselves to taking advantage of interstate banking laws and building up consumer branch networks. Bank-America bought Security Pacific Bank of Los Angeles for $4.7 billion in 1991, the largest bank merger in American history.
More recently, as profit growth has slowed in banking, the large banks have again turned to corporate banking. Nationsbank, the nation's third largest, based in Charlotte, N.C., has become an especially aggressive competitor, offering large loans at attractive prices to build market share among corporations.
Citicorp, meanwhile, which was the most aggressive corporate lender in the 1980's, has de-emphasized lending to companies in the United States, which it finds less profitable than lending in Asia and Latin America.
 
Seeking Other Opportunities
 But all the big banks are trying to do other business with large companies, like trading foreign currency with them and selling them new products called derivatives, which let corporations manage risks in currency and interest-rate markets.
That is a principal motivation behind this merger, the executives said at their news conference. Continental had found that some companies did not want to do business with it because its credit rating was only triple-B, the lowest investment-grade rating. BankAmerica is rated single-A, and its credit is improving.
The merger should also take care of another problem that had faced Continental -- its relatively high cost of deposits used to finance loans. BankAmerica's deposits mainly come from its branch network, a cheaper source of money than the certificates of deposit from large investors that Continental relies on.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard M. Rosenberg, left, BankAmerica chairman, and Thomas C. Theobald, Continental Bank Corporation chairman, announcing the banks' proposed merger at a news conference yesterday in Chicago. (Associated Press); Chart: "The Banks at a Glance" Source: Associated Press.

HEADLINE: Report of Low Inflation Lifts Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Bond prices rose sharply yesterday after a Government report showed inflation under control despite brisk economic growth.
The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond, which added 20/32 point on Thursday, rose another 20/32 point, or $6.25 for $1,000 face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.21 percent, from 6.26 percent late Thursday. 
 The Commerce Department said yesterday morning that the nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 5.9 percent in the last three months of 1993, the best since the fourth quarter of 1987.
The rise was based on consumer buying of big-ticket items like houses and cars. Spending on durable goods rose at a robust 14.3 percent annual rate, helping to fuel a healthy 4 percent increase over all in consumer spending.
 
Surge in G.D.P.
 The growth in fourth-quarter domestic product was stronger than the 5.5 percent that many economists had predicted. Usually, a surge in economic growth sends bond prices lower, on the premise that more aggressive economic activity could lead to inflation and higher interest rates.
But the report yesterday also included data indicating that while the economy was growing, inflation remained benign.
The so-called G.D.P. implicit price deflator, a broad-based measure of inflation, came in at 1.3 percent, well below the 3 percent some economists were expecting.
Economists and traders seized on that figure and bid bond prices higher, sending the 30-year bond up nearly a point in morning trading. Prices settled back in the afternoon as traders squared positions ahead of the weekend.
The inflation data represent "the ultimate nirvana for the fixed-income investor," said Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "If you're going to have growth without inflation, there's still terrific value in the long end of our market."
Bond investors want inflation under control because it erodes the value of long-term fixed-income investments.
But Mr. Roach said he was not as optimistic as the rise in bond prices yesterday might suggest. With the domestic economy improving steadily, interest rates could be bottoming out, he said.
The balance between risk and reward "is tilting away from further reduction in the inflation rate," Mr. Roach added.
Brian Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Securities Inc., said he expected the economy to grow only half as fast in the first quarter of 1994, compared with the last quarter of 1993.
"There are too many uncertainties out there," he said, including the California earthquake and snowstorms in the Northeast.
Mr. Fabbri said the Federal Reserve would probably not raise interest rates until after the first-quarter numbers are in, sometime in April.
Prices of shorter-term maturities posted smaller gains. Short-term Treasury securities rose 1/32 point to 5/32 point, and intermediate maturities were up by 5/32 point to 9/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 2.49, to 1,314.15.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stages Rally in U.S., Reversing Overseas Losses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher in hectic trading in the United States yesterday in a sharp turnaround from an earlier selloff overseas.
In New York, the dollar ended at 109.90 Japanese yen, up from 108.65 yen on Thursday. It also rose to 1.7425 German marks, up from 1.7285 marks. 
 Gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery settled at $376.90 an ounce, down 50 cents. But the Republic National Bank quoted spot gold at a late bid price of $377.30 an ounce, up $1.
The dollar declined in European trading, continuing a drop that had gripped the markets in the previous session. The selling gained momentum when trading shifted to American markets, analysts said.
"It was a wild day," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group. After what he called a "massive" selloff, "the dollar came roaring back at the end of the day."
Traders spent the morning sifting through the Government's latest report on the economy, which showed that gross domestic product surged to a 5.9 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1993, the best quarterly performance in six years.
The dollar did not rally, since the figure was largely in line with expectations. Further, a component of the report showed that inflation was being kept at bay, reducing the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates. High interest rates enhance the value of dollar-denominated securities.
But the dollar drew strength from a political compromise in Japan that preserved Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's coalition Government.
The dollar also strengthened against the yen in response to comments by a Fed governor, Wayne D. Angell, who said he did not necessarily favor a higher yen as a way to hold down Japan's trade surplus with the United States. Speaking in Davos, Switzerland, Mr. Angell said he preferred stable exchange rates.
Trading was "very very busy, and a bit thin," said John McCarthy of ING Bank. "But this is still a very nervous market."
The British pound also slipped in New York after rising overseas, ending the day at $1.4945, down from $1.5090 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: The Senate's Green Light on Vietnam

 BODY:
This week the Senate staged a pre-emptive strike -- a 62-to-38 non-binding vote urging an early end to America's long economic embargo against Hanoi. The senators deserve praise for taking another step back from the bitterness of that war.
Vietnam is now giving all the cooperation Washington has asked for in the search for information about Americans lost in the Indochina wars. That deserves official recognition. And flooding Vietnam with U.S. businessmen may be the best way to flush out further information on the few remaining cases. 
 The bipartisan Senate effort was led by two Vietnam veterans -- John Kerry, a Democrat, and John McCain, a Republican -- with White House encouragement. The Clinton Administration concluded last month that Hanoi's actions justified lifting the embargo. But, sensitive to President Clinton's own avoidance of military service, it first checked the political waters. Thursday's Senate vote should have provided all the encouragement needed.
Opponents of economic ties cite human rights problems concerning Vietnamese citizens, ambiguous evidence of past deception on U.S. prisoners and the less than 100 remaining "discrepancy cases" involving Americans who may have survived capture but never returned.
The Administration responds that other forms of leverage, like diplomatic recognition, can be used on human rights; that allegations of deception concern long-ago events and are not sustained by hard evidence; and that while every discrepancy case needs to be aggressively pursued, Vietnamese cooperation has brought the remainder down to a very low number compared with other wars.
Those arguments will never persuade some Americans still angered by the loss of a loved one, humiliated by the outcome of the war or otherwise embittered against Hanoi. But many Americans personally touched by the Vietnam debacle, like Senators Kerry and McCain, have wisely concluded that it is time to let go of the past. Few Americans have any quarrel with the Vietnamese people; and Vietnam's Government is moving toward many goals Americans would approve of, including a market economy. It is no longer in America's best interest to isolate Vietnam. May the White House now quickly proceed to order an end to an outdated and pointless embargo.

HEADLINE: Learning From Russia's Reverse

 BODY:
Economic reform in Russia is on the ropes, and the Clinton Administration is groping for a response. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Ambassador at Large Strobe Talbott say the West must hold up aid until Russia puts market reforms in place; a spokesman for the Secretary of State denies that is U.S. policy. Which is it?
The U.S. cannot undo Russia's recent election, which produced a Parliament split down the middle over reform and drove President Boris Yeltsin to appoint an anti-reform Government. But Washington can prepare for the possibility that Russia may again reverse course and resume the tortured path toward markets. To do that, President Clinton needs to learn from his mistakes. 
 The election showed that reform cannot proceed without popular support; and Western aid could prove critical to that support by helping to cushion the worst effects of reform.
The West never delivered most of the aid it promised -- deciding it was more important to make sure the money wasn't wasted than to back reformers who wanted to take Russia down the road toward democracy and markets. So it held up the money, waiting until reforms were locked into place -- and virtually assuring that they would never be tried.
This sad story suggests that for Western aid to sway the political debate in Russia, it must be delivered up front, allowing reformers to set up relief funds for dislocated workers, an inevitable fallout from true reform.
No country this century has undertaken radical market reforms without sizable foreign aid; Russia is not likely to be the first. If the West gets another opportunity to promote reform, it must be ready to deliver substantial aid without delay once a credible government promises a feasible reform strategy.
This week's Senate hearing did little to clarify U.S. policy. Mr. Talbott, the President's Russia expert, told senators: "Our support will follow their reform; it cannot be the other way around." If the Administration sticks to that line, it will undermine Russian reformers when the current Government's financial mismanagement gives them a chance to return to power.
Senators accused the Administration of being blind to the suffering of Russian workers. The truth is that few leaders at either end of Pennsylvania Avenue were prepared to face American taxpayers -- millions of whom were unemployed and had exhausted government benefits -- and say that a few billion dollars was needed to set up a relief fund for Russian workers.
Russia's new course is not the first wrong turn in its tortured path to transformation, nor will it be the last. The hope is that Russia's leaders will reverse course before hyperinflation destroys what is left of the economy, and that America's leaders will be ready to help.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: 'Three Strikes' -- Two Views;
Harsh, Sure, But Fair

BYLINE: By Mario M. Cuomo; Mario M. Cuomo, Governor of New York, proposed a "three strikes" crime law in his 1994 State of the State Message.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Violence has shattered the order of our civilized life like a bullet through the living room window. In response, political leaders across the country have offered a spectrum of tough new laws. One in particular has gained attention everywhere. In New York, we call it "three strikes and you're in." It would put those convicted of three violent felonies behind bars for life, with no possibility of parole.
Nearly 30 states are considering some version of this law, and President Clinton in his State of the Union address proposed such a measure for violent Federal offenses. In all its many variations, the idea has received widespread support, and on both sides of the political aisle. 
 It is imperative that we act forcefully to help the American people regain their basic sense of security, and a well-formulated "three strikes" law can be part of the answer. But we should not give in to the appeal of a solution with a snappy name and a gratifying harshness, only to create a rigid law that won't do much good or will come back to bite us with unintended costs or consequences.
The merits of the law are clear, so long as it is carefully written to focus on the worst offenders. Studies by criminologist Marvin Wolfgang and others have shown that 15 percent of offenders account for 85 percent of personal-injury offenses. A "three strikes" law would give us a heavy hammer to use against these career criminals. The law would not only protect us from the most violent criminals, it would surely have a powerful deterrent effect. While it will be years before we can know the full effects of "three strikes" laws, for many prisoners not even execution is more frightening than the idea of spending the rest of their lives behind bars.
Despite the strength of the "three strikes" idea, others have raised legitimate questions about its consequences. One objection is that the law would not affect enough criminals to do any good. In 1992, of 25,000 offenders imprisoned in New York State, only 286 were sentenced as three time violent offenders. Thus a "three strikes" law would have kept "only" 286 murderers, rapists, armed robbers and other violent felons off our streets.
If that number seems small, imagine the public outcry if we announced that instead of locking these felons up for life, we intended to release that many. If a "three strikes" law prevented only one rape, one murder, one assault, it would have been worth the trouble to pass the legislation.
Other critics suggest that the law will cost too much money by producing long and expensive trials. Experience tells us that most violent crime is committed by relatively young people and that even repeat felons tend to get less violent as they get older. Thus, the argument goes, we would be spending money to incarcerate people who would eventually cease to pose much of a threat.
But the number of potential cases is relatively small, so the criminal justice system could absorb the consequences of appeals and delays without difficulty, especially since the alternative -- releasing these offenders on parole -- would likely result in more arrests and trials for future offenses.
More importantly, all too many incorrigible offenders never drop their violent behavior, and our criminal justice system doesn't provide an adequate way to keep them off our streets. Surely we can afford the price of incarceration -- even for a life term -- if it means protecting our citizens from serious harm and pervasive fear.
Certainly, no single proposal will end violence in our society. To stop the tide of violent crime, we will need to take aggressive steps on many fronts -- tough gun control, tough law enforcement, tough love and a society that offers young people real economic opportunity. But a "three strikes" law can be part of an intelligent, comprehensive answer to one of the most urgent problems of our time.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: Let's Normalize Relations With Vietnam

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Tie Vietnam Status to Rights Reform" (letter, Jan. 15), Viet D. Dinh is right to cite Hanoi's abuse of the human rights of its citizens in answer to your Jan. 6 editorial call for lifting the United States economic embargo against Vietnam. But to say that Buddhism is persecuted goes, I believe, beyond the evidence. The state's attack is against those Buddhists who want a church independent of state control. 
 However, Mr. Dinh is wrong to state that Hanoi is "desperate to have the embargo lifted." All of our major capitalist rivals, with the addition of Australia, have not only unencumbered trade and investment with Vietnam, but full diplomatic relations as well. Small and medium-size high-tech products of the United States are readily smuggled into Vietnam by Asian middlemen.
If the United States adhered to Viet Dinh's excellent standards of human rights, we would never have had relations with the Soviet Union or with South Africa, and would not now have them with China.
We need full diplomatic relations with Vietnam to show Hanoi that we have truly ended our war against the Vietnamese. It is only when we make peace with Hanoi, and guarantee respect for Vietnam's territorial integrity, that we gain the right seriously and properly to pursue human rights issues with the Vietnamese.
One surely hopes that once United States recognition is established, we can then present a united diplomatic front of democratic states for human rights.
I regret, however, that Viet Dinh was not able to mention problems affecting Christians and the highland ethnic minorities of Vietnam.
The Southern highland peoples, with their increasing attraction to Christianity, suffer thrice over, as cultural-linguistic minorities. Christians, and those who, in considerable part, resisted the Communist takeover after 1975. (In the 1960's, they fought the Saigon regime for independence and, later, autonomy.)
No outside church groups or international human rights agencies have been permitted extensive contact with these Deqa peoples since 1975. Hanoi acknowledges that there have been serious ecological and economic problems in the highland regions, as lowland, ethnic Vietnamese have been settled there, and Northern highlanders were encouraged to move to some Southern upland areas.
Plans being made for the enormous Ta Bu Dam threaten the Thai speakers and other peoples in northwest Vietnam.
 
ROBERT FRANCOIS
Greensboro, N.C., Jan. 20, 1994
 
The writer is a researcher on the world indigenous rights movement who worked in southern highland Vietnam in 1966.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A Cookie That Never Crumbled

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
SOMETHING about the Buffalo Bills has bothered me for the last three years, but I couldn't put my finger on it until now.
The feeling went beyond compassion or contempt for their three straight Super Bowl losses. It had more to do with what gods Buffalo crossed to earn the cruel fate of Sisyphus. Three times the Bills have rolled this heavy rock to the top of a steep hill; three times it's rolled back. 
 Last week, when Jimmy Johnson boldly predicted what the Cowboys were going to do to San Francisco -- and then did -- the answer to what bothered me about Buffalo became apparent: The Bills lacked swagger. The Bills lacked flair. The Bills lacked Cookie Gilchrist.
That was the missing piece: Where is Cookie Gilchrist?
Carlton Chester Gilchrist was a punishing 6-foot-3-inch, 250-pound fullback who effectively put Buffalo on the football map. He joined the Bills in 1962 after six seasons in the Canadian Football League. He is the only player elected into the C.F.L. Hall of Fame to refuse induction, citing racism and exploitation.
With Gilchrist running the football for Buffalo, the Bills became the American Football League's first great ball-control team, and he was its first great power runner.
"Cookie was the Jim Brown of the American Football League; he was the icon of the league," said Booker Edgerson, a member of the Bills 1964 championship team and a 10-year veteran. "But the biggest thing about Cookie is that Cookie did not take any mess off of anyone. That's his legacy."
He lasted three seasons in Buffalo before being traded after friction with Lou Saban, the Bills' head coach.
My first exposure to Gilchrist came in 1964 as an eighth grader. I was fascinated by how Gilchrist was virtually a self-made man: He left high school after the 11th grade, tried out with the Cleveland Browns as an 18-year-old halfback, then went to Canada and played for a couple of semipro teams before being picked up by Hamilton. He enjoyed two sensational seasons but was traded after challenging the coach to a fight after a disagreement.
Gilchrist was the first athlete I remember who openly and forcefully spoke his mind. The first time I heard the phrase "attitude problem" attached to an athlete was in connection with Gilchrist. I later discovered that the phrase was generally reserved for black athletes who asserted their independence or went against the grain. Gilchrist did both.
"Cookie was a leader when someone needed to be a leader," Edgerson said. "When nobody else wanted to confront the coaches he'd do it and he took a lot of heat for it, especially back then."
At halftime of the 1964 championship game against San Diego, Gilchrist took over and summarily threatened the team. He told the players in explicit language that if they lost, he would kick everybody's butt in the locker room.
Paul Maguire, a linebacker on the team, once recalled. "I was so far back up in my locker the only thing sticking out of my locker were the tips of my shoes. If I could have got them up in farther I would have because I knew he meant it." That, essentially, was Gilchrist. His spirit is what Buffalo needs, and what it lacks.
Gilchrist's most significant moment came in 1965 on the eve of the A.F.L. All-Star Game in New Orleans. A few black players had visited the French Quarter and had been refused admittance to two clubs. They came back enraged.
Gilchrist organized a meeting and five hours later, 21 black players left town and vowed to boycott the game if it was held in New Orleans. The game was subsequently moved to Houston.
Nearly 30 years later, Gilchrist, 57, lives a private life in Philadelphia. He says he has little to do, not only with the Bills, but also with the N.F.L. and its players association. He reserves most of his criticism for black athletes who he thinks have done nothing, in an economic sense, to relieve suffering in the black community.
Despite his bitterness, Gilchrist is a crucial part of Buffalo's unresolved history. Gilchrist will not say much publicly about his relationship with the Bills. But he thinks that they will not be totally successful until they make amends with him.
Before last year's Super Bowl, he said, he wrote Ralph Wilson, the Bills' owner, and volunteered to bring his "winning presence" to Pasadena and address the team if the Bills would fly him out. Wilson declined. The Bills were routed.
If I were Wilson and wanted desperately to avoid having the stone roll down a fourth time, I'd call Gilchrist today, fly him first-class to Atlanta and have him swagger into the locker room before the game.
Sisyphus would have done a lot better with Gilchrist pushing the rock.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Purchasing Rather Than Renting;
A Belief in Recovery Jogs Both Buyers and Banks

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
MATHIAS MEINZINGER does not consider renting a viable option. His company, Creative Bath Products, makes bath accessories on expensive machinery that requires a lot of electricity to run, and his cost of setting up shop is high.
"If I'm going to pay to improve a building, I'd rather improve one that I own," he said. 
 So last year Mr. Meinzinger moved into a 210,000 square foot building he had built for his company on 20 acres that he bought in Central Islip, L.I. The site is big enough to accommodate his expansion needs for some time. The Town of Islip came through with a tax abatement, the Long Island Lighting Company with reduced rates and Chemical Bank lent him the money he needed.
"Maybe people think the banks don't want to lend, but, hey, I certainly do, that's how I make my money," said Hank H. Auffarth, a Chemical Bank vice president in Queens.
This is no isolated tale. Many companies have grown comfortable enough with the economy -- and thus with their futures -- to buy their own buildings. And many banks are lending them the money to do so.
As low interest rates have made other investments less attractive, investors have been trickling back to the real estate market. And with more potential buyers around, property prices are inching up, enticing more owners to put their properties on the market.
A result has been a surge in commercial property sales in the last six months or so, the likes of which investors and brokers say they have not seen in five years.
"I am amazed at how much money is pouring into real estate," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W & M Properties, a frequent investor.
"I'm not sure we did as much as $50 million in sales in 1990," said Peter Hauspurg, president of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a real estate investment banking firm in Manhattan. "In 1993 we did more than $200 million, and most of that was in the last half of the year."
In fact, competition for buyers has turned into competition among buyers for decent properties. Mr. Malkin's firm was outbid on five of six properties it tried to buy last year.
Adrienne Albert, president of Marketing Directors Inc., which just added a commercial sales division to its residential condominium business, bid on a 16-story office building near Rockefeller Center that went on the market in late November. By Christmas -- traditionally a very slow time in real estate -- the owner had 10 bids on the table.
"There are real buyers in the marketplace now, not just the bottom fishers of the last few years," Ms. Albert said. "And because of that, there are a lot more sellers too."
The sales push is not confined to New York. Equitable Real Estate Investment Management, for one, sold $611 million worth of properties nationally in 1993; in 1992 it sold only $240 million worth.
In New Jersey, Public Service Electric & Gas Company, which runs one of the country's oldest utility-driven economic development programs, reports that the number of companies inquiring about industrial space was up by 20 percent in 1993 from the year before. Although the utility does not compile separate figures for renters and buyers, Stephen J. Kukan, its general manager for area development, guesses that a lot of the interest came from potential owners.
"The cost of money is substantially down, and New Jersey's incentive programs encourage buying or building," he said.
The most dramatic numbers are in Manhattan, where everything, even in a recession, seems to be more expensive than almost anywhere else.
Darcy A. Stacom, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, said building sales volume in Manhattan hit $900 million in 1993, up from $400 million a year before. Even properties in beleaguered downtown are selling, particularly, Ms. Stacom noted, to investors from Brooklyn's Hasidic community, who like downtown's proximity to Brooklyn.
"Manhattan has become irresistible to everybody," she said.
Still, the bulk of the deals, if not of the dollars, were outside Manhattan, as companies bought factories and warehouses.
Sanford Zuckerbrot, president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot, a Queens-based brokerage, notes that warehouses languished on the market until recently, with prices plummeting from as high as $75 a square foot to below $30.
"Then the banks started finding themselves with large cash reserves and started courting potential corporate owners," he said. "Add to that the incentive packages that cities and utilities offered, the favorable prices and the strengthening economy and we suddenly find ourselves in a healthy market for industrial building sales."
Indeed, some brokers even report a scarcity of decent industrial properties. John Ritter, an executive vice president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot, tells of a kitchen-supply distributor who is looking for a 50,000-square-foot building in eastern Queens.
"They'll probably get stuck renting because there's just nothing for sale that meets their requirements," he said.
Banks have fueled the shortage by prodding clients to buy and helping them find the right incentive packages.
Chemical Bank recently showed a small household-utensils company how a combination of tax abatements, moving grants and mortgage money would enable it to afford its own 25,000-square-foot building.
"We guide small businesses through the morass of red tape associated with incentive programs," said Thomas F. Pergola, a vice president who handles much of Chemical Bank's real estate financing.
The market for office buildings is a bit less frantic. But even here, sales are heady, as more tenants recognize that the economics have tilted toward buys.
In the late 80's, prime Manhattan office space was selling for maybe $500 a square foot and lending rates were about 15 percent. Now space can be had for $150 to $200 and financing can go as low as 5 percent.
"Buying something at $150 a foot that costs $350 to replace makes great sense," said Michael Myers, chairman of Corporate Realty Partners, a new commercial brokerage.
WITH virtually no new construction in New York, replacement costs may be a specious comparison. Still, when a lease runs out a tenant has an expired lease; when a mortgage is paid off, a tenant has a building. Examples of such thinking are rife. Beth Israel Medical Center, which originally planned to rent space, just paid $34 million for about 350,000 square feet of commercial space at 10 Union Square.
Steelcase Inc., which makes office furniture, just bought 4 Columbus Circle, an eight-story, 124,000-square-foot office building originally designed by Swanke Hayden & Connell, the architectural firm, for its own use, for $18.15 million. Although the building is about three-quarters occupied, Josh N. Kuriloff, a Cushman & Wakefield director who represented the owners, said he had marketed it primarily to corporate owner-users.
"Owner occupants are the trend in the market," Mr. Kuriloff said. For now, Steelcase will occupy only part of its new building.
Slowly, investors are rejoining the market.
"They realized that if they stood on the sidelines too much longer the users would own everything," said Ms. Stacom.
The investors are not getting the generous financing that users are, though. The investors that bought 200 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, put up close to half the $25 million purchase price in cash. Similarly, investors got financing for only half of the $4.4 million they paid for 240 Madison, near 38th Street.
Owners did not get the kind of money they would have liked, either.
Mr. Hauspurg, of Eastern Consolidated Properties, said the owner of 240 Madison Avenue had turned down $18 million five years ago, when real estate prices seemed to be on a never-ending ascent. Similarly, an investor group recently bought 150 East 58th Street for $61.5 million; Equitable paid $145 million for it in the late 80's.
Of course, neither Equitable nor other solvent property owners are taking such lumps across the board. Many continue to hold their properties off the market on the theory that if they can get a good price now, they can get an even better one tomorrow.
"We are not putting a lot more properties on the market," said Timothy J. Welch, an Equitable executive. "Near-term prospects are for improvement, and our clients have the capital to be long-term holders."

LENGTH: 1448 words

HEADLINE: Someone Spying? So Are the Teddy Bear and the Potted Plant

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: MORGANVILLE

 BODY:
SEE the cuddly teddy bear over on the shelf? Well, it sees you, too. "Right here is the camera, behind the left eye," said Marvin Bandler, the owner of Spy Mart, a Monmouth County company dedicated to the proposition that what you don't know can hurt you and what you do know protects you from being caught off guard.
"There's a wireless transmitter in here," Mr. Bandler said, holding the teddy bear in his arm and pointing to its furry little head. "It can send a signal up to 300 feet away, so you don't even need a wire to attach it to a VCR." 
 Mr. Bandler, a licensed private investigator and former chief investigator for the New York State Department of Corrections, was demonstrating some of the items he sells from Spy Mart's showroom.
"See that planter over there," Mr. Bandler said, pointing in the direction of an ordinary-looking potted plant. "There's a camera in the pot. We built it last week. I was shopping with my wife, I saw the planter and I came up with the idea."
Mr. Bandler's business is an answer to a challenge: how do you find out what someone is up to without his finding out what you are up to first?
"Most of my customers are law-enforcement types," Mr. Bandler said, referring to the police, private detectives and prosecutors' investigators who come to avail themselves of the latest in clandestine surveillance technology. "But we also have a lot of private-sector people and businessmen who come in because they want to record their own telephone conversations or because they're afraid their businesses are being bugged."
 
Paramilitary Atmosphere
 Spy Mart, which Mr. Bandler opened about two years ago, is on the second floor of an office building in Morganville. Mr. Bandler, a tall, burly man with a penchant for 10-gallon hats, also runs his private investigator business from the location. The atmosphere is decisively paramilitary, with a secretary and an assistant calling Mr. Bandler "sir" in terse, formal exchanges.
He instructed the secretary to call him on a telephone atop one of the glass display cases that line the walls of the showroom. The phone rang, and Mr. Bandler lifted the receiver.
"This is a prototype," he said, telling his assistant to pick up an extension in another room. A red light on the phone blinked on.
"See? The phone went dead," Mr. Bandler said, holding the receiver out for a visitor to verify that the phone was quite dead. "What happened was, if I'm talking and somebody gets on the line with a listening device or comes in the room with a transmitter, the light goes on and the phone automatically disconnects the conversation."
He intends to market the new telephone to other spy shops around the country. The price? About $750.
"It's very high tech," he said. "This will detect just about everything."
Many of the devices in the Spy Mart showroom, including the phone that goes dead, are items Mr. Bandler designed himself and then built out of components available in any well-stocked electronics store.
"This is a microphone in a button," he said, holding out for inspection what appeared to be, well, a button with a wire attached to it.
"You can put it on the sleeve of your shirt and attach it to any tape recorder," he said. "It's battery powered, and you can change the actual button so it matches the buttons on your shirt."
He then showed a pen that, he said, has a tiny microphone inside. Even upon close inspection, nothing about the pen appeared unusual.
"The microphone is behind that hole," he said, indicating a hole about the size of the period at the end of this sentence. "It's supersensitive, too," he said, asserting that the tiny microphone is about 10 times more sensitive than the microphones built into microcassette recorders now on the market.
"See that calculator?" he said, pointing to a credit-card-sized calculator. "That's a transmitter. But it's not for public use, only law enforcement. It's not F.C.C. approved."
Mr. Bandler's clandestine eavesdropping devices fall into two general categories: hard-wired, like the shirt button microphone, which plugs into a microcassette recorder, and wireless, like the calculator that transmits to an FM receiver some distance away.
 
Behind the Picture Frame
 Some of the wireless transmitters, like one that replaces an ordinary electrical wall socket, can transmit up to half a mile away, drawing power from house current. Others, which use tiny batteries for power and are about the size of sugar cubes, transmit for less distance but are handy for surreptitious placement in vases, behind picture frames and attached under tables and other furniture.
"Again," Mr. Bandler said, "these are for law enforcement, not for public use. It's illegal to record audio unless you're participating in the conversation."
But if that's the case, who might use the teddy bear with a video camera for a brain?
"Anybody," Mr. Bandler replied. "It's not illegal to videotape."
In fact, he said, the teddy bear was designed for clients who wanted to be able to keep track of how a child's nanny was treating the child when the parents weren't home. The teddy bear was set on a high shelf in the child's room and connected to a video recorder locked in the parents' room.
The cost? "Around $1,000, not including the VCR," Mr. Bandler said. "And there are ways we can make them work in total darkness."
Mr. Bandler pointed to what looked like a clock hung on a wall. He instructed his visitor to look at a video monitor just underneath the clock. On the screen was an image of a confused reporter looking at himself looking at a video monitor.
"Now watch this," Mr. Bandler said, switching off the office lights. The image on the video monitor dimmed slightly but remained clear and distinct. "All we do is introduce a small infrared light source -- we can hide it anywhere in the room -- and it will bounce around and illuminate the room like it was daylight."
A regular customer of the Spy Mart, a Middlesex County private investigator who declined to give his name, described yet another product that makes use of infrared light.
"I bought infrared filters for the headlights on my car," the investigator said, explaining that he used the filters while staking out errant spouses for divorce clients. "I sit in my car with a video camera, aim the headlights at the house or the motel and wait. The infrared filters light up the place like it was daytime. I can see them, but they can't see me."
The investigator said Spy Mart was more than a high-tech toy store for real-life Sam Spades and amateur spies.
"Marvin doesn't just sell you things and send you out the door," the man said. "He tells you how to use what you buy. He gives you suggestions. You tell him what you want to do and he'll figure out how to do it."
And for those new to the business of espionage and counterespionage, Mr. Bandler also offers a small library of arcane books with such titles as "How to Disappear Completely and Never Be Found," "Get Even: The Complete Book of Dirty Tricks," "How the Underdog Gets Justice" and "Methods of Disguise."
Though Spy Mart caters to law- enforcement officials, Mr. Bandler said, a growing segment of his business involves executives and business managers concerned about employee theft and corporate espionage.
"We have a lot of small businesses installing hidden video systems," he said, adding that it is illegal to install such equipment in areas where people are entitled to expect privacy, like dressing rooms and bathrooms.
 
Worries About Wiretapping
 "We also sell a lot of systems to people who think their businesses or home offices are being bugged or wiretapped by the competition," he said. "And we help people who want to record their telephone conversations. A lot of insurance brokers are now recording customer conversations, which is legal."
Though the market for surveillance devices for law enforcement never seems to dry up, he said, the market among business customers tracks the economy.
"When things are bad out there for business, then business is good for me," Mr. Bandler said. "When the economy is bad, people are stealing more, and there are more bad things going on."
One of the last items he showed his visitor was his personal favorite.
"This is a bug detector," he said, opening a case that contained a small electronic control panel. He took a small wand with a wire attached to it out of the case and pointed the wand at the calculator, which was really a hidden transmitter and was supposed to be virtually undetectable. The bug detector flashed and beeped an electronic warning.
"It's one of my most popular items," he said.

LENGTH: 1303 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Paula Williams;
When Bed-and-Breakfast Inns Team Up

BYLINE: By HELEN PIKE

DATELINE: STANHOPE

 BODY:
NINE years ago, after the divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Paula Williams left the company and started a modest bed-and-breakfast in a Victorian mansion that she and her husband, Joe Mulay, restored and named the Whistling Swan Inn.
Six years later, with her business booming, Ms. Williams added more bedrooms. Mr. Mulay took early retirement from his own job at A.T.& T. to help his wife full time. 
 Despite her success, Ms. Williams missed the benefits of working in an office. Specifically, she missed the camaraderie, problem solving and networking that comes when a group is united in a common goal, she said. She soon realized she was not alone.
"The innkeepers were feeling isolated from one another," Ms. Williams recalled of the tenor in the oft-repeated conversations she and Mr. Mulay had with other bed-and-breakfast owners when they traveled around the state.
So, using the organizational skills she learned as a phone company installation and maintenance manager, Ms. Williams canvassed the owners of other inns, guest houses and small hotels about forming a professional association.
Three years after the first meeting at the Normandy Inn in Spring Lake, the fledgling group goes by the name of the Bed and Breakfast Innkeepers Association of New Jersey. It has incorporation papers, bylaws, criteria for membership, the attention of Trenton's code officials and a marketing strategy that includes a four-color brochure and a guest membership program to attract repeat business by offering discounts on lodgings.
All the work to get the association up and running was done by innkeepers whose previous professional affiliations included law, accounting, finance, art, publishing, construction, woodworking, travel and architecture. Ms. Williams was recently re-elected its president for a second term.
"We are like one big 500-room hotel," she said, describing the association, which has 80 out of a possible 90 inns as members. And she believes that New Jersey may have more bed-and-breakfast places in the future.
She cited a Professional Association of Innkeepers International study that describes these establishments as "the fastest-growing in-home industry" and said she and Mr. Mulay regularly fielded inquiries from couples looking to quit the corporate merry-go-round to go into the hospitality business.
"It really does become a way of life," Ms. Williams said. "Your business is in your house with you. You must learn how to balance the two."
But while she had to learn the ropes of finance and marketing, Ms. Williams didn't have to learn how to cook, because she grew up helping her grandmother make her hearty farm recipes, especially corn pancakes.
"I think I went into the B.& B. business because there were always people around our dinner table when I was growing up," Ms. Williams said.
Ms. Williams and Mr. Mulay continue to refurbish the imposing mansion, which was built by the village ice-house merchant and justice of the peace at the turn of the century. It is in the Pocono Mountains foothills, about a mile from Lake Musconetcong in Sussex County.
Q: What are the minimum requirements for membership in the association?
A: An inn must have 4 to 20 bedrooms; the owner or manager must live on the premises or adjacent to the property, and there must be proper signage to identify the inn, which, in turn, must be licensed and registered with the state, including having a sales tax number.
Also, the inn must serve breakfast. It must be located in a nice neighborhood, have its lawns mowed and have light bulbs in all its rooms.
Q. What is happening to the association in 1994?
A. By raising membership fees to $125 per inn, plus $10 per room, the association plans to have an administrative office and a part-time employee who will handle telephone inquiries, mailings and membership information. We are looking at the Jersey Shore area because it is equidistant from north and south Jersey. Membership costs also cover printing and distribution of the new directory, more advertising and a membership drive.
Q. What code changes has the association brought about in Trenton?
A. In 1992 we lobbied to change the state's fire codes to make them more applicable to home-style settings instead of to hotels and motels. What helped is the association's nonsmoking criterion for membership.
The association also succeeded in winning changes to the commercial dishwashing standard in order to allow for the use of disinfectant rinses instead of harsher detergent. After all, we're using our grandmothers' hand-painted china.
Q. What, if any, inspections do you perform?
A. Beginning this year, the association has a self-evaluation sheet with criteria we all agreed to meet. Also, we do put stock in A.A.A. and Mobil Guide inspections.
Q. How long does it take to create a successful bed-and-breakfast?
A. There are slight variations depending on people's talents and how much financial resource they have when they start up. The average length is five years. At that point, either they bail out or they are in it for the long term.
Some couples get started by turning their homes into weekend B.& B.'s while they have regular Monday-to- Friday jobs. Usually, they have four bedrooms. A six-bedroom B.& B. will generally pay for itself. Nine to 12 bedrooms means a couple can work it full-time with no additional staff.
Q. Does the association act alone?
A .We are an independent organization, but members individually work with their local and regional tourism councils in looking for opportunities where their B.& B.'s can partner with surrounding attractions and events. If we all don't make it, then the B.& B's aren't going to make it.
As an example of tourism's growing importance to the state's economy, tourism in Sussex County has surpassed agriculture as the largest income-grossing industry.
Q. Is there any economic data on the impact of bed-and-breakfasts?
A. In the Professional Association of Innkeepers International's study, the estimate is that for every dollar spent at a B.& B., another $15 is spent in the local economy. Also, 99 percent of the guests want fine or casual dining while only 1 percent want to stay curled up in front of the fireplace.
We did our own anecdotal survey based on 10 couples who stayed one recent night at the Whistling Swan Inn. On a per-couple basis, each spent about $15 for tickets to local attractions and gas, $20 for a deli lunch and $60 on fine dining. Three of the 10 couples asked for the nearest bank's automated teller machine.
Q. What is the association's marketing campaign?
A. Besides group advertising in consumer magazines and regional newspapers, the association has printed a glossy brochure that doubles as a directory of the inns and of the state's geographic regions and attractions that can be found in each. We needed a marketing force to promote us -- we are in a historic state that occasionally gets a bad rap.
Q. What is the guest member program?
A. For $20, guest members get the following year's directory free, two $10 gift certificates at two different inns and four newsletters. Since the program was started in July, 250 guests have signed up.
 
Profile
 Born: March 18, 1943, in Tulsa, Okla.
Education: B.A. in speech therapy, 1965, Oklahoma State University; M.B.A., 1978, Illinois Institute of Technology.
Career: Speech therapist; management positions at Illinois Bell and A.T.& T. in New Jersey; began running a bed-and-breakfast inn in 1985; organizer and president of the Bed and Breakfast Innkeepers Association of New Jersey.
Family: Married to Joe Mulay, her partner at the Whistling Swan Inn; two grown children, Denise Hicks of Chicago and James Mulay of Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

ARTIST AS CRITIC
 Two artists from different generations, sharing a singular passion for righting the wrongs of society with humor and compassion, are joined in an exhibition opening on Tuesday at the Nardin Galleries in Somers. It will remain on view through March 14. 
One of the artists is William Gropper, whose satirical cartoons influenced popular perceptions of American life from the 1920's to his death in 1977 at the age of 80, and posthumously in collections, books and exhibitions like this one. More than 40 drawings, cartoons and several oils, including a self-portrait, form a retrospective of his long career. Among the many honors he received was election to the National Institute of Arts and Letters.
The co-exhibitor is Bill Mutter, 39, whose lifesize ceramic cowboys tackle the issue of violence. Seemingly hale, hearty and heroic, glazed in colorful Western garb, the sculptures reveal, on closer inspection, the frustration and fear that result when human communication is reduced to mayhem. "The Bully," "Death of the Poet," "Horse and Rider" and "Comin' Round the Corner" are some of the titles.
Nardin Galleries is a quarter of a mile north of the Elephant Hotel on Route 202, open Tuesdays through Sundays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Call 276-8485 for more information.
 
ROCK AND REGGAE
 Where Italian opera once reigned in the 68-year-old hall at 7 Willow Street in Port Chester, the beat of the 90's now prevails. Open from 9 P.M. to 4 A.M. and serving nothing but music and drinks, the nightspot named for its address is open Thursdays through Saturdays and on a random schedule the rest of the week.
This Friday's bill features the Sons, a classic rock group that has established a reputation in Manhattan at Wetlands, Tramps, Lone Star Roadhouse and other downtown venues. Bret Reilly is the leader, singer and songwriter; his brother Parker is the keyboardist; Stephen Murphy plays the guitar, and the percussion section is in the hands of Nick Varchaver and Peter Wilson.
Ripton Hylton, better known as Eek-a-Mouse, will be on stage Saturday night, performing reggae but with an imprimatur as off-the-wall as his name, which he took from a race horse. He draws inspiration from a childhood spent in Kingston, Jamaica, threading through his music an inexhaustible supply of personal and fanciful stories.
He manipulates his voice into improbable ranges and inhuman sounds, frequently decked out in get-ups as un-reggae as gladiator, pirate, coolie, Mexican bandit or Robin Hood.
The cover charge on Friday will be $7; on Saturday it will be $10 in advance, $12 at the door. For reservations or an information tape about performances other than those on Thursday through Saturday, call 939-1474.
 
TOPICAL TALKS
 Marcia Ann Gillespie, editor in chief of Ms. Magazine and former editor in chief of Essence magazine, will give a talk about "Racism and Sexism in the Media" at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers on Tuesday at 1:30 P.M. She is now serving as project coordinator and editor of a United Nations publication on the global impact of AIDS. The program will be held in Reisinger Auditorium, and admission is free.
Another free lecture, to be held in Titsworth Hall on Thursday at 8 P.M., is titled "1994 Challenges to Environmentalism: Science and Regulations." The speaker will be Frederic D. Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, based in Manhattan.
Mr. Krupp and his team of scientists, engineers, economists and lawyers seek solutions to the problems of global warming, ozone depletion, degradation of the tropical rain forests and the impact of acid rain and toxic chemicals on the water supply.
For more information, call 395-2411 or 395-2220.
 
HEALING POWER OF BEES
 The medicinal and therapeutic benefits of honeybees and the products obtained from them have not been proved within the American scientific community, but they are used widely in China and by some practitioners here. An introduction to the subject will be offered in a program titled "Honeybees and Health," to be conducted at the Greenburgh Nature Center on Saturday at 2 P.M. by Dr. Theo Cherbuliez. The center is on Dromore Road off Central Avenue.
Dr. Cherbuliez is a Scarsdale psychiatrist and master beekeeper who has employed bee-sting therapy on an experimental basis as a treatment for symptoms of arthritis and multiple sclerosis. The treatments have been in progress for two years, sometimes in conjunction with bee pollen and royal jelly.
Last year, he and his wife, Susan, who will assist in Saturday's program, visited China, attending an international Apimondia Conference in Beijing and an Asian bee-therapy conference in Nanjing. They also observed the use of beeswax in the treatment of burn victims at a burn clinic in Beijing. About 300,000 patients have apparently benefited.
Slides will accompany Dr. Cherbuliez's talk, and he will have samples of beeswax, bee glue (a waxy substance collected from buds of certain trees by bees), royal jelly and bee venom (which is contained in ampules).
Admission will be $3 and includes access to all the center's exhibitions. Call 723-3470 for more information.
 
ILLUMINATING PHRASES
 "Translucent Writings," opening today at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, spans 30 years of that particular form of art in which words and language are combined with video and/or light. It was organized by the museum and Grita Insam, owner of Grita Insam Galleries in Vienna. It continues through April 3.
The 19 artists in the show represent 12 countries, including the United States, and each work is focused on words as art in conjunction with light beams, flashes, projections and neon. Complex meanings, symbols and philosophies inherent in the pieces may be lost on the viewer who is accustomed to straightforward oils and watercolors, but exploration of this new territory continues to expand.
One of the installations is by Peter Weibel, Austrian contributor to the 1993 Venice Biennale. Titled "Cultural Exodus From Austria," it consists of screens inscribed with the names of Austria's artists and intellectuals who fled the country during Nazi occupation.
Jenny Holzer, an American artist, uses words in lights, usually ironies or platitudes about sex and politics. Viewed as isolated moving signs, they assume a sudden importance.
The museum is on the campus of Purchase College, 735 Anderson Hill Road. Visiting hours are Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is free. The number to call is 251-6100. ELEANOR CHARLES

LENGTH: 1525 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 23-28

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring and Frederik Eliason

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Pleasant Economic Surprises
The good economic news just keeps coming. On Friday, the Commerce Department said the economy grew at a 5.9 percent pace in the fourth quarter of 1993 -- better than the already upbeat projections of most private analysts. It was the best quarterly performance for the gross domestic product in six years. Perhaps as good as the strong and broad-based gain was that core inflation grew just 1.3 percent in the quarter, the best since 1967. Economists are predicting that growth in coming months will not be as powerful as last quarter's rate, but it should be strong enough to keep consumers upbeat about the future. In 1993 over all, the G.D.P. grew 2.9 percent. It was the best rate since 1988 and a better annual rate than in any year during the Bush Administration. Understandably, the number delighted the Clinton Administration. 

CBS Skates Near the Edge
Let's face it. With the possible exception of those guys bumping helmets today on a frightening number of television screens, figure skating is now the hot sport. It already is the Winter Olympics' glamour sport, but when you mix in a bitter rivalry that leads to a nasty conspiracy, everyone pays attention. But this creates an interesting problem for CBS. In ads promoting its coverage of the Games, it's dying to capitalize on the Kerrigan-Harding drama, but if it gets too sordid, it will turn people off. That would not please advertisers paying $250,000 or so for 30-second spots, like Coca-Cola, I.B.M. and Sears. The solution, for now: Skating will still figure big in ads, but CBS has dropped one that focuses on Nancy Kerrigan and will devote more attention to Ukrainian and German skaters.
 
Helping L.A. to Its Feet
Los Angeles took quite a hit in the Jan. 17 earthquake -- officials now say the quake just might become the costliest natural disaster in American history, exceeding the $30 billion tab for Hurricane Andrew in 1992. So last week President Clinton asked for a quick $6.6 billion in emergency aid -- just tack it onto the budget, he said; don't play games trying to find spending cuts to balance it. And he asked California to match just 10 percent of it, not the normal 25 percent. Only cynics would whisper that there is any link between this gesture and California's 54 electoral votes.
 
Shifting Sands on Health Care
Nobody in Washington seems able to get a grip on this health business. President Clinton vowed in his State of the Union speech to veto any bill that does not include universal coverage. Then Lloyd Bentsen said more companies might be allowed to bypass the huge purchasing groups. But they've said all along that unless most Americans belong to these groups, the whole thing won't work. And the No. 1 dart-thrower seems adrift too. Bob Dole devoted much energy last year to a Republican effort at radical health reform. But then after Mr. Clinton's speech he came up with a new line: There is "no health care crisis" -- although 84 percent of Americans say there is. What does this all add up to? One view is that the problem is so vast the politicians are addled. Then again, there's such momentum for change that political zigzagging can't stop it.
 
Of Clean Air and Cold Cash
 Clean-air advocates are forever promoting mass transit, but most commuters continue to vote with their gas pedals. Now, the Clinton Administration is including a proposal in the Federal budget that would use a most direct argument for taking the bus or train: cash. Where employers pay their workers' parking fees at non-company lots, the companies would be required to offer cash to workers who forgo the free parking. But it is far from certain that Congress will validate this parking bill. And even if it did, one benefits expert said, workers who do not get free parking would ask employers to cut their taxable income and provide tax-free parking instead.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Faith in Japan From Afar
Tokyo's stock market can't seem to decide whether the political turmoil is something to worry about. For more than a month, prices have risen, mainly because foreign investors have decided that despite a local recession and shaky Government, this is where they want their money. This momentum was jolted Monday when the market plunged nearly 5 percent, a reaction to Prime Minister Hosokawa's loss of a crucial vote the previous Friday. But it regained 2 percent by week's end, again fueled from abroad. Outsiders seem to think that East Asia is the place to invest and that Japan offers the bargains. Only time will tell whether the local or global view is right.
 
Tangled in a Spanish Mess
 The affairs of Banco Espanol de Credito, the big Spanish bank that was seized by the Government a month ago, provide yet another example of how the investing world has shrunk. An investment partnership set up by J. P. Morgan, the New York banking company, held an 8 percent stake in Banesto. And the U.S. Central Credit Union, which provides financial services for thousands of American credit unions, acknowledged this week that it had $255 million deposited in uninsured accounts in the bank. Just as American mutual fund investors are buying more and more foreign stocks for flashy returns, financial institutions have gone abroad looking not only for better yields but also simply for diversity.
 
Limiting Tiny's Vast Reach
 Roland W. Rowland is nicknamed Tiny, but he stands well over 6 feet tall. He heads a publicly traded British company, Lonrho P.L.C., but he has not bothered to meet with securities analysts in two decades. He now says he is an absolute equal with his co-chief executive, Dieter Bock, but nobody else seems to believe it. Lonrho announced that four allies of Mr. Rowland were retiring from its board, and Mr. Bock is believed to be eager to get rid of many of the 700 companies that Mr. Rowland, 76, has accumulated over the years.
 
Flying High in the Mideast
 The F-15 fighter jet emerged from a fierce dogfight with an order from Israel of about $2 billion for McDonnell Douglas. The loser in the battle for one of the biggest foreign arms orders in years was Lockheed, even though the company campaigned heavily in Israel.
 
Ready to Remove an Old Barrier
The embargo against trade with Vietnam has endured for nearly two decades, but it now seems certain to be lifted within months, if not days. The way has been eased for the President by a bipartisan Senate vote urging an end to the embargo. An official at the United States-Vietnam Trade Council estimates that American companies might share in as much as $9 billion of trade and investment.
 
COMPANIES
 
Greed at Green Point?
The whole idea of a "mutual savings bank" is that the little people own it -- a piggy bank here, a modest nest egg there. So when one such institution, Green Point Savings Bank, of Queens, outlined a plan to convert to stockholder ownership, it disturbed some depositors that executives and trustees stood to gain millions. Last week the New York State Banking Department, equally disturbed, barred the lucrative payments but said the conversion could go ahead. Then a Federal judge stopped the offering, but a panel overruled him. On Friday, the stock was sold, in the largest such sale in 20 years. Federal regulators said they were drafting rules to protect depositors in such situations.
 
Conde Nast Names Brit
Top American editors often speak with a British accent: Tina Brown at The New Yorker, for instance, and Harold Evans at Random House. Now, Conde Nast has named James Truman, 35, the editor of Details, to succeed Alexander Liberman, 81, as editorial director of Vanity Fair, Vogue and 11 other magazines.
 
Big Blue's Good News
A few short years ago, when I.B.M. reported profits, everyone yawned and said, "How many billions this time?" In 1990's fourth quarter, say, it earned $2.46 billion. Gone, long gone. Last week I.B.M. turned a profit in the mere millions, and it was big news -- because the $382 million it made in 1993's final quarter was its first profit in more than a year. "We are making progress," said Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman of this humbled giant, whose payroll is off by 45,000, to 256,000, in the past year. But the stock, which ran up on Monday after a favorable Barron's article, slipped on the news anyway, from $58.625 before the earnings report to $57.75 at week's end.
 
Big Buy for BankAmerica
For decades after World War II, the nation's largest banking company was BankAmerica, based in San Francisco. But in 1982, the New York-based Citicorp ascended to the top spot, and soon its total assets had far surpassed its closest rivals. Last week, however, BankAmerica said it would pay $1.9 billion to acquire Continental Bank of Chicago. It is the largest acquisition ever involving big money-center banks in different states, although the price is less than half of the $4.7 billion BankAmerica paid for Security Pacific in 1991. By the time BankAmerica digests Continental, its assets are expected to be above $200 billion, not far behind Citicorp's $216 billion.
