HEADLINE: In I.B.M. Deal, State Offers A Loan to Create 700 Jobs

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
New York State will provide $40 million in low-interest loans to a computer-chip company from California if it concludes a manufacturing agreement with I.B.M. that could create more than 700 jobs in the economically troubled Mid-Hudson Valley, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced yesterday.
The computer-chip company, Cirrus Logic Corporation, based in Fremont, Calif., produces software and integrated circuits for desktop, portable and hand-held computers, as well as telecommunications and consumer electronics equipment, according to the company's 1993 annual report. 
 If it concludes its joint-venture agreement with International Business Machines, the company would convert an existing I.B.M. plant in the Dutchess County community of East Fishkill and, by early next year, employ about 700 workers, said Steve Vitoff, a spokesman for Vincent Tese, New York State's director of economic development.
International Business Machines has long been the linchpin of the Hudson Valley economy and the dominant private employer in three counties: Dutchess and Ulster, where it has manufacturing plants, and Westchester, home to its corporate headquarters.
 
A Harsh Year
 In the last year, however, in the first layoffs in its 79-year history, I.B.M. has cut 7,700 members of what in 1992 was a Mid-Hudson work force of 21,500. And in East Fishkill alone, where the proposed joint manufacturing venture would be located, the work force has been reduced to 5,200 from 9,200.
In a prepared statement, Governor Cuomo said yesterday: "New York State is committed to helping the talented and hard-working men and women laid off by I.B.M. in the mid-Hudson Valley find new jobs, and to helping the area's economy recover. We expect that laid-off I.B.M. employees will find many of the new jobs created by the Cirrus Logic-I.B.M. venture."
Lee Webb, executive vice president of the State Urban Development Corporation, described Cirrus Logic as a rapidly growing computer-chip company. "Sales go up 20 to 30 percent a year," Mr. Webb said. "It's on the cutting edge of all of the new technologies." The company's total net sales in the fiscal year ending March 1, 1993, were $354.7 million.
Asked if the state expected the company to eventually create more than the initial 700 jobs at the East Fishkill plant, Mr. Webb said, "Certainly we believe that if this venture is successful, there's no reason to stop at this."
The founder of the company, Suhas Patil, was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
 
Stock Offering Due
 Mr. Vitoff said Cirrus Logic and I.B.M. are close to finalizing their agreement. "The reason the state aid package is being announced on a Saturday," he said, "is that Cirrus Logic is in the process of a secondary public stock offering, and is therefore required by Federal law to disclose the existence of its discussions with I.B.M.
"That disclosure was made public by them in a prospectus they filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission," he said. "The timing seemed propitious for state officials to come forward and disclose that the assistance package is ready to go."
The state assistance is expected to include a $15 million loan from the State Urban Development Corporation and a $25 million loan from the State Job Development Authority. The U.D.C. loan requires approval of the State Legislature, as part of the Governor's executive budget.
After the I.B.M. layoffs, Mr. Cuomo formed a task force of public officials and business executives to coordinate job-creating efforts for the region. The connection between Cirrus and I.B.M. came out of that effort.
One of the factors that favored a Cirrus operation in Dutchess County, Mr. Webb said, "was the quality of life in the area, and that Mr. Patil had lived in the Hudson Valley 15 to 20 years ago when he worked at I.B.M."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
G.O.P.-TV: New Image In Appeal To Voters

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
"There are a lot of choices on TV," says Ronald Reagan, staring into the camera. "But my choice is 'G.O.P.-TV.' "
Unlike many ordinary Americans, former President Reagan does not tune in to "The Simpsons" at 8 P.M. on Thursdays. He says he watches the Republican Party's new show.
George Bush heartily agrees with his Presidential predecessor's viewing habits, saying, "I also make time for 'G.O.P.-TV.' " 
 Both men, of course, were fibbing. Their testimonials, which appeared during the debut of G.O.P.-TV on Thursday night, were taped long before the broadcast. But their cameo appearances attest to the importance the party attaches to its new show.
 
Folksy-Talking Host
 For 60 minutes every Thursday evening, Republicans will broadcast the program, "Rising Tide," by satellite, available to any one, or any group, with a dish. Like the door-to-door precinct captains in the old days, they see satellite technology as the best new way to drum up grass-roots enthusiasm and to raise money. (They also hope to make converts out of the independents and to get wavering Republicans back into the fold.)
The show, broadcast from the party's headquarters here in a television studio that underwent a renovation at a cost of more than $1 million, was modeled after the news magazines that have proliferated on the networks. The host is Haley Barbour, the folksy-talking party chairman who campaigned for his job on a platform that he looked good on television.
Other party-officials-turned-broadcasters break in during the fast-paced show with "news updates" and reports from the field. One guest on Thursday night, Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, took calls from viewers at an estimated 1,000 sites around the country where local Republican Parties had set up viewing parties.
"It's just like Larry King," Anne Gavin, a party spokeswoman, said in the studio, moments before Mr. Barbour went on.
Well, not quite. The live "news" reports had a decidedly Republican tilt.
 
Wave of Parties' Future
 Republicans and Democrats are increasingly turning to satellite technology to spread their political messages unfiltered by the news media -- and even to announce political campaigns. President Clinton's aides have discussed starting a Bill Clinton-TV network.
Last year, Paul M. Weyrich, a leading conservative, started the 24-hour National Empowerment Television, which is available by satellite and on cable. Also last year, Lamar Alexander, a former Tennessee Governor and Secretary of Education, began the Republican Exchange Satellite Network. The program, broadcast once a month, is intended to raise the Republican perspective on issues (and also raise the image of Mr. Alexander, who is considering a campaign for President in 1996).
But until Thursday night, no political party had ever produced its own weekly television program, slick graphics and all. It was more like a 60-minute commercial for the Republican Party, interrupted by solicitations for money.
 
Questioning Credibility
 Here is how Mr. Barbour led into the main segment: "He talked the talk, but will he walk the walk? Republicans are wondering whether Bill Clinton's action will match his words. We're talking about Tuesday's State of the Union speech. Dan Leonard was on Capitol Hill for the speech and reports Republicans have several questions about Clinton's credibility."
The picture switched to Capitol Hill, where Mr. Leonard, a Republican staff aide who has the blow-dried look of a young television reporter, said, "In his first State of the Union, President Clinton was quick to take credit for job creation and a revived economy, an economy which began rebounding even before he was elected."
Between segments there were taped pleas for viewers to send in $25 to join the party ("Operators are standing by," the announcer says), or to call an 800 number for party bumper stickers.
One promotion urged people to watch next week for "live exclusive coverage" of a Republican fund-raising gala featuring Mr. Reagan and Margaret Thatcher, the former Prime Minister of Britain. "Tickets are $1,000 a plate," the announcer said, "but you can see the event free on G.O.P.-TV." (That is, if you can afford your own satellite dish.)

GRAPHIC: Photo: Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chairman, on the set of the party's new television show, "Rising Tide." The weekly satellite television show is intended to raise money and grass-roots enthusiasm. (Vincent Ricardel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fingerprints-for-Welfare May Widen

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POMONA, N.Y., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Louis Jeanty did something this morning that some say could save the state welfare system millions of dollars but that others see as demeaning to him.
He had his fingerprints taken. 
 It happened under a 14-month-old pilot program ordered by the State Legislature here in Rockland County, in the lower Hudson Valley, and in upstate Onondaga County, which includes Syracuse. Mr. Jeanty and several thousand others who seek public assistance under the Home Relief program must have their fingerprints recorded to insure that they have not used assumed names to apply for multiple benefits. Home Relief, a state welfare program, is aimed primarily at single individuals and childless couples.
At the welfare office here, recipients place their index fingers on a scanner and their prints are recorded electronically. Mr. Jeanty, a 31-year-old unemployed shipping clerk from Spring Valley, said he had "no problem" being fingerprinted if it meant that the integrity of the welfare system would be assured. And he shrugged off a central criticism of the program -- that it makes welfare applicants feel like criminals.
"I've been fingerprinted lots of times," said Mr. Jeanty, who moved to the state from Haiti 12 years ago. "To get my passport to come here. My green card picture. It's no big deal for me."
If officials can curtail cheating in the welfare system, he added, "the more I'm going to get."
 
Savings for the State
 The fledgling fingerprint program received renewed attention this month when a Cuomo administration study determined that it had saved the two counties nearly $500,000. The savings, the report found, came from the 4.3 percent of Home Relief recipients who chose not to reapply for welfare after being informed they would have to be fingerprinted. When that figure was extrapolated across the entire state, the study projected an annual savings of $46.2 million in welfare benefits.
Aides to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said that at the least, he would probably ask the Legislature to expand the fingerprint program later this year to several counties that surround Rockland, and Onondaga.
Proponents of fingerprinting contend that the savings in the two counties justify broader implementation across the state. But critics emphasize that the program has yet to catch a single welfare recipient in the act of cheating, and may have deterred some legitimate recipients from reapplying.
Patricia Feeley, the co-leader of the Rockland County Coalition for the Homeless, said she saw the program as a violation of applicants' privacy and worried that their prints might someday be shared with other agencies, including law enforcement. Ms. Feeley said she wondered whether a stipulation in the current statute that bars the social service system from releasing such information would eventually be discarded.
"To me it seems almost Orwellian," she said. "Any time we want to amass large amounts of information about individuals, I just question the ultimate purpose."
 
No Control Group
 The study assumes that many of those who did not reapply for benefits had hoped to cheat the system, or were perhaps already cheating it, and were scared off by the fingerprint request. But it cannot say so conclusively because researchers did not employ a control group, which would have allowed the state to compare an office that uses the fingerprint system to one that does not. Michael J. Dowling, the state Social Services Commissioner, said not using a control group was a mistake that would be corrected in future research.
Nevertheless, social service officials in Rockland County said they had learned enough to recommend that the program be expanded. They said they had demonstrated that the computer equipment that runs the system works properly -- it includes an optical scanner tethered to a data bank that can compare a fresh set of prints to thousands of others on file in a matter of minutes. The process, which involves no ink, electronically converts a print into a mathematical formula.
Rockland County officials said they were also encouraged that few applicants had objected to having their prints taken.
"We make an effort to explain to the clients what we're doing, why we're doing it and that the information is retained within our offices and not shared," said Norman Garfield, systems coordinator for the Rockland social services department. "It's been surprisingly well received."
The program's ultimate goal is to catch individuals who use phony documentation, like fake driver's licenses, to collect multiple benefits from several welfare offices near their homes. But because the two counties in the pilot program are across the state from each other and have only one welfare office each, officials said they could not yet judge the program's full potential for intercepting fraud. Expanding the program to surrounding counties would help measure its effectiveness, they said.
 
'Have to Do Something'
 Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, said he was eager for the state to bring the program to his county, which is directly across the Hudson from Rockland. But Mr. O'Rourke, a native of New York City whose family was on welfare for much of his childhood in the 1940's, said he empathized with those welfare applicants who might be skittish about participating.
"I would not have liked to have been fingerprinted," Mr. O'Rourke said. "It would truly have been demeaning."
"But conditions have changed," he added, referring to the ease with which people can drive from one county to the next. "We really have to do something."
Officials in Suffolk County were so eager to emulate the pilot program that the County Legislature adopted a law last October that would require fingerprinting of all Home Relief recipients. Regardless of whether the state includes Suffolk, the county is willing to implement fingerprinting on a "go-it-alone basis," said Paul Sabatino, counsel to the County Legislature.
While Governor Cuomo said he was unsure whether the program should be implemented statewide, he said during a news conference last Wednesday that he disagreed with those who said the process made welfare applicants seem like criminals.
"I'll give you a list today of all the people in this society that are fingerprinted," said the Governor, who by virtue of his office would be on such a list. "Every judge is. Every parole officer. Every bus driver."
"We think," he added a moment later, "that anything that helps identify will be good for the honest people on welfare."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Norman Garfield recording the fingerprints of Louis Jeanty, a welfare recipient, at the Rockland County Department of Social Services. "I've been fingerprinted lots of times," said Mr. Jeanty, who moved from Haiti 12 years ago. "To get my passport to come here. My green card picture. It's no big deal." (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Some Good Out of Chiapas

 BODY:
Mexico's peasant rebellion has brought death, reports of grave human rights abuse and serious embarrassment to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. It has also created some awkwardness for Washington, which identified itself with the Salinas Government on the North American Free Trade Agreement, and which lent Mexico helicopters for drug interdiction only to see the aircraft used in early operations against the rebels.
But the Chiapas revolt has also yielded some positive results. It woke up a political system whose backward and authoritarian ways clashed with Mexico's efforts to build a modernized economy. It brought long-overdue dialogue between Mexico City and the peasants of Chiapas. And now it has brought agreement between all of Mexico's main parties on ground rules for fairer, less money-tainted presidential elections this August. 
 In an added benefit, it has also brought two key governmental appointments that could be important to Mexico's political health down the road. The first is the appointment of Jorge Carpizo McGregor to the Ministry of Interior, or Gobernacion, which is responsible not only for internal security but also the supervision of elections.
When the revolt broke out, the Interior Minister was Patrocinio Gonzalez Garrido, a former Governor of Chiapas with a reputation for aloofness and repression who clearly had to go. To replace him, Mr. Salinas chose a respected human rights advocate and crusader against official corruption. Mr. Carpizo gives Mexicans and interested outsiders reason to believe that this year's election will be more credible than the fiasco six years ago, when computers mysteriously halted, ballots disappeared, and many thought that fraud had denied the presidency to the leading opposition candidate, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas.
The other significant appointment assigned Manuel Camacho Solis to negotiate with the rebels. Several months ago, President Salinas came close to naming Mr. Camacho, a longtime associate, as his designated successor. Instead, he chose Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta. But since the peasant revolt, Mr. Camacho, a man who established special credibility among disaffected sectors of Mexican society, has all but eclipsed Mr. Colosio. There is now even talk of reviving his presidential candidacy before formal ballot positions are decided in March.
Dazzled by his own economic reforms and diplomatic triumphs, Mr. Salinas was humbled by the surprise guerrilla offensive that began New Year's Day. But since then, he has moved with impressive political skill. One way or another, the events of this month are likely to accelerate overdue democratic change. That is good for Mexico and for the U.S.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Minorities and Adult Education Give Women's Colleges a Boost

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Women's Colleges Find a New Popularity" (front page, Jan. 15): Two other drivers of the enrollment surge at women's colleges are adult women and women of color. 
 In regard to adult education, women's colleges were well ahead of the curve in the mid-1980's with the introduction of such now-conventional programs as weekend colleges and other forms of untraditional education. Adult women flock to these programs because they provide access to education that fits the juggling act of most women's lives, and with pedagogy that is appropriate for such students, such as cooperative learning.
At Trinity in Washington, one of the oldest Roman Catholic women's colleges, more than two-thirds of our undergraduate students are adult women, and many other women's colleges can cite similar statistics. Moreover, such women are some of our most challenging students, consistently earning high academic honors and membership in honor societies such as Phi Beta Kappa.
Minority women are also increasingly finding access to education in women's colleges, particularly in urban centers. Minority student enrollment at Trinity has more than doubled in 10 years, from 15 percent to more than 30 percent of our weekday undergraduate population, and more in the weekend program.
Such demographic changes have not been without controversy at our profoundly traditional women's colleges. Yet, they are wholly consistent with the mission of most of our institutions to make a higher education accessible to women who could not otherwise gain access.
Those women today might be 45, working, single parents, women of color and often economically disadvantaged. But they share with their traditional classmates and predecessors those two great characteristics of great students: a great thirst for knowledge as the key to empowerment and self-fulfillment, and a vision of a future society better for their education.
 
PATRICIA MCGUIRE
President, Trinity College
Washington, Jan. 15, 1994

And Bear In Mind
(Editor's choices of recent books of particular interest)
 
BEYOND DESPAIR: Three Lectures and a Conversation With Philip Roth, by Aharon Appelfeld. (Fromm, $17.50.) The Israeli novelist argues that literature can and must deal with the Holocaust or give up its pretensions to be a vehicle of spiritual apprehension.
 
THE BINGO PALACE, by Louise Erdrich. (HarperCollins, $23.) Three decent people look for love on a windblown prairie in this novel whose daily life is enriched by supernatural events and the presence of Indian spirits.
 
A DRINKING LIFE: A Memoir, by Pete Hamill. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) Mr. Hamill's drinking is the organizing theme for the 37 years covered here, but the more fundamental matter is a fine portrait of the emerging artist, boy and man, in a New York that is no more.
 
FRAUEN: German Women Recall the Third Reich, by Alison Owings. (Rutgers University, $24.95.) Ms. Owings hoped, by interviewing German women 70 and older, to find they had been nobler than German men in the Nazi era. They weren't, but the excursion is fascinating.
 
A FROLIC OF HIS OWN, by William Gaddis. (Poseidon, $25.) Mr. Gaddis's fourth novel, easier to like than his previous work, constructs a harsh, misanthropic but hilarious comedy from the language of law and litigation.
 
GOING NATIVE, by Stephen Wright. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A road novel that explodes the conventions of the genre as a weird, dangerous shape-shifting protagonist remakes his identity on the way to California.
 
JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES. Volume 2: The Economist as Saviour 1920-1937, by Robert Skidelsky. (Allen Lane/Penguin, $37.50.) How Keynes reshaped the world's economy, made a lot of money and married a ballerina, by an economics professor whose mastery of many subjects seems to match Keynes's own.
 
LEAVING HOME: A Memoir, by Art Buchwald. (Putnam, $22.95.) What he's really trying to do with his humor, Mr. Buchwald says, is get even for a dark, poverty-stricken childhood. Most readers would agree his revenge is complete.
 
LIVE FROM THE BATTLEFIELD. From Vietnam to Baghdad: 35 Years in the World's War Zones, by Peter Arnett. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A lean, engrossing memoir of reporters and war by a correspondent who was among the first to arrive and the last to leave in Vietnam, and virtually the only voice from Baghdad during the gulf war.
 
PADDY CLARKE HA HA HA, by Roddy Doyle. (Viking, $20.95.) This luminously written Irish novel, winner of the 1993 Booker Prize in Britain, is about the life force incarnate in its narrator, an unforgettable 10-year-old boy in the brilliantly realized world of 1960's Dublin.
 
SARAJEVO: A War Journal, by Zlatko Dizdarevic. (Fromm, $19.95.) A lament for Bosnia and for civilization, by a newspaper editor who celebrates the endurance and heroism of ordinary people caught in an insane conflict.

HEADLINE: THE MYTH OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT

 BODY:
On Martin Luther King Day, the President and I launched our community empowerment program ("The Myth of Community Development," by Nicholas Lemann, Jan. 9). We issued a call to all Americans to come together to help distressed communities and their residents to realize the American dream. Our challenge is not simply another "revitalize-the-ghetto scheme," based solely on trying to create "a lot of new economic activity in poor neighborhoods."
The principles underlying our community empowerment initiative focus on both economic growth and the development of a sustainable community. Our program is dedicated to expanding economic opportunity by involving the private sector throughout each local region in revitalizing its communities. It is also committed to creating communities where the streets are safe, the air and water are clean, housing is secure, human services are accessible, learning is a lifelong commitment and the residents' civic spirit is nurtured -- the types of investments that Lemann himself appears to embrace. 
 We could not be more enthusiastic about this initiative. On May 4, 1993, the President announced the empowerment legislation from the Oval Office. In September, he asked me to chair a Cabinet-level committee -- the Community Enterprise Board -- to develop the program. I have personally met with dozens of community and business leaders to broaden our thinking on these important issues. In short, our attention to this effort has been far from "modest."
No doubt, some past Administrations have tried and, in many respects, failed to turn around the cycle of decline at the core of too many of our urban areas. Others have not even tried. Under our program to rebuild this country together, we will empower communities and their residents -- our most valuable resources -- to become full partners in America's future. We all certainly have an obligation to try.
 
AL GORE
Vice President
Washington

HEADLINE: THE BIG CITY;
She Knows Her Lines

BYLINE: By John Tierney; John Tierney is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. His column will appear in this space every three weeks.

 BODY:
Some of Helen Quinn's fans think that Communism could have survived if there had been line-management experts like her in the Soviet Union. That is debatable. But there's no disputing her accomplishments in New York. I can't think of anyone who has brought so much comfort, discipline and leisure time to the waiting masses.
She has been doing it for a quarter-century without any salary or office or formal title (although she is sometimes called the Queen of Standees). At age 68, Quinn works out in the cold and relies solely on her own devices: a lawn chair, a clipboard, some scraps of paper and a voice that sounds like Ethel Merman as a drill sergeant. "If you don't like the way the line is run," she explains, "go home!" 
 The line is run by Quinn outside the Metropolitan Opera House every Saturday morning, which is when standing-room tickets go on sale for the following week's performances. The box office doesn't open until 10, but the buffs start arriving before dawn. These are highly unusual people -- willing to wait six hours to pay $10 to stand through six hours of Wagner -- yet in some ways they're perfectly representative New Yorkers. Here is a microcosm of life in Manhattan: a crowd of compulsives competing desperately for the privilege of renting pathetically tiny pieces of real estate.
This competition at close quarters is generally assumed to turn New Yorkers belligerent -- all these stressed-out rats squeezed into one cage, all these rude natives who take pride in their reputation for unruliness. When Mayor Giuliani demanded during his inaugural speech that cynics stop calling New York unmanageable, the cynics delighted in watching the Mayor's son uphold the city's traditional image. But the boring truth -- the reason that seven million people can live so close together -- is that New Yorkers actually are meekly manageable most of the time, particularly when someone like Helen Quinn is doing the managing.
Quinn has been a student of lines since 1943, the year she finished high school, started working as a key-punch operator in Manhattan and saw "The Magic Flute." Soon she was up to four or five operas a week, a habit affordable only by lining up for standing-room tickets, and eventually she realized something -- a great insight that continues to elude the gatekeepers at attractions like Disney World rides, rock concerts or Shakespearean plays in Central Park. She realized that standing in line is a stupid and unpleasant way to pass time.
So in 1966 she instituted a system that survives, thanks to popular support and the Met's tacit acquiescence. As people arrive, starting at 4 or 5 in the morning, they write their names on a numbered list on her clipboard. Then they leave the waiting to her. Some go back to bed, others to a coffee shop across Broadway to gossip about singers' throat ailments and reminisce about the days when you could easily bribe the ushers to get into standing room. ("Don't say the Met back then was corrupt. Say it was friendly.")
Everyone returns at 9, when Quinn faces the shapeless throng and puts her instrument to use. Her voice is most impressive when it's challenged, like the miserably cold, wet morning in December when tickets went on sale for three performances by Luciano Pavarotti. Quinn was bundled up and ready for trouble.
"The Pavarotti people can be a little ferocious," she confided. "If I had to live with a group of people the rest of my life, I would pick the Wagnerites. They're the most patient. Domingo people are a close second. The Pavarotti people are at the bottom of the list. I don't mix with them personally. They're loud in their deportment, they talk among themselves and they want extra places for their friends."
She was prepared for them, though. Quinn has her soft side -- she goes through a package of Kleenex every time Louis Quilico loses the soprano to the tenor in "Adriana Lecouvreur" -- but she hid it beautifully when she addressed the crowd of 200:
"Ladies and gentlemen, quiet, please! I'm going to read down the list, and I want you to call out when you hear your name. There comes a point in the list where you'll have to come up and identify yourself because the handwriting is so bad. That's got to stop! There's a limit. Will you please learn how to write!"
People raised their hands and called "Here" as she went down the list. "Quiet back there! You're making entirely too much noise," she said, and in the hush that followed a single giggle was heard from the back. Quinn looked up from her clipboard and scanned the crowd.
"Laugh all you want," she said. "You'll laugh all the way to the end of the line."
There was no more giggling.
Even the Pavarotti people politely formed a single file as she handed out numbered slips of paper. "When I see someone crashing the line, I pounce," she explained. "I'll say to everyone, 'Ladies and gentlemen, this person is crashing the line.' Believe me, it works. It's the most humiliating experience for anyone."
After the line started moving at 10, Quinn stood by the door collecting the numbered slips along with $1 tips. "I tell everyone that they get the same consideration whether they tip or not," she said. "For a long time I wouldn't take tips. I figured that running the line was my contribution to the Met. But people kept saying to me, 'Helen, wise up. You're performing a public service.' "
Perhaps half the crowd didn't bother to tip, and a few people muttered resentfully about her making a profit off something that should be free -- a populist sentiment that sounds nice until you consider a "free" attraction like Shakespeare in Central Park. The summer festival is touted as a great democratic institution, but it's actually one of the most discriminatory forms of entertainment anywhere. To be assured of two tickets to a hit, you must wait with nearly 1,000 others from 10 until 6 on a summer day, which the vast majority of people can't or won't do.
And the ones who do wait aren't getting free tickets, at least not if you value time the way economists do. When they calculate, say, how much Exxon should compensate Alaskans for being deprived of recreation in Prince William Sound after the oil spill, they typically value lost leisure time at half the average local wage. That works out to roughly $10 an hour in New York City, which means each pair of Shakespeare tickets costs $80 and each performance entails $80,000 in lost time.
Meanwhile, operating without any foundation grants, Quinn is providing hundreds of productive hours each Saturday. I conservatively estimate that in her career she has saved humanity a total of 156,000 hours, worth $1,560,000, and my conclusion is: Don't stiff her on the tip. It's money well spent, especially when you consider what it's being used for. Quinn, who's now retired, has been saving since last March for an extravagance this spring: buying an orchestra seat at every performance of her favorite opera, "Otello."
"My theory has always been that going to the opera should be a pleasant experience, not a test of physical endurance," she said. "Otello's not that long to stand through, but I figure for this one I want to sit down and relax like a human being."

HEADLINE: FILM;
Bringing You a Musical . . . With No Music

BYLINE: By JAMIE DIAMOND

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
James L. Brooks did not want to make just any old movie about the movie business.
Not the man who won three Academy Awards for "Terms of Endearment" (writer, director, producer) and went on to make the crowd-pleasing "Broadcast News" in 1987. Not the man who spent the last 25 years working on television classics like "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," "Rhoda," "Taxi," "Lou Grant" and "The Simpsons." 
 Mr. Brooks thought there was something so unreal about Hollywood that he wanted to push the envelope further and make a musical comedy, called "I'll Do Anything." Why not have actors break into song and dance while they stab one another in the back, glad-hand and lie?
With a $40 million budget from Columbia Pictures, Mr. Brooks hired high-profile talent like Prince, Sinead O'Connor and Carole King to write music and Twyla Tharp to choreograph dance sequences. Then he shot a musical about an unemployed actor (Nick Nolte) who suddenly gets custody of his precocious 6-year-old daughter (Whittni Wright), who is herself seduced by the Hollywood game.
The film community sat up. Was it true? Was the Hollywood musical back? Disney had reaped impressive profits with its animated musicals "Aladdin" and "Beauty and the Beast." True, Disney had taken a bath two years ago with the live-action "Newsies," but if anyone could pull off a Hollywood musical, people said, it was Jim Brooks.
At test screenings in August, however, when the actors started crooning, audiences were confused. Worse still, the press found out about the confusion (Time magazine reported that some members of the audience walked out). And the alarm was raised: The roughly 2 1/2-hour cut of the movie was in trouble. This was not going to be a private matter.
Scheduled to be one of Columbia's big Christmas films, "I'll Do Anything" was pushed back two months to give Mr. Brooks time to reshape the film -- to drop all but one of the musical numbers, shoot a few new connective scenes and generally make the plot move smoothly without the songs. The movie, now two hours long, opens on Friday.
"I'll Do Anything" also stars Albert Brooks (no relation to the director) as a growling movie mogul, Joely Richardson as a fickle movie executive who is Mr. Nolte's love interest and Julie Kavner as a down-to-earth marketing expert. In between trying to take on the duties of a parent and win a part in a movie, Mr. Nolte's character becomes entangled with the others when he is hired as the movie mogul's driver.
Jim Brooks, a tall, bearded man who resembles a Giacometti bear, looked shellshocked one recent afternoon as his handlers led him into a hotel suite for an interview. He and the cast of "I'll Do Anything" had just endured a three-hour "press event" promoting the movie. Mr. Brooks seemed undone by the persistent question: What happened to the musical?
The 53-year-old writer and director understood the curiosity. "Everybody is fascinated," he said, "and properly so, that this movie started out as a musical. But I've been working on this movie a long time, and I've processed through it, and it's hard to deal with the fact that no one else has."
The word "process" comes up often as Mr. Brooks speaks, not as it relates to words or food but as a series of decisions that precede a final artistic statement.
Ms. Kavner has had significance experience with Mr. Brooks's "process," having worked with him on "Rhoda" and "The Simpsons," 2 of the 10 television series he helped create. (His tenth, an animated show called "The Critic," had its premiere on Wednesday on ABC and is already shaping up as a hit.)
"In making a movie," Ms. Kavner said, "the word 'process' means there are a lot of surprises along the way. You have to go wherever the story takes you." She took voice lessons for a year to prepare for her musical debut; her song was cut from the movie.
There is no question that tackling a big-budget musical implies risk. (See "Sarafina," or Peter Bogdanovich's "At Long Last Love" or the disastrous attempt at a musical television series, "Cop Rock.") The last singing-and-dancing musical that made any real money was "Grease," in 1978.
Nevertheless, the idea appealed to Mr. Brooks. "I thought the musical form would get me to more of the truth," the director said in an apologetic tone. "For example, I wanted to make a sad ballet out of the table-hopping in Hollywood." The reference was to a scene choreographed by Ms. Tharp in which Ms. Kavner was to have sung her song, "I Can't Love You Anymore," written by Prince.
"I thought music would articulate that which you couldn't legitimately articulate in dialogue," Mr. Brooks added, "like a child talking about her loneliness, something you don't express at that age." This reference was to another song, "This Lonely Life," written and performed by Ms. O'Connor, that was also cut.
"But the music broke the sense of reality instead of enhancing it. I lost sight of my goals, and then I got them back, for which I'm really grateful. I feel like I made three movies. The first was a musical, the second was the compromise, and the third is what you see now." Mr. Brooks believes that the final version should not be considered, in effect, a circus without a clown: the movie as it is now, he said, is closest to the script he wrote, the one that simply said, "Add musical number here."
No one involved with the movie denied there were enormous changes at the last minute. In fact, advance criticism of the film has been so widespread -- Entertainment Weekly referred to the film's "mega-bad buzz" -- that Peter Bart felt it necessary to take the press to task last week in his column in Variety. "I have personally been involved with many movies, going back to the first 'Godfather,' " he wrote, "that previewed badly but were ultimately honed into hits."
The actor Albert Brooks said he doesn't understand why people would criticize a film still in progress. "Making a film is like guiding in a big jet on a foggy night," he said. "If you look at the jet 10 minutes before it lands, it's nowhere near the runway. If that was your final judgment, you'd run out and get the ambulances. Whatever happened to opening night?"
Was making the film a waste of money? "I don't know," he answered. "People always try things that don't work. Bravo to Jim for trying, I say."
Thanks to the director's impressive track record, Columbia allowed him to pursue his dreams, all three of them, and continue editing up to the day before the press screening two weeks ago.
It does not escape Mr. Brooks's notice that the movie mogul in "I'll Do Anything" has his confidence shaken by test screenings. Nor does Mr. Brooks think it ironic that he fell victim to the system he made fun of.
"If you write about a process you're about to go through, market research," the director said, "and you go through it and it doesn't echo what you've written about, you've failed."
Failure is a word that rarely appears in any sentence about Mr. Brooks's career. His approach to comedy is sometimes dark, yet it appeals to the mainstream. He said his greatest challenge in adapting Larry McMurtry's novel "Terms of Endearment" for the screen was that he "wanted to get a laugh on the word cancer." He did.
"Jim is both sad and funny at the same time," said Mr. Nolte, who spent two months "in process" with Mr. Brooks while the director was deciding whether to cast him.
"He's not mono at all," Mr. Nolte said of the director. "He's very much stereo."
It is Mr. Brooks's trademark approach to shine light on that place where conflicting emotions exist simultaneously.
"I talk to people in Los Angeles," said Albert Brooks, speaking from Mexico, where he is filming a new movie, "and they're all petrified about the earthquake. I say something funny and, in between laughter, they're wondering if they're going to die. That's the sort of thing Jim tries to capture. The embarrassing, human, ignoble things we're really thinking underneath."
Allan Burns, who was Mr. Brooks's partner on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and its spinoffs, suggests that Mr. Brooks's comedy is funny because it focuses on the aspirations of the underdog: "Look at that sorry bunch on 'The Mary Tyler Moore Show.' That gang was one of the greatest sets of losers of all time -- a television station that remained mired in last place for seven years. They were screamingly funny because they were so sad."
LIKE MANY WRITERS WHO make people laugh, Mr. Brooks did not have a particularly hilarious childhood. Born in North Bergen, N.J., he was raised by his mother and saw little of his father, a salesman who left for good when Jim was 12. "It was just your regular American dysfunctional life," said Mr. Brooks.
After attending New York University briefly, he worked his way up at CBS from copy boy to news writer, then moved to Los Angeles to work on documentaries for David Wolper. Six months later he was laid off. A latecomer to television ("We didn't have one when I was growing up," he said), he nonetheless began writing sitcom scripts on speculation and fairly quickly had a successful series on his hands in "Room 222."
Mr. Brooks has steered through Hollywood with a steady hand, writing hit television shows, directing hit movies and producing hit films like "Big" and "The War of the Roses." After writing about a television newsroom in "Broadcast News," Mr. Brooks decided he wanted to make a film about what he knew best from firsthand experience (Hollywood) and what he knew least (being raised by a father).
"I had no road map for fatherhood; I had no personal history to draw from," said the director, who has a 22-year-old daughter from his first marriage, and three children under 10 with his second wife, Holly.
"When Nick says in the movie to his daughter, 'Just know I'm there for you whenever you need me,' that was an amazing thing for me. He says the words we all want to hear."
Did Mr. Brooks hear those words as a child?
"No," he answered. "Most of us didn't."

HEADLINE: POP CULTURE;
The New Colossus: American Culture As Power Export

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
Spielbergian Dinosaurs devouring entire national film industries at a single gulp! Silver-haired villains and sloe-eyed ingenues setting new soap-opera standards for political incorrectness as half the world watches! Teen-agers from Bangkok to Beirut wearing Chicago Bulls caps backwards and lamenting Michael Jordan's retirement! Smoke bombs and lasers and thrusting pelvises and outraged clerics and intellectuals from Paris to Teheran to Beijing denouncing Michael Jackson and Madonna!
As the millennium approaches -- "Angels in America" is also big worldwide, but rather higher of brow -- American popular culture has never been more dominant internationally, nor more controversial. American cultural exports swell at least some of us with pride and help reduce the trade deficit. Serious money is involved; this is America's second-biggest export after aircraft. But just as some Americans have doubts about our pop culture -- its propensity to celebrate violence, sexual stereotyping and sheer lowest-common-denominator crassness -- those doubts multiply abroad, especially when the imports are seen as a threat to local cultural identity. 
 A survey of American pop-cultural influence by New York Times correspondents around the world reveals many things, from the quirky to the amusing to the troubling. But the results also raise larger questions: Is America's dominance due to intrinsic strengths of its culture -- its sheer flair and energy, its incarnation of democracy itself as marketable entertainment, its forging of a new international language? Or, as foreign critics lament, is it merely a function of American military and economic domination? Or capitalism run amok, a "pure monopoly in the worst sense," as Jacques Toubon, the French Minister of Culture, put it in the recent debate over world trade barriers?
Statistically, America's impact is overwhelming. Of the world's 100 most-attended films last year, 88 were American, Variety reports. The highest-ranked competitor, France's "Visiteurs," was No. 27. That's not even counting pop music, television, novels and the more nebulous, all-pervasive imagery of American street fashion.
But such dominance can breed insensitivity to other cultures' fears that their traditional values may be lost. Indeed, the insistence at the trade talks by Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, and by Mickey Kantor, the American trade representative and Hollywood lawyer, that such fears were simply a smokescreen for protectionism may have pushed the rest of Europe into siding with the French to erect still more barriers to American films and music. Elite culture has nearly always been protected, even in the United States, and to eliminate that would be to fulfill de Tocqueville's worst fears that a culture's excellence can be leveled by the common taste.
Few could deny that some of America's success is due simply to aggressive marketing. The popularity of a seven-year-old minor soaper like "The Bold and the Beautiful" in countries like Lebanon, Egypt and India is a case in point. For Americans abroad, a troubling aspect of our popular culture is that so much of it, especially in Eastern European and third-world countries, is inferior. Instead of the best films and television -- best here meaning "Roseanne," not PBS -- foreigners get second-tier shows like "The Bold and the Beautiful" and "Baywatch" marketed on the cheap. For executives in search of a deal, and audiences eager for any glimpse of American opulence, it may not matter much. But in the not-too-much-longer run, it tarnishes our national image.
Rampant piracy -- the illegal copying of films, television programs and albums -- contributes to this debasement of America's best popular culture. But while piracy is a big issue for outraged executives in New York and Los Angeles, it is less of one for those interested in the sheer impact of American culture abroad. Yes, companies lose royalties and foreign buyers may get grainier images or muddier sound. But whether Clint Eastwood and Janet Jackson get their cut, their Americanizing influence still spreads from bazaars in Nairobi to stalls in Guangzhou.
In decades past, America's chief cultural exports were debonair crooners and stalwart upholders of truth, justice and the American way. Today, a different America exports products that reflect a chilling propensity for cartoon-like, bone-crunching, eyeball-popping violence. That seems to suit much of the world, if a report from Lebanon below is any indication. There, Islamic fundamentalists, rather like American puritans of whatever political stripe, deface posters of semi-clothed women but ignore lurid images of slaughter.
In the United States, pundits fret about children aping Beavis and Butt-head and about violence on the screen provoking violence in the streets. Abroad, those are real worries, too. But for Americans, another worry should be that foreigners may take our films and our rap literally, as an unexaggerated report on our state of affairs. In Brazil, for example, the police justify atrocities by saying they've seen American judges lead mobs of nightriders on "Dark Justice."
American intellectuals complain that American high culture is ignored in the face of this onslaught of action-heroics and indecent proposals. In fact, it enjoys a pretty heady reputation abroad. In Paris this fall, for instance, it was hard to avoid American painters, architects, authors, dancers, composers and theater directors traipsing through town.
But popular culture remains America's signal cultural contribution to the world. Its dominance today is not all bad -- commercially, morally or imagistically. The picture of multicultural acceptance our films and television purvey, for instance, may be more liberal wish-fulfillment than reality, but it still serves well a world riven by ethnic hatred. That the Fresh Prince of Bel Air can be popular in Spain or Whitney Houston beloved in Egypt may say far more to the world than one more punch in the snoot from Sylvester Stallone.
Then again, maybe "Hollywood" is itself no longer all that American, and its success abroad may be a testimony to its cosmopolitanism. When our supposedly national film industry boasts an Austrian named Schwarzenegger as its biggest star, a Belgian named Van Damme close behind in action films and a Chinese, Bruce Lee, as an honorable ancestor, when the French and the Japanese own studios or invest heavily in "American" films, when Hollywood gets half its profits from outside the U.S., when the new star of the Chicago Bulls is a Croatian named Toni Kukoc, then just how parochially American is our entertainment industry, anyway?
It may be that the world is being inexorably transformed from old to new, from narrow to broad, from kayak to jet. Maybe Western suits worn by Saudi or African businessmen, maybe even the English language itself, are not so much emblems of American superiority as the simple acceptance by a developing world of a single international standard of discourse.
On that model, periodic eruptions of religious and nationalist resentment are mere spray on the sweeping wave of history. On that same model, "Hollywood" and America itself may be more metaphors than velociraptors. They may represent not the monopolistic invasion by one country of all the others but the focal point of an international mass culture forming before our eyes.
No wonder French intellectuals are afraid. What they see is not some alien marauder but the inevitable consequences of their own revolution, the ones de Tocqueville himself found so alluring and terrifying: liberty, equality and, even, maybe, fraternity.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Recalling a World's Fair

 BODY:
A century ago, more than 200 structures were built in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park for the California Midwinter International Exposition, which drew 1.5 million visitors in just over five months. After the event, one building was allowed to remain, eventually becoming the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum, which is celebrating the fair's centennial with a special exhibition scheduled to open Jan. 27.
In the midst of a severe recession in 1894, the world's fair was orchestrated by the museum's namesake, M. H. de Young, who was inspired by the gargantuan World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago the year before. The San Francisco and Chicago expositions were among the few world's fairs to turn a profit since the tradition began in London in 1851. 
 On view at the museum through April 17 will be objects from its charter collection, including Greek, Egyptian and Roman antiquities, wood carvings from the South Sea Islands, 19th-century ladies' fans, bronzes by Troubetzkoy and Makovsky's painting "The Russian Bride's Attire." In addition to banners, medals and other memorabilia, some 40 folio-sized photographs of the fair taken by the exposition photographer Isaiah West Taber will be on display.
The museum is open Wednesday through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. On the first Wednesday of every month, the museum remains open until 8:45 P.M. Admission is $5, $3 for senior citizens and children 12 to 17, and free for 11 and under. Information: M. H. de Young Memorial Museum, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, Calif. 94118, (415) 863-3330.

HEADLINE: POP CULTURE: Channel-Surfing Through U.S. Culture in 20 Lands;
Nigeria: Bruce Lee Is No Fresh Prince

BYLINE: By Kenneth B. Noble

 BODY:
In Nigeria, recent releases like "Jurassic Park" are impossible to find: the few theaters that exist offer low-budget horror films and Bruce Lee retreads. On bootleg video, just about anything by Sylvester Stallone or Arnold Schwarzenegger sells well. Television shows with well-to-do black Americans occupy a secure niche: "Fresh Prince of Bel Air," "A Different World" and "The Cosby Show." By contrast, while T-shirts with the "X" from Spike Lee's film about Malcolm X were ubiquitous, the movie itself did not find much of an audience for its sober message.
Elsewhere in black Africa, one sees sharp contrasts: In Zaire, after 20 years of economic turmoil, there is not one movie theater left in Kinshasa, the capital. The public television station relies heavily on South African nature documentaries, month-old European soccer matches, horror films and Government news. Among Zaireans, eager for any cultural stimulation from abroad, American evangelical programs have become tremendously popular. Jimmy Swaggart, dubbed in French, is a star here; his foot-stomping, hellfire-and-damnation sermons are an electrifying alternative to the straitlaced crusading by local missionaries. 
 In the better-off Ivory Coast, the cult following is Hulk Hogan's. The Saturday afternoon World Wrestling show, dubbed in French, is one of the country's longest-running programs. Young Ivorians also love jazz and rap. Recently, the host of a local dance show, just back from New York, handed his studio audience icons of hip-hop culture: Mets caps, Nike sneakers and fake gold chains.
 KENNETH B. NOBLE

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2581 words

HEADLINE: Tapping Home Equity to Cushion Old Age

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
BERNICE STUART, a Minneapolis suburbanite, worked hard most of her life and still didn't know how she was going to make ends meet when she retired in 1988 at the age of 73. Widowed when her only child was just a year old, Mrs. Stuart "didn't owe anybody a dime" and had managed to put aside savings in an I.R.A. But the retirement money all went to nurse her mother through a final illness, leaving her with little apart from Social Security.
"The handwriting was on the wall," Mrs. Stuart recalls: She would have to sell her three-bedroom house and move into an apartment that lacked space to put up her beloved nieces and nephews. 
 But the story has a happy ending. In 1991 she obtained through a local mortgage broker a $40,000 line of credit, which she uses to cover property taxes and insurance along with the unexpected expenses that wreak havoc on the budgets of those living on modest fixed incomes.
Like the home-equity loans taken out by millions of other Americans, this line of credit was backed by the value of a house. But there is one big difference: Mrs. Stuart is not obligated to pay back a dime until she moves.
Mrs. Stuart is one of a few thousand Americans who have borrowed through an insured "reverse mortgage," the broad term for a loan agreement that gives the elderly a way to tap the equity in their houses without worrying that the sheriff will show up some day with an eviction notice.
Reverse mortages have had a hard start, never quite making the widely anticipated splash. That may be about to change, however, as more lenders enter the field and terms become more flexible. At the moment, it is possible to find a reverse-mortgage lender in all but a handful of states. Anyone who is over the age of 62 and owes little or nothing on his or her home is eligible.
But if reverse mortgages are as good as they sound -- if they are indeed the best thing to happen to older homeowning Americans since the invention of the early-bird special -- why have so few people made use of them? And if reverse mortgages represent a lucrative and nearly virgin trillion-dollar market for lenders, why has the otherwise go-go financial-services industry generally ignored them?
One reason is that the terms of a reverse mortgage are harder to understand than those of a conventional loan. And in many cases they may simply be beyond the comprehension of the older retirees in the best position to make use of them.
"It is very expensive to identify and gain the confidence of customers," says William Texido, president of the San Francisco-based Providential Corporation, which is one of the very few specialized lenders that makes reverse-mortgage loans without financial backing from the Federal Government.
Another is that an insured reverse mortgage is neither a straightforward loan agreement backed by real estate nor a simple life insurance policy or annuity funded with cash. This means that both banks and insurance companies have to stretch their expertise beyond traditional boundaries to design and market the product, an exercise that is bound to be expensive and risky for the pioneers.
"Everyone is waiting for everyone else," laments Mr. Texido.
By the same token, reverse-mortgage loans raise eyebrows at government agencies that were caught looking the other way when savings and loans collapsed in the late 80's.
"There is folklore that some banks tried to get into the market but were turned down by their regulators because banks are prohibited from underwriting life insurance," notes David S. Bizer, formerly an economist with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
This dam may be about to burst, however. Congress has expanded the number of reverse mortgages it is prepared to have the F.H.A. guarantee, and several private financial institutions are now taking a fresh look at their own prospects.
Equally important, suggests Ken Scholen, head of the nonprofit National Center for Home Equity Conversion, lenders in the Federal program are making good use of their limited experience, learning to write reverse-mortgage agreements at lower costs and offering the more flexible terms that borrowers seem to crave.
THE idea of allowing house-rich, cash-poor older Americans to have their cake and eat it too is not new. The first reverse-mortgage loan was made in 1961 by a little savings and loan in Portland, Me. And just two years later the State of Oregon began allowing the elderly to defer property-tax payments, using public-employee retirement funds to finance the loans.
But the market has sputtered and popped ever since, with a handful of private companies leaving most of the action to state and local agencies that make loans to needy homeowning elderly people solely to cover property taxes and critical repairs. As of 1991, 143,000 of these public-sector loans had been made -- a seemingly impressive number until it is realized that the total amount of housing equity encumbered by the loans was just $720 million.
Much of what is still the infant reverse-mortgage market dates from 1989, when the first were made under a Federal pilot program that insured their repayment. To date some 5,500 of these Home Equity Conservation Mortgages, with a maximum value of $560 million, have been created, and the Federal Housing Administration has been authorized to guarantee a total of 25,000 through September 1995.
The nuts and bolts of the federally insured program are relatively simple. Banks, savings and loans, mortgage brokers and other finance companies make the loans, just as they offer F.H.A.-insured conventional mortgages.
To get past the preliminaries, applicants must agree to accept mortgage counseling from a federally approved counselor -- typically a nonprofit social service agency specializing in housing and/or the elderly.
"We encourage them to bring a friend, attorney, child, someone who will help them make the decision," says Carol Greifer, the head of Counseling for Home Equity Conversion, a state-financed service for Nassau County.
This protects the borrower: "Seniors are vulnerable," Mrs. Greifer emphasizes. It also shields the lender from later claims of fraud by disappointed heirs.
Houses of any value can be used as loan collateral. But the amount of equity backing a reverse mortgage is limited to the maximum the Federal Housing Administration can insure, locality by locality. This maximum ranges from $67,500 in most rural areas to $151,725 in the highest-cost housing markets. And the largest lump sum that can actually be borrowed is considerably less than this maximum claim against equity since the debt keeps rising as interest accumulates until the borrower leaves the house.
The interest terms on F.H.A.-insured reverse mortgages are negotiated between the lender and borrower. Only adjustable-rate mortgages linked to United States Treasury rates are currently available, however. This is about the same rate as on a conventional self-liquidating mortgage.
Once in place, an F.H.A.-insured reverse mortgage can be tapped in a host of ways. The simplest, and probably the most popular, is a line of credit like the one created for Mrs. Stuart. Alternatively, a borrower can opt for a monthly payment for a fixed term -- say 10 years. Or the borrower can choose the "tenure" option, which sets a fixed monthly payment as long as the borrower occupies the home.
F.H.A.-insured reverse mortgages are flexible. For a minimal fee, the borrower can change from one option to another. It is even possible to mix and match, combining a line of credit with a regular monthly term or tenure payment. And in no circumstance is repayment due before the departure of the resident. That guarantee applies to couples as well as to individuals.
Perhaps this all sounds too good to be true, And for some potential borrowers it is. One catch is that equity spent is equity spent.
"I tell them you can only go to the well once," says Mrs. Greifer.
AFTER the borrower moves or dies, the accumulated debt -- the lender's cash outlays, plus interest, insurance and any deferred mortgage closing fees -- comes due. Thus someone counting on home equity to cover, say, nursing-home costs of a spouse or to finance the education of a grandchild must choose among priorities. If the owner dies, the estate sells the house and must pay the money owed to the lender before distributing whatever remains to the heirs.
By the same token, it should not be forgotten that lenders are in the reverse-mortgage business to make a profit and the F.H.A.'s insurance program is meant to be self-financing. Thus borrowers must expect to pay a hefty origination fee ("points"), closing costs and the mortgage-insurance premium, along with interest.
Mr. Scholen of the National Center for Home Equity Conversion notes that these costs are generally no greater than those associated with a conventional F.H.A.-insured home mortgage. But many people who borrow against their homes don't need insurance to get a mortgage on good terms. And even at the F.H.A.'s standard rates, the insurance premiums are not trivial: A flat 2 percent of the maximum claim amount is charged when the mortgage is granted, along with another half-percent annually on the loan balance. Neither, of course, is actually collected until the entire loan is due.
A third, not-so-obvious drawback to F.H.A.-insured reverse mortgages is the cap on the maximum claim amount. For those with houses appraised at less than the F.H.A. maximums, this does not matter. But in other, not-so-rare circumstances, the cap can pinch -- especially where the borrower is still relatively young.
Take the hypothetical case of a 65-year-old with a very valuable house, who is nonetheless limited by F.H.A. rules to a maximum claim amount of $151,725. If he (more typically, she) wants to draw a regular sum as long as he stays in the house, the fixed monthly payment, at rates authorized by the F.H.A., will be just $402. A 75-year-old would collect more, receiving $584 a month because he has a shorter life expectancy. But only a relatively old borrower could cash in quickly: an 80-year-old with the same amount of housing equity would receive $723 a month.
THE typically modest payout on federally insured reverse mortgages goes a long way toward explaining the lure of privately insured ones. Robert and Mary Wilson of Ventura, Calif., for example, "had enough to get along" from savings and Social Security.
But in 1991 they opted to borrow against the $225,000 in equity on their house, making it possible for them to receive $927 a month from Providential as long as either of them lived there. The $927 figure was based on Mrs. Wilson's age, 74. If she had been as old as her husband (85) they could have borrowed considerably more.
Thus far, Providential makes loans only in California, where housing prices are exceptionally high and the property tax laws give homeowners enormous incentives to borrow against their equity rather than selling. Moreover, limited access to capital has prevented the company from marketing more aggressively: Through 1992, the company issued just a shade more than 1,000 reverse mortgages, virtually all of which were "tenure" mortgages with lifetime monthly payouts.
Both the availability and flexibility of reverse mortgages are likely to improve, however, and soon, predicts Mr. Scholen. For one thing, mortgage brokers are beginning to think of F.H.A.-insured mortgages as a serious source of profit. Several are offering reverse mortgages in several states, thereby cutting costs and gaining experience in marketing. Among them are Directors Mortgage of Riverside, Calif., ARCS Mortgage of Calabasas, Calif., Amerifirst Mortgage of Hempstead, L.I., and International Mortgage of Owings Mills, Md.
For another, new players are arriving on the scene with competitive privately insured products. Two lenders, Transamerica HomeFirst of San Francisco and Freedom Home Equity Partners of Irvine, Calif., are offering reverse mortgages in several states. And a third, the giant Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) is widely expected to issue its own next year.
Fannie Mae already plays an important, if passive, role in reverse mortgages, buying all the F.H.A.-insured mortgages issued by banks and brokers. But the more active role it is contemplating could prove the breakthrough Mr. Scholen has been waiting for.
WHILE Fannie Mae will not confirm it, there is little doubt that its reverse mortgage would carry a considerably higher insurance cap than the F.H.A. limit. Nor is there much doubt that the giant mortgage broker and investor would be able to match the flexibility of the F.H.A. product, providing lines of credit as well as term and tenure mortgages.
What's more, Fannie Mae has a wide network of banks and other financial agents that are eager to serve as its retailers. And last but not least, Fannie Mae has deep pockets.
"It wouldn't be difficult to fund very large numbers" of reverse mortgages, says Larry Dale, executive director of Fannie Mae's Housing Impact Division.
Oddly, perhaps, the question about reverse mortgages that has gotten the least attention is whether easy access to reverse mortgages is a good thing -- whether reverse mortgages serve broader social interests.
At first look, the answer seems an obvious yes. Society's welfare, after all, is the sum of individuals' interests. And "in a well-planned world," notes Paul Samuelson, the Nobel-prize winning economist, "a lot of people would like to die exactly broke."
But on second look, the answer is more elusive. Americans already save far less than their counterparts in Europe and Asia. If what Mr. Samuelson calls the "inadvertent savings" of the elderly were sharply reduced, the national savings rate would be even lower.
What's good for the elderly may not be good for their grandchildren.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS;
Keeping a Vista in the View

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
The view. Along with the brownstone, it is the defining quality of Brooklyn Heights, an improbable sweep of urban beauty fiercely loved and protected through years of development talk.
Now, state and local officials have taken a significant step toward preserving the neighborhood's treasured visual link to lower Manhattan. They have reached an understanding that would discourage high-rise development of five piers along 64 acres of prime waterfront. 
 But because the agreement is on guidelines, rather than on a specific plan, and because any real action is likely to be years -- and possibly governors -- away, Brooklyn Heights residents are still concerned about how much say they will have in preventing major commercial development.
Anthony Manheim, co-chairman of the Brooklyn Bridge Park Coalition, offered guarded praise about the agreement. Members of the coalition, along with Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden and Assemblywoman Eileen C. Dugan, a Brooklyn Democrat, drew up the principles.
"The engine has been running, but the brakes have been on," Mr. Manheim said. "Now, the brakes are being released and the project is being allowed to move forward. We just hope that the focus will be more on parkland."
Spurred by economic pressures in 1992, the Port Authority was prepared to sell the dilapidated piers to private developers because the concrete slabs with hulking warehouses had become too costly to maintain. Port Authority officials wanted to devote the land to a profit-making commercial venture, like office buildings.
Local officials and residents protested bitterly, saying that such buildings would obscure their views of lower Manhattan and New York Harbor. The state Urban Development Corporation, intervening on behalf of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, halted the sale and asked the community to draw up guidelines for development.
Mr. Cuomo announced the agreement during his State of the State message on Jan. 5, saying: "The U.D.C. will take the lead in implementing a plan developed by the city and Brooklyn Borough President Golden's office and long supported by Assemblywoman Eileen Dugan to create a mixed-use development on the Brooklyn waterfront, at Piers 1 through 5."
But the Cuomo administration later admitted that the agreement involved only the guidelines, not a specific plan.
"There has always been suspicion that the Urban Development Corporation was not committed to moving forward on the project despite the fact we were able to forestall commercial development of the piers," said Alan C. Sullivan, executive deputy director of the State Department of Economic Development and chief of staff for Vincent Tese, head of the Urban Development Corporation. "The message the Governor tried to convey was that the Urban Development Corporation is in fact committed to implementing a plan to be developed by the community."
The guidelines, submitted more than a year ago, consist of 13 principles that the state must adhere to in developing the piers, including a sprawling park and low-rise development, Mr. Sullivan said.
Development of the piers is more than seven years away, he added. Meanwhile, officials are scrambling to find money for the $25 million in repairs the piers must undergo. And crucial details, like how the multimillion-dollar plan would be financed and how the piers would be acquired, are still being worked out, he said.
 LYNETTE HOLLOWAY
