SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3151 words

HEADLINE: That Mess on Hudson Street;
Infrastructure Blues: When Neighborhood Improvement Becomes Neighborhood Plague

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
ASK people in Greenwich Village to name the best thing to happen along Hudson Street since the heavy machinery moved in two years ago, and they're likely to tell you about the chilly Sunday morning last April when Jacqueline Slivko decided she had had enough.
A backhoe was backing and bobbing on her corner -- Hudson as it trundles across Horatio -- its plaintive mechanical beeps jerking her from a deep sleep. It was 7 A.M., too early for the crew to be working, and on a weekend, no less. She called the police, who refused to respond, she said. Then she ran downstairs -- in her nightgown, according to local legend, though Ms. Slivko insists she was wearing street clothes -- and planted herself near the backhoe. Evoking, albeit in a far more parochial vein, the Chinese protester who held off a column of tanks near Tiananmen Square, Ms. Slivko remained there for more than an hour while the backhoe operator yelled at her, a construction supervisor tried to intervene and a neighbor brought her some warm gloves. 
 "It just became a typical New York City situation, which was ridiculous," says Ms. Slivko, an account manager for a small banking-technology company. She was arrested on charges of disorderly conduct, though they were later dropped amid neighborhood outrage. "When the police asked me to move, I said no, move him. He doesn't have a right to be here. I do."
Ms. Slivko's Sunday-morning stand was the crowning moment of a community fury that had been gathering since January 1992, when the city's Department of Transportation began the $23.6 million job of tearing out old trolley tracks, installing a giant water main, replacing antiquated sewer pipes and rebuilding curbs and sidewalks along the three dozen blocks of Hudson Street between Chambers and 14th Streets.
Today, just five months shy of the original deadline and after a long procession of delays -- some planned, more produced by labor strikes, subterranean surprises and the city's attempt to dismiss the contractor for falling behind on the job -- the complicated, attenuated and obstreperous reconstruction of Hudson Street is perhaps half finished. By the most generous forecasts, the street will not return to normal until the end of the year. For now, with most of the work stalled by bad weather, Hudson Street is a boulevard broken by open pits and obstructed by orange and white barricades, its paving uneven and its surface slimed with mud, a vehicular purgatory and a pedestrian hell.
The mess on Hudson Street, of course, is a catastrophe only in the narrowest terms, a plague on a neighborhood that has had the good fortune, and the money, to be spared the most harrowing urban cataclysms. Still, the entire affair is what Ms. Slivko would call "a typical New York City situation," the kind of maddening annoyance that can assault the civic, economic and emotional spirit of a community in a crescendo of small injuries.
Since the work began, bakeries, delis and boutiques accustomed to a drop-in pedestrian clientele have seen that slow to a trickle as sidewalks and corners became impassable. At places like Taylor's bakery on Hudson near West 10th Street, the regulars are regulars no more. The local cafe society has abandoned cafes that had thundering generators parked alongside them, and restaurants normally jammed at lunchtime have had customers walk out in mid-meal because of construction noise.
"For the first time in 30 years, I almost went broke," said Barry Cullen, owner of the Sazerac House, a New Orleans-style restaurant at Hudson and Charles Streets, who founded a merchants' association in desperation after seeing four other businesses fold.
St. Luke's School converted its parking lot into a drop-off area so children wouldn't have to dodge construction vehicles to get inside, then it got flooded by a broken sewer pipe.
"At this point, you give up hope because no one will say when this thing will end," said D.K. Pascarelli, who has a house on Greenwich Street, one block west. "It's just too long to have the street torn up. This was a neighborhood."
Where blame is due, it should be spread around. But while Hudson Street is far from the best project in the tortured history of New York City street repairs, it is also not the worst. And so it offers a graphic portrait of what can happen when one contractor, a half-dozen subcontractors, another half-dozen utility companies and suppliers, monitored by a handful of city agencies and Federal and state inspectors, come together around a very big hole in the ground -- especially one that has thousands of people living and working beside it.
Hudson Street also shows the potential, and the limits, of community activism and municipal public relations. And, finally, in its twists and turns and starts and stops, the story is a guide to what to expect, and how to cope, when the backhoes come to your neighborhood.
 
Great Expectations
 The reconstruction of Hudson Street began with high hopes, even though the local community board had opposed the project in 1990, arguing that other streets were more in need of attention. But the Department of Transportation pressed its case, saying heavy traffic on Hudson was wearing the street away, and went ahead.
Still, wary of the local resistance and wounded by recent public-relations disasters on 14th Street, Mosholu Parkway in the Bronx and Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, the department resolved that this time it would be a more benevolent occupying force.
"Hudson Street was something that we went into with great expectations of this being a good project from the point of including the community, and improving control over the relationship between the contractor and the utility companies," said Lisa Daglian, a department spokeswoman.
To take care of the utilities, the department had the contractor negotiate a price for moving the lines ahead of time, instead of stopping work several times to head to the negotiating table, as had been the custom. To include the community, it printed up newsletters; the first one, issued in March 1992, cheerily declared, "Hello Everybody!" and went on to itemize what would be happening during the reconstruction. A community-liaison specialist, Kahli D. Yaba, was hired to roam the neighborhood and inform people about the project.
The first pick hit the old pavement on Jan. 6, 1992; all work was to be finished by June 1994. And for the first 10 months, work went according to plan. Holes were dug the length of the street to pull out the trolley remnants and make way for the new water main. In late November as scheduled, work stopped for the "Christmas embargo," intended to keep merchants from losing holiday business.
Shortly after workers reported back to the job in January, however, inspectors found flaws in sections of the new water pipe, manufactured by a subcontractor. "We can't put them in out of order," said Sam Sette, president of Sette Juliano, the Queens company that is the lead contractor on the job. So everything stopped until the pipe was replaced.
Mr. Cullen said the construction workers hanging around his restaurant told him they would be done working in his block by the end of February. But instead, they were outside his door until May 6. "They were there for 17 weeks," he said. "The whole thing just smelled."
By now, more than a year into the job, the Department of Transportation's communications efforts were starting to wear thin along Hudson Street.
The newsletters, people complained, did not say when certain parts of the project would start and how long they would take. And the repeated re-excavating of the street -- necessary to put in different kinds of plumbing and utilities at different stages -- caused widespread misunderstanding, despite several newsletters that said, "This means we will be coming back several times to the same block." Even the best explanations cannot smooth over the basic fact of street reconstruction, which is that most people hate it.
Last April, when Ms. Slivko confronted the backhoe, Hudson Street resembled a battle zone, residents said. And her arrest triggered a torrent of complaints, voiced at meetings of a task force assembled by Community Board 2, which includes SoHo and the West Village.
Couldn't the contractor stop his workers from leaving their lunch wrappers all over the street? Why wasn't there better lighting at night to protect people who had to navigate the wreckage on their way home? How about those rats? Couldn't there be a little more notice if the water was going to be shut off? Could they please park their trucks and other huge equipment somewhere else?
"You don't mind that the city has to be rebuilt, but somehow or other they have to do it more efficaciously," said Mr. Cullen. "The feeling you get is one of ineptitude on the part of the city."
He got no argument from his local officials.
"Things should only get to a point," said Rita Lee, district manager of Community Board 2. "It shouldn't be so horrendous that people can't live with it." A sprightly champion of the city dweller who wields her telephone in the manner of Martha Mitchell, she calls Hudson Street "a very sloppy job."
In an effort to prop up the Hudson Street economy, the neighborhood's Assemblywoman, Deborah J. Glick, asked the Dinkins administration to waive or reduce the 6 percent city surcharge on the rent businesses pay. Though her proposal was turned down, she plans to press her cause with the new administration. Ms. Glick gripes about the "deplorable" temporary paving of the street and adds, "I cannot understand how, if there is proper oversight, that is viewed as an acceptable road condition."
Oversight comes in several forms on Hudson Street: from the contractor, the Transportation Department's project manager and a resident engineer, hired by the city to make sure the work is done according to plan. Then there are the inspectors, from various city agencies, like the Department of Environmental Protection, and from the state, representing the Federal Department of Transportation, who weigh in from time to time.
"There's no getting around the fact that construction is a very intrusive operation," Ms. Daglian said. "It's always going to have an impact. We're trying to mitigate the negative effects."
The more people are affected, the more complaints you get, says Mr. Sette, the contractor. He is sympathetic, he says, to the neighborhood angst.
"You can't blame the people," he said. "They want you to get in and get out. But we're not building a watch."
 
The Spaghetti Bowl

The next delay didn't really have a lot to do with problems on Hudson Street. In July, concrete-truck drivers all over the city went on strike; a few days later, the backhoe operators followed. Once again, a disheveled quiet settled over the street.
In August, the Transportation Department and the local community board sponsored a weekend "promenade" in an effort to draw shoppers and reinvigorate local commerce. There were banners and posters and a visit by Mayor David N. Dinkins. But it flopped, Ms. Lee said, because everyone was so depressed.
Steve Kelczewski is the resident engineer for Hudson Street. He works out of a third-floor office on Harrison Street in TriBeCa, full of muddy bootprints and blueprints showing the city's subcutaneous complexities, and the job, with all of its New York nuances, has clearly taken its toll on him as well.
Ms. Lee and her constituents can take the credit for that. "When people complain to me, I always ask them, 'Did you call Steve?' " she said.
Actually, he finds the whole situation kind of puzzling.
"I've worked in lower-income areas where the people were thrilled that their neighborhood was getting fixed up," he said. "Here we hear, 'I don't drive. I don't care about Hudson Street.' "
Many of the callers ask when the job will be finished, an increasingly embarrassing question. "It's hard to project the future because of all the difficulties we encounter," Mr. Kelczewski said. "We think it will take us one week to do a block, but we get down there and find ourselves in a big spaghetti bowl and it takes us a lot longer."
Such surprises are what every reconstruction expert fears and expects on a major project like Hudson Street. While blueprints do exist for many of the utilities buried beneath the street, they are often incomplete or inaccurate. Even the advance soundings taken by workers toting arthroscopic-type equipment attached to microphones and video cameras are not totally reliable.
Chief among the surprises on this job was the discovery -- soon after the strikes ended around Labor Day -- of an orphaned oil-static network, used for high-voltage electricity. With records sparse and incomplete, Con Edison and the Transit Authority have both denied owning the network and so have refused to pay to have it moved out of the path of the water and sewer pipes, as required by city law. The dispute continues to this day, but after three months with little new work done, the Transportation Department decided to foot the bill, pending a resolution.
Another surprise was wood-encased pipes of bright green brine that run between a refrigeration plant on Gansevoort Street and the meat-packing warehouses on the Village's western edge. After a brief delay, workers went around the brine lines to preserve them.
In November, increasingly battered by public anger over the project, the city began proceedings to dismiss Sette Juliano.
"We felt he was not meeting his mandate to finish the job within the required time frame," Ms. Daglian said. "We were concerned. We had heard there was a possibility he was financially insolvent." Last month, the action was dropped, and the contractual deadline for completion was extended indefinitely. "He's assured us that he's solvent," she said. "We're going to be watching him very carefully."
But even if a contractor is in dire straits, the heavily bureaucratic bidding process makes it quicker to stick with him than start over.
"The city is its own worst enemy," said Samuel I. Schwartz, a former Deputy Transportation Commissioner and chief engineer in the department, who is now a consultant and director of the Infrastructure Institute at Cooper Union. "It reinforces bad hiring practices. One thing the city ought to do is to have its own construction crew. Then they could say, 'We're going to finish this job.' Otherwise it's at the mercy of the contractors."
 
The Road to Wisdom

The Transportation Department says it hopes to finish by December; Mr. Kelczewski thinks June 1995 is more realistic. Many people on Hudson Street feel as if the work will simply start and stop forever.
In retrospect, Ms. Daglian says, distributing more information would have been helpful: "We've certainly learned things from the Hudson Street project, about bringing the community in even earlier and having a lot of public information resources."
Around the neighborhood, there may be depression, but there is also a sense that the community's activism kept the project from flying completely out of control.
"I think they have a big job," Ms. Lee said of the Transportation Department, "and I think we did salvage it."
Work stopped again in late November, as the second Christmas embargo was observed. Now, the job is proceeding sporadically through a harsh winter. The trolley tracks are gone, but sections of the new water main have yet to be installed. Sewer pipes are partly laid, and the whole job -- covered intermittently with temporary asphalt -- awaits a final paving with 3 inches of asphalt over a 10-inch concrete base. About 150 new trees will be planted, a triangular park near Chambers Street will be renovated, and sidewalks in historic areas will be replaced with concrete tinted to match the old 19th-century bluestone.
And what, Ms. Daglian was asked, will Hudson Street ultimately look like? "Pretty much the same as it did before."
 
 
 
LIVING WITH STREET REPAIR
 Road reconstruction is reasonably democratic. At some point, nearly every New Yorker can expect to encounter it, near home, school or office. And face it, it's never pleasant. Still, there are some things you can do that may make living with it a little less unbearable.
* Generally, a community board is a sort of one-stop outlet for the mystified, frustrated and fed up. Ask to speak to the district manager. The manager and staff will, at the least, give you basic information about the project and probably make you feel that you are not the only one with a problem. They can also put you in touch with the resident engineer hired by the city to make sure the project is done without hazard or unnecessary hardship. Also worth calling: your City Council member.
* If your tap water suddenly looks like last week's coffee, you can call the Department of Environmental Protection's 24-hour hot line: (718) 699-9811.
* If the noise from the jackhammers outside drowns out anything but a shout, call the Department of Environmental Protection hot line. At night or before 7 A.M. on a weekday, a call to the local police precinct is also in order.
* If customers in your store or restaurant complain that construction has made parking impossible, call the Department of Transportation's director of customer service, Elliott Jacobson, at (212) 566-6380. He's in charge of protecting business interests. Ditto if customers complain about construction noise. Or call your local merchants' association, if there is one.
"You can really get action out of this city if you know who the players are," said Rita Lee, the district manager of Community Board 2, which includes Hudson Street. "And you have to know when to yell."
 
 
 
ALSO AROUND TOWN: WHERE THE BACKHOES ARE
 In addition to Hudson Street, the Department of Transportation has eight street-reconstruction projects under way or planned for this year. Here they are, with projected schedules and costs.
* Avenue of the Americas, Manhattan, end to end, $43 million. Started in 1990. To be completed this fall.
* Malcolm X Boulevard, Manhattan, end to end, $42 million. To begin this spring and end in the spring of 1996.
* Columbus Avenue, Manhattan, from 59th Street to 110th Street, $75 million. To begin this fall and end in the fall of 1996.
* Frawley Circle (Fifth Avenue between 109th and 111th Streets), Manhattan, $5.9 million. To begin next month and end in the summer of 1995.
* Dean and Bergen Streets, Brooklyn, $20 million. To begin this spring and end in the fall of 1996.
* Boston Road, the Bronx, $35 million. To begin this spring and end in the fall of 1996.
* Hook Creek Boulevard, Queens, $7.3 million. To begin next month and end in the fall of 1995.
* Sayres Avenue, Queens, $5.6 million. To begin this spring and end in the fall of 1995.
